column2: Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy disclosed yesterday that he had received an anonymous telephone call threatening his life.
PARIS, July 31 -- President Charles de Gaulle and, according to newspaper estimates, 1,699,999 other Frenchmen will leave Paris this week-end in the annual migration of August vacationers.

Commonwealth Edison Company and its subsidiaries achieved a 14 per cent gain in first-half kilowatt hour sales of electricity, Willis Gale, chairman, announced yesterday. Mr. Gale noted that industrial sales were up 19.9 per cent, residential up 8.4 per cent and commercial up 9.4 per cent.
AS the mood of the Thirties continues to creep into present fashions, designers have only to forsake sleep to be inspired.
MOSCOW, July 31 -- Managers of the American National Exhibition hope in the next few days to restore to open shelves some of the books removed at Soviet insistence.

Uncertainty over rumors arising out of the International Sugar Council meeting in London produced mixed world sugar prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Final prices were 2 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) up to 1 off on 18,300 tons.

The one-story store building on the Boardwalk at Columbia Place in Atlantic City has been purchased by Joseph Lefkowitz New York hotel builder and operator. He plans a six-story motor hotel on the site. The Darey Products Company is associated with Mr. Lefkowitz in the project.

Supreme Court Justice Birdie Amsterdam yesterday reserved decision on a plea by Costenze Peter Valenti, a visitor to the Apalachin crime conference in 1957, that he be transferred from Civil Prison here to a jail nearer his home in Rochester, N. Y.

BELLPORT, L. I., July 31 -- The Corry Trophy will spend the next year at Larchmont. Stan Ogilvy's Flame won the coveted bowl, emblematic of Great South Bay Star Class supremacy, convincingly by capturing today's final race in the series.

Geisinger Germain, realty operators, have bought the five-story apartment house on plot 50 by 95 feet at 1235 Vyse Avenue, southwest corner of Freeman Street, the Bronx. The building contains two stores and twenty-three apartments and is assessed at $74,000.
MILWAUKEE, July 31 (UPI) -- Senator John F. Kennedy said here tonight that "racketeers who have operated under the guise of business men" posed one of the greatest threats to American society.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The Civil Liberties Union ,urged Congress today, to withhold proposed new censorship powers from Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The head of a Colorado oil company testified today that Frank Leahy, former Notre Dame football coach, got $150,000 last year for stock he had been helped to buy for $50,000.

The manager of Longchamps Restaurant in the Empire State Building used what he called "an old Army trick" yesterday afternoon to recover $800 from a thief who had snatched the money from the restaurant's cashier.
MONTREAL, July 31 (AP) -- Roy Emerson and Neale Fraser crushed Cuba's Garrido brothers in the opening singles today and sent Australia into a 2-0 lead in the American Zone Davis Cup finals.

The high cost of money is causing a lag in bond retirements. This conclusion is indicated by the drop in bonds called for redemption in July before maturity and in the decline in such redemptions in the first seven months of the year. Payments are off sharply for both periods from previous years.

Sharply higher earnings for the first half of 1959 helped to push stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange in July to the highest level in history. Traders apparently disregarded the steel strike and the possibility of a strike in the aluminum industry as stock prices climbed.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Commission on Civil Rights made public today testimony from four staff members that its staff director said showed "a consistent pattern of denial of equal protection of the laws as regards voting in six Alabama counties."
THIS week-end probably will be a time of disaster for bluefish and school tuna, if the weather holds.

Cities Service Company and subsidiaries yesterday reported a first-half net of $18,904,000, equal to $1.76 a share. This compared with $18,067,000, or $1.68 a share, in the like 1958 period. The 1958 figure does not include a nonrecurring credit of $6,551,000.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday it sought only fair employment practices in its drive to obtain a larger share of Harlem business for Negro wholesale-liquor salesmen.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Farm product prices declined a fraction of 1 per cent between mid-June and mid-July.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox parlayed nine hits and four Washington errors into a 7-1 victory tonight behind the four-hit pitching of young Barry Latman.
VIENNA, July 31 (AP) -- A hot dispute over press freedom and an attempted bombing of an anti-Communist publishing office enlivened the Communist-sponsored seventh World Youth Festival today.
Major debt financing in the public capital market will be moderately heavy next week. Major bond offerings totaling $183,256,700 are slated, with local Government issues predominating.

LENOX, Mass., July 31 -- Charles Munch conducts the Requiem by Berlioz as if it were one of the towering masterpieces of all art, and he comes close to persuading one that his affections are well founded.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 31 (UPI) -- A former Communist said today that only a spiritual revolution would be able to combat communism successfully in the battle for the minds of men in the Americas.

ALBANY, July 31 -- The Rockefeller Administration has started a study of the state's medical resources. The survey seeks to discover how the services can be made more readily available to the average New York resident.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Interstate long-distance telephone tolls will be cut by five to twenty-five cents to achieve the $50,000,000 reduction the Federal Communications Commission ordered last week, it was announced today.

DUMONT, N. J., July 31 -- A ten-year-old boy was swept by floodwaters into a two-foot-wide sewer pipe during a heavy downpour here today and was carried 150 feet. He surfaced, gasping for air, at a catch basin. from which he was rescued.

IDAR-OBERSTEIN, West Germany, July 21 -- Nestled along the Nahe River on the southern slopes of the Hunsrueck mountains, this town has once again become a mecca for jewelers from all over the world. They have been attracted by outstanding craftsmanship in the cutting of precious and semi-precious stones.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., July 31 -- The Empire State Musical Festival made its contribution to the Handel bicentennial tonight. It took the form of a performance of "Semele," the oratorio that Handel wrote shortly after "Messiah."

MYSTIC, Conn., July 31 -- Emil R. Capita's newly launched 45-foot mahogany sloop, Hi-Q II, out of Port Washington, and Philip Dollin's 32-footer, Norsaga, of the Orienta Y. C. fleet, Mamaroneck, were the major trophy winners as the twenty-eighth annual American Y. C. Cruise ended with a race around Fishers Island today.
Two foreign films are scheduled to open today at first-run theatres.
TRENTON, July 31 -- Wesley L. Lance, President of the New Jersey Senate, emphasized today that he did not favor the adoption of a broad-based state tax.

GENEVA, Aug. 1 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter of the United States and Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd of Britain reviewed today the three-power conference here on a ban on tests of nuclear weapons.
The voters of the state will be asked at the November election to decide whether New York City should be permitted to borrow $500,000,000 beyond its debt limit to finance school construction.
A TRUNCATED version of "Carmen" -- long on the latest techniques in sight and sound -- was offered to a Hollywood Bowl audience last week. The results, music critics agreed, were artistically short.

BALBOA, C. Z., Aug. 1 -- Remote jungle rivers will go on the airwaves to report their own levels and passing storms will tell how many inches of rain they pour on the area treetops after the Panama Canal installs an electronic telemetering system throughout the Gatun Lake watershed.

RECENT years have seen the appearance of several handsome illustrated editions of the Bible, but perhaps none has more effectively blended the arts of printing, binding and pictorial reproduction than "The Masterpiece Bible" and "The Rembrandt Bible" of the Abradale Press, a subsidiary of Harry N. Abrams, Inc., New York.

OUTDOOR wooden steps which rot, crack or sag become an eyesore detracting from the appearance of the house. They also create a safety hazard which should be eliminated. One permanent way to do this is to rip off the old steps completely and build a new set -- using poured concrete or cement block rather than wood.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 1 (AP) -- A runaway Erie Railroad engine struck another engine at the Pavonia Avenue crossing today, injuring four men.

Seismologists at Columbia University and the California Institute of Technology are about to begin construction of a "lunar seismograph." If found practical the apparatus will be sent by rocket to the moon to detect "moonquakes" -if they exist -- and to radio any such information down to earth.

I have been following the comments on Air Charters in the Travel Section of The Times. The American Society of Travel Agents feels that charter fares discriminate against the greater part of the traveling public.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 1 -- Officials here said tonight that they had no reason to think the Americas' foreign ministers conference, scheduled to open here Aug. 12, would be postponed or that Cuba would be absent.

' Vre have the largest and most difficult Title I program In the United States," New York's Mayor Wagner declared last week. "The fact that its administration here can stand improvement is a form of criticism. * * * [We] try to improve as the resultof criticism."

AT the height of the controversy over Postmaster General Summerfield's postal ban on the D. H. Lawrence novel "Lady Chatterley's Lover" Washington cartoonist Herblock portrayed Summerfield admonishing his mailmen with a scowl: "Some of you still seem to have the old-fashioned idea that we're supposed to deliver the mail!"
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 1 -- The Lebanese hills were a-glitter last week with the headlights of hundreds of cars ascending the winding roads that led to the opening of the 1959 Baalbek Festival.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Russians have discovered and explored a mountain wilderness in Antarctica described as "a geological paradise" rich in valuable minerals.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 -- The feasibility of establishing a California automobile accident commission to handle mounting traffic accident claims is being considered by Gov. Edmund G. Brown.

NAIROBI, Kenya, July 27 -- Five years of field work by a research team of the East Africa High Commission has proved that malaria can be almost eliminated in infected areas by spraying powerful insecticides twice a year.

ST. THOMAS, V. I. -- Whether it can be attributed to political unrest elsewhere in the Caribbean or to the new low air fare, which brings the cost of the New York-San Juan round trip down to $81, both Puerto Rico and the American Virgin Islands are currently enjoying a tourist boom.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Prospects of favorable Congressional action on President Eisenhower's request for authority to raise interest rates on Government bonds were revived today.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 1 -- The accent was on elegance as Roosevelt Raceway, the mint of Nassau County, opened its harness racing season tonight with the $50,000 International Trot as the jewel of the evening.

A new, more sophisticated type of American tourist is beginning to show up in Moscow these days as the result of the work of a hitherto unpublicized institution: a briefing center for ordinary Americans visiting the Soviet Union.

GENEVA, Aug. 1 -- It is still possible that the foreign minister's conference will agree on an interim settlement of the Berlin crisis -- about as possible as the chances of the Washington Senators' winning the American League pennant.

A season or two after joining the widening fraternity of pleasure boatmen, the skipper and his family jot down in their memo took of ambitions the Lord Rideau. After awhile this becomes an obsession. They talk Rideau, dream Rideau, plan Rideau.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- JQoseph A. Beirne, president of the Communications Workers of America, announced today that a school to teach Latin American workers "vigorous industrial democracy" will be opened at Front Royal, Va., on Aug. 14.

ABIT self-consciously but with a touch of obedient determination, Dominicans have been singing and dancing since late June a jumpy merengue whose oft-repeated tagline cocksurely proclaims that, "collecting alms, they will not overthrow him."
The greater demand for its products and an improvement in operating efficiency have resulted in the oil industry's snapping out of the recession in which it was engulfed in the first half of 1958.
THE gaudy display of road-side flowers reaches a peak in midsummer. Motorists can appreciate wild-flower colors for the tall-growing species are numerous.

THE American is wonderfully alive; and his vitality, not having often found a suitable outlet, makes him appear agitated on the surface; he is always letting off an unnecessarily loud blast of incidental steam. Yet his vitality is not superficial; it is inwardly prompted, and as sensitive and quick as a magnetic needle.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 1 -- Golf's little man continued to cut a wide swath today in the Professional Golfers Association championship.
WARSAW, Aug. 1 -- A campaign to present Vice President Richard M. Nixon's visit to Poland as a smashing triumph for Polish Communists began in Warsaw today.

NEW statistics on Americans traveling abroad have been released by the Passport Office. The agency, headed by Frances G. Knight, has compiled over-all figures for the year July 1, 1958-June 30, 1959. During that period 699,042 passports were issued or renewed, a 7 per cent gain over the previous year's 652,253.
An Army private was held on a homicide charge yesterday in the beating of his wife during a quarrel in their basement apartment on the upper West Side.

The hamster, long a favorite pet of children, has become fashion's pet as well. Outstanding among a number of unexpected furs enhancing the scene for fall, hamster is soft, light in weight and supple. The skins, distinctly patterned in shades of brown, henna and white, are adaptable to dramatic designs that include fall's handsomest hat, the fedora.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Congressional investigators looking into possible influence-peddling in connection with defense contracts will summon officials of some of the nation's biggest corporations to testify next week.
The question of how to handle students with superior ability was given renewed attention last week by the Board of Education after it had received a surprising report on the subject.

IT is almost time for the summer holiday. As a man shuts his typewriter and prepares to open his ears to the fluting of the thrush rather than the cheeping of the soprano and to the soughing of the wind rather than the rumbling of the basso, he lets his mind drift. Let practicality go hang. Conjure up visions. Scale unimaginably soaring peak Make the impossible possible
WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Aug. 1 -- The fifty-third annual Cruise and Race Week of Long Island's Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association concluded on a gratifyingly salty note today.
HONG KONG, Aug. 1 -- Reports of a closely guarded conference of Chinese Communist leaders reached here through usually reliable sources this week.
Queens Borough President John T. Clancy yesterday issued a call to the ramparts for the defense of the right not to plant trees.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Gen. George H. Decker, who has been chief of the United Nations command in Korea, today became Vice Chief of Staff of the Army.

IT is not their victories on the battlefield that nations take to their hearts. It is their Lost Battalions, their Light Brigades, their Valley Forges. In line with this tradition, Dunkirk is more warmly cherished by Britons today than the triumphs of 1945, which broke the back of German resistance.
A group of college students from seventy colleges and twenty-one states met here last week to compare notes on some unusual sight-seeing.

BY all natural laws a man of 45 or more should have had it in sports. The message relegating him to more sedentary pastimes should have arrived. But, somehow, it doesn't get through to tennis players. Dragging paunches and fallen arches they go on and on like old soldiers, with an awesome passion for the game.

HARTFORD, Aug. 1 -- With Connecticut cities holding their biennial elections in November, campaign activity is already under way because of the early endorsement requirements of the state primary law.
The metropolitan area is being attacked by its worst invasion of mosquitos in ten years, according to John C. Pallister, research expert on insects at the American Museum of Natural History.

THE question before the house is: just how did I go about writing the original screen play that Alfred Hitchcock has put to celluloid for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as "North By Northwest"? (See photo above.) The mere posing of the question seems to assume special circumstance, as though perhaps I might have used not pen nor pencil, but a dagger dipped in blood.
NEWARK, Aug. 1 -- A 15 per cent increase in interstate fares went into effect today on the New Jersey Central and Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroads.

ABOUT a million and a half Americans will go abroad on vacation this year. About half of these will go to Western Europe. Few of them will learn much about Western Europe as it is today, or as it hopes to be tomorrow. They won't find out how people live.

MONTEAGLE, Tenn., Aug. 1 (AP) -- County and state law enforcement officials raided integrated Highlander Folk School last night, arrested a Negro woman and three white men and confiscated a quantity of liquor.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 1 -- A fugitive from a Georgia prison described today how he had made good his escape by winning the friendship of two bloodhounds.

SCIENTISTS, astronauts and authors of books on outer space are zeroing in on the moon as these three additions to the growing space library prove. Already this year there have been "A Book of Satellites for You" and "The True Book of Space," which were primers of scientific fact.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 1 -- For the second straight time, the Pennsylvania All-State team used a strong line to turn back the National High School All-Americans, 18 -- 0, tonight before an overflow crowd of 22,000.

Although steel production is at a standstill, most Cleveland business indicators were relatively unchanged in the week ended July 25. Sales of new automobiles totaled 1,535, down only seven from the preceding week. Used car sales were off only nineteen units to 1,813.

SOUTHOLD, L. I., Aug. 1 -- Two neophyte astronomers, using a mechanized version of the same technique employed by Galileo in making telescope lenses, completed polishing two six-inch reflectors here this week.

HORSE RACING Babu, running as an entry with Inside Tract, beat the favored Sword Dancer in the $113,300 Brooklyn Handicap as Jamaica closed yesterday. Babu paid $47.80. Royal Native won the $55,000 Monmouth Oaks, with the favored Silver Spoon third behind Indian Maid.

THERE is an unutterable tragedy in having to stand by and watch a man "come apart at the seams" and be unable to do anything about it G. K. Chesterton must have had some inkling of it when he wondered why men could find sublime inspiration in the ruins of an old church and none in the ruins of man.
BARABOO, Wis. -- A new museum created to capture and preserve the color, sounds, atmosphere and tradition of the golden age of the big-top American circus is off to a good start.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 1 -- The University of Notre Dame will confer two honorary degrees at its summer commencement Tuesday afternoon. About 250 students, most of them nuns, will receive degrees at the exercise.

CENTRAL PARK'S new amphitheatre called Theatre-in-the-Park will devote this week and next primarily to dancing of one sort or another. Beginning tomorrow evening, it will present a "World Dance Festival" nightly through Friday. Beginning Monday evening, Aug. 10, it will bring in the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo for seven performances, the company's first Manhattan engagement in several seasons.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A single success story brightens the labor movement's otherwise gray record of corruption cleanup of the last two and one-half years.
CAIRO, Aug. 1 -- A Cairo club has resumed playing cricket on the basis of a ruling that the game is not "essentially British."

The early goldenrods come to bloom, rich yellow roadside spangles and promise of September's golden haze. If we still wove homespun we would soon be out gathering "dyer's weeds," as goldenrod once was called. It provided a strong saffron yellow dye which brightened many a pioneer mother's dress. Now that dye is largely forgotten, as is the anise-scented tea made from sweet goldenrod leaves to abate late-summer weariness.

MOSCOW. ON Tuesday morning, July 21, the crates of sculpture were piled on trucks for transportation to the exhibition site, followed by the paintings late in the afternoon. Through the courtesy of Soviet officials all these were stored at the Pushkin Museum as a safety measure.

SINCE it has become customary for theatregoers who love "Porgy and Bess" to see it and make studious comparisons every time it is revived, it should become a similar custom for those who enjoy it on the screen to pay it at least a couple of visits and then see it again, in the future -- whenever it is reissued, which it certainly will be.

NEWPORT, Tenn. -- Not many years ago, the Appalachian Highlands of the Virginias, North Carolina, Kentucky and Tennessee were less accessible to the average vacationist in search of mountain scenery than the Canadian Rockies or Yellowstone Park.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon told the Soviet people tonight that they would "continue to live in an era of fear, suspicion and tension" if Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev tried to promote the communization of countries outside the Soviet Union.

Industrial investments in the Chicago area for June totaled $15,684,000, more than double the $6,293,000 of June, 1958, and well above the $11,738,000 announced during May this year. The Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry said total investments for the first half of 1959 reached $90,482,000 compared with $77,350,000 in the like 1958 period.

The impasse in Washington over lifting the 4 1/4 per cent cost ceiling on long-term Government borrowing has momentarily been rendered less acute by the success of the Treasury's $14,000,000,000 August refunding.
OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug, l -- Royal Native, Perne Grissom's 3 - year - old filly, scored one of the major upsets of the year today in winning the $55,000 Monmouth Oaks.

IN 1825 a group of about forty people sailed from Norway to America in a ship one fourth the size of the Mayflower, the Restoration. They were Norwegians of the Quaker faith, fleeing religious persecution, and they founded a settlement near Rochester, N. Y., under the leadership of the indomitable Cleng Peerson.

The fans turned out early, despite the 2:15 P. M. start for the program. A number of the out-of-town visitors, in New York for the first time this season, arrived early simply because they were unaware of the starting time.
Mr. Kennan's article mentions the Quaker relief work in Russia as one of the small-scale but "valuable independent contributions" to the massive aid which Herbert Hoover provided in 1921.

I HAVE read with great interest Jack Gould's comment relative to the Mike Wallace show on which I appeared in connection with the documentary "The Hate That Hate Produced." [A series about Negro extremist groups]

BARBARA GREER comes from the same upper strata of New England society as the main characters of Stephen Birmingham's first novel, "Young Mr. Keefe." Again the author dramatizes the power of tradition and its overwhelming effects on the individual, a dominant theme in American literature since Henry James.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 -- Some sort of record may already have been set this year for the number of foreign visitors, large and small, to come knocking at the Kremlin gates.

YONKERS, Aug. 1 -- Herbert Baxman was leaning against a utility pole this afternoon at the corner of South Broadway and Lawrence Street. With the curiosity of a 14-year-old he began idly prying with a key at the metal casing of a power line running up the pole.
AFFAIRS may not be going too well with the Yankees this year. But there is one thing the Bombers have that no one can take away from them. That is a record of achievement that never can be erased.

The big corporate news of last week was the record profit of $254,948,000 reported by the United States Steel Corporation from record sales of $2,526,331,000 in the first half of this year. The announcement came about two weeks after the start of a strike by steel workers throughout the nation for higher wages.

IF ALL the ingredients now out on the table mix successfully, we might have a boom in magnetic tape in the coming season. Several hundred thousand tape machines have moved into consumer hands each recent year. As noted in this space last month, the industry now gives every appearance of being at last ready to push commercial recordings on tape, in two forms.
BERLIN, Aug. l -- Jean Behra, one of the world's top racing drivers, crashed in the rain at the Avus track today and died instantly of a fractured skull.

LIST 30-year-old Richard Einfeld as one of the newer independent producers determined to make pictures his own way on a frankly unspectacular scale. He arrived here last week with plans for two features, calling for location treks to Kentucky and Ireland, and to discuss with Twentieth Century-Fox a promotional campaign for his second, recently completed production, "The Oregon Trail."

A LIGHTWEIGHT soldering iron which has a built-in temperature control cannot overheat because the temperature is controlled right at the tip. The controlled heat assures more reliable soldered connections when used on electrical work, and saves on electricity since wattage consumed is cut in half when the iron is "idling."

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Harry J. Fishbein of New York and John Gerber of Houston, Tex., won the National Men's Pair Championship today in the American Contract Bridge League tournament at the Conrad Hilton Hotel here.

VIENNA, Aug. 1 -- The organizers of the seventh World Youth Festival had their first major success tonight. A parade of the festival delegates along the famous ring between Schwarzenberg Platz and the Burg Theatre drew big crowds.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 -- The United Foundation of Metropolitan Detroit said this week that its funds for fighting cancer would be allocated in the future to the Michigan Cancer Foundation instead of the American Cancer Society and its southeastern Michigan division.

MONTREAL, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Australia's new Davis Cup doubles combination of Rod Laver and Roy Emerson clinched the North American zone tennis final today. They defeated Cuba's Garrido brothers, Reynaldo and Orlando, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, for a 3-0 lead in the three-out-of-five series.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Eisenhower has sent a message to Vice President Richard M. Nixon commending him on the way he has conducted himself during his tour of the Soviet Union.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 1 -- Two leaders of the World Jewish Congress declared here today that the Jewish people must awaken to the danger of losing their identity.
AMARILLO, Tex., Aug. 1 (UPI) -- The man who taught President Eisenhower how to fly, Brig. Gen. William L. Lee, has been retired after thirty-four years of military service.

SUMMER is an important note-taking time for the city gardener in search of permanent material for his terrace or yard. The radiance which spring gives to every leaf and twig dims appreciably in the wilting days of August, and it is unwise to buy plants without knowing how they tolerate heat and soot.

THE unmistakable uproar of Ethel Merman belting out a number from "Gypsy'' was issuing from a gramophone in the mobile dressing room on C Stage at the Pinewood Studios. Hammers banged and chains clanked.

LA GRANCE, Ga., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Three Negroes, drinking and armed with knives, wrested two young white women from white escorts and Negro protectors and raped them twice early today, authorities reported.
FARMVILLE, Va., Aug. 1 -- A showdown is near on whether private schooling can save segregation in Prince Edward County.

FOR Cyril Falls, whose knowledge of both the first and second world wars is compounded of both active service and scholarship, the war of 1914-18 was the Great War. It left as many dead in millions as World War II, he remarks.

" All trolley cars to Jamaica connect with the track," the Metropolitan Jockey Club advertised on Monday, April 27, 1903, when the brand-new race track began its life with a nine-day meeting in the wooded wilds of Long Island.

ALL along the Atlantic coast this month the beaches will get a final workout -- a last call for children to build sand castles, for girls to test bikinis and young men to flex muscles, for office palefaces to suntan and mothers to unpack tuna fish sandwiches, for everybody to exclaim (turning slightly blue) that the water's not cold once you get in.
Even today, when the individual is supposed to be dominated by the corporation, American industry provides many examples of companies that are but the lengthened shadows of forceful men.

THE literature of the New Deal and of its consequences up to the present is copious but uneven. Historians have reenacted the dramatic story of the depression crisis; biographers have dissected the personality of Roosevelt, with varying emphasis upon the lion or the fox; memoir writers, apologists, polemicists and partisans have had their say.

HAVANA, Aug. 1 -- General passenger train service was suspended temporarily late yesterday as the Cuban Government tried to speed the evacuation from Havana of the thousands of peasants brought here for Premier Fidel Castro's 26th of July celebration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- All ten House Labor Committee Republicans have urged President Eisenhower to make a nationally televised appeal for House passage of a strong labor reform bill, it was disclosed today.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 1 -- Congress will debate next week whether to allow President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes to be tried under charges of defamation brought by the leader of the principal Left-wing Opposition party.

At the edge of a swimming pool, a man in a tuxedo leaned toward a woman, swimmer. Behind him a piano tinkled through the noise of a party from a near-by bungalow. The man extended his arms and the woman pulled him into the pool.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 -- Vessels flying foreign flags are beginning to make the Great Lakes their own waterways as American bulk freighters continue their parade to the docks and to indefinite idleness.

CHICAGO -- The principal achievement of the national bridge tournament now coming to a close here is not its new attendance records. That phenomenon has become as commonplace and predictable as the population growth of the United States.

A COUPLE of weeks ago a group of national conservation leaders, meeting in Washington with a representative of Senate Majority Leader Lyndon Johnson, urged attention to pending legislation dealing with two main conservation objectives: clean streams and a system of wilderness areas maintained under a soundly established national policy and program.
A slight, white-haired physician who is just about to complete his first round-the-world voyage as a ship's surgeon firmly believes in magic.

I WAS sorry to see Paul Goodman's "The Empire City" reviewed so indifferently by Robert Gorham Davis. * * * "The Empire City" is probably the most inventive novel we have seen in twenty years -- not an easy book to skim through -- but it's traditional enough for a serious reader to make his way on a first reading.

ORDINARILY it is a son who suffers in the shadow of a great father and the instances of creative self-assertion on the part of his seedling under the great oak are so rare that the emergence of a Dumas, fils, despite a Dumas, pere, was regarded as something of a wonder even in the last century.

MORE than a quarter of a century has passed since Herbert Hoover left the White House, and we still have no satisfactory history of his Administration. To meet this need, Harris Gaylord Warren, Professor of History at Miami University, Oxford, Ohio, has written what his publishers call "the first serious evaluation" of the Hoover years.

The Communists have been staging '%vorld youth festivals" bieldally since the war--in Prague (1947), Budapest (1949.), East Berlin (1951), Bucharest (1953), Warsaw (1955) and Moscow (1957). Their fo'r;mula is a combination of county fair razzledazzle, music and folk festival, and serious political meetings.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Farm experts are considering whether the surplus of corn and other livestock feed grains is being transformed into a surplus of meat.

SOME months ago Alan Watts, with the help of Sumire Jacobs, was responsible for an excellent introduction to Japanese Haiku poetry. Now they have collaborated once again on an anthology: Zen and Senryu (MEA, Box 303, Sausalito, Calif.).

TO a large number of middle-aged record collectors, Mozart's Le Nozze di Figaro has a special place in the affections. It was in 1937 that Victor released the Glyndebourne recording, conducted by Fritz Busch, and a new world was opened to many of us.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said today her general impression of Russians was that they were "extremely friendly."

A proclamation from President Eisenhower has designated the week of November 8-14, 1959, as American Education Week. The President urged the public to display its "pride in this primary instrument of democracy" by participating actively in the week's activities. Schools throughout the country will hold open house for an estimated 26 million parents and citizens who will study this year's theme, "Praise and Appraise Your Schools."

ALBANY, Aug. 1 -- The capital political scene was enlivened this week by an unlikely clash between two prominent Democrats -- one a local leader of legendary strength, the other the only state official to survive last fall's Rockefeller landslide.

GLYNDEBOURNE is this year celebrating its twenty-fifth year of existence not counting the wartime break of 1940 through 1946 during which however Rudolf Bing and the late Mrs. Christie one evening hit upon the notion of what was to become the Edinburgh Festival.

AFTER considerable silence, Lee Wells is back kicking up more dust in the cactus. In GUN FOR SALE (Avon, 35 cents) he writes of Clay Manning, a trail town marshal, who pulls out of his job wearing a belt crammed with reward money to mosey around on a hunt for a ranch.
DENVER, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., and India's Ramanthan Krishnan won semi-final matches today in the national hard court tennis championships.

The transfer of the State Barge Canal to the Federal Government was recommended last week.
A marriage between Steven Rockefeller and Anne Marie Rasmussen would have the blessing of Governor and Mrs. Rockefeller.
Tire retreading, a war-baby industry orphaned after war-time rubber shortages ended, has become one of the fastest-growing consumer industries.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Don Drysdale, the Los Angeles Dodgers' star right-handed pitcher who had a 6-0 record during July, today was named the winner of the National League's player-of-the-month award.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 1 -- It will be an all-South African final in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament tomorrow afternoon at the Meadow Club.
Perhaps we should recall with pride that 1921-22 wasn't the first time America responded to a famine cry from Russia.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Jim Landis' double with one out in the ninth scored two runs and enabled the first-place Chicago White Sox to gain a 2-1 victory over the Washington Senators today. The Senator's losing streak was extended to fourteen games.
GOTEBORG, Sweden, Aug. 1 -- The bulky-shouldered man with the face of a boy ambled wearily toward the huge picture cutout of the world heavyweight champion.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug 1 (AP) -- The Little Rock School Board has assigned six Negroes to once-white public high schools that will reopen in September, a board member said today.

THE late Eric de Bisschop was a Pacific personality well known from Honolulu to Papeete. He was probably more intimately acquainted with the Pacific Ocean itself than any of his contemporaries, since he had crossed it not only in modern vessels but in Chinese junks, Polynesian canoes and finally bamboo rafts.

A HENRY ADAMS READER. Elizabeth Stevenson, Ed. (Anchor-Doubleday. $1.25.) Generous samplings of the writing of one of the most stimulating American men of letters of this century chosen to illustrate the many facets of his personality and interests -as journalist, novelist, biographer, historian, letter writer, medievalist, autobiographer, verse writer and speculative essayist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr. asserted today that subordinates within the executive branch "have encroached on the constitutional powers of Congress" by improperly denying it necessary Government information.
DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Twentyone Guns scored a major upset today by heating Find, the favorite, in a stretch thriller in the $20,000 added San Diego Handicap at Del Mar.

MANY people have superstitions and fallacious beliefs, but it seems that gardeners have just a few more than their share. Very often the novice grower is left bewildered by the cultivation tips given him by well-meaning, but uninformed, neighbors.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- This year's crop of labor regulation bills in Congress is unusually heavy. Approximately fifty have been presented, most of them in the House of Representatives and many of them overlapping.
In a "then and now" mood the New York Stock Exchange has looked into the performance of fifteen stocks that it says have "treated investors poorly" in the years since 1927.

I HAVE read with interest your July 5 and July 26 articles by Paul J. C. Friedlander on the Civil Aeronautic Board's supervision of air charter flights. Your observation that the "zeal to protect the certificated airlines" has restricted the chartering of airplanes with resultant adverse effects on travelers, is, I believe, well founded.

ON Thursday the big two-day Eastern International Gladiolus Show will get under way at the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center, L. I. It will be the first time the show has even been held in the New York metropolitan area.

The possibility of a Communist return to power in the tiny, crag-bound republic of San Marino has brought Sammarinese anti-Communist politicians to this country to appeal for help in next month's elections.

ANNA SOSENKO has taken another step in the direction of Broadway. Not so long ago she disclosed that she had purchased the rights to Irving Stone's "The Passionate Journey," the story of John Noble, an American artist who died in 1934, never having achieved the position some in the art world believe was truly his.

Fo.' a year and a half lJae leaders of the major powers have debated the idea of a summit conference as a means of dealing with the problems of the cold war. The idea has been pushed by Moscow, accepted by London, and resisted hl varying degree hy A'ashington, --Paris and Bonn.
A seven-year study in Peru indicates that, after an atomic attack or other disaster, salty water can be used in place of blood plasma for treating burns in a mass scale.
A team of Swiss mountaineers, fresh from nineteen first-time ascents in the Andes, has been exploring the peaks of New York.

After more than half a century as a two-league operation, big-time baseball this week was faced with the prospect of a third major league. Although it had been rumored for some time, the formation of the new league -- called the Continental -- caused considerable surprise among both fans and major league officials.
Eight new cars for the New York subways arrived last night in the New York. New Haven and Hartford Railroad yards at 149th Street and Bruckner Boulevard, the Bronx.

LONDON, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- Nikolai Mikhailov, Soviet Culture Minister, said in an article before the opening of the first Soviet International Film Festival in Moscow that "the days of Hollywood's domination of the world [film] market are coming to an end." The article was quoted in a dispatch by Tass, Soviet press agency.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, said today the Senate rackets committee might have to call James R. Hoffa back for more questioning.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Nineteen teams, of which only four were undefeated, entered the sixth round of play in the Masters' Team-of-Four Contest for the Nate B. Spingold Trophy at the American Contract Bridge League's tournament tonight.
Sutro Brothers Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, has leased a floor in the building being constructed by Samuel Rudin at 80 Pine Street.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 2 -- A dramatic finish marked Bob Rosburg's triumph in the Professional Golfers Association championship today. The title went to the Palo Alto (Calif.) pro with a 72-hole score of 277 after he had rallied at the Minneapolis Golf Club with a spectacular fourth round 4-under-par 66.
HONOLULU, Aug. 2 -- Imminent statehood is being accompanied by a ferment in Hawaii's economy.
TIJUANA, Mexico, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Federal police arrested the opposition candidate for municipal president (Mayor) of Tijuana late today on charges of disturbing the peace.
The property at 212 to 224 East Sixtieth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, has been purchased by an investor for cash over mortgages amounting to $350,000.
Seven illuminated pools -- a large rectangular one and six smaller ones -- will be part of a landscaped plaza along the front and side of the new forty-eight story Time and Life Building.

A SYMPATHETIC view of a community involved in the current steel strike was offered yesterday over Channel 4. With Chet Huntley narrating, the telecast included filmed interviews with striking workers in Gary, Ind.

BERLIN, Aug. 2 -- Nose to tail, three blood-red Ferraris swept round and round the ace race circuit in this afternoon's Grand Prix of Germany. All opposition broke down or crashed trying to hold their fantastic pace. Victory, after 2 hours 9 minutes 31.6 seconds, went to Tony Brooks of Britain. His margin over Dan Gurney, the rookie from Riverside, Calif., was about a car length.
KATMANDU, Nepal, July 28 -- Nepal offers an unusual example of cooperation between the United States and India.
The National Commander of the Jewish War Veterans warned yesterday against the acceptance here of Soviet propaganda.
Eight new films are slated to open in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
A training center for teachers in educational television has been established by New York University in collaboration with the Radio Corporation of America.
WILMINGTON, Del,, Aug. 2 (AP) -- An explosion today wrecked the home of Mr. and Mrs. George Rayfield for the second time since the Negro couple moved into the previously white suburb of Collins Park.

The Rev. James Gordon Gilkey Jr., pastor of the Bethany Union Congregational Church in Chicago, will become executive minister of Riverside Church Sept. 1. He will succeed the Rev. Dr. Norris L. Tibbetts, who retired June 30.

The "comprehensive analysis of hospital facilities and medical care programs in New York State" ordered by Governor Rockefeller will explore the fundamentals. Under the direction of Dr. John J. Bourke, executive director of the Joint Hospital Survey and Planning Commission, it will examine the factors involved in the economics of medical care. Six state agencies will cooperate.
DENVER, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Ramanathan Krishnan of India and Sandra Reynolds of South Africa won the men's and women's singles titles today in the national hardcourt tennis tournament.

AIX - LES - BAINS, France, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Yola Ramirez of Mexico today won the women's singles final in the Aix-Les- Bains tennis tournament by defeating Francoise Durr of France, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 3, 6-4.

The season's largest audience, 18,000 listeners, turned up at Lewisohn Stadium Saturday evening for the twelfth annual Rodgers and Hammerstein Night, which was also the closing performance of the summer concert series.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The first session of the Eighty-sixth Congress opens the long drive toward adjournment this week with Democratic hopes for a record of accomplishment riding on four major bills.
GENEVA, Aug. 2 -- A failure that no longer alarms anyone is in prospect for the Big Four foreign ministers' conference, now sputtering to a close.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced himself yesterday against proposed legislation to liberalize state laws on criminal insanity. He predicted the proposal would greatly increase the number of insanity acquittals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey announced today that he planned to introduce an omnibus farm bill that would provide "everything" the Administration needed to help the nation's food and fiber producers.
Volume in the steamship charter market continued low last week, and freight rates showed slight decreases.
Record first - half sales and earnings were reported by American Home Products Corporation and its subsidiaries.

HALIFAX, N. S., Aug 2 -- The appointment of Maj. Gen. George Philias Vanier, a Roman Catholic French Canadian, as Canada's next Governor General was generally well received.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- A Foreign Office spokesman tonight described the picture the Imam of Oman had drawn earlier today of British activity in that country as "ludicrous."

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Richard C. Poole Jr., the race chairman of the Echo Bay Yacht Club, had a frustrating day on Long Island Sound today.

KANSAS CITY, Aug 2 -- Casey Stengel, who manages the Yankees and, from time to time, the American League All-Stars, had a busy day today. Aside from his regular chores, Stengel spent considerable time answering telephone calls.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Several Senators of both parties said today that they favored an invitation to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union to visit the United States.
In a letter to Governor Rocke feller, the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce has protested a proposal to give the name of Verrazano to the bridge to be built across the Narrows.
A 15-year-old Brooklyn boy was held without bail yesterday in the fatal beating of an elderly man who had chided him for being in a park with a girl at night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- The Chicago White Sox widened their American League lead to three games today with 3-2 and 9-3 victories over the Washington Senators, whose losing streak reached sixteen games.

A political science professor and officials of two minority parties urged last night that radio and television networks continue to give equal time in their news programs to all bona fide candidates who seek political office.
VIENNA, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Nine United States and British anti-Communist delegates to the seventh World Youth Festival described today a roughing up they received from Communists during a peace parade.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 -- Some steel users were becoming a trifle worried last week about future steel supplies. But most customers gave the supply situation little thought. It will be another week or so before more steel consumers become anxious about the length of the steel strike.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Harry J. Fishbein of New York and John Gerber of Houston, who won the Men's Pair Championship in the national tournament here Saturday, are the authors of two of the best-known bidding conventions.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- British troops manned roadblocks on Cyprus tonight in an effort to halt gun running.

CAIRO, Aug. 2 -- The Imam of Oman said today he considered himself president of an independent republic.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 2 -- Ted Hood's self-designed forty-foot keel-centerboard sloop Robin looked more and more the red-hot boat of the New York Yacht Club cruise today. She won in her division for the third time and none other could match her in consistency against formidable opposition.

MOSCOW, Aug. 2 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that he believed Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev should "at some time visit the United States." The Vice President declared at a news conference winding up a ten-day visit to the Soviet Union that it would be up to President Eisenhower to decide whether the invitation should be extended.

TRENTON, Aug. 1 -- One of the chief functions of a Governor is to see that prisons and mental hospitals operate effectively. Visiting Russia with other members of the executive committee of the Governors Conference, I had an opportunity to question health officials, and I had brief views of a mental hospital and a prison in the Moscow area.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A crack appeared today in the defense thrown up by Southern Democratic Senators against civil rights legislation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 2 -- The World Jewish Congress opened an eleven-day assembly here tonight with a session attended by members of the diplomatic corps, including the West German Ambassador.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 2 -- All oil stocks were in heavy demand last week. Turnover was heavy and prices kept rising. Royal Dutch opened the week at 177, mounted to 195 1/2 and closed at 192. Standard Oil started at 219, swept up to 239 1/2, and closed Friday at 236.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- The nation's penitentiaries held a record population of 205,643 prisoners at the end of 1958, the Federal Prison Bureau reported today.

WHILE everybody was talking about it, two enterprising Bryn Mawr students decided to do something about the weather a couple of years ago. In the process they netted a tidy sum and launched a campus fad.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 2 -- After several months in the background, Royal Dutch staged a spectacular comeback in the last week. It showed a sharply increased turnover and a considerable price rise.

A report on the first five years of the anti-malaria campaign in Kenya, East Africa, carried out by the British and local governments with assistance from the United Nations Children's Fund, has now been issued. An area of about 100,000 square miles is involved.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller emphatically eliminated himself today as a possible Republican candidate for Vice President.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Billy Bruton batted in six runs with two triples to spark the Milwaukee Braves to an 11-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in the second game of a double-header today. The Cards won the opener, 4 -- 3, with an unearned run in the ninth on two Milwaukee errors.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- A search was on today for the body of a patrolman who disappeared and was believed to have been killed in a street cave-in late last night.
A group of Florida packers has allocated $3,300,000 for a fall program to promote sales of frozen orange concentrate.
Dominguin came out of retirement in 1956 to challenge the 27-year-old Ordonez' position as Spain's best active bullfighter.

Confirmation was received over the week-end that Michael Hordern had been signed for "Moonbirds." The British actor, who is well known on the other side, will make his first Broadway appearance in Marcel Ayme's comedy fantasy as translated by John Pauker.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 -- Baseball, as an eminent jurist once ruled, "is a business peculiar to itself," and that it is. Only in baseball can one see what's happening at the moment. Here we have two blistering pennant races and an added attraction -- the rare spectacle of the once-mighty Yankees lying flat on their backs, striving desperately to get on their feet again.
Corporate profits rose sharply in the second quarter of 1959, a tabulation by the First National City Bank of New York showed yesterday.
FLEMINGTON, N. J., Aug 2 -- Champion Cote de Neige Sundew, Pembroke Welsh Corgi from the kennels of Mrs. William B. Long, Concord, Mass., celebrated his third birthday in great style today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- The Army and Marine Corps disclosed today that they would equip infantrymen with a guided missile designed to destroy low-flying combat planes.
RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 2 -- The United States and Morocco have reached an agreement that will put approximately $1,000,000 a month of needed foreign exchange into the Moroccan treasury.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 2 -- Backers of Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts for the Democratic Presidential nomination seized the initiative today in a bid for delegate support among Governors who are largely uncommitted.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Two fires burned dangerously close to the boundaries of Yosemite National Park today. Forestry officials hoped for control by tomorrow.

Two books about the late Frank Lloyd Wright are planned for publication in the near future. One is a biography by Finis Farr, titled "Study in Fame." To be published by Scribner, it will be illustrated with examples of the architect's work.
WARSAW, Aug. 2 -- The Government of Poland greeted Vice President Richard M. Nixon with punctilious propriety today and the people of Warsaw greeted him with eager and tender acclaim.
Four youths were arrested early today in the beating of a 29-year-old physician on the East Side.

Thanks to Jamin and Tornese, international harness racing is here to stay. When the two European horses trotted Trader Horn, the United States entrant, into the expensive Westbury real estate of Roosevelt Raceway on Saturday night, they provided a challenge that this nation's horsemen cannot ignore.

Grievances of non-professional employes in New York's voluntary hospitals will be arbitrated by the American Arbitration Association in its hearing rooms without administrative fees.
W. Averell Harriman praised Vice President Richard M. Nixon yesterday for "calling" Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev in their public discussion in Moscow last month.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 2 -- Every country of the Middle East showed a trade deficit in 1958, exclusive of oil. That commodity, however, poured into national coffers a record bounty of revenues and canceled out the minus signs for the region.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Home runs by Duke Snider and Charley Neal sparked Los Angeles to a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today. The Dodgers moved back into second place, displacing the Milwaukee Braves.
Members of the nation's two largest unions of unlicensed seamen will soon be asked to finance one of the most ambitious organizing drives in maritime history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The National Committee Against Mental Illness cautioned today that, if the present rate of incidence continues, one out of ten Americans would spend a part of his life in a mental hospital.

I have recently had an opportunity to read the most interesting series by Walter Sullivan on the Soviet's scientific surge. The New York Times is to be congratulated in making available to the American people such an up-to-date and factual report.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The stock market continued relaxed but firm last week, still under the influence of the midsummer doldrums laid to the arrival of the holiday season and the probability of fall elections.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 2 -- Let's face it, Oh ye who agitate for adventurous programs: the weather counts for at least as much as the music.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 -- A smog research project is being started that may help New York as well as smog-ridden Los Angeles.

There is no occasion for surprise over the fact that the Communists have opened up a fresh and large-scale assault in the border areas of the Kingdom of Laos. It has obviously been in the making for some months. The danger flags have been flying.

The public relations offices of the steel companies and the steel union, whose advertisements appeared periodically in your paper since May, are performing a real disservice to the public by so distorting and burying the facts as to make informed public opinion on the merits of the respective sides virtually impossible.
Cotton futures contracts traded in the domestic market ended last week with minor gains and losses. Prices of spot cotton continued to decline sharply.
MONTREAL, Aug. 1 -- Shipping delays at the Welland Canal, particularly since the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway have spurred plans for a steel-producing complex in the nearby Contrecoeur area.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- After holding the spotlight as the most bullish commodity on the Board of Trade for the previous three weeks, soybean futures encountered more resistance last week and eased slightly.

General Motors is considering financing a broad study of the possible link between automobile exhaust fumes and lung cancer. In a related move, it is reported developing a new filter that would cut the noxious fumes that contribute to air pollution.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 2 (AP) -- King Hussein announced today that Jordan would reestablish diplomatic relations with the United Arab Republic "in the near future." Earlier, Premier Hazza Majali said relations would be resumed before the end of this month.

OKMULGEE, Okla., Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Searchers found the bodies of three persons near the wreckage of a private plane here today after the only survivor had staggered to the home of the pilot's parents, less than a mile away.

BELGRADE, Aug. 2 -- Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels, who are highly placed in this country's political pantheon, had scant use for the Southern or Yugo Slavs. "I have damned little sympathy for them," wrote Engels. And, in a joint essay, the two proto-Communists declared: "The Panslavist South Slavs are nothing more than the waste products of a highly confused development which has gone on for a thousand years."
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A Puerto Rican throng demonstrated for independence today for the benefit of State Governors here for their fifty-first annual conference.

OTTAWA, Aug. 2 -- When George Philias Vanier takes over as Governor General of Canada, to which he was named yesterday by Queen Elizabeth II, he will not be entirely unfamiliar with the duties of the vice-regal post.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 2 -- Bob Rosburg, the son of a physician, preferred baseball to golf when he attended Stanford University. He was a college second baseman, but he wasn't speedy enough to try for the major leagues. Today Rosburg became a major leaguer in golf in winning the Professional Golfers Association title.
MACON, Ga., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Harold Thurston cranked the propeller to start his private plane with the throttle open too much today. The plane lurched, breaking a mooring line.

STRATFORD, Conn., Aug. 2 -- Speak gratefully of the Connecticut Shakespeare company for staging a comedy that is seldom seen. "All's Well That Ends Well" had its official opening in the Festival Theatre last evening.

Soltzer-Lampert, realty operators, sold the six-story apartment building on a plot 91 by 126 feet at 299 to 305 Adelphi Street, Brooklyn, to Samuel Davidson. The building contains seventy - one apartments and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $252,500 through the Philip Fogel Company.
ROME, Aug. 2 -- Sunny Italy is being told that she is becoming too sensitive to heat.
The annual Sylvania television awards, established in 1951 to honor "those who are advancing creative television techniques," may be discontinued by their sponsor, Sylvania Electric Products, Inc.

Long Island Lighting Company reported over the weekend sizable gains for the fiscal year ended June 30. Operating revenues set a record at $129,784,000, or 11 per cent above the $116,307,000 of the year before.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 2 -- When the Yankees left New York two weeks ago they were fourth, only five and a half games out of first place and loaded with confidence
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A hat made out of New York ice cream was suggested today as a gift for James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- If British teachers had their way, youngsters in other countries would be taught that the English are not unfriendly.
More and more states are acting to reduce drunken driving.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 2 -- Herman, who is making his movie debut, will get billing for cooing. Herman, a blue-bar pigeon, will probably however never get written into another script by George Wells.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- A two-run homer by Willie McCovey and Willie Mays' clutch double paced the San Francisco Giants to a 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today. The triumph kept the Giants on top in the National League race.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 2 -- Winner over Alex Olmedo at the Merion Cricket Club, Ian Vermaak gave an even more masterful performance today in winning the seventy-first Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.
Peter J. Reidy, Commissioner of Buildings, said yesterday that he believed there was no appreciable corruption in his department.

When the Joint Congressional Economic Committee was reshuffled last January to take account of the 1958 election changes, it emerged with a new chairman, Senator Paul Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, generally considered the ablest economist in the national legislature.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 -- The second All-Star game of 1959 will be played tomorrow by the pension-minded myrmidons of the National and American Leagues.

Giacomo Cardinal Lercaro, Archbishop of Bologna, Italy, is expected to arrive here on Aug. 17 on his way to the twentieth annual North American Liturgical Week to be held at the University of Notre Dame, South Bend, Ind.

Americans must be deeply moved by the incredible reception the people of Warsaw gave Vice President Nixon yesterday. In the heart of Communist-ruled Eastern Europe, in a nation with Soviet troops on its soil and with Soviet troops on its eastern and western borders, about one hundred thousand people turned out spontaneously to cheer and throw flowers to the Vice President of the United States.

St. Joseph's Seminary, a former sanatorium near Saranac Lake in the Adirondack Mountains, will be dedicated Sunday as a major training institution for the White Fathers, a Roman Catholic missionary order.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Queen Elizabeth II returned today, looking fit after her arduous six-week tour of Canada.

The Rev. J. C. Michael Allen preached his first sermon yesterday as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's in-the-Bouwerie, Second Avenue and Tenth Street. He succeeds the Rev. Dr. Richard E. McEvoy who resigned last December to become an archdeacon in the New York Diocese.
Labor and management have found a common meeting ground in mutual funds.
DUMONT, N. J., Aug. 2 -- On Friday 3-year-old Timothy Brady can stop asking his parents: "Is today the day we go back to Alaska?"

H. Daroff Sons, Inc., Philadelphia, manufacturers of men's clothing, has purchased Harris Frank, Inc., operators of a twenty-one-store chain of men and women's specialty clothing, it was announced yesterday. The purchase price was not disclosed.
ONE of the busiest souvenir shops here is in the city's most august basement. It is the United Nations Souvenir Shop in the General Assembly building.

ONE of the best written and most psychologically perceptive novels I have read so far in 1959 is "Barbara Greer," by Stephen Birmingham. It is not only an impressively expert work of fiction; it is also a significant milestone in Mr. Birmingham's career, for "Barbara Greer" is a second novel and second novels are proverbially the crucial test of fictional creativity.

Society news, which usually eludes comment on this page, has been breaking its customary bounds and gone to Page 1 in the heart-warming romance of Steven Clark Rockefeller and Anne-Marie Rasmussen of Norway. Yesterday the engagement was announced, with paternal blessings. Governor Rockefeller, the father, is "very fond of Anne-Marie," whom he describes as a "very attractive and intelligent young lady."
The United Steelworkers of America and the major producers will meet here today in their second joint negotiating session since the national steel strike started on July 15.
Primary contests for Tammany district leaderships are in prospect in twenty-four of the thirty-three districts in Manhattan.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- The Government has just published a report showing that France's foreign trade was in balance during the first six months of this year. The report followed a French decision to increase from 50 to 70 per cent the liberation of trade with the dollar zone from quota restrictions.
A profound revolution is in the making in this ancient land.

Governor Rockefeller's son Steven will marry Anne-Marie Rasmussen, the Norwegian girl whom he met when she came to this country three years ago to learn English. A late summer wedding in Norway is planned.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller warmly commended today Gov. Robert B. Meyner's program for affording railroads tax relief in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- When Hawaii's Governor-elect William F. Quinn was in town a while back, he dropped in at A.F.L.-C.I.O. headquarters to shake hands and say "thanks" for the endorsement of his candidacy by COPE -- the merged labor organization's Committee On Political Education.

MOSCOW, Aug. 2 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon's long years of political controversy are beginning to pay off. He has been in the center of so many battles in the last decade, usually as the principal target, that he has learned to control his temper, his voice and even his facial expressions.

A thirty - five - story office building is planned on Fifth Avenue at Sixtieth Street, adjoining the Sherry-Netherland Hotel. It will be known as 785 Fifth Avenue and will represent an investment of about $20,000,000, including the cost of the land.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A new robot switchboard being displayed at an Army meeting has a switching system that automatically by-passes battle-damaged communications lines and reroutes messages over the fastest available circuit.
LONDON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Moscow radio made a special effort tonight to refute Vice President Richard M. Nixon's denial that he had tried to give money to a workman in a Moscow meat market.
For well over a decade the United States has maintained an exceptionally high excess of exports over imports, running as recently as 1957 to more than $6,500,000,000.

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., Aug. 2 -- Billy Uhl of the Old Cove Yacht Club who took three firsts in the four-race competition, won the Lightning Class title in the nineteenth annual Eastern Long Island Yachting Association three-day regatta. He finished first in today's race, held in a twenty-five knot breeze on Shelter Island Sound.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 4 -- Ten thousand Russians attended the premiere here last night of an American variety show assembled by Ed Sullivan.

AN Irish designer who already has made a name for herself at home and is now beginning to attract attention outside Ireland is Evelyn Gaughan. Her fall collection, shown recently before a select audience at the Gresham Hotel.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Federal Reserve Board's annual "Balance Sheet of Agriculture," just released for publication, reveals that the financial asset position of the nation's farmers reached the highest level last year in the nation's history.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- Several leading delegates predicted today that Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev would address the General Assembly during his visit to the United States.

George G. Creal, vice president for marketing of The Western Union Telegraph Company, has been elected to the board of CandyGram, Inc., Chicago, which operates the new service started by Western Union.
The standing of short-term United States Government obligations continued to improve in the public market yesterday, with the new 4 3/4 per cent notes still commanding most of the day's business.

YONKERS, Aug. 3 -- The main building of the first S. Klein department store in Westchester County was opened here today At 10 A. M. There was no ceremony, but there was a rush by thousands of shoppers.
CHARLESTON, S. C., Aug. 3 (UPI) -- An earthquake jarred South Carolina from the coast to the Piedmont early today. Little damage resulted. No one was injured.
Franklin D. Roosevelt was the only United States President to visit the Soviet Union while in office. Not one Russian Czar, President or Premier has ever come to the United States.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 3 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, commenting today on the planned exchange of visits by the Soviet and United States leaders, said: "I hope Khrushchev's tour will convince him of the power and resolution of the United States of America to safeguard peace and freedom in the world."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- The General Services Administration said today that a lamp bulb apparently had caused a five-alarm fire that swept through a storage room at the Defense Department July 2.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 3 -- The replacing of Westchester's Park and Recreation Commissions by a joint department headed by a professional administrator was recommended to the Board of Supervisors today.

FALL fabrics to buy by the yard are keeping right in step with the fashion trends in ready-made clothing. Last year at this time, the stores' fabric departments were stacked with bolts of soft, fuzzy-surfaced woolens. cut velvets and satins all vibrating with color. This time around, it is a different story.

The Duquesne Light Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues for the three, six and twelve months ended June 30. Net income, however, in the six and twelve months trailed that of the 1958 periods, chiefly because of a large drop in credit for interest charged to construction.

Reports of merger negotiations between the Tidewater Oil Company and the Skelly Oil Company were confirmed yesterday when George F. Getty II, president of Tidewater, said that a report of the proposed merger had been filed with the Department of Justice.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 3 -- Six Western Allies -- the United States, Britain, France, Canada, Belgium and The Netherlands signed agreements with the Bonn Government today covering the status of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces stationed in West Germany.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- British leaders welcomed without reserve today the coming exchange of visits between President Eisenhower and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev.

The Eisenhower Administration's castigation of management and labor in the national steel strike touched off an angry exchange of charges yesterday. Each side blamed the other for prolonging the three-week-old walkout of 500,000 steel workers.

Somebody saw smoke yesterday and told the station-master at Rye, N. Y., about a "big fire" on the tracks of the New Haven Railroad. Thus starts the tale of why Train 245 out of Stamford, Conn., reached Grand Central Terminal forty-one minutes late.
One workman was killed and five others injured on a Manhattan housing project site yesterday when a 190-foot crane buckled as they poured concrete on the sixth floor of an apartment building.

I read with interest Walter Sullivan's third installment in The Times series comparing scientific progress in the U. S. S. R. with that in the United States. It is headed "Party Dogma Is Found to Curb Some Areas of Soviet Science."
MANY a little gem of information and piquant prose winks and flashes in the Fish and Wildlife Report of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.
The New York Philharmonic left International Airport yesterday for Europe and the longest foreign tour in its history -- ten weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A space capsule designed to carry a man will be sent up unoccupied next month from Cape Canaveral, Fla. The launching thrust will be given by a vehicle called Big Joe, essentially a modified Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile. The missile will rise vertically to about 120 miles, then tilt at right angles and slightly downward.
Plans for a new and expanded phases of the Welfare Department's family counseling program were announced last night by Deputy Welfare Commissioner James R. Dumpson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Treasury today reported a slight drop in the interest cost on its offering of ninety-one-day and 182day bills which it markets on a discount basis for cash or in exchange for the maturing issues each week.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 8,637 pints of blood in July, 1959. The total in July 1958, was 8,253.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- An official of the Federal Food and Drug Administration warned today about what he called a multi-million-dollar quackery racket in the field of nutrition.
THE war between the sexes extends to college clothes. It is a cold war, to be sure, with plenty of la politesse, but still a head-on collision of ideas.
