Conrad Cooper, chief negotiator for the steel companies, in answer to a statement Saturday by James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, calling on both sides to negotiate seriously. The union also issued a reply to the Conrad statement.
Dreyfus Fund, Inc., reported yesterday that its net assets on June 30 ran 33.2 per cent higher than the March 31 level and 77.8 per cent higher than the Dec. 31, 1958 figure.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The fate of a future second All-Star game each year will be left to the players. A random poll of the players today indicated they favored the idea.

A system for setting concrete floors that is said to reduce by about one-third the time required by present methods is being used in a variety of structures in the New York metropolitan area and in Pennsylvania and Washington, D. C.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Senate today scheduled hearings into charges that piggy-back freight movement -- the shipment of loaded highway trailers on railroad flatcars -- was leading into cutthroat competition.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- There was little hostility today toward the exchange plan. However, doubt was expressed about its value. Many were enthusiastic about the idea as an aid to peace.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 3 -- The proposed exchange was hailed on curbstones today, with only a few sour notes.

Jed Harris is back in action again. Absent from this precinct since he did "Child of Fortune" (1956), the producer-director said yesterday he was eager to put on "Con Amore." Arthur P. Carter is the author of the romantic comedy, dealing with Italian-Americans in New England.
Maximum security measures will be taken to insure the safety of Nikita S. Khrushchev on his visit to the United States in September.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 -- A freshman pitcher and an old catcher proved the winning combination for the American League today.

ROME, Aug. 3 -- An early Christian catacomb has been found on the southern outskirts of Rome. The underground cemetery and place of worship contains many tombs, some frescoes and a number of scratched inscriptions that are being studied by experts.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A single smoke flare, saved for use at just the right moment rescue yesterday to two men marooned seven nights and days high on the barren face of an Alaska glacier.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that New York would cooperate in receiving Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union "to any extent requested by the State Department."

The Hudson Celebration Theatre-in-the-Park made its second trial at a dance program in the open air last night and came off considerably better with it than it did with its first. This time it was working with a less formal and demanding medium than the classic ballet, and could accordingly cut a good many corners.

WARSAW, Aug. 3 -- Richard M. Nixon walked briskly into a reception room here today, shook hands with the stiff, withdrawn man waiting for him and then became the first Western leader to negotiate with Wladyslaw Gomulka, Communist ruler of Poland.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 -- Casey Stengel and his Yankees may have lost some of their glamor of former years, but they still have Yogi Berra.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug 3 -- Thoroughbred horse facing was back here again today, for the ninety-first season since the sport was introduced to the Spa on Aug. 2, 1864. The opening day of the twenty-four-day meeting was regarded as a successful one, in view of the turnout of 15.183 horse players in delightful weather.

A major rift in the ranks of Rosensohn Enterprises. Inc. yesterday dimmed the possibility of a return world heavyweight title bout here in September between Ingemar Johansson of Sweden and Floyd Patterson of New York.
VIENNA, Aug. 3 (UPI) -Paul Robeson, the American Negro singer, charged today that United States foreign policy was being infiltrated by "fascism."
THE seventh season of free concerts in Washington Square opened last night with a function that was more in the nature of a civic celebration than a serious concert.
The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday the election of Dr. James R. Killian Jr. as a director. Dr. Killian is chairman of the Corporation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
THE good old Anglo-Saxon game of lawn tennis, which Maj. Walter Clopton Wingfield gave to the world in 1873 under the patented name of Sphairistike, has been getting around.

The report of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., for the six months ended June 30 showed yesterday a net income of $216,050,691, compared with $145,924,663 cleared in the first half of last year. The income is equal to $4.61 and $3.08 a share for the respective periods. Net sales rose to $1,068,166,177 from $852,574,109.
BAY SHORE, L. I. Aug. 3 -- Patricia Tiernan, Wheatley Hills, took the medal today with a 38, 36 -- 74 in the Women's Cross Golf Association's match play championship at Southward-Ho.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation threw its hat in the ring yesterday. It announced that it would sponsor television and radio coverage of the 1960 Presidential nominating conventions, campaigns and election returns over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

BOSTON, Aug. 3 -- Opinion appeared today to be weighted slightly in favor of the exchange. Differences seemed to swing between those who felt the visits would be a waste of time and those who felt anything that would advance the cause of peace was worth trying.
New York City has an average of more than one water main break a day in the course of a year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Senate voted today to give the National Aeronautics and Space Administration its requested $530,000,000 budget. It thus rejected a House appropriations cut that threatened to hamstring" the national space program.

The National Association of Mutual Savings Banks has decided to establish its own graduate school for management training, it was learned yesterday. The move is one outcome of the widening rift between savings and commercial bankers over the question of higher Federal taxes for the mutual thrift institutions.

The International Business Machines Corporation is offering its electronic computers on an hourly basis to businesses across the nation next year. In a radical departure from its traditional monthly leasing policy for data processing equipment, the company announced yesterday it would establish twenty-five to thirty Datacenters in major cities.
ATHENS, Aug. 3 -- Greece has rejected a Bulgarian offer of a twenty-year non-aggression pact, it was disclosed today.

The first unit of the proposed $30,000,000 Harlem Hospital Center opened yesterday.
BERLIN, Aug. 3 -- In sports as in all else Germany is divided.

NOW that the wrangling is over (God save the judges of the Appellate Division) free Shakespeare has resumed in Central Park. Joseph Papp and his fresh-air actors opened "Julius Caesar" last evening at the Belvedere Lake Theatre. Stuart Vaughan having taken up his old position at the director's podium.

Within the limits of the city there are hundreds of acres of land on which ragweed thrives, and by mid-August thousands of hay-fever victims will be tearfully aware of the fact that the plant's pollen has appeared.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn gave his support today to the labor reform bill that the House Education and Labor Committee put together to the dissatisfaction of most of its members.
KARACHI, Aug. 3 -- Clarification of Pakistan's jute policy to remove misunderstandings among American buyers was made here today by Osman Ali, the Secretary of the Ministry of Commerce.
DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Production of 1959 models by the Chrysler Corporation has ended and General Motors divisions begin shutting down this week.

LYNBROOK, L. I., Aug. 3 -- The Lynbrook School District today became the first in the state to receive tentative approval for state aid under a new bond-financing law designed to reduce interest costs.

The New York City Guide says that Giovanni da Verrazano, Italian-born explorer sailing under the French flag, discovered Staten Island in 1524. After telling about his various explorations the Encyclopaedia Britannica says "nothing is certain of the eventual fate of Verrazano, although it is thought that he was either killed by Indians or hanged as a pirate on a later expedition to America, probably South America."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Army exhibited its ultimate weapon today -- a fighting soldier of the future. At the same time, the new chief of staff, Gen. Lyman k. Lemnitzer, forecast a "strategic nuclear disarmament" of the United States and the Soviet Union.
THE following menu for a summer dinner was inspired in part by the cuisine at a midtown restaurant. The meal is relatively simple, yet interesting enough to provoke commendation and pique appetites.

KRISTIANSAND, Norway, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- Young Steven Rockefeller and the Norwegian girl he will marry sought seclusion in the hills near here today for a respite from the excitement generated by the disclosure of their romance.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation averaged $100,000,000 sales a month during the first half of 1959. This brought the volume to $607,903,000, largest in its history and 31 per cent ahead of last year's $465,735,000 total for the first half.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 3 -- Glenmont, the home of the late Thomas A. Edison, was turned over today to the National Park Service and dedicated as a part of the Edison National Monument.
A World Series is a World Series is a World Series, even without the Yankees. The Gillette Safety Razor Company will back this contention with an advertising outlay of $5,400,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union, independent, opened its cash receipts books for July today and showed a paid-up membership of 77,338.

ALL novels are historical novels, but some, to paraphrase George Orwell, are more flagrantly historical than others. One of the pleasures of reading them is to find out how people lived in ages as perplexed as our own. Another, of course, is that the genre allows us to regard as dramatically picturesque sinful doings that in contemporary settings would call for the censure of the professionally pure.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Aug. 4 -- The poisoning of the Deerfield River for the sake of good fishing has been completed now, and some surprising things came out of it.

Top-flight professional, college and high school basketball players will appear on a Long Island basketball court in exhibition contests Saturday at noon. The games will be for the benefit of a scholarship fund for needy metropolitan area high school players.
NEWARK, Aug. 4 -- Groundbreaking ceremonies for Newark's long-planned underground garage in Military Park were held today. The project had been in the discussion stage for thirty years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Warren Spahn's brilliant three-hitter helped Milwaukee post a 6-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight and regain the lead in the tight National League pennant race.
Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer directed yesterday that the minutes of a grand jury investigation into the alleged rigging of television quiz shows be turned over to a House subcommittee.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Most share groups were buoyant on the stock market here today after the three-day bank holiday week end.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Mrs. James R. Hand eliminated Gail Wild, the 1948 titleholder, 2 and 1, in the first round of the thirty-fourth Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship at Sleepy Hollow today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -Congress approved and sent to the White House today a bill providing $39,228,239,000 to finance the country's military programs until next July 1.
Two educators pointed up a need yesterday for new sources of revenue for an increasing school population.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Monmouth Park enjoyed its second day today of having more than $2,000,000 pushed through the pari-mutuel machines. With the absence of competition from metropolitan New York, a crowd of 25,747 bet $2,210,395.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- "A Raisin in the Sun" had its London premiere tonight at the Adelphi Theatre. It was warmly applauded by the audience and coolly received by the press.
Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan yesterday denied a motion by Alexander L. Guterma to have the 44-year-old financier's fraud trial transferred from the Southern District of New York to Buffalo.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender said today that the Secretary of Agriculture had torpedoed hopes raised by President Eisenhower for a compromise farm bill this year.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Lieut. Gov. Carroll Gartin took a slim lead tonight in early returns from the Democratic primary voting for Governor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Motorola Inc., announced today that its sales in the second quarter had risen to $65,214,062, or 49 percent above the 1958 level, while profits quadrupled. Six month sales, of $128,867,246, and profits also established new records.
RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 4 -- King Mohamed V came home suddenly today after a months's stay in Switzerland and France.
ALBANY, Aug. 4 -- Governor Rockefeller has set up a new fiscal target -- cutting back next year's state budget below $2,000,000,000.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 3 to 17 points (15 to 85 cents a bale) yesterday with the strength most pronounced in the distant months.

Vice President Nixon is scheduled to return today from his eventful trip to the Soviet Union and Poland, which has been the focus of world attention these past two weeks. Few men ever have their every action, word and mood so closely studied, reported and interpreted as has the Vice President since he left this country. It was a grueling test of Mr. Nixon's physical endurance, mental alertness and stability.
WARSAW, Aug. 4 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon visited a plain red brick Roman Catholic cathedral in Warsaw today.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., Aug. 4 -- Sam Barton Jr. and his American Yacht Club crew of brother Bob and Tyler Keys took a 4-point lead today for the Junior Racing Association championship of Long Island Sound. Two championship races were held, five crews in each. Barton, who is 17, won both.
WARSAW, Aug. 4 -- The Vice President of the United States leaned toward the small, dapper Pole.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, told the Senate today that his mail had confirmed his charge that New York had the worst racial unrest, prejudice and police problems of any city in the country.

The Felsway Shoe Corporation, operator of a chain of thirty-five shoe stores in the East, has leased space on the second floor of the first section of Industry City. This is a group of buildings in the area from Ninth to Eleventh Avenues between Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets.
WARSAW, Aug. 4 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a speech delivered tonight by Vice President Richard M. Nixon at a United States Embassy reception here:
Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman yesterday denied a motion by the Securities and Exchange Commission to adjudge Robert Maurice Sherwood, Canadian financier. in contempt of court.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Aug. 4 -- Delegates from nine independent African states and Algeria heard an appeal today to both Algerian nationalists and France to "ease" their "extreme positions" and agree to a negotiated settlement.
JERUSALEM Aug. 4 (Israeli Sector),-- Special restrictions on the movement of Israeli Arabs will be eased beginning this week.

FIRST the two-car family, now the two-house one. One home is not enough for Boris Kroll, the fabric designer, or Jens Risom, the furniture designer. They require two on the same lot to house their families.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- A state of emergency has been proclaimed in five battle-torn provinces of Laos, it was reported tonight in a Laotian broadcast monitored here.
Rear Admiral Henry C. Perkins, commander of the Eastern Coast Guard Area, received a citation of achievement yesterday for the building of the new Coast Guard base at the Battery.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The major scheduled airlines of the world urged the Civil Aeronautics Board today to approve their effort to keep the credit card plans out of the industry.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 4 -- Two Staten Island youths today drew long prison terms after they pleaded no defense to the holdup slaying last Dec. 18 of Stephen F. Sladowski, Bayonne City Prosecutor.
KARAKORUM, Outer Mongolia. For 600 years not one stone atop another has remained to mark the site here of the mighty Mongol capital that a son of Genghis Khan built to fulfill his father's dream.

The article on the state bar association's proposal to revise New York's outmoded test for insanity (News in Review, July 26) may leave the erroneous impression that New York will be the first jurisdiction to adopt a more enlightened standard for determining criminal responsibility.
The nation's largest waterfowl, the trumpeter swan, was reported yesterday to have been saved from extermination.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A committee report to the Senate today condemned James R. Hoffa and two of his chief aides in the Teamsters Union.

A survey of civil rights laws enacted in 1958-59 presents "striking evidence" that state legislatures are moving to wipe out racial and religious discrimination, the American Jewish Congress said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- The final round to decide the contract bridge masters' team championship began here tonight in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament. The winning team will represent North America in the world championship matches in Rome next April.
"A Loss of Roses," the William Inge drama scheduled to open Dec. 30 at the Coronet, has lost its director. Yesterday it became known that Arthur Penn had resigned from that post.

There is a serious question as to whether the purposes of the law creating the State Commission Against Discrimination (SCAD) are being subverted by the curious position this agency is taking in the Aramco matter.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 -The ten-man Pennsylvania Banking Board will meet in Harrisburg on Aug. 19 to consider whether Pennsylvania banks should be permitted to pay higher interest rates to depositors.
The Treasury's two new issues of 1 3/4 per cent notes rose to new high prices yesterday in another trading session marked by heavy bidding for short-dated securities.

ALBANY, Aug. 4 -- An experimental program to promote two-year nursing education in community colleges was announced today by the State Education Department and Teachers College of Columbia University.

Darryl F. Zanuck, formerly head of production for Twentieth Century-Fox and now an independent producer, will make ten features for the company in the next two years at a total cost of about $30,000,000.
The long-rumored plans of the Western Maryland Railway for splitting its stock were confirmed by the carrier yesterday.
OTTAWA, Aug. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Three West German shipping lines withdrew today from Great Lakes shipping conferences.

ANAMOSA, Iowa, Aug. 4 -- (AP) -- Paul Engle, famed Iowa poet, and a daughter were on the way to their summer home near here last evening when their car was stopped at a police roadblock. Two men from a state prison farm were being sought in the area.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
GENEVA, Aug. 4 -- The Big Four foreign ministers were reported tonight to have agreed on a way to reopen the deadlocked disarmament negotiations in the United Nations.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Governor Faubus was not available tonight for comment on the board's action.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced last night that his office had been investigating since July 23 the "promotional activities" behind the Floyd Patterson - Ingemar Johansson heavyweight championship fight.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Vada Pinson's two-run homer in the third inning provided the Cincinnati Reds with the margin they needed for a 4-1 victory tonight over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
An 1881 law was invoked by Democratic party insurgents yesterday to enable them to inspect city financial records.
Landmarks are taking their place with trade-marks on the corporate scene.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 4 -- In talks with Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut and Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey, Governor Rockefeller today renewed his promise to recommend tax relief for nonresidents of New York State subject to the state's income taxes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Seven trade and consumers organizations today asked Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, to reject a request for restrictions on imports of cotton textiles.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Miscellaneous statistics and other items pertaining to the American Contract Bridge League's tournament now coming to a close in Chicago:
GENEVA, Wednesday, Aug. 5 -- After three hours of phrase-by-phrase wrangling, the Big Four foreign ministers agreed early today on a Western draft of a communique on recessing their long conference.

WILLIAM VACANARAT SHADRACH TUBMAN, who opened a conference of nine independent African states yesterday, has been President of the Republic of Liberia since 1944. Mr. Tubman has been in politics for most of his adult life. He has worked hard to build a strong Administration and to promote the welfare of Liberia.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians' general manager, Frank Lane, accused Casey Stengel today of a "thinly veiled damned dirty trick" in the way Stengel, the Yankees' manager, handled pitchers at yesterday's All-Star game.
The Department of Health announced yesterday that it would take polio vaccination clinics to the public, which has not been going to the stationary clinics for its full quota of Salk shots.
VIENNA, Aug. 4 -- The seventh World Youth Festival ended tonight with a mass gathering in City Hall Square. Folk dancers and singers from many countries regaled the thousands of delegates.
DEAL, N. J., Aug. 4 -- New Jersey won amateur golf's Stoddard Cup today by defeating Long Island and Westchester at the Hollywood Golf Club.

Like just about all other business developments, dividend news continues to be very good indeed. Investors basked in a particularly warm glow last month. In July, according to a survey by Standard Poor's Corporation statistical and advisory service, sixty-six companies declared dividend increases as compared with only thirty in July, 1958.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 4 (Reuters) -- Archbishop Makarios, the Greek Cypriote leader, said today there were "no substantial differences" between hmiself and Gen. George Grivas, leader of the four-year underground war to end British rule on this island.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 -- The atmosphere here began to glow with warmth today as Russians assessed more deeply the news that Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev would visit the United States and President Eisenhower would come here.

OVER the years, Peck Peck has come to represent not only clothes but also a way of life. Its reputation for fine, well-cut fabrics with classic understatement is well-known in cities and suburbs throughout the country.

FROM now until the end of August shoppers in some of New York's fish markets may see on display trays of silvery-white fish about two to three inches long. These are whitebait, very young, tender fish that are usually served fried and eaten in their entirety.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 4 -- The Sleepy Hollow Stable's Avalon Hanover and the S. L. and K. Stable's Elaine Rodney led the qualifiers with victories in the trials for the $28,500 Miss America 2-year-old filly trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
Governor Rockefeller, a strong believer in polls, is lagging far behind Vice President Richard M. Nixon in national and regional straw votes for the Republican Presidential nomination.

SOEGNE, Norway, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Steven Rockefeller announced today that he and his fiancee, Anne Marie Rasmussen, had decided on Aug. 22 as the date for their church wedding here. He said "most" of his family would attend the ceremony.
Five teen-aged Queens boys their small boat awash in the Narrows, were pulled from a choppy sea yesterday by a lifeboat crew from the Dutch freighter M. Z. Banda.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, whose seismograph-on-the-moon project was announced last week, is seriously worried about a threatened cut in its budget request.

City and Federal officials, in a move to cut costs and reduce delays in acquiring sites for Title I housing, have undertaken an exhaustive review of condemnation procedures involving the Title I program.
Pennsylvania borrowed $120,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the payment of a bonus to Korean war veterans.

The near wool positions were weakest yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Profit taking, heavy stop-loss selling, light trade hedging and chart selling depressed prices. The market opened steady on trade short covering and new speculator buying.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -Representative Graham A. Barden accused representatives of organized labor today of trying to "take over" the House Labor Committee during the drafting of labor legislation.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug 4 -- The Governors Conference unanimously approved today the Rockefeller Committee recommendations on fall-out shelters.
The Pennsylvania Electric Company sold $15,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds to investment bankers yesterday. The price was 101.5799 for obligations hearing a 5 per cent interest coupon.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- Official French reaction to the announcement of the forthcoming round of top-level diplomatic visits stressed the fact that France had been consulted at each step of the preparatory process. This apparently was aimed primarily at influencing French public opinion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower may meet in Paris this month with the heads of government of all the North Atlantic Treaty nations, diplomatic sources said today.

The head of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations sought yesterday to find a solution to a growing inter-union jurisdictional dispute over crewmen of Great Lakes iron-ore ships.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 4 -- Mrs. Lester Sacks of Philadelphia will soon be getting the six skeins of Orlon yarn she needs thanks to the kindness of the postmaster here.
PURCHASE, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Willie Turnesa of Knollwood and Mrs. Jerome Miller of Rockrimmon won the low gross in a Metropolitan Golf Association mixed foursome tournament today.
A minor correction is in order on James Reston's column from Moscow, published July 26, on the Order of the ZIS in the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The House Judiciary Committee refused today to recommend a declaration by Congress that states and localities are "obligated'' to move toward the desegregation of public schools.
Gasoline taxes now total more than $4.5 billion a year, and other Federal automotive excise taxes amount to nearly $2 billion yearly. Gasoline is already overtaxed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The United States finally rejected today fifteen Philippine claims amounting to about $950,000,000. It recognized other claims, including $73,000,000 for additional war damage payments.

The four Owens brothers, each of whom owns 25 per cent of the Owens Yacht Company, Inc., of Baltimore, are letting the public into the corporation. In twenty-five years, the brothers Charles J., Norman G., John B. and William C. Owens have built the concern into the second largest maker of pleasure boats in the country.
MEN make the big money on Wall Street, but it is the women who work for them who spend a fortune there.

Kimmelman-Zauderer, investors, have acquired the largest minority stock interest in the twenty-twostory office building and in an underlying leasehold estate at 400 Madison Avenue from the Lefcourt Realty Corporation. Coleman Co. were the brokers.
Stocks moved quietly downward yesterday. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange expanded to 2,530,000 shares from 2,410,000 on Monday and the losses outnumbered gains.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Aug. 4 -- A small nuclear plant of new design is planned by the Atomic Energy Commission.
WARSAW, Aug. 4 -- The Polish newspaper Zycie Warszawy said today that an editorial in The New York Times commenting on Vice President Richard M. Nixon's visit to Poland was "offending."

CARACAS, Aug. 4 -- The immediate cause of the demonstrations was said to have been the resignation of Dr. Celso Fortoul, the director of a public works program that was designed to employ several thousand jobless persons in this capital city.
The $1,500,000 advertising account of the United Aircraft Corporation will leave Lennen Newell, Inc., at the end of the year.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 4 -- Mobs rioted against the Venezuelan Government and fought army troops and the police for more than nine hours today in downtown Caracas.

Three thugs hijacked a truck carrying radios and high-fidelity equipment valued at $30,000 in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn yesterday. The truck driver was seized, but he was released unharmed three hours later.
I have been invited to the United States as a guest of the Department of State to become acquainted with the wonderful achievements of this splendid democracy.
WASHINGTON. Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower extended for another two years today the quota restriction on imported rye at 186,000,000 pounds a year.

FORT LEE, N. J., Aug. 4 -- Theatre buffs in northern New Jersey got their opportunity today to demonstrate that their love for the stage is at least dollar deep. The North Jersey Playhouse here, which became a non-profit foundation on June 25, formally began a campaign for $20,000 to assure its survival.

By now most folks must agree that the Yankees don't -- and won't -- have it this year. Last night at the Stadium, they were beaten again by Frank Lary and the Detroit Tigers, 4 -- 3, and fell to sixth place.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 4 -- The Soviet Union came under sharp attack today at the assembly of the World Jewish Congress here.
An all-out war might be prevented if America's military power were matched by an effective civil defense system, leaders of the Jewish War Veterans were told yesterday.
TRENTON, Aug. 4 -- The state moved today to assure financial assistance for some of its indigent college students in the coming academic year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4, (UPI) -- The Air Force announced the award of a $73,360,000 contract today for the development of a Titan missile nose cone designed to "nullify missile defenses."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Senate subcommittee on housing approved today a somewhat modified housing bill to replace the one that President Eisenhower vetoed last month.

One reason we have business cycles and why they behave as they do is that there are wide differences between the way people react to changes in the economic and business climate as respects different forms of activity.
Proposed offerings of new debt securities were announced yesterday by the Philadelphia Electric Company and Hooker Chemical Corporation.

IN many households, a bottle of capers, bought because a few of the tiny buds were needed for some specific recipe, sits idly in the refrigerator. It may be neglected for months. The cook has no idea how to make use of the remaining capers and, eventually, she may throw them away.

A new Code of Ethics for city workers was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council. It is designed to hold all 225,000 officials and employes of the city to rigid standards of conduct and to end conflicts of interest.
Three Democratic Senators moved yesterday for direct Congressional action to speed a settlement of the national steel strike.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 -- The price of a pack of American cigarettes and the meaning of the "American dream" are the questions most often put by Russians to the electronic answering device at the American National Exhibition here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission announced today it would sponsor a two-day sympo:;ium for management and technical personnel on the reprocessing of used nuclear fuels. The symposium will be held in cooperation with A.E.C. contractors Oct. 20-21 at Richland. Wash.

Electric revenues for the West Penn Electric Company system were 10.9 per cent higher in the second quarter than in the 1958 period, the company reported yesterday. First half industrial revenues were up 14 per cent; commercial up 6.6 per cent and residential up 6 per cent.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- The Greentree silks are making themselves evident in the winner's enclosure at the Saratoga track. The pink and black representing the John Hay Whitney and Mrs. Charles S. Payson racing interests were flaunted today by two winners, one of which took the featured purse on the program.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 4 -- The talks between Cambodia's Premier, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, and South Vietnam's President, Ngo Dinh Diem, on improving relations between their two nations appear to have been successful.

All the leading drivers in national championship competition are entered for the Sports Car Club of America races at Montgomery, N. Y., on Saturday and Sunday. This means that George Constantine of Southbridge, Mass.; Walter Hansgen of Westfield, N. J.; Ed Crawford of Chicago, Jim Jeffords of Milwaukee and E. D. Martin of Columbus, Ga., will be rivals in one of the big races on Sunday.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 4 -- Backers of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota today challenged supporters of Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts to a showdown battle in Wisconsin's Democratic Presidential preferential primary next April 5.

William Joseph Fello, president of the Bi-County News Company of Garden City, L. I., who was indicted last month for conspiracy and extortion, surrendered to the District Attorney's office here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Treasury is re-emphasizing an old trick for snaring income tax evaders -- monthly reports by banks and other financial institutions on any unusually large currency transactions they have handled.
The Maritime Administration has issued a primer on a twenty-five-year-old piece of shipping legislation that it believes has been widely misunderstood abroad.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 4 -- Three teamsters were arrested here today and charged with coercion after allegedly threatening an employe of an auto agency.
Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens, who is seeking re-election, and two of his rivals for the Democratic nomination filed designating petitions yesterday for the primary to be held Sept. 15.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- The Senate Public Works Committee approved today a hurry-up measure designed to make acceptable to President Eisenhower the pending self-financing bill for the Tennessee Valley Authority.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass. Aug. 4 -- Walter S. Gubelmann's yawl Windigo and Henry D. Mercer's 12-meter Weatherly sped across Massachusetts Bay today as vigorously as in the earlier New York Yacht Club cruise events and won again in their classes.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 4 -- The Little Rock school board voted unanimously tonight to reopen its four public high schools next Wednesday, nearly a month ahead of schedule.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 4 -- "Revisionism" is probably the dirtiest word now available in the rich Communist lexicon of opprobrium. To be called a revisionist is to imply that a party member is an ideological traitor. This was the favorite adjective Stalin applied to Tito when he sought to isolate and squash him. Zhukov was labeled revisionist by Khrushchev before he was put upon the shelf.
Ethel Merman will star in a one-hour cavalcade of the Broadway musical theatre next season over the National Broadcasting Company television network.
Following are the texts of a statement yesterday by David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, and a reply by Conrad Cooper, chief negotiator for the steel companies:
The present low inventories of United States shoe manufacturers induced active buying at the two-day Leather Show, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
A month's experience with banning buses from all but a small part of Washington Square Park has satisfied neither the community that demanded the rule nor the bus company that acceded to the demand.
Beetles imported from West Germany will be used instead of poisonous sprays to try to control aphids that are destroying balsam trees in this country.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 4 -- Ramanathan Krishnan suffered a jolting defeat today in the Eastern grass court tennis championships.
A new air-conditioned post office was dedicated and opened in Washington Heights yesterday. The station, called Washington Bridge, is at 555 West 180th Street and serves Postal Zone 33.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Army expects to test within months the Nike - Zeus anti-missile missile. The missile has been scoffed at by some Air Force officials but received substantial support recently in Congress.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 4 -- Governors of all the states, despite political differences, were uniting tonight in a campaign to block a threatened curtailment of Federal financial contributions for highway construction.

The Celanese Corporation of America increased sales to the highest level for any quarter or half-year period in its fortyone year history in the three and six months ended on June 30, according to the report issued yesterday.

The consolidated net income of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the Motors Insurance Company, a wholly owned subsidiary, was $10,712,255 in the April-June period, compared with $12,879,973 in the three months of last year.

WHO are the foremost living American novelists? In all probability ninety-nine out of 100 American or European readers would reply, Hemingway and Faulkner. That those two enormously gifted writers deserve to be widely read and generally admired is beyond question; but their pre-eminent reputations are based in part upon special circumstances: their personal mannerisms and peculiarly individual outlooks on life have provided stimulating material for masses of critical analysis.
The net earnings of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) for the first half of this year were 50 per cent above the like period of 1958, the company reported yesterday.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 4 -- A giant "radar telescope," whose dish antenna will be as high as a fifteen-story building, will be built on the Stanford University campus. The telescope, which is designed to explore space, the sun and planets, will be America's largest and the second largest in the world.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee voted today to "go more deeply" into charges of waste and inefficiency in the foreign aid program in Vietnam.

For the bored business man seeking new challenges, opportunity is knocking with such items as folding anchors, fish pudding or a better light-bulb package. These are just a few of the products figuring in more than 100 foreign trade opportunities newly compiled by the United States Department of Commerce.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 4 -- Further rebel advances in northern Laos were reported today. Two more military posts in the province of Phongsaly have been captured and the large village of Mong Het in Samneua province is encircled, reports said.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Efforts to promote an exchange of information between teachers on both sides of the Iron Curtain have been fruitless so far.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Britain looked forward today to a change for the better in the struggle between East and West.
Liberia will supplement its examination and licensing system for its merchant marine officers by providing for the issuance of radar observer certificates.

WARSAW, Aug. 4 -- The mission of Richard M. Nixon to the Soviet Union and Poland ended tonight in a garden back of the United States Embassy with the Vice President discussing Chopin, piano lessons and Harry Truman, Admiral Hyman G. Rickover talking philosophy with the Polish Premier, Jozef of Warsaw.
COON RAPIDS, Iowa, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Roswell Garst, whose farm here has become a showplace for visiting Soviet officials in recent years, may get a visit from Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev next month.
The inclement weather yesterday came as no surprise to the people at the Ford Motor Company: Richard Goodrow is in town.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 5 -- Racial integration will be instituted by at least four school districts and expanded by a dozen others this fall.

The usual summer increase in motoring drained 1,661,000 barrels from the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 186,496,000 barrels, compared with 188,157,000 a week earlier and 178,715,000 a year ago.

The new experimental program of neighborhood conservation and rehabilitation announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner offers the promise of substantial achievement because it sets up a working partnership between the city government and citizen, community leadership. Everyone interested in the welfare of New York City will hope that, by this technique, a way has been found to accomplish the program's major goal, to slow up the rate of housing obsolescence and decay.

The sale by the Herbert J. Yates interests early last month of their controlling interest in Republic Pictures Corporation and the sale by Abraham Davega of his interest in the Davega Stores Corporation, also effected early in July, both showed up yesterday in the "insiders' list" of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Both British and United States sources emphasize that President Eisenhower's itinerary is not "firm," but informal discussions indicate that Prime Minister Macmillan will meet with him during the last week of this month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- The contract bridge masters' team championship was won early today by the team of Oswald Jacoby of Dallas, Samuel M. Stayman, Victor Mitchell, Morton Rubinow and William Grieve of New York and Ira Rubin of Los Angeles.
Ground was broken yesterday for the forty-eight-story Zeckendorf Hotel, the largest built in New York since the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was opened in 1931.

Additional members of the arrangements committee for the Golden Anniversary Ball on Saturday have been announced by the chairman, Mrs. Charles P. Morrow. The event, a benefit for the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital, will be held at the Sharon Country Club.

The President announced the exchange of visits between himself and Premier Khrushchev of the Soviet Union as a firm arrangement, signed and sealed. The Premier has "accepted with pleasure" the President's invitation "to pay an official visit to the United States in September," and the President in turn has "accepted with pleasure" the Premier's invitation in kind to the Soviet Union "later this fall."

WARSAW, Aug. 5 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon left here this morning far from optimistic about any spectacular political results from the coming meetings between President Eisenhower and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev. Mr. Nixon favored these meetings, but is afraid of exaggerated public expectations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- President Eisenhower will address the nation tomorrow night to plead for what he considers effective labor control legislation.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 5 -- William M. Ingram's 3-year-old roan colt, Scotland, raced from last place in the $55,300 Choice Stakes at Monmouth today to defeat the 1-2 favorite, Atoll, by a length and a half.
MOSCOW, Aug. 5 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev said today that the question of Germany would have top priority in his coming talks in the United States with President Eisenhower.
AMERICAN families, many of them young families with children, bought $66,800,000,000 in life insurance in 1958.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- The Marine Corps' Blue team, led by Lieut. Col. Walter R. Walsh, won the .45-caliber pistol team championship today with 1,156. The score was one point better than the record set in 1955 by the Marine Corps' Grey team.
Prices staggered in the stock market yesterday then regained equilibrium and moved forward slowly. At the close on the New York Stock Exchange, they could be described as off but firm.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A parole was granted today to William R. Rose, the Ellenville, N. Y., bank president who misapplied more than $1,000,000 of the bank's money.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Administration officials said today that no decision had been reached to resume atomic testing on Oct. 31.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Six of the seven foreign trotters that competed in the International at Roosevelt Raceway last week will return here Saturday night for two special races.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Aug. 5 -- Charlottesville public schools are expected to desegregate for the first time this fall, but how many Negro pupils will be admitted to formerly all-white schools is still uncertain.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 -- It's quite fantastic what one sees going on out here in this metropolis of stiff winds and breezy people, and you really have to see it to appreciate it to the full.

District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Brooklyn yesterday announced the arrest of a former insurance broker on a charge of swindling a group of "prominent" lawyers of $27,000 in an insurance-selling scheme.

Selma Tamber, a member of Saint Subber's producing staff, will put on a play herself. Her first venture, "Viva Madison Avenue!," is by George Panetta, who dramatized his novel of the same name, published by Harcourt, Brace Co.

LOS ANGELES, Aug 5 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers, sparked by Duke Snider, who smashed two long home runs, rallied from a 3-0 deficit tonight and defeated Cincinnati, 6 -- 3, before 18,956 fans at the Coliseum.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- A woman business executive was killed and seven other persons, six of them nuns, were injured this morning in a two-car collision in a heavy rainstorm.
TRENTON, Aug. 5 -- Workmen are putting the finishing touches on this city's newest edifice, the town house of Mary G. Roebling.
EASTCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- The basic unit of a joint merchandising enterprise, the Vernon Hills shopping area, was formally opened at 11 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today the rejection of a proposal by the New York Central Railroad to drop all passenger train service on its St. Lawrence Division in upstate New York.
A new $1,750,000 sludge vessel is scheduled to be delivered today to the division of sewage disposal of the Department of Public Works.

Electric power production rose to a new high of 13,775,000,000 kilowatt hours last week from 13,577,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The latest level is slightly above the previous record of 13,749,000,000 kilowatt hours set in the week ended June 27.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 29:
BROOKHAVEN, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Fire Island beach buggies operated by hot-rod drivers have become a problem for Brookhaven.
Following is the text of Mr. Nixon's address on his arrival in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 5 -- The New York Yacht Club's cruise paused in this New England capital of sail and power boats today for shoreside recreation in the rain. Tomorrow the competition will be resumed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- The Senate Commerce Committee unanimously approved today President Eisenhower's nomination of Frederick H. Mueller as Secretary of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Army is apparently abandoning the use of enlisted men as servants for high-ranking officers, Representative Frank Kowalski reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Douglas Dillon, Acting Secretary of State, urged the Senate Appropriations Committee today to restore House cuts in the foreign aid money bill to insure the security of the United States and its allies.
The State Banking Board reestablished yesterday a maximum dividend rate that New York State mutual savings banks may pay their depositors. There had been no ceiling on this rate for six years.
WARSAW, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Following is the text of Vice President Nixon's farewell speech at the Warsaw airport:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency says that almost all civilian planes would be grounded at once in case of a major war.

Specialty clubs, as the name implies, are concerned with one breed. Among the most active is the German Shepherd organization. Fifty-seven local shepherd groups throughout the United States hold shows at which American Kennel Club championships points are awarded.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

TOLEDO, Spain, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Roman Catholic primate of Spain, Enrique Cardinal Play Deniel, has denied that he personally condemned mixed bathing and arm-in-arm walking by engaged couples. The Associated Press, in a dispatch July 10, said the Cardinal had done so in a communication published in the ecclesiastical bulletin of the archdiocese.

Louis G. Lindsey, formerly of Stanford University, has been named head rowing coach at the United States Naval Academy. He succeeds Russell (Rusty) Callow, the famed dean of rowing coaches, who retired June 30 owing to failing eyesight and poor health after developing some of the greatest eight-oared crews to come out of Annapolis.

The election of Irwin A. Zuckerman as executive vice president of the Hudson Pulp and Paper Company has been announced by William Mazer, president. The appointment of Bruce W. Martin as vice president-manufacturing also was announced.

While the Anaconda Company continued its negotiations with the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers International Union for a new labor contract, news of favorable earnings results for the first half this year were being mailed to stockholders.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points off to 4 points up yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.

" Blockbusting" tactics have begun in white neighborhoods in Queens concerned with the prospective transfer of Negro and Puerto Rican children from schools in Brooklyn, a spokesman for sixteen ministers in the area asserted yesterday.

SEATTLE, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The second day of trials for Sunday's Gold Cup race ended today with eleven unlimited hydroplanes well over the minimum speed needed to enter the event. Four boats qualified today.
LITTLE ROCK, Aug. 5 -- Publis school authorities here started today to notify teachers to report for duty next Monday to prepare for the opening of the four public high schools next Wednesday.

World sugar prices declined yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. A report of a lack of constructive action on the part of the International Sugar Council which met in London last week to halt the decline in the price of sugar caused the decline.
A prominent Soviet novelist and playwright, Valentin Petrovitch Katayev, said here yesterday that he wanted to learn about the Beat Generation writers and poets in this country.

Directors of Spiegel, Inc., yesterday voted to split the common stock on a three-for-two basis. They also declared an extra dividend of 12 1/2 cents with the regular quarterly of 25 cents, payable Sept. 15.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Treasury announced plans today to borrow $1,700,000,000 cash in the coming several weeks. This will complete its financing for the July-September quarter of the new fiscal year.

The chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, served notice on Wall Street yesterday that Congress was ready and able to regulate the Government securities market if need be.
GENEVA, Aug. 5 -- The Big Four foreign ministers announced tonight that they had had "useful" talks here on the future of disarmament negotiations.

IN reporting the forthcoming exchange of visits between Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev and President Eisenhower, the television industry faces probably the most costly journalistic undertaking in the medium's ten years.
Queens has 2,440 miles of streets, but only 712 receive the attention of the Department of Sanitation, John T. Clancy, Borough President, said yesterday.

The controversy over naming the bridge to be built across The Narrows continued yesterday with the resignation of Dr. Natale Colosi as chairman of the public health committee of the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Two Kansas City employes of E. F. Hutton Company, New York and Kansas City brokerage concern, have been accused of manipulating prices of March and May, 1959, wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade, the Department of Agriculture announced today.
HAVANA, Aug. 5 -- Premier Fidel Castro is having considerable success with his "government by radio and television." He is reaching 95 percent of the people in his lengthy broadcasts.
PARIS, Aug. 5 -- The possibility of a Paris meeting of the fifteen heads of government of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization late this month was virtually ended today.
Three students in different rural schools in the Catskills who want to study Russian will be able to do so this fall under an experimental program aided by the Ford Foundation.

Reflecting sharply increased revenues, consolidated net earnings of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation in the first half this year rose 42 per cent to $5,332,000 from $3,760,000 cleared in the initial six months last year, the report of Robert E. Harvey, president, disclosed yesterday.
William Wugen is retiring after chauffeuring a succession of six heads of New York University for forty years.

New York City has borrowed $70,000,000 on 2 1/2 per cent tax anticipation notes due on Nov. 2 and Nov. 4, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday. The notes are subject to redemption at the option of the Controller five days before they are due. The obligations were sold by allotment to nineteen banks and trust companies, as follows:

MONROVIA, Liberia, Aug. 5 -- An Algerian Nationalist flag, four times as big as the flags of nine other delegations present, was hoisted today on the Liberian capitol, where African leaders have been meeting since yesterday.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 5 -- The integration of two previously all-white school districts is expected when classes resume late this month.
American Mail Line, Ltd., of Seattle, signed a $36,016,784 contract yesterday with Todd Shipyards Corporation, of San Pedro, Calif., for three new cargo-passenger ships.
Preliminary negotiations toward the possibility of a merger were disclosed yesterday by Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., and the Harbor Plywood Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon returned home today. He receive an enthusiastic "well done" from President Eisenhower and a roaring reception from crowds at the airport.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Ross Barnett of Jackson moved past Lieut. Gov. Carroll Gartin tonight in the Mississippi Democratic primary Governor's race.

Bobby Shantz, the smallest of all the Yankees, blanked the Detroit Tigers, 3 -- 0, in the cold drizzle at the Stadium yesterday. Before the little left-hander was able to claim the shutout, though, he had to wriggle out of a ninth-inning jam as the visitors loaded the bases after two out.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 5 -- With warm expressions of thanks to the United States and the University of California, the University of Indonesia graduated the largest number of medical students in its history.
Pacific Power Light Company is offering $10,996,000 of fifteen-year 4 3/4 per cent convertible debentures to its stockholders in the ratio of $100 of debentures for each forty common shares held.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 5 -- An eight-acre tidal pond was drained this afternoon because a housewife flicked her left hand and her engagement ring fell into the pond.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 5 -- A ninety-minute debate on Russian-American relations enlivened the closing sessions of the annual Governors Conference today.
A top official of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States accused the State Commission Against Discrimination yesterday of contravening the purpose for which it was created.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- San Francisco's sensational rookie, Willie McCovey, smashed two home runs today as the Giants regained first place in the National League with a 4-1 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

Two American women back from a month-long Soviet visit advise other touring Americans to go to Moscow with an open mind but to be a bit skeptical.
The premium price commanded in the public market by the Treasury's two new issues of 4 3/4 per cent notes rose yesterday to 5/8 of a point above 100, a new high.

CENTRAL air conditioning. inter-communication gadgets, built-in vacuum cleaning systems, ultramodern kitchen equipment and recessed lighting no longer are restricted to expensive, custom-built homes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Foy D. Kohler, a veteran Foreign Service career officer, has been given the job of "coordinator" for the trip of Nikita S. Khrushchev to the United States.

The Columbia Broadcasting System plans to develop a one-hour comedy television series starring Robert Dhery, author and star of "La Plume de ma Tante," the French revue now playing at the Royale Theatre.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Irish Jay of the Wheatley Stable and Make Sail of Capt. Harry Guggenheim's Cain Hoy Stable were the stars of the show at the Saratoga track today. Each of these 2-year-old fillies won a division of the Schuylerville Stakes and each showed fine potentiality in scoring.

Two new films open at first-run theatres today. "North by Northwest," an Alfred Hitchcock melodrama starring Cary Grant and Eva Marie Saint, arrives at the Music Hall. Mr. Hitchcock directed and produced the film for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, release.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- the directors of Harrods, Ltd., big department store concern, have ended a struggle for their company by accepting the bid of the Debenhams Stores Group. Debenhams and two other concerns had been bidding for Harrods since June.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 5 -- A proposal to desegregate a seventh white public school this fall has been blocked temporarily by Virginia's State Pupil Placement Board.
Senator Clinton P. Anderson, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, predicted last night that the United States would resume testing atomic weapons after Oct. 31.

The Brooklyn Cancer Committee announced yesterday that appointments for examinations this fall in cancer prevention-detection clinics in seven borough hospitals were now being made on a first-come, first-served basis.

THE gray-haired matron in Abraham Straus' College Shop was not buying for her daughter. Nor was the 13-year-old who was sizing up Bermuda shorts looking ahead to college life. Last month's rainy spell has had a diverse effect on the resort scene. In the metropolitan area business generally has been below par, but the New Jersey shore spots report that theirs has been booming.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 5 -- Every time James Caleb Boggs runs for office his popularity is affirmed. As a Republican, he has been elected and re-elected in a state that is steadily growing more Democratic. It is more than possible that he was elected chairman of the Governors Conference in Puerto Rico today not because he was the most eminent man there, but because everybody likes him.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 6 -- When Frederick E. (Ted) Hood of Marblehead, basically a sailmaker, designed and then built in his own small yard a 40 foot shoal-draft sloop he named Robin, he may not have thought he was creating the queen of the New York Yacht Club's distinguished racing cruise.

HAVANA, Aug. 6 -- A United States consular official visited Rafael del Pino, a United States citizen, this afternoon in police headquarters here, where he is being held on charges of counter-revolutionary activities. Under recent Cuban laws the charges are punishable by death.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 6 -- West Germany's continuing coal crisis brought a threat yesterday of protest demonstrations in Bonn unless the Government took measures immediately to alleviate the situation in the Ruhr.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Allen M. Dorfman, a young Chicago broker who wrote insurance for the welfare funds of the brotherhoods of teamsters and electrical workers, kept for his own use $51,461 that belonged to a New York insurance company, Illinois officials charged today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Eisenhower signed the Tennessee Valley Authority bond-financing bill today, but only after having received extraordinary assurances that Congress would delete a provision he had opposed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson warned today that this country might soon lose its fishing fleet unless steps were taken to match giant new Soviet trawlers.

The arrival of "Saturday Night" at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre, where the musical was scheduled to open Jan. 21, has been canceled. The investment is to be returned to the backers over the week-end.
Yul Brynner has been signed to star in "A Gift From the Boys," a film version of the novel by Art Buchwald about an American gangster deported to Italy.
Mayor Wagner yesterday assigned his legal aide, Jacob Lutsky, to act as his personal watchdog at all future meetings of the Committee on Slum Clearance.

IN a spate of tournaments such as the one that has just ended, with a succession of near-by and local tournaments leading up to the long national championships in Chicago, a bridge writer may seem to forget that regular rubber bridge exists.
With the question of discrimination so much before us today, I should like to direct some attention to discrimination in health as it affects the Negro in New York City.
The Post Office announced yesterday that it was all right to mail germs to fifty-three overseas destinations as long as they were put into proper containers and carried official violet labels.

Fischer-Landis, realty operators, have contracted to buy the ten-story showroom building at 31 West Thirty-first Street. The structure, on a plot 33 by 100 feet, is east of Broadway. It was sold by the estate of Philip Smith in a deal negotiated by the Cross Brown Company, broker.

Last week's explosion and total loss of a small pleasure boat near Sandy Hook, causing the hospitalization of the boat's party of four emphasizes anew the potential danger of gasoline fumes. It has been estimated that 800 pleasure boats will be lost this summer in explosions and fires.
A two-week training tour for 643 members of the 106th Aeromedical Transport Group of the New York Air National Guard will begin tomorrow at Hancock Field, Syracuse.
The nation-wide steel strike, the sixth of its kind since World War II, entered its fourth week on Wednesday with no evidence of an early end to the deadlock.
The Fire Department ordered a Brooklyn tenement house evacuated yesterday and announced that it had closed six basement and store - front churches because of fire hazards so far this summer.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 6 -- Governor Rockefeller suggested today a prescription for a Republican victory next year. He flew to New York with Mrs. Rockefeller after having been in Puerto Rico since last Saturday for the fifty-first annual Governors Conference, which ended yesterday.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 6 -- Every year the Berkshire Music Festival stages "Tanglewood on Parade," a side show for the benefit of its scholastic wing, the Berkshire Music Center. This year's parade was held in a drizzle.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 6 -- A parade of old carriages and automobiles here will be a feature of a program Wednesday for the benefit of the Ladies Village Improvement Society.

LONDON, Aug. 6 (Reuters) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has sent President Eisenhower a message stressing the special importance of an improvement in Soviet-United States relations, Tass, the official Soviet press service, reported today.

ALTAMONT, Tenn., Aug. 6 -- The Negro educational director and three white teachers at the Highlander Folk School contended in court here today that their arrest last Friday was part of a campaign of harassment by the police.

GENEVA, Aug. 6 -- The exodus of the foreign ministers who attended the East-West conference here was completed tonight with the departure of East Germany's Dr. Lothar Bolz. He was the only one to leave by train.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower, in his nation-wide broadcast tonight, stressed these points as the chief legislative goals of a new labor-management relations law:

The reassignment of news department executives in London, New York and Chicago was announced yesterday by Frank H. Bartholomew, president of United Press International. He said the following shifts would be made next month:

Brisk purchasing by Cuban interests raised world sugar prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Rebounding after three days of losses, the market closed 1 to 5 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) higher on 27,950 tons.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 6 -- Israel's third Knesset (Parliament) adjourned tonight to prepare for the general elections Nov. 3.
An agreement reached yesterday between two unions ended a bitter jurisdictional dispute over the crewmen of Great Lakes iron ore ships.
ALBANY, Aug. 6 -- Deer hunters everywhere in New York State will have more deer to hunt this year because of favorable conditions during the early spring deep-snow.

Increasing costs of American production are promoting the development of local food processing industries in foreign countries, Charles S. Bridges, president of Libby, McNeill Libby, said in the annual report to stockholders, released today.
The Transit Authority has decided on a "do-it-itself" program for the new ads to be placed on the outside of the 2,091 city buses.
Concerted action to cut down the number of insolvencies and the resulting credit losses in the ready-to-wear apparel industry was taken yesterday on behalf of a group of manufacturers.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- A horse with an aristocratic name for the Corinthian sport of steeplechase racing took the sixtieth Beverwyck Steeplechase Handicap today. Fairfax, a 5-year-old gelding owned by Mrs. Ogden Phipps, scored over Mrs. Michael A. Walsh's Independence by more than two lengths.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 3 -- The loyalty of the Lebanese Jewish community was attacked recently in a stormy session of Parliament.

A Change in the Doughnut What was once America's most popular breakfast food -- the doughnut -- has become a symbol of change because of the inventiveness of the baker, the curiosity of the public and the intrusion of the interior decorator.

Defense issues continued to lose ground in yesterdays session of the New York Stock Exchange but the rest of the list showed little inclination to follow. The net loss for the day was small and made without an increase in turnover, which was interpreted bullishly.

The Jewish War Veterans of the United States called on Congress yesterday to enact a law that would empower the Attorney General to prosecute all bombings of public buildings and private homes "regardless of the state in which such bombings occur."

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 6 -- Tournament officials at the Eastern grass court championships found themselves keeping one eye on threatening skies and the other on their men's singles' seeded list at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

Connoisseurs of the pace and trot at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night will witness an event without hazarding a wager. Three Russian horses, comprising its grand champion troika team, will perform prior to the running of the first race.
Investors in homes to be constructed at Lakeside Village in northern Westchester County asked the Federal Court here yesterday to reorganize four development corporations.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Ross Barnett and Lieut. Gov. Carroll Gartin began planning today for their run-off contest for Governor. Meanwhile, the winner in the first Democratic primary was still in doubt.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 -- Thousands of Soviet citizens pored over American newspapers that were displayed for the first time today at the American National Exhibition in Moscow. For most of them it was their first view of the Western non-Communist press.
Higher metal prices were instrumental in lifting the earnings of American Metal Climax, Inc. in the three and six months ended on June 30 over the periods a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Boeing Airplane Company denied today any intention of influencing Congress and the public improperly on the merits of its Bomarc antiaircraft missile.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 6 -- The Connecticut Public Utilities Commission charged today that its regulations had been ignored when this town permitted a private road to be built three years ago over a high-pressure, natural-gas pipeline.

" IF parents only 'listened,' what a child doesn't say is often more meaningful than what he does." This is the opinion of Mrs. Dorothy K. Whyte, director of the editorial bureau of the Health and Welfare Division of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Tugboats tooted, airplanes rushed hither and thither, the East River rolled blackly on, and strains of Mozart filled the interstices. The occasion was last night's opening concert, the first of three this month (next Thursday and the week after), at Carl Schurz Park.

It is now the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. At least this was the contribution yesterday of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to the controversy over what to call the bridge to be built between Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, and Fort Wadsworth, S. I.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Farmers desiring a non-recourse Government price support loan in excess of $50,000 on 1960-crop wheat must reduce their total acreage of this crop 20 per cent below their Federal acreage allotment.

The Freeport Sulphur Company, completing plans to pump molten sulphur from 2,000 feet below the floor of the Gulf of Mexico early in 1960, is using a new development to keep the sulphur from "freezing." Without such protection the sulphur would "freeze" in the line in less than forty-eight hours even at a depth five feet below the mud bottom, according to Freeport's test engineers.
MOSCOW, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The newspaper Sovetskaya Kultura published today a list of what it said were objectionable books still displayed at the American exhibition.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 6 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that Communist China had violated the spirit of an agreement regulating trade and travel between India and Tibet.

Stanley Warner Corporation has agreed to relinquish its 79 per cent interest in Cinerama Productions Corporation in order to cancel the contract giving Cinerama Productions a share of the profits from five Cinerama movies.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points down to 5 points up yesterday. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.)
Some hoodlums leave calling cards at the scene of their crimes. John D. Thompson, an ex-convict, did much better, it was reported yesterday in Felony Court.

PARAMUS, N. J., Aug. 6 -- On April 11 Calvin A. Sommer of 794 Arbor Road, here, made a mistake that presumably anybody could make. Four months later the Midland Bank at Bergen Mall here and the Mosler Safe Company cleared up what became a $1,412 headache.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Stock market prices scored widespread fresh gains here today and the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary stocks rose 2 points to 244.2, a new peak for the second day in succession. The index has gained 7.2 points in the last three days.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 6 -- Ragnar A. Hummel, former chairman of the board and director of the Lone Star Cement Corporation, died here today. His age was 72. He was a resident of this city.

Additional evidence as to why the Yankees will, before too long, be listed as also-rans in the American League race was seen by 16,746 customers and 8,578 Yankee Juniors yesterday at the Stadium. Seldom have the Bombers looked more futile than they did while succumbing, 4 -- 0, to Paul Foytack and the Detroit Tigers.

Directors of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation yesterday proposed a three-for-one stock split. The board also increased the quarterly dividend to 55 cents a share from 50 cents for payment to common stockholders on Sept. 30.
UNTIL last April 9, Samuel Sloan Colt often found time to leave his desks to don gardener's gloves at his six acres in Westhampton Beach, L. I.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Britain's committee of "three wise men" appointed by the Government two years ago to review prices and productivity reported today that the economy could stand a cut in prices -- and perhaps even some raises in pay.

BUFFALO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Buffalo Hospital Council came into being today to administer a union contract with Our Lady of Victory Hospital in near-by Lackawanna. The institution is one of the few nonprofit hospitals in the state to sign contracts with unions.
Mass examinations of men and women for cancer in the Soviet Union have shown that about 1 per cent of those examined have previously undiscovered tumors, polyps or other pre-cancerous conditions.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks rose $38,000,000 to $9,746,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This brought the cumulative increase since July 1 to $43,000,000, and the decrease since Dec. 31, 1958 to $173,000,000.

ONE of the gayest and newsiest collections of college and career clothes in town is at Ohrbach's. The store's second floor is richly stocked with assorted goodies from six countries -- Austria, England, Israel, Italy, Sweden and Switzerland.

Northern Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for six and twelve months ended on June 30. Gas sales soared in the first half to 218,752,929,000 cubic feet from 211,096,751,000 a year before.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter returned today from the Geneva foreign ministers' conference and blamed the Soviet Union for the meeting's failure to achieve agreements.
The Treasury's new 4 3/4 per cent notes due in 1964 led most United States Government securities in a further price rise yesterday.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Aug. 6 -- Mrs. Pat Cici of the Lido Country Club won the Women's Cross County Golf Association match play championship at the Southward Ho Country Club today by defeating Patricia Tiernan, Wheatley Hills. 4 and 3, in a 36-hole match.

A water main at Seventy-eighth Street and Madison Avenue broke early today, taking off a manhole cover, gouging a hole twelve-foot square in the pavement and cutting off the water supply to hundreds of persons in the area.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Aug. 6 -- A scramble is on for industrial sites in Oak Ridge.
A grandmother who had confessed embezzling at a Brooklyn lamp manufacturing company to set up housekeeping for one of her daughters was sentenced yesterday to two and one-half years in prison.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- A former mental patient went on a shooting rampage today, killing two men and injuring five in a nursing home before being stopped by police bullets.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Archaeologists who have dug into the foundations of Nonsuch, the fifth and greatest palace built by Henry VIII, have discovered that the south walls were adorned with gold.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today legislation to prevent states from levying an income tax on a company that solicits business in the state but has no stock of goods there.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 6 -- Dr. Jonas Salk told officials today he saw no need to cancel the opening of high schools here because of a poliomyelitis outbreak. City and state health authorities also took this portion.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 6 -- Pope John XXIII visited future missionaries here tonight and wished them "ever stronger faith and courage."

Lumber production rose for the fourth consecutive time, last week, to 243,906,000 board feet from 237,894,000 board feet the week before, according to reports received by The New York Times from regional associations.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- Neale Fraser and Rodney Laver, both left-handed players, were named today to represent Australia in the singles against Italy's Nicola Pietrangeli and Orlando Sirola in the Davis Cup matches starting tomorrow.

A floor in 575 Lexington Avenue, at Fifty-first Street, has been leased by the Federation of Nigeria for occupancy by its United Nations delegation, consulate and trade and development bureau. The Cross Brown Company was the broker, while Cushman Wakefield, Inc., served as agent for the building.

Ed Wynn will wear a beard in his next television role. He has been assigned to star as Santa Claus in "Miracle on 34th Street," which will be presented on Nov. 27 from 8:30 to 9:30 P. M. over the National Broadcasting Company network.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A skeletonized "draft movement" to get Governor Rockefeller the Republican Presidential nomination was outlined at the Capitol today.
Everything was just as it should be after a honeymoon when Walter Urbanski and his bride walked into their very own apartment at 783 Seneca Avenue in Brooklyn last month.

MONTREAT, N. C., Aug. 6 -- Entertainment on a racially unsegregated basis for adults but segregated for young people was adopted as formal policy late last night for the Southern Presbyterian Church's summer assembly here.

BONN, West Germany, Aug. 6 -- United States commercial airlines are regarded as such serious competition in jet passenger service that a merger of some European airlines has become a necessity, Transport Minister Hans Christoph Seebohm said at a briefing today.
Expurgated copies of "Lady Chatterley's Lover" now on the stands will not have to be marked "not an unexpurgated edition."
