Because of the testing of nuclear weapons, the atmospheric concentration of radioactive carbon 14 has increased 15 per cent in the Northern Hemisphere during a three-year period.

Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, denied yesterday that his controversial "sense of Congress" resolution advising the Federal Reserve System on how to conduct its operations had inflationary implications.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Senator Thruston B. Morton, Republican of Kentucky, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today he was willing to meet with Mr. Morhouse "and his group" any time to discuss convention plans.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates scored ten runs in the ninth, the most in one inning by a National League club this season, as they routed the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, 18 -- 2, with a twenty-three hit barrage.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 6 -- The Government of Morocco showed extreme sensitivity today to a suggestion that it had reached even tacit agreement with the United States on the status of American air bases here.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 6 -- This port city on the Acushnet River is filled today with about equal measures of salt air and hospitality. It is awaiting the invasion of an expected 20,000 persons for the New Bedford Scallop Festival, which will be held tomorrow and Saturday.

EUGENE, Ore., Aug 6 -- Oregon will salute Virginia tomorrow night with the presentation of "Dawn's Early Light" at the University of Oregon here. Patrick Henry and Thomas Jefferson are the leading characters in the modern-dress play.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon has abandoned his plan to make a detailed report to the nation over television on his visits to the Soviet Union and Poland.
ALBANY, Aug. 6 -- The Consolidated Edison Company was ordered today by an Appellate Division justice to continue the conjunctional billing system in New York City.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Soybeans retreated today, and another fairly general setback occurred in grain futures prices on the Board of Trade, the third time this week.

LIVING and dressing with style is an objective that many women seek but only a few attain. Among those who reach this elusive goal are many who neither possess great wealth nor garner widespread publicity. But for all women, particularly at this moment, style is a subject that makes news.
Average borrowings by member banks rose $144,000,000 to $1,034,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 5 -- The regime of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner is doing what it can to dress up democratically for the American foreign ministers' conference this month in Santiago, Chile. However, it is unlikely that the disguise will spare Paraguay from being classed as a dictatorship.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris and Jaroslav Drobny of London led the way into the doubles semi-finals of the German tennis championships today. They defeated Pierre Darmon and Gerard Pilet of France, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 -- Between Coogan's Bluff and Morvey's Hill lies something like 3,000 miles as the jet flies. Yet the two do, or will, have something in common.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- In a challenge to Congress' new anti-secrecy law, the Eisenhower Administration denied today a request by House investigators for information on the foreign aid program.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 6 -- The leading members of the ruling Congress party took a frank look at their party today.

It is to be devoutly hoped that General Motors will follow through with its broad plan to underwrite a major study of the possible link between automobile exhaust fumes and lung cancer. The results might be a valuable contribution to a facet of cancer research where rumor, theory and mere conjecture too long have held sway and where definite knowledge has been sadly lacking.

The setting of strike deadlines for most of the country's major copper, lead and zinc producers increased yesterday the danger that the steel shutdown would spread to other essential industrial metals.

I have read with interest your July 27 article entitled "Democrats Vying at Doorbell Politics." As president of the Board of Elections and having had over fifty years of practical politics, I deem it imperative to call your attention to the misinformation it contained.

The El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday sizable gains in operating revenues for the three and six months ended on June 30. Net income for both periods fell behind that of the 1958 periods.
Following are the texts of addresses on labor reform legislation broadcast last night by President Eisenhower and George Meany, A. F. L.-C. I. O. president, as recorded by The New York Times.

Increased consumption by the public, plus new and improved products swelled sales and earnings of the National Dairy Products Corporation in the first half this year to the highest mark in the history of the nation's largest dairy producer.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 6 -- No clashes were reported in northern Laos today between Government and Communist forces.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Congressional leaders were quick to react tonight to President Eisenhower's radio-television address on labor reform legislation.
ULAN BATOR, Outer Mongolia. For twenty miles along the valley of the Tarany River in Outer Mongolia, a two - mile swath has been slashed by tractor-driven gangplows across the virgin grassland.

A changing psychology of the American people is analyzed by Richard La Piere in "The Freudian Ethic: An Analysis of the Subversion of American Character." Duell, Sloan Pearce will publish it Aug. 21. The author contends that the idea of self-reliance and enterprise has been replaced in the last few decades by the belief that man cannot and should not be provident and venturesome, but should be supported, protected and socially maintained.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 -- The civic host committee for the 1960 Democratic national convention remained divided today about how admission tickets should be divided.

IN his foreword to "Lover Man,"* a collection of fifteen short stories by Alston Anderson, Robert Graves calls Mr. Anderson a born writer. Mr. Graves, who is equally distinguished as a poet, historical novelist, translator and student of the ancient world, does not scatter such tributes casually. Judging by these stories, one finds him justified in doing so.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- World educators urged today a revision of history textbooks to eliminate national prejudices and "blood and thunder" emphasis on war.
A new 13-inch low profile tire engineered specifically for the small cars that will be coming to market this fall has been developed by the United States Rubber Company.

Michael H. Prendergast declared yesterday that reports of efforts to curtail state expenditures next year formed part of a campaign by Governor Rockefeller to obtain the Republican Presidential nomination.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- A Government research scientist reported today that the death rate of heavy cigarette smokers was nearly twice as great as the rate for nonsmokers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Anti-Communist groups here announced today they would picket Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev if he visited Chicago. The police said they would permit such demonstrations.

Premier Khrushchev has pledged that while talking peace with President Eisenhower he will not heat up the Berlin crisis. Apparently no such pledge applies to the Far East, where Communist forces are attempting a new breakthrough in Laos which, the State Department implies, has been engineered in Moscow.
ATHENS, Aug. 6 -- The New York Philharmonic tonight scored another triumph in this ancient city. Thomas Schippers, 29-year-old American-born conductor, was on the podium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Secretary of Defense Neil H. McElroy expressed hope today that Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet Premier, would change his mind about refusing to see military installations in this country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon expressed hope today that Mrs. Eisenhower would accompany the President on his goodwill visit to the Soviet Union this fall.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Eisenhower appealed tonight for a reform law effective enough to drive corrupt elements from the labor-management field.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 6 -- Governors Rockefeller of New York and Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey participated today in the opening of a Caribbean Trade Development Office of the Port of New York Authority here.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Lawrence E. Gerosa, New York City's Controller, started an all-out campaign here today to convince upstate voters that the proposed $500,000,000 bond issue for school construction in New York was unnecessary.

The New York State Central School District composed of Newfane and Wilson yesterday sold $1,764,000 of serial bonds due from 1960 to 1980 to a syndicate headed by John Nuveen Co. The price paid was 100,195 for 3 3/4 per cent obligations, resulting in an interest cost of 3.737 per cent. Reoffering was made at yields of 2.5 to 3.85 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Willie McCovey knocked in the first run and Eddie Bressoud and Willie Mays hit homers today as the San Francisco Giants beat Lew Burdette and the Milwaukee Braves, 7 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Businesses accumulated 52,500,000,000 of inventories in the second quarter, the Department of Commerce reported today.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 6 -- A senior vice president of the Long Island Lighting Company was accused today of having stolen $14,700 to make a political payoff.
A union proposal that the present contract dispute be submitted to arbitration was rejected yesterday by negotiators for the shipbuilding division of the Bethlehem Steel Company.
Eighty feet below the surface of the Mediterranean, a team of four Americans will try to win the International Spearfishing Contest that begins off the island of Malta on Aug. 15.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 6 -- The Southern New England Telephone Company presented some of its subscribers today with the antidisestablishmentarianism of phone numbers. It's 1122125551212.

Stockholders of the American Beverage Corporation, producer of Dr. Brown's Cel-Ray and other beverages in the New York area, will meet next Monday to vote on a proposed merger with the Golden Age group of soft drink bottling companies in Ohio and Texas, it was announced yesterday.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 6 -- President Romulo Betancourt sharply criticized Venezuela's Communists today. He called their opposition to the Government's suspension of certain constitutional guarantees unjustifiable and illegal.
TRENTON, Aug. 6 -- The last of 3,500 persons who began receiving old-age assistance at the beginning of the state program in July, 1932, died in March, the State Bureau of Assistance reported today.
AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 6 -- President Eisenhower's invitation to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to visit the United States drew implied support today in the Texas Legislature.

DETROIT, Aug. 6 -- Several hundred officials and staff members of the United Automobile Workers are being called on to make back income tax payments on expense allowances they did not list as income in previous years.

Louis M. Hacker, the foreman of the grand jury that looked into television quiz shows, urged yesterday that the jury's pressentment be made available to a House of Representatives investigating subcommittee.
A Douglas DC-8 jetliner landed at New York International Airport yesterday for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Paralytic poliomyelitis cases increased again last week. The total of 183 was a weekly high for 1959.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Britain protested to the Maldivian Government today against what she termed a recent invasion of a Maldivian atoll that had rebelled. Britain said the invasion had resulted "in serious loss of life."

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 7 -- Rachel Goodman, 16-year-old daughter of Benny Goodman, the clarinetist, made her concert debut here tonight playing the piano in a concert with her father at the Silvermine Guild Hall.
Two major films have been scheduled to open at first-run Broadway theatres this month.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Aug. 7 -- The longest run of the New York Yacht Club cruise brought more silverware to Henry D. Mercer's 12-meter, Weatherly, today than yachts usually acquire for a single effort.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Gen. Benjamin W. Chidlaw, retired, former head of the Continental Air Defense Command, belittled today the idea that retired military officers might influence the award of defense contracts.

The news that a reigning Queen of England is expecting a baby is not without precedent. But it has been rather a long time -- more than a century -- since word got around that Queen Victoria and Prince Albert were expecting their ninth child.
Support of the Landrum-Griffin labor-reform bill was urged yesterday by two prominent organizations.

An agreement was announced last night to halt the picketing of retail liquor stores in Harlem by members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People while charges of discrimination are investigated.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 7 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today that English should be used in India as an "associate official language" for an indefinite period.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 7 -- Brazil hopes to play the role of moderator in the debates of the American foreign ministers convening in Santiago, Chile, next Wednesday.
COLUMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 7 -- Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike and his former Food Minister, Don Philip R. Gunawardena, a Marxist, touched off an uproar in the Lower House of Parliament today.
A twenty-inch water main that burst under Madison Avenue at Seventy-eighth Street at 1:05 A. M. yesterday was replaced by a new pipe by 1:30 P.M.

Irving Kahn yesterday offered to open the accounting books to Ingemar Johansson or to any Johansson appointee wishing to inspect the financial records of the June title fight between the Swedish heavyweight and Floyd Patterson.

A representative of the Japanese Artistic Sword Preservation Association has arrived to track down forty-two Samurai swords, national treasures of Japan believed to have been brought home by service men after the war.

A leading Government securities dealer asserted yesterday that more and better information on the use of credit by outsiders should help prevent a recurrence of the sharp break in the Government securities market that occurred in June, last year.

School board members and administrators ending a conference yesterday at Teachers College unanimously urged the State Legislature to bring state aid for education into line with the higher level of present-day educational costs.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 7 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano said today that the West German Government welcomed the Eisenhower-Khrushchev talks as fitting in with its long-held view "that attempts should be made to keep the international discussion going."
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 7 -- Meadow Maid, Jean Laird and Philip Frost are the favorites in the three feature events tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway.

In the face of Premier Khrushchev's avowed aim on his visit to the United States to seek an end of the cold war, Secretary Herter confirms on his return from Geneva that the conference of foreign ministers could not translate Soviet words into deeds because the Soviets made successful negotiations impossible.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Delta Air Lines of Atlanta pressed its long-standing bid today for a southern route across the United States.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 7 -- Striking sugar workers in the city of Tucuman in northwestern Argentina attacked and injured the governor of Tucuman Province today. One striker was killed in a clash between the police and the rioting strikers.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The stock market ended the week strongly with a long list of rises despite profit taking. The Financial Times index of industrial ordinary stocks rose a further 1.5 points to 245.7, a new peak for the third successive day and a gain of 8.7 points for the week.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 7 -- Many of the 27,000 residents here commute from well-kept homes on tree-lined streets to New York, which is twenty-two minutes away as the bus rolls.
Seven union leaders from Tunisia yesterday visited the Manhattan Trades Center, at Rivington and Forsyth Streets, which is maintained by the Board of Education.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 1 -- The performance of Yugoslavia's economy is causing Belgrade vest buttons to pop with pride.

MALMOE, Sweden, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Ray Norton of San Jose State, the United States' top hope for the 100-meter dash in the Rome Olympics next summer, won his specialty in the good time of 10.2 seconds tonight in an international track meet.
GENEVA, Aug. 7 -- The Soviet Union charged again today that "ruling circles" in the United States were seeking to torpedo the three-power conference here on a ban on nuclear weapons tests.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Queen Elizabeth II is expecting her third child early next year. An official announcement issued this afternoon from Buckingham Palace stated: "The Queen will undertake no further public engagements."

ROSEBURG, Ore., Aug. 7 -A truck loaded with six tons of dynamite and explosive fertilizer blew up like a huge bomb near the heart of this city today, killing at least eleven persons and possibly twenty-five.

A ridiculous image of America is on the way out. Congress, the Treasury and the art community have finally joined in splendid and enlightened cooperation this year to rewrite the archaic customs law on the entry of art works.
Gaspar Ortega of Mexico scored a split decision over Benny (Kid) Paret of Cuba at Madison Square Garden last night in the ten-round welterweight feature.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -The three major television networks rejected today a request by Democratic leaders for equal time to reply to President Eisenhower's broadcast on labor reform legislation.

"N0 one, I suppose, ever read Yeats' 'Collected Poems' as a kind of versified autobiographical novel of the boy-loses-girl-and-continues-to-lose-her variety.'' John Unterecker remarks, "but Yeats makes it perfectly possible for anyone to do so."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- The Air Force successfully launched a weather balloon by rocket today for the first time. The balloon was released at a height of nearly fifty miles, more than twice the altitude reached by standard weather spheres.
The United Hospital of Port Chester, N. Y., will benefit from the forty-second annual Westchester Kennel Club Dog Show, to be held at the Blind Brook Polo Club in Purchase, N. Y., on Sept. 6.
Municipal bond issues are scheduled to form the bulk of the new debt securities to be offered to investors next week.
A short side trip off the much-traveled Cape Cod Highway at Wellfleet, Mass., will provide an experience equally rewarding for both the esthetic and spiritual senses.

Israel, striving to conserve foreign exchange, has overcome seemingly insurmountable obstacles to produce a wide variety of items that formerly were imported. Notable among these are heavy electrical equipment and tire cord.

No matter what part of one is in, there are always surprises in store for the alert shopper. Some New York shops specialize in decorative American accessories; others comb the world for interesting items.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Military Appeals upheld today the conviction of a former Marine Corps private, Peter H. Green of Evanston, Ill., who publicly criticized the corps for refusing to release him as a conscientious objector.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, British Guiana's Minister of Trade, accused Britain tonight of retarding his country's development.
TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 7 (AP) -- A Federal judge dismissed today a suit seeking integration of public schools in Hillsborough County.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Aug. 7 (UPI) -- The Manchester Union-Leader published tonight a poll indicating state legislators favored Vice President Nixon over Governor Rockefeller as the Republican Presidential candidate, 5 to 1.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have noted with interest your recent editorial strongly supporting home rule for the citizens of the District of Columbia.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 7 -- When Grant Overlook wheels his ice cream truck into Ward Street each night, neighborhood children come running with their dimes.

SUFFERN, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- The Rockland Community College, the eighteenth two year college authorized by the State University of New York, will open in September, according to an announcement by the Rockland County Board of Supervisors.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Title I slum clearance program must continue. A coordinated attack on New York's slum problems is a basic necessity.

FREEPORT, L. I., Aug. 7 -- A clergyman who is familiar with the slide rule and the drafting board as well as the Scriptures will officiate on Sunday at the ground-breaking for a new church building that he designed.

Better forest management can restore Eastern white pine to its former role of "king of woods," according to a study issued this week. The report was prepared by the Northeastern Forest Experiment Station of the United States Forest Service. It noted that in colonial days East ern white pine, found mostly in the Northeastern states, was considered one of the wonders of the New World.

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- General de Gaulle's decision to receive President Eisenhower after the latter's London visit instead of before it will permit the French President to carry out a planned trip to Algeria beginning Aug. 27.
LONDON, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- An American company filming a television series in Britain abandoned the project today because of union troubles.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 7 -- The physical collapse of Maria Bueno, the Wimbledon tennis queen, and the elimination of two more ranking players in men's singles provided the chief excitement at the Eastern grass court championships today.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 7 -- The final week-end of the Berkshire Music Festival is to be, in effect, a Beethoven festival. The first of the three concerts to be devoted to that master was given at Tanglewood tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Willie Mays singled in the winning run in the ninth inning tonight as the San Francisco Giants beat the Cincinnati Reds, 3 -- 2. Johnny Antonelii scored his sixteenth victory of the campaign, the first major leaguer to reach that figure.
ANOTHER national contest begins today -- the twenty-sixth annual tournament of the American Bridge Association, which was founded in 1933.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A California stockman was granted a patent this week for artificial cattle horns. He described them as a money-saver for the rodeo operator and as humane for the rodeo steer.

Dr. Ida Scudder, now 90, has been a medical missionary in India for more than fifty years. A biography of her has been written by Dorothy Clarke Wilson and will be published by McGraw-Hill on Oct. 22. It will be called "Doctor Ida.
STEELE, N. D., Aug. 7 (AP) A couple from Indiana, three Canadians and a visitor from Britain were killed today in the head-on collision of two cars near this town in Central North Dakota.
The bond market ended the trading week on a strong note yesterday, with the Treasury's new 4 3/4 per cent notes due in 1964 the leading performer.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On behalf of the Madison Project I should like to express my deep gratitude for Gene Currivan's excellent article published July 26 describing this work in school mathematics in central New York State.

The watchdog of the securities markets, the Securities and Exchange Commission, is brooding. The agency is unhappy, in particular, over a proposal in Congress to cut its staff. James C. Sargent, a commissioner, said yesterday that the fiscal curtailment would "nominally" save taxpayers $175,000 in this fiscal year, but cost investors millions by helping to bring about a breakdown in securities law enforcement.
BALLATER, Scotland, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth, looking happy and healthy, began her summer vacation in the Scottish highlands today.

Old-Timers' Day, introduced here in 1939 and now an annual Yankee Stadium feature, will be staged today. With some 33,000 tickets sold in advance, it is likely that upward of 50,000 persons will turn out.

NAIROBI, Kenya, British East Africa, Aug. 7 -- The Tanganyika Sisal Growers Association announced today that after thirty years of secret experiments it had produced a sisal hybrid plant that could revolutionize the world industry.
Chief Justice Earl Warren and the new Secretary of Commerce, Frederick H. Mueller, visited the Soviet Exhibition here yesterday.

The situation resulting from the emptying into Queens sewers from sources not so far discovered of illegal and damaging industrial wastes has become so bad that Public Works Commissioner Zurmuhlen has been forced to call upon several city departments and other agencies for help in cunning down the offenders. The illegal substances -- largely copper, chrome and nickel -- have made the $50,000,000 Bowery Bay pollution control plant almost inoperative.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A Senate panel opened hearings today on the problems of more than 800,000 migratory farm workers, whose pay and living conditions were called "appalling."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -The House Appropriations Committee, accusing the armed forces of "piecemeal and shortrange planning," today slashed 18 per cent from President Eisenhower's request for military construction funds.
Copper prices surged forward yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Final quotations were 22 to 82 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) higher on 491 lots.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 7 (UPI) -- The countdown reached zero minus eight minutes in today's firing of Explorer VI and everything appeared to be going smoothly.

SEABROOK, N. H., Aug. 7 (UPI) -- The parents of scholarly Emery N. Eaton Jr. learned today that their son apparently had gone to Europe with $19,000 in receipts from the state liquor store managed by his father.
Stocks closed a confused week yesterday with losses in New York Stock Exchange market values of almost $3,500,000,000 on the week and $1,800,000,000 on the day.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Aug. 7 (AP) -- For the honor of his ship, Peter McNulty, a steward, went climbing 1,500 feet up a Norwegian mountain.
BOGOTA, N. J., Aug. 7 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and postal authorities joined the police here today to hunt the person who threatened a local tavern owner.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7--An independent study has called United States aid a "major stimulant" to Vietnam's development.
Builders here are attacking a new interpretation of rules on the installation of incinerators in apartment houses.

Plans for consolidating the billion-dollar operations of Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., in the United States and Canada into a single operating unit, the Mobil Oil Company, were announced yesterday. The Mobil Oil Company will continue to function as an operating division of Socony Mobil.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Rye futures advanced but all other grains and soybeans were steady to weak in light dealings today on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The director of Space Flight Development for the National Astronautics and Space Administration told news men today that the path of the Explorer VI over the earth would appear erratic because of the extremely elongated nature of the orbit.

BEAUFORT, S. C., Aug. 7 (UPI) -- A veteran Marine Corps pilot who fell nine miles, seven of them before his parachute opened, after having been ejected from a stricken jet plane, is recovering from frostbite and other injuries.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Robert Moses, State Power Authority Chairman, issued an informal invitation today to Nikita S. Khrushchev to tour the $720,000,000 Niagara power project. Mr. Moses said the Soviet Premier "might be envious" of what he would see.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- More than 100,000 striking printers went back to their jobs in Britain this week. But they returned too late for many newspapers to publish their normal-size week-end editions.
The Soviet representatives on the committee that organized the International Geophysical Year urged yesterday that the I. G. Y. be taken as a model for continuous cooperation in various fields.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower asked the Senate today to approve an additional star for four Army major generals, including Surgeon General Leonard D. Heaton, who operated on him.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon will be seen on two half- hour television programs tomorrow between 7 and 8 P. M. with filmed highlights of his recent trip through the Soviet Union and Poland. Mr. Nixon will serve as narrator and will give his reactions to the visit.
Half-year earnings of the American Smelting and Refining Company's (Asarco) were depressed by the low level of lead and zinc prices, the midyear report disclosed yesterday.

The new electronic surveillance system, disclosed yesterday, is only one, although probably the most promising, of several United States methods to detect missiles and atomic bombs. Some of the systems are in operation; others are in the planning stage.

ATHENS, Aug. 7 -- The world's emotional balance has improved immensely as a result of this week's startling announcements. However, it is too soon to prejudge their eventual effect upon the world's political balance. Outbursts of goodwill are not in themselves sufficient to end the cold war. The reasons for rivalry remain unchanged.
ALGIERS, Aug. 7 -- Premier Michel Debre was winding up a brief visit to Algeria tonight.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Shirley Jones of the Brae Burn Farm made a thrilling finish to take the $30,900 Test Stakes today. Considered one of the weak sisters among the fifteen 3-year-old fillies in the seven-furlong sprint, Shirley Jones showed strength indeed as she scored by a half-length over the Circle M. Farm's Mommy Dear.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 6 -- Because the foreign ministers' conference at Geneva adjourned without settling the Berlin crisis, some news correspondents call the meeting a failure. I disagree.

Prime Minister Nehru has gone before the Indian Parliament with a strong condemnation of some phases of Red Chinese activity in Tibet. By inference he charges, also, that Peiping has ignored the famous "five principles" embodied in this treaty, the first of which is "non-interference."
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- As was the case in their meeting here in 1955, Australia won the opening two singles matches from Italy today in their Davis Cup interzone tie at the Germantown Cricket Club.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Jimmy Caspers, a 37-year-old plumber from Racine, Wis., took the lead in the men's division of the world archery championships today. He equaled the world record from fifty meters with 290 points and scored 318 points from thirty meters for aggregate score of 1,100 points.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 --Dr. William John Thaler has been described (by someone very close to him) as the sort of fellow who does not care much about what other people think, so long as he is convinced he is right.

ALBANY, Aug. 7 -- The Consolidated Edison Company today withdrew its month-old application before the Public Service Commission for an increase of 1 per cent in its natural gas rates in New York City.
HONOLULU, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The lush little Hawaiian island of Kauai lay torn and battered today in the wake of Hurricane Dot.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 7 -- Protests by Main Street merchants because the state tore up 200 feet of the street for repairs without notice have brought a promise that in the future the town will be notified when a street is to undergo repairs.

No longer the all-conquering Athletics who only a week ago were rolling along on an eleven-game winning streak, the Kansas City club dropped into the Stadium last night and forthwith dropped a 3 -- 0 decision to the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Soviet missile and satellite firings have been monitored for months from locations within the continental boundaries of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower, after a delay of more than two months, approved today the addition of Tokyo to a British Overseas Airways Corporation route to the United States.
ROME, Aug. 7 -- The coming Eisenhower-Khrushchev meetings and Italy's desire to be consulted before any important step in the development of East-West relations were discussed officially here today.

OTTAWA, Aug. 7 (Canadian Press) -- The appointment of Alexander Watson, retiring head of the Transport Department's 250-vessel fleet, as chairman of the Canadian Maritime Commission was announced today.

THOSE interested in Early American furniture for their home can read with profit Ethel Hall Bjerkoe's new book, "How to Decorate For and With Antiques." For one thing, they can find out what the term "Early American" really means.

WHEN the temperature and humidity are high, refrigerator-freezer units are opened frequently to remove ice cubes, cold drinks and snacks. ARUSHA, Tanganyika -- Half an hour from Mount Kilimanjaro by air, this safari base is proud of the fact that it is midway between Cairo and Cape Town, and that it is the geographical center of British East Africa. For a traveler who has spent six months between Kilimanjaro and Cape Town's Table Mountain, Arusha is thus a natural place to take stock.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 8 -- In Laos communism is an illicit import from Vietnam. With the Communist half of Vietnam this little landlocked kingdom has 600 miles of mountainous, poorly guarded, badly marked frontier. Across the monsoon-drenched northern stretches of this frontier Communist Vietnam this week acted to spark a recrudescence of Communist insurrection in Laos.

NEGOTIATIONS are in progress for "Much Ado About Nothing," the Shakespearean comedy starring John Gielgud and Margaret Leighton, to be transferred to television after the play completes its Broadway run later this year.
In upper West Side slums, a Dominican revolutionary group is recruiting Americans of Puerto Rican descent as mercenary fighters against the dictatorship of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- Dr. Raymond B. Allen, former chancellor of the University of California at Los Angeles, is being considered for appointment as new head of the United States foreign aid mission to Indonesia, informed sources said today.

The advent of intercontinental ballistic missiles in the Soviet arsenal two years ago confronted American defense planners with a difficult problem. The ICBM was vastly more swift and free-ranging than any bomber, and it far exceeded the capacity of the warning systems devised for bombers. The problem was to find a detection system that would give more than a few minutes' warning of an incoming ICBM.

THE air charter policy of the Civil Aeronautics Board has been explored in articles published recently in this section. Last Sunday the subject was investigated pointedly by Representative Emanuel Celler, who, as chairman of the House Judiciary Committee and of its Antitrust Subcommittee, has long been a student and, sometimes, a critic, of C. A. B. policy and actions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Unlike the hemlines in Paris or the leaves on a New England hillside, the foreign policy of the United States does not change with the seasons. The china, glass and gift market at the Merchandise Mart ended the first week of a two-week showing with reports of excellent attendance and heavy demand. Sponsor of the market was the fifteenth Floor Merchandisers Club.

SARATOGA SPRINGS -- This month as always is the height of the season at Saratoga. The old Spa. which has been through many phases, both ups and down, seems to be accommodating itself to the current frenetic age with success.

KAWAIHAE, Hawaii, Aug. 3 -- A second port for the "big island" of the fiftieth state is nearing completion at this village at the base of Mauna Kea and the Kohala Mountains.

ONE look at the tarnished, dented old bugle hanging in his friend's cellar convinces Peter Holcomb that he simply must have it. Pete's parents and neighbors suffer aplenty while he is mastering the art of bugling under the tutelage of his grandparents, but he soon shows promise enough to enroll at Camp Morning Star, where he hopes to become the official bugler.

The first Swiss Horticultural Exhibition, "G/59," now being staged in Zurich, features many landscaping ideas that can be adapted by American gardeners. Visitors can see the displays through Oct. 11. The accompanying pictures show how the Swiss imaginatively introduce water on the home property.

FIFTY-TWO plant scientists from foreign institutions will be among the 150 guests at dinner Wednesday night in the Lorillard Snuff Mill at the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park. The dinner highlights the Month International Conference on Plant Growth Regulation, scheduled Monday through Friday.

HEADED by Margaret Bourke-White, a list of ten outstanding American women photographers received citations at the Sixty-eighth Annual Exposition of Professional Photography held recently in Los Angeles. The others were Tana Holan, Philadelphia; Dorothea Lange, Berkeley, Calif.; and Bunny Yeager, Miami, Fla.

THE day of the spare tire may soon be over. Three leading manufacturers have developed a new tire that is in effect a tire within a tire, thus making the spare unnecessary and obsolete. But the manufacturers concede that further improvements are still needed, and while technical experts continue to work at this problem there is a further obstacle to eliminate -- how to overcome the psychological barrier involved.

Ten tanned and youthful canoeists completed a fifteenday trip down the Hudson River yesterday and received a reception that would have gladdened the heart of Henry Hudson 350 years ago.

Harry Horwitz, realty investor, who recently bought the blockfront on the east side of Tenth Avenue between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets, has added two abutting parcels to the property. He bought the house at 452 West Forty-eighth Street from the Jet Realty Company and the building at 465 West Forty-seventh Street from John Leone.

MONTGOMERY, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- George Constantine of Southbridge, Mass., won the national sports car feature race before a crowd of 10,000 here today. He averaged 76.9 miles an hour for fifty laps on the 1.85-mile airport course in an Aston Martin.

Statistical evidence of religious revival and increasing religious influence "simply does not jibe" with the personal experience of clergymen, the Rev. Dr. David W. Barry, executive director of the New York City Mission Society, said yesterday.

Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday urged the immediate enactment of legislation for a greater safeguarding of civil rights. He indicated that would be an effective move to heighten western prestige at the time of Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's visit to the United States.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 9 -French and United States specialists will begin a new joint training program for the Laotian Army this month. The American role in the program will be to give instruction on the use and maintenance of weapons and other equipment.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- Les Halles, Paris' famous central wholesale market and rendezvous for tourists with a yen for early morning onion soup, now appears certain to disappear from the site it has occupied for more than 800 years on the Right Bank.

The effects of the post-war "baby boom" are already being felt in our schools. Many classrooms throughout the country are overcrowded. Many suffer from lack of adequate teaching personnel. PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9 -- The steel strike was building up future troubles for steel users and steel makers last week. While there were no concrete signs of serious shortages, there was additional evidence that steel warehouses would continue to do a "land office" business.

Wednesday will be Goodwill Industries Day at the Palisades Amusement Park. Admission to the park and several rides will be free to those members of the public who bring old clothes to be donated to Goodwill.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- Global production of cheese in 1958 set a record of 2,912,000 metric tons and was 70 per cent higher than in the years prior to the second World War, the Food and Agriculture Organization said today. Yet consumption kept pace with output.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Bishop Kyprianos of Kyrenia was shouted down today when he spoke from the pulpit criticizing the recent agreement to give independence to Cyprus.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9 -- The Soviet Union's leading chemist urged a reorganization of the nation's scientific work today. He proposed that the heads of institutes be given much broader powers over the financing of research and top priority on orders for new equipment.

William B. Gorman has announced his resignation as general manager of Gimbels, New York department store, and as assistant secretary of Gimbel Brothers, the parent corporation, effective Aug. 31.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Braves edged the Los Angeles Dodgers, 8 -- 7, today and dropped the secondplace Dodgers a game and a half behind the league-leading San Francisco Giants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -The United States' paddlewheel satellite, Explorer VI, had traveled more than 455,000 miles in its long elliptical orbit around the earth today. It was launched at 10:23 A. M. Thursday at Cape Canaveral, Fla.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 9 -The twenty-second Berkshire Festival ended at Tanglewood this afternoon. For the fourth successive summer, Charles Munch closed the festival with Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. Thus many listeners streamed away from the grounds with the "Ode to Joy" still humming in their heads.

Governor Rockefeller named thirteen men yesterday to form the nucleus of the Limited Profit Housing Mortgage Corporation. The corporation's purpose is to help finance middle-income housing throughout the state to rent for about $25 a room a month.
W. Averell Harriman suggested yesterday that President Eisenhower be blunt in his talks with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 9 -- A billboard sign that was erected here by the Danbury Chamber of Commerce in an effort to lure workers to Danbury has been removed as the result of a protest by the Bridgeport Chamber of Commerce.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug 9 -- "Faun in the Forest," a new one-act opera by the English composer Gerald Cockshott, had its world premier tonight at the White Barn Theatre here. It completed a bill of three one-act operas performed by the After Dinner Opera Company.

A second group of sculptures has been added to what has been called the greatest chance find of this century in Greece -the cache of ancient art treasures that was discovered on July 18 in a sewer repair excavation in Piraeus, the busy port of Athens.

Three floors in the new office building at 355 Lexington Avenue, corner of Fortieth Street, have been leased by the Sterling National Bank Trust Company from Samuel Rudin, the builder. The bank will move in December from its present quarters at 122 East Forty-second Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9 -The merger of San Francisco's two afternoon newspapers, The News and The Call-Bulletin, will eliminate approximately 400 jobs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Orlando Cepeda's tenthinning home run enabled the San Francisco Giants to beat the Cincinnati Reds, 4 -- 3, today. The victory lifted the Giants' National League lead to a game and a half.

BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 9 -Robert Wissmann's Harpoon, a converted lifeboat, captured the South Bay Cruising Club's thirtysix-mile overnight race from Babylon to Bellport and return. Harpoon led the fleet of twentyfive home in 10 hours 8 minutes. The victory earned the Foulke Trophy for Wissmann.
RIVERTON, Wyo., Aug. 9 (AP) -- The directors of the Susquehanna Corporation voted yesterday to split the common stock two for one.

The state has started a program to help the city evaluate more acurately the trends in its economy.

HERBERT CLARK HOOVER reaches his eightyfifth birthday today, alert to the problems of the world, the standing of the baseball clubs and intent upon substituting work for pills. He has made one concession to his advancing years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A new Administration plea in behalf of its school construction bill is expected this week.

THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo opened last night a week's engagement in Central Park in the new open-air Theatre-in-the-Park before a sizable audience and a demonstratively loyal one.

Members of the New York Mechantile Exchange, which conducts trading in Maine potato, platinum, butter and egg futures and spot butter and eggs, voted into effect yesterday a new charter and by-laws permitting it to organize trading in securities. RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 10 -- The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors approved two proposed highway projects today and appealed for aid on three others that have been blocked by depletion of Federal highway funds.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 10 -- The New York Philharmonic left here for Turkey today after a warm but unexcited reception from Lebanese audiences in two outdoor concerts at the Baalbek Festival.

The Union Electric Company, St. Louis, notified stockholders over the week-end of plans to offer to them rights to purchase 1,036,602 shares of common stock in the ratio of one new share for each ten shares held on Sept. 10. The price will be fixed by the board just before the offer is made.

The General Electric Company's large steam turbine generator department at Schenectady, N. Y., has on hand contracts for more than 2,000,000 kilowatts of heavy generating equipment, it was revealed yesterday.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Two letters rode 5,000 miles in a Thor-Able nose cone that was recovered from the Atlantic last May, the Air Force disclosed today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 -- City Attorney Roger Arnebergh advised the city today to delay a $2,000,000 grading and street preparation job for the Dodgers' new baseball stadium.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The State Superior Court upheld today the convictions of two former Commissioners of the Pennsylvania Turnpike and two other men for a conspiracy to defraud the commission of $19,500,000.
UKIAH, Calif., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Brush and forest fires, some of them believed set, broke out today along the heavily traveled Redwood highway U. S. 101.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved legislation today to provide liberalized pensions for veterans of World War II and the Korean conflict whose disabilities were not connected with their service.
MOSCOW, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's Olympic-style athletic competitions, called the Spartakiad, progressed through the third day today with no records reported imperiled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Eisenhower flew back to the White House from Gettysburg, Pa., today after having opened a temporary office in the Gettysburg Hotel. He plans to return to Gettysburg tomorrow and stay there until shortly before his departure for Europe Aug. 26.

Admiral Karl Doenitz, the man responsible for rebuilding German submarine strength and conducting the U-boat campaign during World War II, has written his autobiography that will be published by World on Sept. 28. LONDON, Aug. 10 -- An official of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development said today that India and Pakistan had largely resolved their old dispute over the water of the Indus River and would sign a treaty by the middle of next year.

TOKYO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Pascual Perez of Argentina retained his world flyweight championship tonight with a unanimous fifteen-round decision over Japan's Kenji Yonekura, but his performance was not impressive.
BOSTON, Aug. 10 -- The Yankees, two outs away from being shut out, tied the score with four runs in the ninth inning and then beat the Red Sox in the tenth, 7 -- 4, tonight.

Schwarz opened last Wednesday, the rain was coming down in wind-driven sheets, but the customers were pouring in, too.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Directors of National Homes Corporation, the nation's largest prefabricated house builder, today approved acquisition of seven other home manufacturing companies by purchase or merger.
A Pan American World Airways jet returned to New York International Airport tonight after a woman passenger was stricken with a heart attack and died.
Sharp price declines were registered yesterday in wool trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. Final prices for wool tops were down 1.4 to 2.9 cents a pound. Futures were off 2.3 to 2.8 cents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A Negro American language specialist will leave tomorrow for the Republic of Guinea to help the former French West African territory break the language barrier that has isolated it from its English-speaking neighbors.

The Rev. Kenneth Naudin, a member of the Roman Catholic Congregation of the Passion (Passionist Fathers), was drowned Sunday at Oakwood Beach, S. I. The body of the 56-year-old priest was found floating in the water shortly before 8 P. M.
LAGRANGE, Ga., Aug. 10 (UPI) -- With a Negro on the jury selected today, the trial of three Negroes accused of raping two young white women here ten days ago got under way.

KANSAS CITY, Aug 10 (AP) -- Rocky Colavito broke out of a long batting slump and paced the Cleveland Indians to a 6-4 victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight. He clouted a double, two singles and his thirty-third homer in five times at bat.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it would try to extract nuclear power from thorium, a metal element three times more abundant in nature than uranium.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 10 -- Peter Lebhar of Yonkers, seeded first, and John Reese of Hewlett, L. I., seeded second, led the favorites into the third round of the boys 15 years division of the metropolitan junior and boys tennis championships today at the Cherry Valley Club.
The cards would seem to be stacked against the steel workers.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 10 -- The Suffolk County special grand jury charged today that county-owned land on the proposed route of the Sunrise Highway extension had been sold illegally to a real estate speculator.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The House Ways and Means Committee rejected today a new proposal to increase the Federal gasoline tax in an effort to meet the financial crisis facing the interstate highway program.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 10 -- Two Government ministers publicly differed today over the purchase of foreign aircraft for military and civilian purposes.

ANCIENT tides have left indelible marks on the stone walls of Senator Barry M. Goldwater's new home in Phoenix. A childhood reverie has become a reality for the Senator, whose desert dream house is made of the red sandstone he found forty years ago on a Navajo reservation 240 miles north of Phoenix.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 10 -- The prosecution delivered a 15,000-word opening statement today outlining its case against thirty persons persons charged with high treason. The defendants pleaded not guilty last week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- House investigators announced plans today to give Bernard Goldfine, Boston industrialist, another chance to answer questions he refused to answer last year.
A group of school officials from Southern states reported here yesterday that racial integration below the college level could not yet be contemplated in many parts of the South.
The Maritime Administration announced yesterday its approval of loan and mortgage insurance for three large tankers to be built by the Aristotle S. Onassis shipping group for American-flag operation.

The Queen Elizabeth was picked up on the radarscope of the American Hunter for ten minutes prior to the July 19 collision of the vessels in fog in Ambrose Channel, officers of the freighter testified yesterday.

FORT COLLINS, Colo., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Business men and Americans in general should guard against an excess of optimism as a result of the present economic prosperity, the president of the United States Savings and Loan League said today.
Continued demand yesterday raised the price of the Treasury's new 4 3/4 per cent notes due in May, 1964, to a point where the investment yield to buyers was only slightly more than 4 1/2 per cent.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The official death toll from the floods on this Nationalist Chinese island rose today to 619. The missing were said to total 459.

THE great game of politics is played in Allen Drury's "Advise and Consent" for the ultimate stakes of life and death. This is the best novel about Washington I have ever read. It is set in the future. But every page crackles or murmurs with overtones and undertones of events in our own time.

The United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday announced the twelve men who will represent the United States against Canada in the Gordon Trophy matches for the international team championship for senior players at Quebec's Seigniory Club, Friday and Saturday.
Four Negroes, one of them a woman, were arraigned in Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday on charges of inciting a riot in the Bronx Sunday, when two white detectives were kicked and punched by a mob.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 10 -- The Suffolk police continued their search today for a car they hoped could help solve three recent hold-up murders.

TOKYO, Aug. 10 -- North Vietnam warned today that it would regard intervention by a foreign army in neighboring Laos as an act directly threatening North Vietnam's security. "In such a dangerous situation, the Vietnam Democratic Republic Government will not stand idly by," the Peiping radio said in a broadcast quoting Ta Quang Bun, Deputy Defense Minister.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana readily endorsed today suggestions that Queen Elizabeth II give her expected baby a real Commonwealth name -- a Ghanaian name, to be exact.

Fifty-six judges and leading lawyers, seeking ways to speed up American judicial procedures, began a five-day study of English pre-trial practices yesterday. Their instructors are eight prominent British jurists and court officials.
The city was asked yesterday to transfer the four-block area of the Bellevue South project from its Title I program to the new neighborhood rehabilitation program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, accused the Senate rackets committee today of "star chamber proceedings" in an impending hearing involving his union.

EDISON, N. J., Aug. 10 -- Tom and Jim Swales are not trying to accommodate all of New Jersey's bowlers at one time. However, they are quickly approaching a condition where this might some day be possible.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 10 -- The United States plans to let the "moderate" Governments of Latin America take the initiative in proposals at the conference here.
Tenants of Greenwich Village's old brownstones, tenements, apartments and studio dwellings were asked yesterday what they would like in the rehabilitation of their buildings.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 -- William L. Clay, a Negro Alderman here, and two companions were arrested yesterday when they refused to leave a Howard Johnson restaurant after they had been denied service. They were charged with disturbing the peace.

The Columbia Broadcasting System ended its search for a television program chief on its own doorstep yesterday. It promoted Oscar Katz, head of daytime programs, to be vice president of network programs.
SKOVDE, Sweden, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- Ray Norton and Jim Graham scored victories for the United States tonight during an international track and field meet.
DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP) -- About all that is left of the 1959 model car year is the final production spurt of Ford and Chevrolet.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board criticized today the A. F. L.-C. I. O.'s no-raiding agreement as restricting an employe's choice among labor unions.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 10 -- The Louisiana Legislature, summoned to a special session by Gov. Earl K. Long, rebelled tonight and voted to go home. Both houses voted to adjourn within an hour after they had assembled, thus depriving the Governor of a chance to address a joint session before a state-wide radio and television audience.

AMITYVILLE, L. I., Aug. 10 -- The Fenner Trophy, emblematic of the men's sailing championship of the Great South Bay, may return to the family if the crew representing the Westhampton Yacht Squadron can continue its performance in the six-race series.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Yola Ramirez and Rosa Maria Reyes of Mexico won the women's doubles title at the German international tennis championships today. Their opponents Germany's Edda Buding and Mme. Suzi Kormoczy, a Hungarian exile, withdrew in the second set of the final.
SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 10 -- This festival city is enjoying one of its greatest seasons since the war.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 10 -- Alfred T. Taylor's Miss Orestes, whose only victory of the season had come in the Molly Pitcher Handicap, today again whipped top talent when she accounted for the $22,800 Margate Handicap at Atlantic City.

WASHINGTON, Aug 10 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter left today for Santiago, Chile, with the expressed hope that a special inter-American conference of foreign ministers there would ease tensions in the Caribbean.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- A report released today by George D. Meade, president of the Glens Falls Insurance Company, on the operating results for the first six months of 1959 showed an increase in premium writings and investment income, and an unprofitable underwriting result.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 -- When a community, steaming in heat, turns out 57,989 strong at this time of season to see two high school football teams play, as happened here the other evening at the North-South Shrine game in the Coliseum, you could come close to having seen it all.
GAEVLE, Sweden, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Dan Waern bettered his own world record for 1,000 meters today when he ran that distance in 2 minutes 18 seconds.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Carin Cone, a slim 19-year-old blonde from Ridgewood, N. C., shaved another tenth of a second from her own American record in winning the women's 110-yard back-stroke in the Pan-American swim trials tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- The House approved today the last regular money bill of the session, a $1,285,002,700 appropriation for military construction. This was 18 per cent below President Eisenhower's request.

The answer to H. T. Osborne's query, "Who would invest in Cuba today?" is that Russia would, and, enthusiastically, on its hopeful way to win a new continent. This is the critical fact which makes our present attitude toward Castro a portent of future disaster.
WHITE pepper cannot equal the pungency of the freshly ground black version, but it should not be neglected altogether.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Fifty-five Americans of college age will leave London tomorrow for a brief visit in Belgium before going home from a summer of work that seemed more like play.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 10 -- The Newport invitation tennis tournament started today at the Casino with Davis Cup players from England, Italy and Mexico.

I learn with interest that most Thruway officials warn motorists traveling at a speed of sixty miles an hour to keep a distance of 265 feet behind the car in front, except when passing, since at sixty miles an hour a car travels 220 feet in two and a half seconds.

The Duke and Duchess of Manchester are honorary co-chairmen for the Summer Gala, a supper dance to be held at the Scotch Mist Inn in Southampton, L. I., on Aug. 21 for the benefit of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind.

MONTREAL, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- Truman Gibson, the president of the National Boxing Enterprises, announced tonight that Yvon Durelle would "definitely" sign for a return third match with Archie Moore, the light heavyweight champion, tomorrow at 10:30 A. M. and that Wednesday's title fight at the Forum would be staged as scheduled.

Reflecting the capacity operations at all plants and the greater automotive production, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company expanded its sales and earnings to record levels in the quarter and six months ended June 30.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Following is the text of the broadcast address of Sam Rayburn, Speaker of the House of Representatives, today on labor reform legislation:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn appealed tonight for public support of the Elliott labor reform bill as "the road of reason and fair play."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- John Hay Whitney, Ambassador to the Court of St. James, paid a visit to the race track today, and while he was about it, he made a trip to the winner's enclosure after the forty-seventh running of the Sanford Stakes.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

NEWARK, Aug. 10 -- A hearing on an application to the Public Utilities Commission by the Lackawanna Railroad to discontinue a number of trains on its Montclair and Morristown branches opened today before Examiner Walter T. McGrath.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Treasury announced today the marketing of two issues of Treasury bills. These securities, sold on a discount basis for cash or in exchange for maturing bills, went at interest costs little changed from last week's.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Civil rights advocates sought unsuccessfully at an ultra-secret "exploratory" session today for a way to end Southern delaying tactics in the Senate Judiciary Committee.
SAMNEUA, Laos, Aug. 10 (Reuters) -- The Royal Laotian Army began a full-scale airlift into this mountainous northern province today to strengthen its forces against the Communists.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- Within a few weeks, the filming of "The Mountain Road" will end and a retired American general will leave Columbia studios to return to the work of writing, painting and testing recipes.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushehev has declared that the Soviet Union would "accept the most solemn obligation" not to be the first nation to resume tests of nuclear weapons.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Aug. 10 (Canadian Press) -- The ship Lacordillera passed through the Soo Locks today -- the 200th salt water vessel to make the upbound trip through American and Canadian locks.
GREENVILLE, Me., Aug. 10 -- This is a hazy, cloudy, lowery day, a good day for being shown what a big, landowning paper company is doing for the hunting and fishing public around Moosehead Lake.

WARSAW, Aug. 10 -- Poland's peasants have just about finished taking in the harvest, but all summer long they have been working without that special thing every farmer needs -- just a little bit of luck.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Futures prices for the feed grains were stalled almost on dead center in meager dealings today on the Board of Trade while bread grains and soybeans worked to the higher side of preceding closes.
Judge William B. Herlands declared in Federal Court here yesterday that the courts were not equipped to handle the cases of persons who committed crimes under the stress of narcotics addiction.

LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A lumbering old London double-decker bus trundled off today on a 4,000-mile trip to Moscow and back. The big red bus, decorated with typical posters advertising Scotch whisky, carried forty Oxford University students.
The stock market experienced its sharpest decline yesterday since last November. Losses ranged from $1 to more than $8 a share. The "paper loss" came to about $6,800,000,000.

Reuss argues that the "sense of Congress" amendment to the interest-ceiling bill, for which he claims credit, is "a sincere attempt by the Congress to give some needed guidance to the Federal Reserve, the agency to which Congress had delegated some of its monetary powers."

A 14-year-old boy who had been reprimanded by his father disappeared yesterday near the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn, setting off a search by a police helicopter, an emergency squad and three patrol cars.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Gactano (Thomas) Morgano, reputed Indiana boss of the Chicago crime syndicate, was ordered deported today to his native Sicily.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Commercial Credit Company reported consolidated net income for the first six months of this year at $13,572,170, the highest in its history.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that Westerners, on the average, are the biggest spenders in the nation's retail stores.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Stock-market prices went ahead here today, although the weakness of Wall Street and some American selling tended to offset demand.

The Walter Urbanskis are enjoying peaceful nights and days again -- with no jangling telephones and voices at the other end calling for the police. The couple has been given a new number for their apartment at 783 Seneca Street, Brooklyn.
Bridgeport, Conn., announced plans yesterday for borrowing $2,675,000 in the public bond market. The sale is to be held on Aug. 27.

It is encouraging to learn from a new report by the State Commission Against Discrimination that in the past year there has been a "dramatic change" for the better in the attitude of employers toward the hiring of older workers. Effective July 1, 1958, it became unlawful to discriminate in employment because of age. The new SCAD report is a summing-up of a year's operation of this section of the law.
Economical and permanent lighting systems have been developed for hotel ballroom functions, eliminating the need for the renting of extra costly lighting equipment.
PARIS, Aug. 10 -- A spate of rumors that a French test explosion of an atomic bomb was imminent in the Sahara was quashed today by responsible authorities here.

HOUSTON Tex., Aug. 10 (AP) -- If a Democrat goes to the White House in 1961, Texas Democrats and Republicans alike hope it will be Lyndon B. Johnson, the Senate majority leader, The Houston Post said today.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 10 -- A possibility that the Soviet Exhibition might be transferred to Mexico was seen here today.
An off-duty patrolman and another man were beaten on the head with a crowbar late Sunday night after they had tried to help a woman who had been dragged into a car by an unidentified man in Brooklyn.

Vincent J. Velella, the president of Rosensohn Enterprises, Inc., yesterday asked Ingemar Johansson to fly here immediately to complete negotiations for his return heavyweight title bout with Floyd Patterson.

Stimulated by increased nickel deliveries, a higher copper price and strike-induced demand, earnings of the International Nickel Company, Inc. (INCO) rose sharply in the quarter and six months ended on June 30 above the 1958 levels.

The increasingly international character of movie-making was underscored yesterday when United Artists held its first global promotional meeting. Joining publicity and advertising representatives from its domestic distribution organization were United Artists executives from a number of countries abroad.

WITH the prospect that the distaff side will constitute 80 per cent of the nation's total office force by next year, a panel of ten business women met last week to discuss office furnishings. The three-hour session, held in Philadelphia, was under the sponsorship of the Columbia-Hallowell division of the Standard Pressed Steel Company, a manufacturer of office furniture and steel shop equipment.
HAMDEN, Conn., Aug. 10 -- Joseph P. Crowley, 49-year-old former football star at Yale University, was found dead here today at his home at 345 Ridge Road.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 10 -- Gen. Mohammed Ayub Khan, President of Pakistan, said today that he was unhappy about what he called a small vocal minority in the United States Congress.
Wall Street always likes to find some logical reason outside Wall Street -- something non-technical -- to explain why the market acts as it does at a given time. Yes terday was no exception.
ALBANY, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Four appointments and three reappointments to state boards and commissions were announced today by Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson, acting for Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- The Government has announced that it has sold 1,315 acres of vacant land at Oak Ridge, Tenn., for $210,300, more than three times its appraised value.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 10 -- The community is starting to put sidewalks on thirty-two of the ninety miles of town-owned roadways. The goal is to insure the safety of children walking to school.

The proprietor of a Chinese restaurant in Hempstead, L. I., who has been charged with smuggling Chinese aliens into the country sued the Federal Government yesterday for a judgment on the status of his nationality.

The Soviet Exhibition of Science, Technology and Culture ended its forty-two day run at the Coliseum last night.
GOTEBORG, Sweden, Aug. 10 -- Ingemar Johansson said today that he would start "hard" training tomorrow for his second bout with Floyd Patterson.
ROME, Aug. 10 -- Pope John XXIII has told the Catholic Action movement to stay out of politics.

NICE, France, Aug. 10 -Last Friday -six days and three funeral services after the crash that killed him Aug. 1 -Jean Behra, the race driver, finally was buried here, his checkered helmet fastened to his coffin.
The International Longshoremen's Association made its formal demand yesterday for a new employment contract to meet the competition of time and labor-saving devices on the docks.

August is not much of a "special day" month. It has its own special days and weeks, to be sure. But special days and weeks hit a mild slump in August. It would seem fitting, then, to suggest that another special "day" would fit easily into August's comparatively slim program and that it be called "Let the Children Alone Day," or something of the sort.

First-half dollar premium volume for Allstate Insurance Company was 15 per cent greater than in the like period of 1958, Judson B. Branch, president, announced here yesterday. He spoke at the official opening of the company's one hundred and first New York State sales-service office at 666 Fifth Avenue.
No group of stocks escaped in yesterday's steep market decline. Industrials, rails, electronics and all other components lost heavily. But some individual issues were standout victims.

HAVANA, Aug. 10 -- Revolucion, official organ of Premier Fidel Castro's 26th of July revolutionary movement, confirmed today that a conspiracy against the Government had been broken up. The arrest of more than 1,000 former members of the armed forces of the overthrown Batista regime and wealthy landowners was reported.

The United Aircraft Corporation cut its quarterly dividend on the common stock to 50 cents a share from the 75 cents paid quarterly since Dec. 10, 1955. Reduced earnings caused by increasing costs of development projects and other demands on cash resources were given as reasons for the slash.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 (UP) -- Willie Kirkland's ninth-inning double capped a three-run rally tonight for a 3-2 victory by the National League-leading San Francisco Giants over the St. Louis Cardinals.

The appointment of the Rev. Charles Connors as director of development for the Roman Catholic Order of the Holy Ghost Fathers, with headquarters in Washington, has been announced. He is Professor of Canon Law at St. Mary's Seminary, Ferndale, Norwalk, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- John O. Maberry, president of the Hamilton Gas and Oil Company, said today that options were exercised to purchase 56,000 shares of the company's stock following the sale in 1957 and 1958 of 1,176,000 shares.
TRENTON, Aug. 11 -- The Hospital Service Plan of New Jersey applied today to the State Department of Banking and Insurance for permission to increase subscriber rates by an average of 18.1 per cent.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Ingemar Johansson said today he no longer was committed to a contract for a return bout with Floyd Patterson. Johansson earlier had declined an all-expense-paid offer to go to New York to discuss a rematch.
The discovery of a new class of plant growth-promoting substances has been reported at the Fourth International Conference on Plant Growth Regulation being held in Yonkers.

Frank Erickson, the gambler known as "King of the Bookmakers," had at least two meetings with Bill Rosensohn months before the promoter staged the June heavyweight championship fight between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower's heavy international schedule this fall and winter has ruled out the annual White House social season.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 11 -- President Eisenhower arrived by helicopter at his country home today. The temporary White House offices took on an atmosphere of business as usual.
The Capitol Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-first Street, will undergo major renovations beginning in mid-November. The house will be redesigned along modern lines and reduced in its seating capacity.

MONTREAL, Aug. 11 -- A serious Archie Moore and a gabby Yvon Durelle are ready for their fifteen-round fight for Moore's light heavyweight championship of the world. They will meet at the Forum tomorrow night and the promoter, Eddie Quinn, says the crowd will reach the sell-out proportion of 15,000.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 11 -Gov. Earl K. Long suffered another humiliation tonight when he was hooted into silence by a crowd of teen-agers at a street corner rally.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -The House Ways and Means Committee tried and failed again today to break an impasse over financing construction of the 41,000-mile interstate highway system.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev has accepted an invitation to address the United Nations General Assembly when he visits the United States next month.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The body of a former assistant United States Attorney General remained unclaimed today in the morgue.
A Rockefeller study of the Republican power structure in states other than New York is under way.
Federal Judge William B. Herlands yesterday extended a stay barring the sale of the common stock of Belmont Oil Corporation.

Increased automotive financing operations, marked gains in industrial financing, and "excellent" credit and collection experience this year paid off for the C. I. T. Financial Corporation in record profits for the 1959 first half.

" The Flame Trees of Thika: Memories of an African Childhood," a new book by Elspeth Huxley, will be published in an American edition by Morrow on Aug. 26. Mrs. Huxley was 6 years old in 1913 when she trekked out with her mother in an ox-cart to join her "charming but improvident" father in the wild Kikuyu country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Defense Department has suddenly ended a scientific program for developing high-energy aircraft fuels, which President Eisenhower only six months ago said he had found promising.

A sixteen-ton press has been installed at the plant of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., in Towanda, Pa., to produce ingots of molybdenum, tungsten and other refractory metals used in ultra-high temperature applications. Among these are rockets, jet engines and industrial furnaces.
Anna M. Kross, Commissioner of Correction, said yesterday that overcrowding in penal institutions was causing the city to continue to doubleup inmates in areas built for single occupancy.

The last time the hemispheric foreign ministers met was in Washington in April, 1951, to rally support against "international communism" in connection with the Korean war. In between there was the regular Inter-American Conference at Caracas, Venezuela, in March, 1954, but the conference beginning today in Santiago, Chile, is the first special "Meeting of Consultation" of the foreign ministers in more than eight years and only the fifth in the history of the Pan-American movement.

A small band of volunteers wielded paint brushes yesterday to help redecorate the new headquarters of Neighborhood House. They were members of the Junior League of New York. Clinging to step ladders, they began the work of applying fresh colors and surfaces to the walls.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- College campus marriages are continuing to increase, bringing with them new problems in homes, classrooms and professions, speakers told the Council for the Advancement of Small Colleges here today. The organization is holding its summer workshop at King's College.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 11 -- A trim, gray-haired man of 47 with an admiration for traditions and an awareness of the realities or the present heads Little Rock's school board in this period of troubled change.
MONTREAL, Aug. 11 -- Some Montrealers have become alarmed as a result of a poliomyelitis outbreak that has been described as "showing epidemic tendencies."

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Legislators and the State Banking Department began sounding out local bankers, savings bankers and savings and loan association officers today to get their views on possible banking legislation.

A construction worker was killed yesterday when a retaining wall collapsed at the Cross Bronx Expressway project. Six other men were trapped and injured when tons of steel, rock, wood and dirt showered down.

LUKE CASSIDY, hero of "Victors and Vanquished"* by Francis Stuart, is one of the strangest characters in contemporary fiction. For the first third of Mr. Stuart's beautifully written novel he seems so Quixotic, childlike and remote from all the harsh realities of life that it is difficult to take him seriously.

A public offering is being made today of $30,000,000 of thirty-year 4 7/8 per cent debentures of Michigan Bell Telephone Company. The securities are priced at 102.122 to yield 4.75 per cent. The offering is being made by a group headed by Halsey Stuart Co.
