GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 11 -- The Long Island Association, a regional chamber of commerce, announced today that it would survey the business climate in Nassau and Sufflok Counties.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Forest Hill took a one-point lead today in the second round of the Elizabeth Goss Memorial round-robin tournament conducted by the Garden State Women's Golf Association.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points (40 cents a bale) lower to 2 points (10 cents) above Monday's close yesterday.
ISLIP, L. I., Aug. 11 -- A 27year-old ex-convict with a record of violent crimes was being questioned today in the three recent hold-up-murders in Suffolk County.
CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- The Australian Government cut income taxes and increased social security pensions today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Warner M. Willcox, a champion skipper of the International Class, assumed a 2-point lead for the men's sailing title of Long Island Sound when the eighth annual series for the Clifton A. Hipkins Trophy began today.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Chris von Saltza, 15 years old, of Los Gatos, Calif., won her third straight victory in the Pan-American swim trials tonight.

The current Congressional interest in the managerial aspects of foreign aid programs is worthy of some comment. Foreign aid can and does work, and we all agree that it is necessary. However, if Congress proposes to put more stringent controls over the administration of that program, it may run afoul of its own good intentions.
The proposed new Code of Ethics for 225,000 city employes will be signed by Mayor Wagner, he announced yesterday.
A college president, a banker and a store executive were added yesterday by Mayor Wagner to the Committee on Slum Clearance.
CHICAGO, August 11, (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- A former assistant Air Force Secretary told Congress today that retired officers attempted to influence Defense Department decisions after they had quit to take industry jobs.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Stephen C. Clark's Shield Bearer, in the tourney over the hurdles and a winner on turf, found Saratoga's new dirt-racing strip also to his liking today. The 4-year-old gelding scored a two and a half length victory in the featured $6,008 Schenectady Purse.
HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Esso A. G., a subsidiary of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), today announced it would withdraw from the fuel oil-coal cartel in West Germany on Aug. 13.

Arthur D'Arcy (Bobby) Locke and his venerable putter are back in the United States. The South African pro has gained weight along with years since his first visit here in 1947. But in his golf bag is the same hickory-shafted putter with which he stroked his way to many tournament victories on American greens.
Eighteen prairie dogs are being rounded up in the West and soon will be heading for the rather closed spaces of the Netherlands.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- A retired World War II general offered today to try to bring peace between President Eisenhower and Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 11 -Antonio Palafox, champion of Mexico, made his first appearance in the Newport invitation tennis tournament today and had two stiff matches in catching up with the field.

Inventory buying by industrial users in the second quarter raised sales and earnings of Aluminium, Ltd., from the level of the 1958 period. Halfyear earnings, however, were little changed from those of a year earlier.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Dr. Luis Padilla Nervo of Mexico, a candidate for the presidency of the United Nations Disarmament Commission, called on Secretary General Hammarskjold today.

Robert Moses made public yesterday a letter he had sent to Bernard Klieger, a Brooklyn lawyer, listing the bank deposits of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority as of Aug. 10. Mr. Moses is chairman of the authority.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 11 -- A movement to streamline the Representative Town Meeting was backed today when the Greenwich Young Republican Club recommended that the unit's membership be reduced from 232 to 151.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 11 -- An 8-year-old boy who was caught last night after breaking into an apartment here told the police today that he had committed at least ten burglaries "to buy candy and toys."
In an age when most management believes firmly in the principle of making many widely varied products, at least one company has gone steadily ahead by making a single item in hundreds of guises.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -The battle for labor reform legislation began in the House of Representatives today with the prospect of an extremely close contest between two of the pending bills.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A Department of Agriculture report today showed that July brought further improvement in prospects for a volume of crops that may turn out to be within 3 per cent of last year's record production.
Pre-retirement counseling is expanding and new methods are being evolved to advise a record number of employes now under pension plans of ways to successful retirement.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Details of the first companywide contracts with the Armstrong Rubber Company were announced today by the United Rubber Workers.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Air Force fired its third successful Atlas in four weeks today, moving the intercontinental missile closer to operational status.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -Outlines of a limited civil rights bill emerged today as the possible basis for a measure having the support of Senate Democratic and Republican leaders.

The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 86.6 on Monday, the same figure as last Friday. On August 13, 1958, the index was 86.9. The table below gives the index and its components for the dates listt, based on 100 for the period 1947-49:

The world will be watching Little Rock today. The unhappy history of that city's high schools in these past two years has brought Little Rock notoriety and provided ammunition for Communists and other critics of this nation. Today, when Little Rock's public high schools are scheduled to reopen with token integration in two of them, a new chance presents itself to those who live in Arkansas' capital.
The Transit Authority reported yesterday an operating loss of $10,184,316 for the fiscal year ended June 30. Nevertheless, it expressed satisfaction at the result.
A strong recovery in the second quarter pushed sales of the International Paper Company to a new high in the first half of 1959, the company reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -The State Department said today that the United States would not bypass the United Nations in establishing a new committee for resuming disarmament negotiations.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (AP) -The St. Louis-San Francisco (Frisco) Railway has pleaded not guilty to a criminal information that charged it obtained control of the Central of Georgia illegally.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11 (AP) -President Eisenhower got an invitation today from a man who said that he -- just like the President -- had come up in the world since they last met.

The stock market did the expected yesterday -- twice, in fact. Stocks rallied at the opening of trading and again in the final thirty minutes of the session. As a result, more than half of the loss in Monday's sharp break was erased.
Counsel for the United States Lines sought yesterday to show that when the liner Queen Elizabeth and the freighter American Hunter collided on July 29 the larger vessel was off course.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 -Hard-core Peronist unions staged today what appeared to be the least effective of five general strikes against the Government of President Arturo in the last year.
Motorola, Inc. is diversifying its activities further, through the acquisition of the Dahlberg Company, Minneapolis, Minn. maker of hearing aids and specialized communications systems for hospitals.

The Formula Junior racing car, created in Europe with the prime purpose of training young championship class drivers, finally has found its way to America. It is by far the most interesting development in this field in years. It is light; its power plant of course, is small; it has the true classic lines and it goes.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (UPI) -Willie Kirkland drove in his fourth run of the game in the tenth inning tonight to lift the San Francisco Giants to a 5-4 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The Rev. Dr. J. H. Jackson, minister of Olivet Baptist Church, sent a telegram to the National Association of Colored People today protesting the organization's action against the Little Rock, Ark., school board.
HAVANA, Aug. 11 -- The conspiracy uncovered in Cuba against the regime of Premier Fidel Castro appeared tonight to be larger than was first believed.
GAMBELL, Alaska, Aug. 11 -- Army Engineers blasted up a dozen cans of "live" beer today, the first authenticated samples of the brew that has made this Eskimo village famous.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A veteran foreign correspondent challenged today the accuracy of recent criticism of the United States aid program in Vietnam.

On the last day of their otherwise fruitless Geneva conference the foreign ministers issued a mysterious communique about "useful" talks on new methods for more effective disarmament negotiations. It now turns out that what is proposed is to call for a new ten-nation disarmament commission which would bypass the United Nations and reduce it to a mere "observer" on this life-or-death issue.

DETROIT, Aug. 11 (UPI) -Al Kaline cracked a three-run homer and Coot Veal hit the first home run of his major league career tonight to lead the Detroit Tigers to an 8-1 rout of the league-leading Chicago White Sox.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Senate rackets committee began a closed inquiry of the United Automobile Workers today after it had rejected a union demand that any charges be discussed in public.

KOKAD-JO, Me., Aug. 11 -Was the noble red man as trite and shopworn in the days of Old Nokomis as he is made out to be? Was he able to catch fish in lakes named worse than Madison Avenue could name them?

The Mayor's move to deal with Title I by naming three additional members to the slum clearance committee and asking his able assistant, Jack Lutsky, to sit in on meetings and report back fails to meet a problem that requires radical solution.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 11 -- More than half a ton of cosmic-ray equipment will be sent twenty miles aloft in a balloon over Minnesota, probably this week-end, in the third of a series of experiments for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 11 -Mayor John F. Ryan rejected today a recommendation by the State Commission of Investigation that he dismiss Police Chief Herbert L. Van Ostrand.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 11 -Two-year-old trotting fillies are skittish on a race track. Like women drivers, they bolt, interfere with one another and break stride frequently.
ONE of the best presents that the parents of an obese girl can give her is to stop forcing her to diet.
Ben Gazzara and Jack Hawkins will star in separate dramas this fall on the "Du Pont Show of the Month" over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

AS more and more young women combine college and marriage or career and marriage, the demand for basic but flexible clothes increases. With this in mind, Tailored Woman has assembled a varied collection of youthful fall clothes for both the wedding and trousseau of career and campus brides.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 11 -- India charged today that the Chinese Communist authorities in Tibet had taken five Indian nationals into custody and were preventing hundreds of others from returning home.
TRENTON, Aug. 11 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner ordered Attorney General David D. Furman today to start immediately an intensive campaign to reduce the number of highway fatalities in New Jersey.
The State of Ohio borrowed $30,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance capital improvements. The money was raised by the sale of general obligations secured by the state taxing power.
A merger proposal that would have reduced United States Atlantic-Gulf coastal shipping services to one oceangoing carrier has been rejected by Seatrain Lines.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- California's Indians are entitled to be paid for the land the Government took from their ancestors in 1851, the Indian Claims Commission has ruled in an 11-year-old suit.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 11 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus attacked police leaders and education officials as "Federal puppets" tonight and discussed the possibility of violence over the reopening of the four public high schools here tomorrow.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Austin Boyd Jr. of Ridgewood, N. J., pleaded guilty today to bribery in the Ulster County kickbacks case. He is vice president of the Lansdell Corp., Hackensack, N. J., a road materials company, and was formerly the company's managed here.
Robert Moses estimated yesterday that it would cost $85,000,000 to adapt the city's transit and highway systems for the projected 1964 world's fair here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -Now that President Eisenhower has agreed to talk to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, the hunt is on here for specific proposals to talk about.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 11 -- The East Hampton Neighborhood House will benefit from a card party, fashion show and tea to be held at the Maidstone Club here Aug. 19.
FOR the late-to-bed set WRCA-TV (Channel 4) has begun a new series of advice programs conducted by Dr. Joyce Brothers, a psychologist who once won a fortune on a quiz show.
LONDON, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- Drama critics acclaimed today a new Eliza Doolittle in the musical, "My Fair Lady," but they were not too happy with her Cockney accent.

ARMONK, N.Y., Aug. 11 -North Castle officials approved state plans today for the relocation of busy Route 22, the highway to the Berkshires, for two and one-half miles from Kensico Reservoir to the northeast corner of the airport here.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Twelve hundred men fought tonight to check a dozen forest fires blazing over 10,000 acres of northern California. In most areas the temperature was 100 or more.

Rising prices were again the order of the day in all parts of the bond market yesterday. The Treasury's new 4 3/4 per cent notes due in May, 1964, continued to lead the advance. For the second successive day this issue rose 6/32 of a point. The closing bid was 101 4/32, equal to a yield of 4.47 per cent.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 11 -- Sociologists at the University College of Rhodesia and Nyasaland are trying to find out how racial prejudice may be overcome in this part of Africa.
The fourth week of the national steel strike ended last night with President Eisenhower standing fast against White House intervention.

BALMORAL, Scotland, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana called on Queen Elizabeth II tonight to offer congratulations on the expected royal baby -and to talk about turning his African state into a republic within the British Commonwealth.
No statistics are available, but it's probably safe to say that mutual funds did a lot of stock buying yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Braves collected eleven hits and beat Cincinnati, 7-3, tonight after the Reds had won by 4-3 in the opener of their twilight-night double-header.

Paperboard production climbed for the fourth straight week to a record 336,991 tons in the week ended last Saturday, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. This latest figure compares with 331,482 tons produced in the preceding week and the 288,874ton output of the comparable 1958 week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas said today that nearly 5,000 service men were being used as "grocery store clerks" in military commissary stores.
AFTER more than 300 years of trying, Americans still cannot seem to find a comfortable place to sit down.
A garden apartment developnlent housing 112 families on East Garfield Street. between Third and Fourth Avenues, in Bay Shore, L. I., has been sold by Bay Shore A{anor, Inc.
TORONTO, Aug. 11 (AP) -Mrs. Bruce McGhie of New York, defeated the British Amateur champion, Elizabeth Price, 5 and 4 in the first round of the Canadian women's open golf championship today.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Industrial shares reacted to Monday's Wall Street setback with many minor falls on the stock exchange here today, although the undertone of the market remained firm.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 11 -- An exchange of taped television programs will enable San Francisco viewers to see tonight a full-length concert by the Boston Pops Orchestra.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 11 (AP) -A proposed $750,000 milk-promotion program for New York State was abandoned today. Too many farmers objected to contributing to the fund.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -Grain futures dealers squared themselves off today for what they hoped would be the most advantangeous market positions in the event the Government's August crop report which was released after the close would be either bullish or bearish.
Designating petitions filed yesterday with the Board of Elections indicated contests for Tammany district leaderships in twenty of Manhattan's thirtythree districts in the Sept. 15 primary.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 11 -- The World Jewish Congress closed a ten-day assembly here tonight with an appeal to the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it planned to issue a license for disposal of atomic wastes with low levels of radioactivity off the coasts of Virginia, Massachusetts, New Jersey and California.

For the second successive month the number of persons at work in the United States has established a new all-time high. The new peak in July, 67,594,000, represents an increase over the mark set in June by 252,000. It contrasts with a figure of 65,179,000 in July a year ago, a difference of no less than 2,415,000.

The push-button has taken over another Wall Street bookkeeping chore -- the job of clearing transactions for the American Stock Exchange. The basic function of the clearing operation is to reduce the number of transfers, between brokers, of securities and money.
LA GRANGE, Ga., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Three Negroes charged with raping two white women were convicted tonight. They were sentenced to die in the electric chair.

The producing ranks will be augmented by Larry Aldrich, a manufacturer of women's clothing, who has been dubbed "an editor of style." He is no stranger to Broadway, having made investments in "The Music Man," "West Side Story," "The Tunnel of Love" and other shows.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 11 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter stressed on arriving here today that the United States believed "law and order" should be the basis of interAmerican relations.
The drive by Actors Equity Association to improve backstage facilities at the Majestic Theatre, where "The Music Man" is playing, brought results yesterday.
A visiting Soviet editor chided American publishers yesterday for failing to print Russian books that gave what he described as a fair and comprehensive picture of the Soviet Union.
IF Cinderella were to see I. Miller's new shoe collection, she would get rid of that glass slipper in a jiffy. A princely lot from beginning to end, each shoe makes its own, individual point.

SOME food faddists have taken lately to sipping a glass of vinegar and honey each day on the erroneous theory that it will cure a wide range of human ills. It is just one example of the fallacious ideas about food to which Americans evidently are particularly prone.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Communist battalions are using bicycles to move arms and supplies into Samneua Province from the direction of North Vietnam, a Laotian official said today.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 11 -Jonathan M. Young, 20-yearold son of John M. Young, a partner in the New York investment concern of Morgan Stanley Co., was indicted for first-degree murder today by a Westchester County grand jury.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Bud Daley tonight became the first Kansas City Athletics hurler to pitch thirteen victories in a season as he gained a 7-3 decision over the Cleveland Indians.
Negotiators for the shipbuilding division of the Bethlehem Steel Company yesterday took steps guaranteed to break the existing contract stalemate.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -Al Dark and Tony Taylor came through with tenth-inning homers today that lifted the Chicago Cubs to a 5-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 11 -- The New York State Public Service Commission was asked today to conduct an investigation into the land-buying practices of the Long Island Lighting Company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -The State Department suggested today that the Communist military activity in northern Laos might be part of a Moscow-directed plan to create new tensions in Southeast Asia.
S. I. Newhouse, the newspaper publisher who recently moved into the magazine field, is reportedly negotiating to purchase Street Smith Publications, Inc.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 -- Beautiful Fenway Park, with its all-green background, its jury-box bleachers and that inviting left field wall, rearely has appeared more beautiful to the Yankees than it did today as they achieved their longest winning streak of the campaign.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- House-Senate conferees approved today a $1,200,000,000 appropriations bill providing funds for public works construction programs in the fiscal year that started July 1.
Suffocating gases dazed sixtyfive persons in Brooklyn yesterday and forced the evacuation of 200 more from their homes when a driver of a chemical truck poured nitric acid into the wrong nozzle.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -More Americans were at work last month than at any other time in the nation's history.
Martin Klein, whose letter appeared July 30, complains of New York City's neglect in clearing away ragweed that will afflict so many people between mid-August and frost.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 12 -- Visitors attending the fourteenth annual Garden State Dog Show here on Aug. 21 will have an opportunity to adopt a dog -- that is if they are emotionally compatible with the animal of their choice.
Gilbert Lee Beckley, by reputation a big-time gambler, testified yesterday for a halfhour before the boxing grand jury.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Wheat farmers in the Middle West, oil well drillers in the Gulf of Mexico and apple growers in New England are among the beneficiaries of a weather research center operated here by the Travelers Insurance Company.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Industrial shares bounded forward again today after Tuesday's modest reverse, pushing up the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary stocks 2.4 points to a new peak at 247.4 The previous record of 246.3 was set Monday.
OCALA, Fla., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Four persons were killed today when two cars collided on a rain swept highway.
In a move to win public support for a $500,000,000 school bond issue, the Board of Education announced yesterday the details of its proposed schoolconstruction program for the next ten years.
NEWARK, Aug. 12 -- A committee organized by State Senator Walter H. Jones to counsel him on a plan to aid commuter railroads held its first meeting at the Essex Club today.
The City Planning Commission yesterday turned back another effort to build a bus terminal on the West Side of the midtown area.
Mrs. Asuncion Ortiz, the 25year-old mother of three children who kidnapped a 21-dayold baby last January, was sentenced yesterday to serve a prison term of up to five years.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 12 -- An ex-convict being questioned in three recent hold-up killings bought a .32-caliber automatic only a "matter of hours" before the third slaying, officials were told today. A 32-caliber automatic was used in that killing.

" Pillow Talk," a romantic comedy in color starring Rock Hudson, Doris Day, Tony Randall and Thelma Ritter, has been scheduled to open Oct. 9 at the Palace Theatre, it was announced yesterday by Universal-International.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 12 -- Policemen and firemen held a jeering mob at bay with nightsticks and water hoses here today as Central High School reopened on a desegregated basis.

It is more than five years since the United States Supreme Court handed down its decision outlawing racial segregation in the public schools. Little Rock, Ark., has become a focal point of the ensuing struggle.

Harvey Sorkin Associates, realty investors, bought the sixstory apartment house for thirty families at 825 East 175th Street, the Bronx, for cash over mortgages of $129,000. The building, 120 by 50 feet, was constructed in 1939.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold reported today that the financial situation of the United Nations had become a matter of "deep concern" because of the failure of some member countries to pay their assessments.
An adjustment bureau for the mutual benefit of insolvent retailers of apparel and their creditors is being formed by a group of manufacturers in the field.
WALGROVE SNOOD, the literary banker, and Kim Carruthers, the benevolent bookman, were on the 5:19 train to Debenture Bay.
ALBANY, Aug. 12 (AP) -An eight-member Governor's committee was appointed today to review a five-year-old state law designed to stamp out charity racketeering.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 12 -H. Bogart Seaman, treasurer of Nassau County, opened bids on a $26,237,000 bond issue today and thus brought the total of county funds he has handled in the last twelve years to more than a quarter of a billion dollars.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 12 -- The conference of the Western Hemisphere foreign ministers opened here today on a note of dedication to the traditional inter-American principle of nonintervention of states in one another's affairs.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- A state security court accused seventeen army officers and a civilian today of having plotted to seize power and establish a republic in Jordan while King Hussein was on a world tour last March.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Maj. Gen. David M. Shoup, a Medal of Honor winner in World War II, was named today as commandant of the Marine Corps.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- J. Edgar Hoover, disturbed by an "alarming increase" in bank robberies and burglaries, urged the nation's financial institutions today to make a special effort to thwart such crimes.

MILAN, Italy, Aug. 12 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer called on the West today to show "great realism" in view of the coming talks between President Eisenhower and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev. The West German Chancellor said that these conversations might serve some useful purpose.
You do well to advise your readers as to the differences of opinion in the matter of liberalizing the state laws on criminal insanity.
PARIS, Aug. 12 -- The people of Paris were called upon today to acclaim President Eisenhower when he visits here Sept. 2.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- An expansion of Federal housing loans to permit colleges to build more dormitories was asked today by the Council for the Advancement of Small Colleges. The resolution was adopted at the organization's summer workshop at King's College here.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange finished 2 to 8 points (10 to 40 cents a bale) below Tuesday's close yesterday. The near months showed the most weakness.
The crab grass now is in rich, lush foliage. In ten thousand times ten thousand places it grins at the hot summer sun, stretches, then grows taller with speed almost perceptible to the naked eye.

Installment credit experience of the nation's banks improved in June, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday. Delinquencies in six categories surveyed in 300 banks declined compared with those in the preceding month. They were down sharply compared with those a year before.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, threatened today to have the party's 1960 national convention withdrawn from Los Angeles unless a quarrel over convention spectator seats was settled by next Monday.
Michael H. Prendergast characterized Governor Rockefeller's freeze on major new highway projects yesterday as "premature, ill-advised and unnecessary."
International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday an improvement in net income in the first half of 1959.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Senate Democrats failed today to override President Eisenhower's veto of the $1,375,000,000 housing bill. They then turned to plans for a substitute measure that might win the President's approval.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 12 -- There was supposed to be an unveiling here this morning of what the weekly periodicals call "the new Ike," but it turned out to be something less startling and more interesting.
The State Commission of Investigation yesterday finally heard a man admit that he had attended the Apalachin gangland convention at the invitation of Joseph Barbara Sr.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -Soybean futures slumped today for the sharpest one-day price decline in more than a year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended August 5:

PEIPING, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- The top leaders of Communist China are believed to be holding an important secret conference, with the KhrushchevEisenhower visits in the offing and trouble brewing in the Indochinese state of Laos.

Five games scheduled in the fifth round of the Log Cabin Chess Club's silver anniversary tournament were played to adjournments last night at the Mary Bain Chess Studio, 145 West Forty-second Street. The standings remained unchanged, with William Lombardy, 3 -- 1, continuing to set the pace.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 12 -To increase the pool of qualifiedsubstitute teachers, the Department of Education will sponsor an informal training program for college graduates, starting Sept. 2, the week before public schools open.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 12 -- A Southern Rhodesian tribunal charged today that African political organizations in the three territories of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland were plotting the overthrow of the Government.

DAKAR, Senegal, Aug. 12 -Representatives of the new Federation of Mali are pressing their request for full independence within a French commonwealth in almost constant contacts with President Charles de Gaulle and other French officials.

Vincent J. Velella withdrew last night as the Republican designee for Municipal Court Justice in the Eighth Manhattan District. He gave as his reason his involvement in the grand jury investigation of the Johansson - Patterson boxing rematch.
BOSTON, Aug. 12 -- Richard Cardinal Cushing of Boston has recommended a "crusade of prayer" for Roman Catholics in his archdiocese during the visit of Nikita S. Khrushchev to the United States.

A few days ago The Baltimore Sun reported a demand on the part of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People that liquor wholesalers employ more Negro salesmen in the Harlem area, or their products will be boycotted.

Plans for the production of a film that will cost $12,000,000, the third highest budget in movie history, were revealed yesterday. The film, "The Son of God," will be made by a new independent company, the Parliament Pictures Corporation.

The Department of Buildings is issuing a summons for ninety-four asserted violations in an old-law tenement at 31 West 111th Street, which Borough President Hulan E. Jack and Deputy Commissioner Harold Birns visited on Monday.

Four five-story apartment houses at 1430 to 1436 First Avenue, adjoining the northeast corner of Seventy-fourth Street, have been sold by Alan H. Posner to Louis Sachar. The structures occupy a plot 78 by 101 feet and will be replaced by an apartment building with suites renting for about $55 a room a month.

CANNES, France, Aug. 12 -Bill Rosensohn, the fight promoter who is vacationing here, said today he "would rather not make any comment now" on statements made by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan in New York on Tuesday.

A seventy-five-year-old club record at which they may never again get so good a shot -- but don't bet on it -- eluded the Washington Senators when they beat the Yankees, 3 -- 2, last night at the Stadium. The "spoiler" was Julio Becquer, who hit a three-run, pinchhomer off Ryne Duren in the eighth inning.

Mayor Wagner's stated purpose of strengthening the Committee on Slum Clearance has been convincingly achieved with appointment of Joseph P. McMurray, John D. Butt and Jack I. Straus. They are men the chairman, Commissioner Robert Moses, can rely on. Their varied experience and demonstrated ability should be of great benefit to the committee.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 12 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower arrived here today apparently with a free hand to talk "about anything anybody wants to talk about."

A General Sessions jury began deliberating at 2 P. M. yesterday in the case of the three suspended patrolmen who were charged with attempted burglary at a shoe store. The case went to the jury of seven men and five women after a two-and-a-half-hour charge by Judge Samuel R. Pierce in the trial that began June 22.

AMPAL-American Israel Corporation, private investor in Israeli agricultural and industrial projects, plans to offer $6,000,000 of 5 per cent fiveyear sinking fund debentures and 6 per cent ten-year sinking fund debentures.

The poodle is top dog now. Last month, for the first time in the history of the American Kennel Club, more poodles were registered than any of the other 113 breeds recognized by the A K. C. GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower reaffirmed today a hands-off attitude toward the Republican Presidential nomination if the leading aspirants backed present foreign and domestic policies.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 12 -Plans for a capsule in which a pilot could sit in shirt-sleeve comfort to fly a supersonic plane were made public here today by Chance Vought Aircraft, Inc.

Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc. had record sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended on June 30, according to the results announced yesterday by William S. Paley, chairman, and Frank Stanton, president.
TO most bridge players the word "squeeze" has unpleasant connotations; for it has come to symbolize everything that is complicated about the game.

Electric power production fell to 13,675,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday from a record high of 13,775,000,000 kilowatt-hours produced in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Aug. 12 -- The Bergen County Board of Freeholders voted today to begin legal proceedings against the Port of New York Authority. The board seeks to prevent what it says is competition with private enterprise and a violation of home rule.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -The State Department denied once again today that the United States was establishing bases in Laos or sending troops there.

Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday sizable gains in net income for six and twelve months ended on June 30. In both cases reserves were set aside for possible rate adjustment of a subsidiary company and for other possible adjustments arising from purchased gas and taxes.
WILTON, Conn., Aug. 12 -Protesting the proposed relocation of Route 7, a group has formed the Keep Wilton BeautifulAssociation.
STOWE, Vt., Aug. 12 -- This resort town isn't too far from Times Square as a crow flies, but as sports cars go on rallies, it is close to 400 miles.

Blood will be given today by employes of the New York Telephone Company at 210 West Eighteenth Street at 33-13 Bethpage Turnpike Levittown, L. I., to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. There also will be a donation at the Radio Corporation of America, 155 East Twentyfourth Street.
CHICAGO, August 12 (AP) -The report of; today*s livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Investment bankers headed by Hayden, Stone Co. offered to the public yesterday 140,000 shares of the common stock of Lease Plan International Corporation, car, truck and equipment lessor of New York City. The stock is priced at $11.50 a share.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 12 -- Seven persons, including a close associate of former Prime Minister Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy, were arrested tonight in connection with an alleged plot to cause a public disturbance on Friday, the twelfth anniversary of Pakistan's independence.
The social behavior of humans and animals can be drastically influenced by electrical stimulation of the brain, a researcher said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Nearly sixteen years ago Maj. Gen. David Monroe Shoup distinguished himself as commander of the Second Marines, Second Division, on Tarawa, site of one of the fiercest battles of the Pacific during World War II.
BONN, Aug. 12 -- West Germany's six-month-old fuel oil price cartel collapsed today under the weight of millions of tons of unsold coal.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (UPI) -The Chicago Cubs collected sixteen hits, including four home runs, and defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 11-8, today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- The City Council unanimouslygave final approval tonight to a Title I urban-renewal project that will replace a downtown section with $30,000,000 to $50,000,000 in new buildings.

MONTREAL, Aug. 12 -- Archie Moore had an easier time with Yvon Durelle tonight than he had making weight for the defense of his world lightheavyweight championship. Moore, the perennial of pugilism, knocked out his Canadian challenger in 2:52 of the third round of a scheduled fifteenround bout.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- The House Judiciary Committee announced today that it had approved temporary legislation limiting the taxes states might impose on out-ofstate concerns doing business within their borders.

ONE of boxing's most fascinating facets is its ability to survive despite all efforts from within and without to deal it a final knockout. Nefarious characters may infest its ranks, scandals may pop up and spread like crabgrass in August, but somehow it never seems to be lacking for champions to espouse its cause.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- The Committee on the Bill of Rights of the American Bar Association has come to the defense of the Supreme Court. In so doing, it attacked the action last February of the 248member House of Delegates, the association's policy-making body.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Aug. 12 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the home club increased her lead to 3 points today in the third round of the five-day Elizabeth Goss Memorial round-robin golf tournament at the Forest Hills Field Club.

The best one can say of the beginnings of token integration in two of the high schools of Little Rock yesterday was that a start really was made. The rioting which attended the entry of two young Negro students at Central High School was deplorable. However, Police Chief Eugene Smith performed his duty of protecting the students with courage and a minimum of violence.
Waterfront employers accused the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday of "reaching for the moon" in demands for a new dock labor contract.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Warner M. Willcox, who has been winning major sailing honors for twenty-two years, today captured the Clifton A. Hipkins Trophy, symbolic of the men's championship of Long Island Sound.

Archie Moore is very old as fighters go and he's not especially young as any of us go. The light heavyweight champion of the world says that he was born in Collingwood, Ill., on Dec. 6, 1916, but his mother insists that Archie was born three years earlier in Mississippi.

SCHROON LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- The Sheriff of Erie County said today that the secrecy on names required by the proposed Youth Court Act would be a major factor in the soaring rate of juvenile delinquency. The act is scheduled to take effect next April 1.

A fortnight ago the Washington correspondent of The Economist of London referred to the manner in which the Democratic arithmetic of last January had been scrambled by subsequent events. Under that arithmetic, he observed, "the ban on the Presidential third term, plus a Democratic majority of almost two-thirds, added up to a powerless President."
The New York Yearly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends appealed yesterday to the Governors of New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Vermont to do away with the death penalty.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:
The largest cargo-carrier in the American merchant marine, the tanker National Defender, will be launched Wednesday at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company in Virginia.
DETROIT, Aug. 12 (AP) -The Chicago White Sox unloaded their biggest offensive in nearly three months today, bombarding five Detroit Tiger pitchers in an 11-6 triumph at Briggs Stadium.
Hectic trading marked world sugar dwellings yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. A total of 46,350 tons changed hands during the session.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Queen Elizabeth II added another member today to her Privy Council -- Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, Prime Minister of the young African state of Ghana.

SHELVES of oriental canned goods, including broiled eel and baby octopus and cellophane-wrapped dried foodstuffs, such as seaweed and squid, capture the attention of the mainlander shopping in Honolulu.
ROME, Aug. 12 -- The Sicilian Parliament elected a strongly autonomist administration in defiance of the central Government tonight. The Communists and other Leftists voted with the majority.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Henry James, who never was able to write a successful play, scored a hit on the West End tonight.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Garguilo Francesco could not fight back the thought that this was "finito" -- the end.

Billy Rose's ownership of the National Theatre, 208 West Forty-first Street, is being contested by William Zeckendorf, head of the Webb Knapp realty firm. According to Mr. Zeckendorf, legal proceedings are under way to gain possession of the 1,168-seat house, purchased at an auction by Mr. Rose in June, 1958, for $849,500.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- The revival of a move for union with Greece, discovery of a suspected arms factory and a hitch in constitutional talks posed threats today to the smooth transition of this British colony to independence.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 12 -- A major challenge confronting the twenty-one American foreign ministers meeting here involver reconciling the principle of nonintervention with the clamor against dictatorships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Richard T. Gosser, the United Auto Workers senior vice president, testified behind closed doors before the Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field today.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Two old English insurance companies announced a merger agreement today. They are the Royal Exchange Assurance, incorporated in 1720 and the Atlas Assurance Company, Ltd., founded in 1808.

Four chimpanzee youngsters at the Bronx Zoo did yesterday what many New Yorkers of their age do when the TemperatureHumidity Index goes up. They romped under water jets and in a shallow pool with squeals and shouts of delight.
A RUSSIAN - BORN actress who has given three command performances at the Kremlin hopes that Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev will bring his wife to America for a lesson in "two-way stretch democracy."
A contest for next year's Republican nomination for President would be a healthy development for the party, L. Judson Morhouse said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Army Signal Corps announced today the development of aviation's first aircraft flight control system that can be used with all types of planes.

Motorists took to the roads in increased numbers last week and drained 3,015,000 barrels from the nation's gasoline stocks, according to the American Petroleum Institute. On last Friday supplies were 183,481,000 barrels, compared with 186,496,000 a week earlier and 177,297,000 a year ago.

R. Carl (Hap) Chandler, director and former chairman of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company, sold an additional 11,500 shares of the company's stock last month, reducing his net interest to 500 shares. About two years ago, Mr. Chandler owned 35,000 shares of the company's stock.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- A Democratic Congressman made public today a letter from President Eisenhower turning down a proposal for an exchange of visits with Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China.

FALMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 12 -- This Cape Cod town observed today the centennial of the birth of Katharine Lee Bates, author of the patriotic hymn "America the Beautiful." The poet and scholar was born here Aug. 12, 1859.
After two days of wide gyrations, the stock market took a breather yesterday. Prices eased in moderate trading.

Some of the discouraging figures on city fires given by Fire Commissioner Cavanagh in his annual report for 1958, just made public, have been anticipated by forecasts made by the Commissioner himself. The fully documented report shows that last year 187 persons were killed or died of injuries at fires, fifty-two more than in 1957.

The General Development Corporation, a large home-building and community development concern, increased its net income in the first half of this year to $5,208,368 from $3,684,672 in the 1958 period, Frank E. Mackle Jr., president, reported yesterday.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower told Congress again today that a highway program financed on a pay-as-you-go basis was the only alternative to asking one's grandchildren to foot the bill.
The advance of the bond market received its first widespread check in weeks yesterday.

Two new deans have been appointed at Fordham University, the Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, the president, announced yesterday. They are the Rev. Lincoln J. Walsh, named dean of Fordham College, and the Rev. Philip E. Dobson, named dean of the School of Business.
The invocation of national emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act to end the steel strike is still a month or six weeks away.
A dance in Brooklyn that was sponsored by the Youth Board last night ended in a wild fight in which a policeman was slashed and beaten by about thirty teen-agers.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Christian A. Herter's address today to the opening of the American foreign ministers' conference:
Trans-Continental Industries, Inc., a holding company, plans a one-for-four reverse split of its common stock.
CAIRO, Aug. 12 -- A gold scepter from the tomb of Tutankh-Amen was missing from the Egyptian Museum in Cairo today. The authorities reported it stolen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -The House of Representatives killed the union-backed Shelley labor reform bill today in an atmosphere of rising tempers. The vote was 245 to 132, with fifty-eight not voting.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- Movies have been made of novels, plays, short stories, synopses and ideas tossed out vaguely from on high. Now a collection of humorous essays is becoming a movie at the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studios.
HONG KONG, Aug. 12 -- Communist China declared today that United States activities in Laos posed a threat to China, Vietnam and the peace of all Southeast Asia.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 12 -- Hours before Little Rock's Central High School reopened this afternoon to token integration, tension began to mount in the grey shingle bungalow of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Thomas in the Negro West Side district.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 12 -- The Belgian Government is pressing the view that a plenary session of representatives of the states of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is a necessary preparation for President Eisenhower's coming meeting with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The coming visit of President Eisenhower to Britain begins to shape up as four or five days of free and easy talk about long-range strategy for the West.
SARATOGA SPRINGS N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Bobby Ussery, the 23-year-old jockey from Vian, Okla., is meeting some famous people these days.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Tyner Corning, representing Noroton Y. C., won the Jesse A. B. Smith trophy by scoring 58 1/4 points in the annual Long Island Sound instructors' championship sailed today off Indian Harbor Y. C.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower is expected to visit Queen Elizabeth II at Balmoral Castle in Scotland when he goes to Britain Aug. 28 for talks with Prime Minister Harold Macmillan.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Except for eight ticks of the timer's watch last Dec. 28, the New York Giants, rather than the Baltimore Colts, would be playing the College All-Stars here Friday night in the traditional prelude to the football campaign.

HAVANA, Aug. 12 -- Premier Fidel Castro flew today to Las Villas Province, where a group of counter-revolutionists is reported to be fighting Government troops in the Trinidad hills about 200 miles east of Havana.

VAESTERAAS, Sweden, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Dan Waern, Swedish distance runner, tonight broke four minutes for the mile for the fifth time. He was timed in 3:59.2. On Monday he set a world 1,000meter record of 2:18.

ALTAMONT, Tenn., Aug. 12 -- The State of Tennessee today petitioned a Circuit Court judge here to padlock the Highlander Folk School, alleging that it has become a "public nuisance" and a place which "harbors and protects" persons violating the criminal laws of the state.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- John C. Melaniphy, Chicago Corporation Counsel, gave a written opinion to Police Commissioner Timothy J. O'Connor today in which he recommended that the Commissioner issue a permit for the showing of the film "Lady Chatterley's Lover."
The newly enlarged Committee on Slum Clearance went part of the way yesterday in effecting reforms that Mayor Wagner has demanded in the administration of the Title I program here.
Residents on the site of the proposed Bellevue South Title I project on the East Side were urged last night to resist plans of the Committee on Slum Clearance to condemn the area.
One of the nation's biggest missile and space equipment contractors is out to aid faltering small businesses.

My reading of C. L. Sulzberger's article of July 29 on South Tyrol left me with a sense of concern and surprise. The concern was that the article reveals the existence of Rightist groups who apparently are amassing weapons and arms in Austria while Vienna remains silent.
Isn't it time that someone in America told young Americans -and others -- how to behave on the Continent of Europe?
In contrast to most motionpicture producers, who have just stood there, television will do something about "Don Quixote."
Capt. James D. Craik has taken over as chief of the Coast Guard's Third District merchant marine safety division.
Nassau County, L. I., borrowed $26,237,000 in the public bond market yesterday at an interest cost of 3.7252 per cent.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 12 -Antonio Palafox of Mexico and Mike Green met with unexpected defeat today in the Newport Invitation Tennis Tournament.
Foremost Dairies, Inc., achieved record sales and the second highest earnings in its history in the first six months this year, according to the report issued yesterday.
The plan to hold a world's fair in New York in 1964 gained momentum at City Hall yesterday.

The first Air-Car, which travels on a cushion of low pressure, low velocity compressed air, will come off the South Bend, Ind. production line of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation in November. The 300 horsepower, two-engine vehicle, carries four passengers and travels at a maximum speed of sixty miles an hour. It has no wheels, transmission or clutches.
An advertising agency has taken a searching look at Hawaii and concluded that the new state "should mean a good market" -- better than Alaska.

TOKYO, Aug. 12. -- South Korea reopened diplomatic negotiations with Japan today, partly in the hope of blocking the prospective large-scale repatriation of Korean residents here to Communist North Korea.
JO-MERRY, Me., Aug. 12 -Most of the Great Northern Paper Company's 2,500,000 acres of woodland and 530 miles of improved roads in Northern Maine are open to hunters and fishermen all year.
MONTREAL, Aug. 12 (AP) -- After his quick triumph over Yvon Durelle tonight, Archie Moore threw his hat into the heavyweight derby.
THE widespread use of sour cream in America has been one of the culinary phenomena of the last two decades.
The swift Palermo Football Club of Italy scored its second straight victory in this country as it beat the Rapid Soccer Club of Vienna, 2 -- 1, at Ebbets Field last night.
The annual dinner dance of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the plaza on Oct. 29, will benefit the organization's scholarship fund.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower served notice today that he would pull no punches in his talks with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev on the cause and cure of East-West tensions and the promotion of world peace.

TOKYO, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -Japan is planning to build a ship with 400 shopping booths arranged like a department store on its two middle decks. The ship will be sent on a world tour to cultivate outlets for a wide variety of Japanese goods.

A new man-made wonder of the modern world will begin to take shape today when ground will be broken for the $320,000,000 Narrows bridge, which six years from now will become the first direct connection between Staten Island and the rest of New York City.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a compromise plan giving President Eisenhower temporary authority to raise interest rates on Government bonds.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- A public relations man told Congress today his company, at the Army's request, had done "advertising" to prevent a cutback in the Nike-Hercules missile program.

MONACO. THE June graduate who would give her kingdom for a fascinating secretarial job might cast a green eye on the peach and apricot palace of Monaco. Therein types a tall, tanned Vassar girl with teeth as white as sails. If she broke the bank at Monte Carlo, she could not be happier.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 12 -Countess Adios, a bay filly driven by Del Miller, came within a second of the world record with a 2:02 2/5 performance in winning the $36,914.80 Devotion Pace for 2-year-olds at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon confirmed today plans for a swing through New England this fall. The trip was regarded as a warm-up for the New Hampshire Presidential primary next year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company asked the Government today to underwrite a six million dollar, 15-year loan that it had privately negotiated with the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York and associated companies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers pledged his support today to a New York drive on consumer and securities frauds.

The Times, in a news story on page one in its issue of Aug. 6, and again in an editorial on Aug. 10, presented a picture of a Wagner administration retreat in connection with the plans for a staff of civilian parking meter inspectors which was completely out of accord with the facts.
BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- Thousands of East Germans turned out amid showers and thunderstorms today on Communist orders to engage in gymnastics, volleyball, swimming and other athletics.

Three adjourned games from the second, third and fifth rounds were played off last night in the Log Cabin Chess Club's silver anniversary tournament at the Mary Bain Chess Studio, 145 West Forty-second Street.
MONT TREMBLANT, Quebec, Aug. 13 -- The 1,000-mile international sports car rally arrived here today with forty of the original field of forty-three cars.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 13 -- President Eisenhower's morning-to-sundown visit in Bonn this month will probably be stretched out by a couple of hours, Mr. Hagerty said here today before flying to Paris.
World sugar prices advanced yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has announced the division of its operations into separate aircraft and missiles-electronics groups. L. Eugene-Root was named group vice president for missiles and electronics and A. Carl Kotchian was appointed group vice president for aircraft.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Communist China disclosed today its governmental, military and party leaders are taking up important national problems in an extraordinary joint meeting of the Communist party's Central Committee and the State Council.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 13 (AP) -- The mention of a Negro integration leader's story in a list of "notable books" distributed by a state agency appeared headed today for a legislative inquiry.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A dancer injured by a drunken guest at a cast, party marking the closing of the musical comedy "Where's Charley?" was still at work and is entitled to compensation for the injury, a court held today.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 13 -- With nearly half of the 120,000-man labor force of this region idle because of the strike, it is estimated that the loss in wages to date has been $25,000,000.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 13 -Caribbean passions and hatreds exploded tonight in the interAmerican conference in a public exchange of shouted insults and alleged murder threats.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 13 -- A 28-year-old lawyer will leave tomorrow on a visit behind the Iron Curtain to try to distribute $15,000.

A Chihuahua, a Siamese cat, boa constrictor and other unusual pets entertained a room full of Girl Scouts yesterday. The scene was the educational room of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 13 -- The fifth rocket in the Discoverer series was launched into orbit today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -Production workers will vote tomorrow on settlement of their sixteen-day-old strike at the Standard Oil Company (Ind.) refinery in near-by Whiting, Ind.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 13 -- President Eisenhower settled down to his holiday routine today with the arrival of the fourth member of the Presidential foursome in both golf and bridge.

Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that the continued part-time employment of George E. Spargo and William S. Lebwohl on Title I slum-clearance work would be contrary to instructions that he and the Board of Estimate had given Robert Moses.
It was business as usual yesterday in the eight East Coast shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company despite the imposition of new working rules.

The St Regis Paper Company announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the issuance of 453,731 shares of common stock. The shares would be offered in exchange for the 667,251 capital shares of the Cornell Paperboard Products Company, Milwaukee, Wis.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- An advertising executive with ten children who became a college president for a salary smaller than his previous income tax was cited today as a hallmark of the dedicated educator.

Two years ago Harper published Elisabeth Elliot's "Through Gates of Splendor," a biography of her husband Jim, one of five missionaries killed in Ecuador by the Auca Indians in 1956. Next Wednesday, Harper will publish the biography of Nate Saint, pilot of the ill-fated missionary expedition to the Aucas.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Pete Rademacher scored his first professional victory tonight with a fifth-round technical knockout over Tommy Thompson of Washington.

CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Red Cross representatives of Communist North Korea and Japan signed an agreement today to repatriate Koreans living in Japan. The plan already has touched off diplomatic fireworks with South Korea.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- The twenty-sixth annual harbinger that football is just around the corner will send the College All-Stars, a collection of last year's best varsity players, against the Baltimore Colts, the professional champions of 1958, tomorrow night.

PANAMA, Aug. 13 -- If another invasion of Panama is attempted, the National Guard stands ready to block it with much tougher measures than those used last April, an official spokesman said today. He referred to the defeat of a force of almost 100 men that landed from Cuba then.

There was a notable lack of trader interest in the stock market yesterday as prices sagged irregularly. Trading slumped to 2,020,000 shares, the lowest volume since May 19, 1958, when 1,910,860 shares were handled.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 -- Spokesmen for fabricators, warehouses and construction companies were in agreement that no real pinch had been felt to date in northern California.

AS the Yankees suddenly popped to life, winning six in a row before they tripped over Julio Becquer's bat Wednesday night, an interesting question was posed. After a ball club flounders along hopelessly for weeks on end, what sends it suddenly on a victory binge?
Shipping interests in the port have asked Governor Rockefeller to name an experienced maritime man to the bi-state Waterfront Commission.

The end of the first month of the national steel strike finds critical shortages of metal still more than a month away for most steel users. But hardships are piling up for employers and workers in other industries and the pinch of payless paydays is beginning to send strikers to public relief agencies for help.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Industrial shares moved irregularly in the stock market here today under the influences of a selective demand and increased profit taking. Movements generally were small.
The game of one-z, two-z over the name Verrazano-Narrows Bridge broke out again yesterday during a ground-breaking ceremony in Staten Island.
Five of the most overproduced commodities in the United States are wheat, cotton, corn, rice and tobacco. And yet we persist in paying large subsidies to keep up the overproduction of these goods.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 13 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter told the Latin-American foreign ministers today that the forthcoming exchange of visits by President Eisenhower and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev did not mean a change in the basic policy of the United States on the "cold war."

The steel strike that began on July 15 caused production in the month to fall 53.53 per cent from the June level. Output was 5,233,000 net tons of ingots and steel for casting, against 10,907,634 tons in June, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

One of the disturbing elements in the current wave of prosperity is the low market price of long-term United States Government bonds and the sales resistance encountered in the sale of "E" bonds. The public has learned in these inflationary times that dollars which they thought they were saving and investing soundly are buying less and less.

TRAPANI, Sicily, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Four Sicilians were convicted today of kidnapping an American here nine months ago and were sentenced to prison terms ranging from eighteen to twenty-six years. The four also were convicted of illegal possession of guns, but were acquitted of charges of attempted murder.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 13 -- African political prisoners in the Central African Federation of the Rhodesias and Nyasaland face a long period of internment, in the opinion of observers here.

Suffolk County, L. I., is planning to borrow $3,019,000 in the bond market on Aug. 20 to finance public improvements. The securities will be dated Sept. 1, 1959 and will come due serially on Sept. 1 from 1960 to 1979.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 13 -- Where publicity ends and chicanery begins is sometimes difficult to discern here. For exaggeration is as natural in show business as debt.
Pleasure boatmen are going to get added pleasure -- and protection -- in the waterways of the village of Quogue, L. I. This busy cruising area includes Quantuck, Quogue Canal and Shinnecock Bay.

STOCK up on mint sauce this week-end if you are tired of ham. Thanks to good supply and supermarket specials, leg of lamb is among the best meat buys. Chicken also is priced attractively in many chain stores.
Vincent J. Velella said yesterday that not a penny of Bill Rosensohn's money went into the promotion of last June's heavyweight title fight.
A second Congressional committee was told yesterday that it could have the minutes of the Manhattan grand jury that investigated the alleged rigging of television quiz shows.
A Wagner-sanctioned bill creating the new "meter-maid" force was unanimously passed yesterday by the City Council.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 13 -- A disabled Eastern Airlines plane with only a crew of four aboard made a safe landing today on a foam-covered runway at a former naval air station at near-by Pomona after its left landing gear had jammed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -The Senate approved today a program that, in effect, would revive the New Deal's Civilian Conservation Corps of depression days. The vote was 47 to 45.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 13 -- H. O. (Hop) Perry Jr.'s Myth of the Pequot Yacht Club won two of the three races today to take a lead in the national Atlantic Class championships on Long Island Sound. The event is being held under the auspices of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 13 -Newport Mercury finished first by two and a quarter lengths in the $28,698 Mr. America Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

BUFFALO, Aug. 13 -- Steel reserves in the Niagara frontier appear adequate to meet demands of the next two months, but after that time it is expected that shortages would develop and lay-offs would result.
