LEVITTOWN, L. I., Aug. 13 -- Taxpayers here approved a budget of $10,443,969 to operate the school system tonight.
Four Negroes were indicted by a Bronx grand jury yesterday for their part in a nearriot in the Bronx last Sunday in which 300 persons were involved and two detectives were mauled by the crowd.
A taxi driver was shot and killed in a hold-up in Harlem yesterday and the police ordered a score of detectives to hunt his killer.
DETROIT, Aug. 13 -- Spot shortages in certain sizes and types of steel are beginning to develop in the Detroit area, but are not expected to be felt until after Labor Day.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 13 -- After treating Turkish music lovers to a melodious banquet on each of two nights, the New York Philharmonic left today for Salonika, Greece.
New regulations of employment agencies -- particularly for models -- were adopted yesterday by License Commissioner Bernard J. O'Connell. He acted after a hearing at City Hall.
I share L. O. Rothschild's concern regarding the plan to appropriate a large acreage in Flushing Meadows Park for a professional baseball stadium, and would like to advance an alternative suggestion.
The Stitt Howell Company, floor-covering distributor, leased the one-story office and warehouse building in the Newtown Industrial Center at Vandervoort and Grand Streets, Brooklyn.

Evidence is beginning to develop that the liquidation of inventories built up in anticipation of the steel strike is adding to the accumulation of cash in the coffers of the nation's corporations. Good demand for Federal obligations from non-bank investors, largely corporations, helped the sixteen larger New York City banks to reduce their Government securities holdings by $278,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday.

The Canada Dry Corporation has acquired from a private group Kentucky River Distillery, Inc., Nicholasville, Ky., producer of bourbon whisky. Canada Dry has marketed the whisky under its own trademark as Canada Dry Bourbon since 1955.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Housing starts fell slightly last month but still made their biggest July showing since 1950, the Commerce Department reported today.

THE American Bridge Association, a national organization of bridge players whose members are almost all Negroes, is holding its annual national tournament in Cleveland, Ohio, as reported in this space last week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower will set new guidelines soon for Government agencies dealing with fall-out and other radiation hazards, it was announced today.
FISH RIVER LAKE, Me., Aug. 13 -- This truthful hunting story concerns misfortune, ill judgment, persecution and the final triumph of justice the invincible.
ALBANY, Aug. 13 (AP) -- An Appellate Court denied workmen's compensation benefits today to the widow of a man who died after a drinking contest at a company Christmas party.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Flint (Scotty) Schulhofer, making a comeback as a steeplechase rider after a year working as an assistant trainer, scored his second straight stakes victory over the jumps at old Saratoga today.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Austrian music critics today called a performance of the Jerome Robbins "Ballets: U. S. A." last night a "sensational success" and an "American aid to the festival."

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Aug. 13 -- Foreign Minister Golda Meir said today that Israel would not accept any conditions that would qualify the right to send Israeli cargoes through the Suez Canal in foreign-owned ships.

Despite agreement between Britain, Greece and Turkey to settle their erstwhile bitter dispute over Cyprus by making it an independent republic, new trouble appears to be brewing on that restless island.
PARIS, Aug. 13 -- Paris this August seems like an old woman lazily slumbering and sunning herself on the banks of the Seine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- William Francis Gibbs, leading naval architect, urged today that the United States build an atomic-powered icebreaker bigger and more powerful than the Soviet Union's icebreaker Lenin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee approved today a substitute $1,050,000,000 housing bill. It makes only one major concession to President Eisenhower's objections to the original measure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) -- The board chairman of the Martin Aircraft Company told House investigators today his company had flown high-ranking military officers to the Bahamas for week-end parties at a country club.

THE only feminine official party-giver in the city wears three hats. By appointment of Mayor Wagner, Nina Rao Cameron is Assistant Commissioner of Commerce and Public Events. She also wears the hat of director of the United Nations Committee of the City of New York. Concurrently, she is director of the Consular Corps Committee of the City of New York.
UNITE DNATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold insisted today that the United Nations "retains the ultimate responsibility" for disarmament negotiations.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 13 -- Baltimore and the rest of Maryland are just beginning to feel the strain of the strike.

WOMEN who dye their hair were once considered slightly scandalous. Today, changing the color of one's hair is no more shocking than wearing lipstick. An estimated one of every three women who go to a hairdresser change or improve the color of their hair.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 -- Manufacturers, builders and warehouses here have varying steel reserves that they expect will last from thirty days to six months.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- A labor reform bill backed by President Eisenhower and desperately fought by union leaders was approved by the House of Representatives today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -Congress and the Administration took a long step today toward settling their dispute over the financial crisis facing the interstate highway program.

The United States, the world's largest consumer of petroleum products, will drop from second to fourth place by 1963 in the ranking of nations possessing tanker fleets, according to an analysis made public yesterday.
A philanthropic foundation has been tentatively approved by the Committee on Slum Clearance to take over sponsorship of the four-block Bellevue South Title I project.
NORTHVILLE, Mich., Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Mason Rudolph, a freshman pro from Clarksville, Tenn, fired a four-under-par 67 today to take the first-round lead in the $25,000 Motor City open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -Following are the main provisions of the Landrum-Griffin labor reform bill tentatively passed by the House and the Kennedy bill passed by the Senate:

A bridge 20 feet long and 8 feet wide has been constructed between the Chrysler Building and the adjoining Chrysler Building East to connect the seventh-floor offices of Luria Bros. Co., scrap iron and steel brokers.

A strange-looking "boat," somewhat resembling a Mississippi River steamer, is on its way from England to Iraq. It will be used in building a deep-water terminal for oil tankers twenty-four miles off the Iraqi coast, in the Persian Gulf.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 13 -- Jaime J. Merino, once one of the most powerful figures in Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex), the nationalized petroleum industry of Mexico, has been discharged by the company, according to Pascual Gutierrez Roldan, director of the organization.

"A Private's Affair," Twentieth Century-Fox musical comedy in color, will open today at the Paramount Theatre, Broadway and Forty-third Street. Sal Mineo, Christine Carere, Barry Coe, Barbara Eden and Gary Crosby have the leading roles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company put in bid today for the Interstate a Railroad Company of Virginia, which the Southern Railway System had sought to acquire.
CAIRO, Aug. 13 -- A complete reshuffling of guards was ordered and an item-by-item inventory was begun today at the Egyptian Museum.

More policemen have been sent to the lower East Side where Philip Schickler, a 65-year-old restaurant owner, was killed in a hold-up. Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday he would maintain the extra police in the area until he was certain the racial tensions had abated.

Average member bank borrowings increased $39,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to $1,073,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday Excess reserves increased $149,000,000 to $577,000,000. This produced average net borrowed reserves -- excess reserves less borrowings -- of $496,000,000, down $110,000,000 from a week before.
The Boeing Airplane Company is consolidating its Seattle and pilotless aircraft divisions and its systems management office into a single unit to be called the Aero-Space division.

The two-story garage and parking lot at the southeast corner of Twelfth Avenue and Forty-first Street has been leased by Irving Maidman to J. S. Inskip, Inc., distributor of the Rolls Royce and other English automobiles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The head of the Hamilton Oil and Gas Corporation testified today that the company had bought a $90,000 house in Denver for Frank Leahy, a Hamilton director and former Notre Dame football coach.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 13 (Reuters) -- The Laotian Government said today that all Communist regular troops had pulled out of the country, but that a 1,200-man guerrilla band had been left behind to build up support for another offensive.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 13 -- Lieut. Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution has told Indonesia's Communist party to postpone indefinitely its sixth national congress, which was scheduled to open here Aug. 22, a high military official said tonight.
The General Sessions jury that heard the case of three suspended patrolmen accused of attempting to burglarize a Fifth Avenue shoe store recessed shortly after 1 o'clock this morning.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- The Supreme International Restitution Court in Berlin has recognized the claims of four Jewish families for the return of valuable estates and houses sold to foreign diplomatic agencies during the Nazi era.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 13 -- India has protested to Communist China against propaganda describing this country and the Indians as "imperialists," Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today.

Lumber production rose to 249,487,999 board feet last week from 243,906,000 board feet in the preceding week, according to reports received by The New York Times from regional associations. The latest figure is the highest since the week ended June 27 when 260,176,000 board feet were produced.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 13 -A fingerprint on a venetian blind led to a reported confession of murder here today.

The District Attorney's office yesterday asked Bill Rosensohn to be back in New York before Aug. 23, if possible. Rosensohn is scheduled to appear before the grand jury in the boxing investigation on Aug. 28, but District Attorney Frank S. Hogan would like to move up the date.

IF underwater swimmers turn up soon in polka dot or striped suits with matching aqualungs, only the fish will be surprised. Women, according to the Empire State Underwater Council, an organization of skin diving clubs, already are beginning to make their influence felt in this, the world's fastest-growing sport.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (UPI) -- George Altman, a rookie, drove in five runs with a pair of homers and a single today and Alvin Dark belted a grand-slam home run to pace the Chicago Cubs to a 20-9 triumph over the San Francisco Giants.

I have recently returned to the United States after two years as Fulbright Professor at Freiburg University in the Federal Republic of Germany. During that time I had occasion to teach more than 600 students, take part in a number of colloquiums with German high school teachers, and lecture at other universities.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold announced today that tentative travel plans had been made for his long-projected tour of northern and central Africa. Unless other developments intervene, he said, he will leave Dec. 23 to visit twenty-one African countries and territories, including some of the newly independent states in the area.
NEWARK, Aug. 13 -- Steel still is generally available in this area, with reserves reported sufficient for sixty to ninety days. However, some items are in short supply.

The Waterfront Commission gained yesterday in its effort to examine books and records of The Longshore News, the official newspaper of the International Longshoremen's Association. The State Supreme Court denied a motion to bar the examination.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Following are excerpts from an address by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter at a meeting of the foreign ministers of American states in Santiago, Chile, made available by the Department of State:

SPRING LAKE, N. J., Aug. 13 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon warned today that neither the exchange of visits between President Eisenhower and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev nor statements made in conjunction with them should be used as an excuse for reducing United States defenses.

The National Association of Seecurities Dealers, Inc., self-policing organization of the securities industry, announced yesterday it had expelled eleven members for violations of its rules of fair practice. The members expelled are:
The National Citizens Council for Better Schools said yesterday that it was reorganizing and curtailing its operations.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- There were only a few barely visible gains today in another generally weak grain futures market on the Board of Trade.
Life among the Washington Senators is no longer an almost unbearable series of drab experiences, even though they're still in last place and doomed to stay there.

ST. HELEN'S, England, Aug. 13 (Reuters) -- A six-ton marble statue of Christ by Sir Jacob Epstein, banned by a consistory court after the sculptor had offered it to Selby Abbey, Yorkshire, may be installed in a new church institute here.

GREEN peppers are one of the most handsome offerings at vegetable counters now. Plump and shiny-skinned, these are known as "sweet" peppers. Actually, they are mild in flavor rather than sweet, a term used to distinguish them from hot peppers.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 -The chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Paul M. Butler, was flying tonight from Washington to Los Angeles to try to straighten out the dispute over tickets that is threatened to disrupt the party's plans to hold its 1960 convention here.
A plan that is intended to bring the city from $800,000 to $1,600,000 a year was approved unanimously yesterday by the City Council.
HAVANA, Aug. 13 -- Premier Fidel Castro declared early today that the "counter-revolution has been crushed."
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Steel users in the Chicago area are generally still comfortably fixed.

Alonzo Johnson will seek his fourteenth straight victory tonight in a bout with Alex Miteff of Argentina at Madison Square Garden. The heavyweight contest, scheduled for ten rounds, will be nationally televised.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The fate of the vaunted B-58 bomber, many ambitious Navy projects for nuclear-powered vessels and the Army's Nike-Zeus anti-missile missile is being reviewed by the Pentagon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- George R. Petty Jr. announced his resignation today as president of the 3,500-member Flight Engineers International Association.
RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 13 -- The Moroccan Government has decided to take its protest against the projected French atomic explosion in the Sahara to the United Nations.

While waiting for the excitement in Cuba to die down it is worth while considering the forces that make such upsets almost predictable. Cuba can expect lots of things to happen in the next few years, but what it cannot expect is a calm, peaceful existence.
MONTREAL, Aug. 13 -- Archie Moore is interested in Ingemar Johansson and is not at all concerned with fighting Ray Robinson, the middleweight champion.

Roy Carlisi, a 50-year-old Buffalo restaurateur who attended the Apalachin gangland conference Nov. 14, 1957, refused yesterday to answer questions about the gathering put to him by the State Investigation Commission.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee authorized its chairman today to order an on-the-spot investigation of the administration of foreign aid in South Vietnam.
Earnings of Pan American World Airways, Inc., staged a sharp recovery in the second quarter of this year, according to the statement issued for publication today.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, which long has preferred to create, develop and control its own television programs, will open the door to independent producers.

A balanced analysis of the truth and consequences of the struggle over labor union reform legislation, now coming to a climax in Congress, may have to await the competence in research and the perspective of some future Edward Gibbon. But the stakes of the battle are plain in contemporary view.

A civil engineer from New Jersey was arraigned yesterday in Chief Magistrate's Term here for failing to answer 123 traffic tickets, and was promptly labeled "Prince of Scofflaws" by court officers. The defendant wept during his court appearance.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 13 -- The State Department of Health today sharply criticized the operation of the municipal dump as inadequate and urged the city to take immediate steps to remedy its "open dumping" system.
The nation-wide steel strike is taking an increasingly heavy toll of freight traffic and revenues of the railroads. In the week ended last Saturday the carriers loaded only 532,304 cars.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The guardsmen at Buckingham Palace were given a new incentive today to maintain poise in their struggle to hold their ground against the numerically superior forces of tourists.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Aug. 13 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos of Baltusrol and Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches tied for the lead in the tenth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association 36-hole senior golf championship today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Senate passed a bill today to increase pensions to veterans with non-service-connected disabilities by about $10,000,000,000 through the next forty years.
A fifty-year-old dream of planners began to take tangible form yesterday when ground was broken for the $320,000,000 bridge across the Narrows.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 5 points (25 cents a bale) up yesterday.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa declared yesterday that he had a "perfect right" to campaign upstate against the proposed $500,000,000 bond issue for New York City school construction.
ALBANY, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The New York Democratic party's annual fund-raising dinner upstate will be held in Troy on Sept. 23.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 13 -- The mob, behind the flags of the United States, Arkansas and Dixie, marched up Fourteenth Street toward the thin line of police holding an intersection yesterday a block from Central High School.

AN electric floor washer was introduced this week by the Hoover Company. The appliance, which is said to be the first of its kind, scrubs, picks up dirty water and vacuums the cleaned surface dry in minutes. It is designed for use on any flooring material that can be washed.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 13 -- The order of "The Nicaraguan Campaign Hat and the Bull Durham Sack," a citation that definitely does not exist among the official Marine Corps awards, was presented here today to an Air Force master sergeant for services rendered twenty-seven years ago.
A steady stream of dots and dashes still is the main support of the Western Union Telegraph Company. But a more modern money maker is becoming increasingly important.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- A polite tug-o'-war began today between New York and Washington over which should be host to a world's fair in 1964.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
PENSACOLA, Fla., Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Navy is planning to get a husband for Miss Baker, the half-pound monkey that made history as one of the country's first space travelers.
The League of New York Theatres announced yesterday that on Oct. 28 it would test the practicability of raising the evening curtain for all Broadway shows at 7:30 o'clock, an hour earlier than usual.

The upturn in the nation's economy, cost control and greater operating efficiency enabled the Dow Chemical Company to attain in its latest fiscal year the highest sales and earnings for any year in its history.

New York and Connecticut tax experts met yesterday in Governor Rockefeller's office here to start preliminary studies of mutual arrangements that might bring relief from tax burdens on Connecticut residents who work in New York.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- There was a continued rise in both exports and imports in Britain in July, according to provisional figures released by the Treasury today.

LAST year Wilfred Fienburgh, a 38-year-old Labor Member of Parliament for North Islington, London, was killed in an automobile accident. His death was not important news in this country. Most Americans have never heard of him. But Mr. Fienburgh had completed the manuscript of a novel, "No Love For Johnnie,"* which is impressive evidence that if he had lived to write a half dozen other novels as good, his death would have caused international regret.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- A painting criticized by President Eisenhower has become a great drawing card for Soviet visitors to the United States National Exhibition in Moscow as a kind of "Symbol of Freedom," it was declared today.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Bob Gardner, the defending champion, overcame the heat, humidity and two rivals today in the metropolitan amateur golf championship.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Two boys from Mamaroneck whose willingness to work hard attracted the attention of a general made history here today.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers survived a five-run St. Louis rally in the ninth inning tonight and beat the Cardinals 7 -- 6.
McALESTER, Okla., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Somebody stole the Pan-American Games torch from City Hall last night. Two youths turned up with it an hour later.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 13 -- The second day of desegregated classes passed today at the city's newly reopened high schools with no attempt at disruption.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Court-appointed monitors reported today that James R. Hoffa, teamster union president, had thwarted their yearlong efforts to examine the financial records of a union local.

NEWARK, Aug. 13 -- The Essex County Board of Freeholders voted 6 to 3 today to increase the annual salary of Freeholders from $8,000 to $10,000, effective Jan. 1. The resolution will come up for a second reading and final action Aug. 27.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) -- Cash dividend payments by corporations issuing public reports came to $852,900,000 in July. They compared with $806,600,000 in the like month last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
ALBANY, Aug. 13 (UPI) -- A television actress who applied for unemployment insurance on the basis of re-run commercials lost her claim today in the Appellate Division.

The National Citizens Council for Better Schools is ending the direct-action phase of its program. The council's announcement may sound like the communique of a victorious army headquarters walking out on its troops.
PARIS, Aug. 13 -- The impression developed here today that President Charles de Gaulle planned to make some new political move to end the fighting in Algeria.
Several of the nation's leading out-of-town newspapers have held discussions looking toward the establishment of a joint selling and creative operation in this city.

TRENTON, Aug. 13 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner implied today that the State Senate was delaying action on a bill to provide six more Superior Court judges solely because he had declined to reveal the names of those he might appoint.

ISLIP, L. I., Friday, Aug. 14 --Francis H. Bloeth, construction worker and ex-convict, confessed last night that he had committed three recent hold-up slayings in Suffolk County. His confession came after his wife, Jane, had pleaded with him for two hours "to spare more innocent people from being killed."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Frederick H. Mueller, Secretary of Commerce, warned today against Federal program to aid the mining industry that might hurt the general economy
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 -The steel supply here is plainly much tighter than it was a fortnight ago. In some specialized areas, shortages are beginning to set in.
Price fluctuations were irregular in investment grade debt securities yesterday. It was a quiet and inconclusive session influenced largely by the adjustment of trading positions by professionals.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 13 -- Chris Crawford gained his most notable victory of the tennis season today at the Newport Casino.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The contract of Paul Richards to manage the Baltimore Orioles of the American League was extended today for two years.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Two New York officers who came to Brazil to speed the return of Lowell McAfee Birrell, New York lawyer and financier, for trial on fraud charges win go back home empty handed, perhaps tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The United States is considering sending a model of Explorer VI, the paddle-wheel satellite, to the American National Exhibition in Moscow.

Two weeks ago the New York City Board of Education presented its first paper in documentation of the need for liberalizing the city's borrowing power by $500,000,000 for school construction in the next decade. Its inventory showed 190 of 844 schools now in use to be obsolete or inadequate by modern standards.
KAHULUI, Maui, Hawaii, Aug. 5 -- The Hawaiian sugar cane industry, considered the most highly mechanized industry of its kind in the world, is experimenting with still further automation.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 13 -- It is expected to be a month to six weeks before Birmingham and Gadsden, Alabama's principal steel-making cities, begin to feel any real pinch.
GAMBELL, Alaska, Aug. 13 -- Five hundred cans of beer have been found and destroyed by Army Engineers in Operation Beer Bust, which entered its fourth day today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, called today for prompt action on civil rights legislation to strengthen the hand of local officials enforcing schol desegregation in Little Rock, Ark., and elsewhere.

The evening performance of "Sound of Music" on Jan. will benefit the American Ballet Theatre. The new Rodgers and Hammerstein musical starring Mary Martin is scheduled to open at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre on Nov. 12.

Eighty-four young Americans who attended the seventh World Youth Festival in Vienna flew home from Europe yesterday. They were somewhat chastened in their belief that a little free speech can be an effective counter to a lot of skillfully managed propaganda.
An expansion of two-year-old plans to rehabilitate La Guardia Airport was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.
The Treasury's new 4 3/4 per cent notes due in 1964 moved to a new high yesterday in an irregular market. Volume was active for a midsummer Friday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago and the city today filed in Superior Court general denials of responsibility for a school fire Dec. 1 that claimed ninety-five lives.

Plans for a fifteen-story apartment building in the Lenox Hill district were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the property at 327 to 341 East Sixty-sixth Street, west of First Avenue. The buyer was the Security Operating Corporation, A. Marinoff, president

The Hartford Fibres Company, a division of BigelowSanford Carpet Company, has been licensed to sell in this country a regenerated cellulosic fiber known as Zantrel. Next year the concern expects to begin production of Zantrel staple fiber at its plant in Rocky Hill, Conn.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 14 -- Francis H. Bloeth, 27-yearold ex-convict who confessed to the killing of three robbery victims in Suffolk County, was put in the county jail here today.

THE next women's hair style to come out of Italy may very well be a Yul Brynner cut. It all started when a group of movie stars and starlets were shorn for their roles as World War II Yugoslavian collaborators.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -The fourth-place Chicago Cubs continued their recent power binge and subdued the leagueleading San Francisco Giants, 7 -- 5, today on the strength of three two-run homers.

A new forty-family garden apartment building at 1100 Edgewood Avenue, Trenton, was sold by Samuel Muncher and Jerome Harris for cash over a mortgage of $200,000. Herbert Apfelbaum was the broker. The property was bought by the Fortune Holding Corporation of New York, which was represented by David Go0amAn of Goodman lV[abel, lawyers.
Graham - Paige Corporation reported yesterday that stockholders' equity as of June 30 was at the highest level since the former automobile maker became a registered investment company in 1949.

NEWARK, Aug. 14 -- The minutes of the Hudson County grand jury investigation of alleged payments by two Jersey City companies to insure labor peace were ordered turned over to the Attorney General's office today.
A bottleneck that has caused thirty-one accidents in less than a year on the new Long Island Expressway at Parsons Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, will be removed within two weeks.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Richard M. Nixon, a sports fan with an unfulfilled yearning to be a sports writer, outlined his ideas today for a kick-off column.

The Columbia Gas System, a holding company with subsidiaries in the Midwest and Central Atlantic States, reported yesterday an 8.5 per cent rise in revenues for its fiscal year ended June 30. Net income, however, shows a fall from the 1958 level.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Tom Thumb moved into the stakes winning category today at Saratoga by taking the American Legion Handicap. And he won the event, run for the thirty-third time, like a true stakes competitor, scoring by seven lengths over Howell E. Jackson's Tick Tock in record time.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 14 (UPI) -The Air Force failed today to recover a 300-pound capsule that was ejected from the Discoverer V satellite high over the Pacific.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota said today that he planned to enter the Wisconsin Democratic Presidential primary next April 5. He said he expected to win it.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP) -Alex Grammas' pinch single with the bases filled in the eleventh inning tonight enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to defeat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2 -- 1.
ROME, Aug. 14 -- Italian newspaper readers appear to be puzzled by dispatches from Washington and other Western capitals discussing the "new Eisenhower."

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Private capital for the expansion of small colleges is available if the schools learn how to tap it. Philip Willkie, an Indiana lawyer and banker, told the Council for the Advancement of Small Colleges today.

Taking advantage of a twenty-two and one-half pound edge in the weights, Alex Miteff of Argentina won a unanimous decision from Alonzo Johnson of Braddock, Pa., in the featured ten-round heavy- weight bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

FRONT ROYAL, Va., Aug. 14 (UPI) -- Warren County High School here, boycotted by its entire white student body in February to avoid integration, began today quietly registering white and Negro students for the new term.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- The House agreed today to accept all but one of several Senate amendments to legislation increasing non-serviceconnected pensions to more than 1,100,000 veterans, their widows and orphans.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -The big rush to sell out long positions in the grain futures market appeared today to have come to an end with the renewed appearance of scattered investment buying on the Board of Trade.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The stock market ended the week with share prices advancing on a wide front despite the customary dampening effects of week-end profit taking and the imminent end of the three-week bookkeeping account.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- A survey of the British press since the announcement Aug. 3 of the forthcoming Eisenhower-Khrushchev visits indicates that the President of the United States has regained some of the prestige he lost in the shadow of the late John Foster Dulles.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo offered last night a completely different program, which is to be repeated for the remainder of its week of performances in Central Park's open-air Theatre-in-the-Park.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- (AP) Cattle rustlers reportedly have discarded their six-shooters and are arming themselves with tranquilizer guns.
HONG KONG, Aug. 14 -- The people of Communist China were called upon yesterday for a supreme new effort to combat the effects of drought, floods and insects.
" COULD you give me a recipe for an old-fashioned fresh peach pie with a latticed top?" Mrs. G. D. Schrader, Havertown, Pa.
ALTHOUGH small home accessory shops are scattered all over town, some areas are more concentrated than others. One such area is Fifty-ninth and Sixtieth Streets, between Madison and First Avenues.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board says there were fewer airline accidents last year, but a great many more fatalities than in 1957.

MOSCOW, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Moscow City Court ruled today that the estate of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, creator of Sherlock Holmes, may press its claim for royalties before the Supreme Court of the Russian Republic next week.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Sweden's Ingemar Johansson, who still hasn't been I paid for his knockout victory over Floyd Patterson, today proposed the formation of worldwide Boxers'. Union, so Ithat "fighters can get their {rights."
When the liner African Enterprise arrives from Capetown today with thirty-five passengers, the engine-room telegraph will ring "finished with engines."
LEVITTOWN, L. I., Aug. 14 -- Revolts against rising school taxes have led to the prospect of sweeping changes in the operation of this community's schools.

MOSCOW, Aug. 14 -- The full burden of describing, explaining, defending and selling the United States and its ways at the American National Exhibition here has fallen on the shoulders of seventy-five young guides.
Weak electrical currents applied painlessly to implanted cancers in mice have brought about total regression of the cancer in a high percentage of cases, two scientists reported yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Residents of suburban Collins Park are establishing a fund for the defense of eight men charged in the first of two explosions at the only Negro home in the community. They met last night and made an initial pledge of $1,800.
Roy Carlisi, a member of the Apalachin gangland gathering in 1957, was ordered to Civil Prison yesterday for refusing to answer questions of the State Investigation Commission.
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Aug. 14 -- Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won the tenth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association senior golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Senate advocates of civil rights legislation gave up hope today of breaking through Southern opposition in the Senate Judiciary Committee. They said they would carry their fight to the Senate floor.

Sales of the nation's major chain and mail-order companies exceeded the 1958 level by 1 per cent both in July and in the first seven months of the year according to a survey made yesterday by The New York Times.

NATACHA, the distinguished dancing bear, broke up the party at the British Embassy in Moscow. She had previously nipped a presumptuous Soviet colonel. But colonels are plentiful; nipping them can easily be topped by taking a bite at a field marshal or even an admiral. Crashing into an immense tableful of Her Majesty's best diplomatic china and crystal was bound to make a greater uproar in the world.
David J. McDonald asserted yesterday that use of the eightyday injunction provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act to halt the steel strike would delay a final settlement, not speed it.
An article that disputes United States newspaper reports on the persecution of Jews in the Soviet Union has been sent to The New York Times by the Soviet Embassy in Washington.

THE death of a former Army buddy at the hands of Fulgencio Batista's secret police and a conviction that "free men should take up arms and stand together" against dictators are said to have led William Alexander Morgan to the Escambray hills of Central Cuba in 1957.
PARIS, Aug. 14 -- Final arrangements for President Eisenhower's visit here were discussed today by a White House staff headed by Mr. Hagerty and aides of President Charles de Gaulle.

The American Export liner Independence yesterday received the Ship Safety Achievement Award for 1958 for outstanding contribution to sea safety. The award, given annually by the National Safety Council, was presented to Admiral John M. Will, retired, president of American Export Lines, Inc., by Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.
TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 14 -For the first time in nearly a month, the Welland Canal-St. Lawrence Seaway link between Lake Ontario and Erie was free yesterday of a backlog of ships waiting for passage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- An electronic refrigerator that is noiseless and has no moving parts was patented for the Philco Corporation of Philadelphia this week by William E. Bradley, director of technical research.

PHILLIPSBURG, N. J., Aug. 14 -- Twenty-four hundred workers employed at plants of the Ingersoll-Rand Company here and at neighboring West Eaton, Pa., struck this morning. Their walkout forced idleness on 1,300 nonunion clerical and supervisory employes.

In rejecting the application of a sight-seeing bus company to erect a new bus terminal on West Forty-first Street, the City Planning Commission has taken the only possible action consonant with established city policy. KANSAS CITY, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics pounded six Chicago pitchers for thirteen hits, including three home runs, and defeated the White Sox, 7 -- 2, today behind the nine-hit pitching of Ned Garver.
CAIRO, Aug. 16 -- The United Arab Republic and Jordan have resumed diplomatic relations.

CAIRO, Aug. 16 -- The Nile in annual flood brought rising and filted waters to Cairo and the Delta today.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 16 -Frank Gifford, the halfback, was quite willing to criticize Frank Gifford, the quarterback, this morning, twelve hours after the New York Football Giants lost their first exhibition game of the summer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Administration believes the battle against inflation is being won.

CALVERTON, L. I., Aug. 16 -- Investigators of the Civil Aeronautics Board began trying to learn today why a Boeing 707, pride of United States commercial jet operation, crashed near here late yesterday. All five crewmen aboard were killed.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 -- Moscow's first International Film Festival will end tomorrow with most Russians delighted to find themselves on the world movie map but a little disappointed with the fare shipped here for their appraisal.

The City Planning Commission announced yesterday that thirty city departments and agencies had requested 1960 capital budget allocations totaling $605,534,982 in additional funds subject to the city's debt limit.
At least twelve large hawks are making their homes atop city skyscrapers and zooming down to snatch pigeons from Central Park. Wall Street and the banks of the Hudson.

A merchant seaman shot and killed his wife on an upper Manhattan street yesterday, lost his pursuers in a seven-mile chase on the West Side Highway, and then committed suicide in his apartment, the police said. He shot himself in his apartment as two policemen approached his door.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -The police said arsonists set two fires early today causing minor damage to an apartment building occupied only hours earlier by three Negro families. The neighborhood is predominantly white.
The Universal Match Corporation has elected John L. Wilson president and chief executive officer.

The House Ways and Means Committee has voted the President authority to raise the interest rate ceiling on Government bonds. Moreover, it has approved the measure without the amendment to which Chairman William McC. Martin Jr., of the Federal Reserve Board, supported by Secretary of the Treasury Robert B. Anderson, had vigorously objected.

Thousands of Philippine homes may soon be humming with activity to supply American homes with a host of distinctive craft products. Such a burst of activity is the hopeful anticipation of Senora Remedios G. Grefalda, soft-spoken and energetic marketing missionary for Philippines cottage industry.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 16 -- The completion of scoring in the 1,000-mile international rally that ended here last night revealed today a number of additional honors, particularly for the Jaguar and MG entries.

FISHERS ISLAND, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- Fleet Admiral William F. Halsey, one of the Navy's top leaders in World War II, was found dead in bed here today at the Fishers Island Country Club, where he was vacationing.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- James C. Hagerty, President Eisenhower's press secretary, left London Airport today after saying that he was not yet able to disclose what detailed arrangements had been made for the President's forthcoming visit to Britain.
A Canadian clergyman returned to preach for his fortieth consecutive summer yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal church here that had helped him to continue his education in 1919.
The steamship charter market continued dull and lifeless last week, maintaining previous low volume and rate levels.
MOSCOW, Aug. 16 (AP) -Praise was expressed today by a Soviet engineer-writer for the automobile exhibit at the American National Exhibition and the men who tell about the products on display.

Mickey Cantle gave many of the 46,041 spectators something special to talk about while the Yankees and the Red Sox were dividing a double-header yesterday at the Stadium. Boston took the opener, 6 -- 5, despite three homers by the Yankees, who captured the second game, 4 -- 2.

I followed with concern the five articles on Outer Mongolia by Harrison E. Salisbury (Aug. 3 to 7). I differ strongly with the second article, "Soviet and Red China Compete for Power in Outer Mongolia," and contend that there is no major rivalry between Soviet Russia and Communist China over Outer Mongolia.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 16 -- Australia stands in the Davis Cup challenge round for the sixteenth consecutive time since 1938. It will face the United States at Forest Hills, Queens, Aug. 28, 29 and 30 for the international tennis trophy it lost to the team headed by Alex Olmedo last December in Brisbane.

The Port of New York Authority has decided to spend $1,250,000 for a new 3,350-foot extension on one of the major runways at New York International Airport in Idlewild, Queens.

Because of a break in a thirty-six-inch water main early yesterday morning, traffic will be diverted for several days from New Chambers Street, a heavily traveled artery linking the East River Drive, Brooklyn Bridge and the City Hall area.

The 352 West Forty-second Street Corporation, Morton Ryweck, secretary, has purchased 1241-49 Lexington Avenue and 147-51 East Eighty-fourth Street, in Yorkville, for improvement with a cooperative apartment house.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The United States in the coming year will explore unknown areas of Antarctica, attempt to determine if the frozen continent is divided, and study the birds and fishes of the polar region.

John Godley (Lord Kilbracken) has kept his ancestral home of Killegar, Ireland, solvent not by opening it to the public but by involving himself in adventures and writing and lecturing about them. Some of these were recorded in "Living Like a Lord," which was published in 1956.

George P. MacGregor has been elected vice president in charge of advertising and merchandising of Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc. He has also been made a member of the executive committee and a director.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today it would be a mistake to assume that the Soviet line was softening because of his visit to the Soviet Union and the fact that Premier Nikita S. Krushchev was coming here.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Former, Foreign Minister Ole Bjoern Kraft, a leading Danish conservative, has called off a lecture trip to the United States and Canada.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa declared yesterday that the city's borrowing power for permanent public improvements within its debt limit would increase by $279,000,000 next year.

A plan to have commercial airlines supply United States military bases in Europe and Asia was announced yesterday by four air carriers.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The financial district noted with unconcealed satisfaction last week that London's stock market not only weathered the squall over Wall Street but rebounded to another record high.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Let it never be said that a Philadelphia politician was caught speechless.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Warren Spahn salvaged the finale of a four-game series for the Milwaukee Braves today, beating the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5 -- 2, in the second game of a double-header. Pittsburgh took the opener, 2 -- 1, as Bob Friend posted his 100th major league victory.
ALBANY, Aug. 16 (UPI) -- The administration of Governor Rockefeller was reported today to be ending a forty-two-year-old State Police tradition as an economy move.

Helen Hayes, Judith Anderson and Siobhan McKenna will star in the revival of "The Cradle Song." Miss Anderson and Miss McKenna will re-create the roles in which they first appeared in 1956 over the National Broadcasting Company network.
The American independent tanker fleet is doomed, according to an owners' group, unless present competitive tactics of the major oil companies are restricted.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 16 -West Germany will support a United States plan for a new international development loan agency, Government officials said today.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 16 -- After an initial rise last week to a new high of 317, the stock index dropped sharply to 309, compared with 315 the previous week.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 -- No medium or large sized steel user was quoted as being "hurt" by the steel strike last week. But smaller miscellaneous fabricators of steel were beginning to notice spot shortages. It may be a few more weeks before a larger number of steel customers begin to be affected by spot shortages or imbalance in inventories.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Senate will decide tomorrow whether to pass a housing bill that would take the place of a more expensive measure vetoed by President Eisenhower. It is almost certain that the bill will be overwhelmingly approved.
Panama won the top rating among twenty-four Latin American export markets for credit and collections in the survey by the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau for the first half of 1959.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 16 -- The Inter-American Peace Commission, a body designed to deal with small problems, took on today one of the hemisphere's biggest -- the Caribbean conflict.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Y. A. Tittle's 16-yard touchdown pass to Clyde Conner with nine seconds left lifted the San Francisco 49ers to a 27-24 victory over the Washington Redskins today. It was the opening exhibition for the National Football League teams.
ISLAND BEACH, S. P., Aug. 16 -- Look for a "hard winter." That's the forecast of John B. Verdier, superintendent of Island Beach State Park.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 -- Installment buying of more expensive consumer goods will begin in most parts of the Soviet Union within the next month.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Home runs by Ernie Banks and Lee Walls lifted the Chicago Cubs to a 5-4 victory over the league-leading San Francisco Giants today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Gov. David L. Lawrence of Pennsylvania said today that Adlai E. Stevenson was the ablest man in either party to fill the office of President. He said Mr. Stevenson could not be counted out of the running for 1960.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 -- In the scramble for California's support in the Democratic Uresidential nominating convention, the most effective delegate-seeker so far is not Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois or Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts or Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, but Clark Clifford, who is running interference for Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri.

Pier watchmen in this harbor have received surgical, hospital, accident and death claim benefits aggregating $1,892,336 over the last eight years. This was reported over the week-end by the jointly managed New York Shipping Association - Port Watchmen's Union Welfare Fund.

THE Central Connecticut Championships, played at Norwich over the last weekend, have for several years filled a gap in the tournament schedule of this region. Except for this one tournament, all is dull and dead for New York players from late July to Labor Day.
Benton Bowles, Inc., is continuing what appears to be a reorganization of its creative departments.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 16 (UPI) -- Rebellious Khamba tribesbmen have killed four Chinese Communist soldiers in a clash in western Tibet, according to reports reaching here today.

WHITE for night stands as one of the most dazzling rivals of understated black. All-white theatre suits, slinky dinner dresses and magnificent ball gowns appear in crepes, silk satins, heavy brocades and filmy chiffons.
NORTHVILLE, Mich., Aug. 16 (UPI) -- Mike Souchak fired a 2-under-par 69 today for a nine-stroke victory and top money of $3,500 in the Motor City open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The United States announced today the signing of an agreement to extend a credit of $135,000,000 to the European Atomic Energy Community.
SEWICKLEY, Pa., Aug. 16 (AP) -- The United States completed a 4-3 upset over Britain today and regained the Wightman Cup after a year's absence.

VALLETTA, Malta, Aug. 16 -- Terry Lentz of Monterey Park, Calif. won the world underwater fishing championship today with a catch of 106.44 pounds.
UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Aug. 16 -- George Meany marked his sixty-fifth birthday here today.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- Paul Kelly of Sleepy Hollow become the metropolitan amateur golf champion again this afternoon. At the Fairview Country Club course, the 28-year-old former Rutgers golf captain defeated Bob Gardner, the defender from the Essex County Club, in the scheduled 36-hole final.
The time capsule buried fifty feet deep in Flushing Meadow at the 1939 World's Fair may be opened 4,975 years ahead of time.

The gross receipts for the gate and subsidiary rights to the Ingemar Johansson Floyd Patterson heavyweight title fight in June should approximate $1,318,795, according to figures released yesterday by the New York State Athletic Commission.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- Cultivation of quick-growing poplars since World War II has added $1,000,000 a year to the economy of the Po River Valley in northern Italy. The development is credited by the Food and Agriculture Organization with having wrought a transformation in the region which could be copied with profit by other Mediterranean countries.

Plans for the construction of a five-wing home, with the latest facilities and comforts, for retired Broadway performers were announced yesterday by Vinton Freedley, president of the Actors Fund of America.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A number of United States citizens living and working abroad are finding themselves liable for Federal income tax that they had become accustomed to not paying.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Joseph Downes, 63 years old, of Moscow, Pa., a former union leader awaiting sentence on a Federal conspiracy charge, died in a hospital today of injuries suffered when his automobile hit a tree.

Trucking concerns hauled 5,761,422 tons of intercity freight in June, a gain of 4.2 per cent from the 5,528,904 tons moved in May, and 21.6 per cent more than the 4,737,542 tons in June, 1958, the American Trucking Associations reported over the weekend.
Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller left for Soegne. Norway, last night to attend the wedding of her son Steven to Anne Marie Rasnussen Saturday.
ELKIN, N. C., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Two automobiles skidded on a curve and rammed head-on early today, killing seven persons and injuring two critically.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The streetwalkers were virtually gone from London today. They were not to be found on many streets in the West End that were crowded with them the night before.
ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Andre Darrigarde of France today won the world professional bicycle road racing championship.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 16 -- A compromise plan for coping with the Caribbean crisis emerged today in the conference of the twenty-one American republics. The compromise sets forth the functions and powers of the Inter-American Peace Commission in dealing with the crisis.
PARIS, Aug. 16 -- Premier Michel Debre said today that France "must be in a position to make herself heard and understood" if she is to "avoid being crushed by agree ments between very great powers."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 16 -- In the capacious files of Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer is a script aptly called "Forever." Owned by Metro since 1940, it has a peculiar function these days.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 16 (AP) -- J. A. Tony Pickard of England today won the Newport Casino invitation tennis tournament singles final, defeating third-seeded Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, 0 -- 6, 6 -- 3.
A Southern Negro college president said yesterday that no group of churches, whether predominantly white or Negro, was doing all it could to solve the problem of race relations.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Aug. 16 -- The labor federation is planning a major modification this week in its policy of full support for the Government's reciprocal trade program. Alarmed by recent increases in imports of goods manufactured in countries with low wage standards, the federation's high command is slated to approve a call for legislation to safeguard domestic production against inroads from foreign "sweatshops."

The Palermo F. C. of Italy, led by Corrado Perli's four goals, trounced the Italia F. C. of Toronto, 7 -- 0, in a soccer match before 5,000 at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. Palermo now has won three straight on its tour of this country and Canada.

ON May 23, 1498, Girolamo Savonarola and two of his most faithful disciples were hanged in the Piazza della Signoria of Florence. As soon as they were dead their bodies were burned. Most of the large crowd approved but enough did not, so that soldiers had to prevent women from scooping up ashes of the condemned heretics as sacred relics.
LOCAL fruit stands are concrete evidence that summer is here.

The House Ways and Means Committee did not find it easy to take the responsible way of financing the interstate highway-building program, but it finally came around. Three days after it had voted 15 to 8 against a temporary increase of 1 cent a gallon in the gasoline tax it reversed itself and voted 16 to 9 to accept a compromise formula that includes the tax rise.
PIETERMARITZBURG, South Africa, Aug. 16, (AP) -- African resentment against white rule erupted in a riot in a village near here today. Two rioters were shot dead and a policeman was wounded.

The great change in Asian attitudes toward communism since the days when Premier Chou of Communist China beguiled the Bandung conference of 1955 with his pleas for "peaceful coexistence" is demonstrated anew by some of the latest developments. The change, building up slowly as Asia watched China sink into slavery, received a tremendous impetus from the Chinese Communist rape of Tibet, which was to Asia what Czechoslovakia and Hungary were to the West.

HAVANA Aug. 16 -- Maj. Raul Castro, commander of Cuban military forces, left by air today for the inter-American foreign ministers' conference in Santiago, Chile.

Bankers who have shown ingenuity in developing new customer services are hopeful of ending an old one, check kiting. Through a kite, a customer creates fictitious bank balances by depositing worth less checks simultaneously or at carefully timed intervals at two or more banks.

I., Aug. 17 -- Seven contemporary homes, built in recent years to meet the requirements of gracious country living in the Hamptons, have been selected for showing in connection with the Architectural Section of the Artists of the Region Exhibition to open on Sunday. It is scheduled by Guild Hall.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The Czech Philharmonic Orchestra, in refusing to play with a Hungarian violin soloist, has abrogated its agreement and will not make its scheduled appearances at the Edinburgh Festival.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A small research device in a back room at the Naval Research Laboratory may have scored the scientific breakthrough that could lead to harnessing the power of the hydrogen bomb.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 17 -- Nathan Leopold was among 11,500 students who started classes today at the University of Puerto Rico in Rio Piedras.

June's business volume was the largest ever written in a single month by the Home Insurance Company, Kenneth E. Black, president, told stockholders yesterday in an interim report for first-half operations. He also reported new highs in consolidated assets, a reduction of over $6,500,000 in underwriting loss and a continued profitable operation in investments.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug 17 -- A trio from Broadway is instigating rebellion in Hollywood. The group wants movie musicals to have the sort of vivacity that is associated with a live performance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- The House adopted today by a vote of 368 to 2 a resolution putting itself again on record as opposing the admission of Communist China into the United Nations.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants increased their National League lead to three games tonight, rallying with five runs in the last three innings for a 6 -- 3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.
BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- Dr. W. Rupert Maclaurin of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology plunged to his death today from the roof of the Sheraton Plaza Hotel. He was 52 yeas old.

SIENA, Italy, Aug. 17 -- The Palio of the Contrade, which was disputed here yesterday, may rank as the most electrifying of all European spectacles. The Palio, held twice a year, is a wild and woolly horse race straight out of the middle ages. The horses, selected by lot, rep-I resent ten sections of the city, and the race sym-I bolizes the poten tiaily violent rivalries among the[ sections. Medieval tactics prevail.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Tempted of the Mooring Stable outraced her field all the way in winning the $56,600 Diana Handicap today. The fine filly had no trouble taking the twenty-first running of the mile-and-a-furlong stakes, finishing more than five lengths ahead of Ned Brent's Polamby, who beat Edward O'Brien's Spar Maid by two-and-a-half lengths.
WASHINGTON SQUARE continues to find eighteenth-century music congenial these hot summer nights.

ONE recent lunchtime, portly Ernest Koves rushed into the glassed-in dining room of the Sulgrave Hotel, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street. Mr. Koves is general manager of the restaurant, now known as Jacque's at the Sulgrave.

Although these hot days would be perfect for three-hour lunches and meetings on golf courses, most agency executives are occupied with internal affairs.

It was a lazy day yesterday in the stock market. Prices edged up for a while and then edged down again to close irregularly lower in aimless trading. Volume hovered around the 2,000,000-share mark for the third straight session.

Wanda Landowska was a musician's musician, but she gave great pleasure to uncounted thousands of simple music-lovers in her long life. The genius she possessed was like that of the child who saw "a world in a grain of sand/And a heaven in a wild flower."

William A. Shea. the organizer of the proposed Continental League that would bring a third major circuit to organized baseball. may seek a teen-club set-up when his group and officials of the National and American Leagues meet today at the Hotel Warwick.
A merchant seaman who shot and killed his wife on Sunday and then committed suicide was identified yesterday as Arthur LeRoy Wright, one of the nine Scottsboro Boys.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -The Senate moved toward passage of a substitute $1,050,000,000 housing bill today after ignoring Republican threats of a veto.

DETROIT, Aug. 17 -- The challenging Year of the Small Car started formally today -- in reverse. For the first press preview of the 1960 models was the showing of General Motors Cadillac, probably the biggest car that will roll off assembly lines.
Danish shipowners, highly competitive in the world's maritime trades, are out of the running in the building race for "super-vessels" spokesmen for Danish operators declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Rules designed to cut the kill of wild ducks by one-third to one-half in the Atlantic, Mississippi and Central flyways during the 1959-60 hunting season were announced today. Only a slight curtailment will be imposed on the Pacific flyway.
BROOKLINE, Mass, Aug. 17 -- With the United States Davis Cup captain Perry Jones, looking on, Alex Olmedo and Earl Buchholz began their quest today for the National Doubles Tennis Championship.
New Yorkers learned yesterday that the city could operate without traffic lights. At some intersections traffic seemed to move more smoothly than it did with the help of traffic lights.
The New York Telephone Company reported that except for doing a roaring-business with a flood of calls, it was unaffected by yesterday's power failure.

There's a bumper crop of new companies this year. Dun Bradstreet, Inc.'s, latest count shows that 119,562 new corporations were formed in the first seven months. This set a record and was up a healthy 44 per cent from the level of a year earlier.
PARIS, Aug. 17 -- French authorities are concerned over possible consequences the American steel strike may have on United States economic and financial policies.
Archie Moore, the world light-heavyweight boxing champion, is a well-spoken man, considering that he never had time to read or pay much attention to schools.

Mary Martin, whose former television contract with the National Broadcasting Company was terminated in 1957, has agreed to star in two shows for the same network. Although neither has been scheduled, one will be "Peter Pan."
Thousands of extra policemen and detectives were assigned to emergency duty last night to ward off possible outbreaks of crime in city areas plunged into darkness by power failure.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Seaboard Finance Company reported today net income for the nine months ended June 30 of $5,935,882, or $1.10 a share. This compared with $5,706,256, or $1.12 a share, a year before. Volume of business was $332,377,261, compared with $297,880,602.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Scientists lighted an orangeyellow sodium flare 150 miles above the earth at dawn today and startled early risers along a 1,400-mile sweep of the Atlantic seaboard.
Copper prices turned sharply lower yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Final quotations were 122 to 136 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) lower on 541 lots.

MONTREAL, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press) -- James Muir, chairman and president of the Royal Bank of Canada, says curtailment of credit has been forced on chartered banks by tight money coupled with the 6 per cent legal ceiling on the lending rates of chartered banks.

HAVANA, Aug. 17 -- A writ of habeas corpus was granted late today by the Havana Court of Appeals for Armando Cainas Milanes, former president of the Cattlemen's Association, who is being held for counter-revolutionary activities.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 17 -- Haiti asked the Organization of American States tonight to intervene in the invasion of her territory by a small band of rebels from Cuba.

The Board of Education has taken the only defensible position in supporting the Superintendent of Schools in his decision to transfer some students to Queens from overcrowded classrooms in Brooklyn. Some of these pupils are also being sent out of their own neighborhood into other Brooklyn schools.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Brookfield Farm's In Thee set an American record for five and one-half furlongs on the grass today in winning the President Purse at the Atlantic City race course in 1:03 2/5.

Quebec Natural Gas Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to spend $12,325,000 on construction and improvements in fiscal 1960. This was disclosed in the annual report for the year ended June 30, issued yesterday.
Loss of hydraulic pressure after take-off forced a South America-bound Boeing 707 jet airliner carrying 122 persons to return to New York International Air port yesterday.
The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday suspended the matchmaker's license of Bill Rosensohn and the promotor's license of the company he used to head, Rosensohn Enterprises, Inc.
The power failure brought a host of household inconveniences to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Soll of 164 West Seventy-ninth Street. But it was a picnic for their two children.

Directors of the United Fruit Company voted yesterday to omit the regular quarterly dividend that would have been paid on Oct. 15. Shareholders had been receiving a dividend of 50 cents quarterly, the last of which was distributed on July 15.

While the Senate still wrestles with mutual security appropriations, cut by the House below safety levels, the Eisenhower Administration has launched another major project designed to enlist the whole free world in helping its under-developed members to develop their full potential in freedom while at the same time relieving the United States of some of the increasingly onerous burden of "foreign aid."

Hundreds of residents west of the Hudson River had their own power problems last night. Their trouble was caused by a violent storm that swept trees down on power lines and plunged homes into darkness.

New York's subways escaped the full brunt of yesterday's Consolidated Edison power failure, but about 125,000 passengers on the IND lines to upper Manhattan and the Bronx were subjected to slowed-down service.
WHAT many people consider the sweetest and most delicate of herbs is now available wherever fresh herbs are sold.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that fewer pigs should be raised in 1960 but that it opposed legislation to provide a guarantee of $14 a hundred pounds to producers.

Clark, Dodge Co. and associated investment bankers offered to the public yesterday 280,000 shares of non-voting class B common stock of Hugh W. Long Co., Inc., Elizabeth, N. J., at $32 a share. The company has a contract to manage open-end investment companies with net assets of $735,000,000. The companies are Fundamental Investors, Inc., Diversified Investment Fund, Inc., and Diversified Growth Stock Fund, Inc.
A major part of Manhattan was only a dark and grotesque image of its usual glittering self last night. To many it looked like a wartime dim-out.
The problem of race relations involves the question of "whether you want to be a flag waver or whether you want to be a humanist so you can live with the other fellow, even if he's different."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -The Chairman of the House subcommittee that is considering the health-for-peace bill said today that it would not be passed at this session unless there was a change in the attitude of the Administration.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the counsel to the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority could act as director of the Committee on Slum Clearance, provided his slum work was full time.

THE home seamstress is in for a whirl at Stern's. To celebrate the opening next Monday of the store's new "one-stop" sewing center -- all departments related to sewing and allied arts will be grouped on the fourth floor -- a series of fashion shows and how-to-do-it clinics will be held next week and the week thereafter.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 17 -- An Indian Communist party leader accused Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today of a "partisan" attitude in dismissing the Communist regime in the State of Kerala.
New York Typographical Union Six yesterday accused David Minkin, New York real estate operator, of delaying construction of a 700-family housing cooperative in Woodside, Queens.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) to 2 points up yesterday after holding in a narrow range all day.
Some of New York's major hospitals demonstrated yesterday that they could keep functioning without city power -- for a time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- The House Space Committee is investigating the Government's decision to write off its search for high-energy fuels for future atomic bombers after spending $200,000,000 on the project.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 17 -- Francis H. Bloeth's lawyer said today that Bloeth had confessed to new crimes. At the same time he reiterated that Bloeth was insane and not responsible for the slaying of three robbery victims.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 17 -- The Rev. Dr. Israel Goldstein of New York said here today that he would devote himself to efforts toward setting up a world academy for peace.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- No matter where Premier Nikita S. Krushchev decides to go in the United States, he already is assured of a crowd on hand.
Moscow, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Soviet film "Destiny of Man" has won the Gold Medal Grand Prize in the First International Film Festival here, it was announced today.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he would base his decision on whether to seek the Presidency on his own evaluation of his ability to render effective and constructive public service, not on any public opinion polls.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Treasury announced tonight the marketing of two issues of bills. The average interest cost of the ninety-one-day issue was the highest since the bills dated Nov. 14, 1957.
Four foreign students returned here yesterday from a 14,000-mile tour of the United States and reported that the country's greatest appeal lay in the hospitality of the average home.
Queens political and civic leaders held a two-hour conference with aviation authorities yesterday on the airport noise problem in that borough.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- A spokesman for the Laotian delegation said today that Laos would try "other methods" if Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold found it impossible to send an observer to investigate the border fighting.
Most television and radio stations were not affected by the failure in the city yesterday.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 7 -- A Hollywood contingent of 59ers has invaded Alaska to make the motion-picture version of Edna Ferber's "Ice Palace."

All American Engineering Directors of All American Engineering Company have agreed to acquire Hyair Corporation, Glendale, Calif., Charles W. Wendt, president of All American, said yesterday in Wilmington, Del.
If three of the articles appearing on the editorial page of The Times of Aug. 14 were read in sequence the reader probably would be shocked; he certainly would have cause to think.

ALGIERS, Aug. 17 -- The controversial French offensive in Kabylia has put 1,015 nationalist guerrilla fighters "out of action" in the twenty-five days since it got under way, the French Army announced tonight.

Mayor Wagner told 127 graduates of the Police Academy yesterday that he had the fullest confidence in Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy and in the way the department was handling tense situations in the city.
The missile age has already had its effects on activities in the merchant marine industry, the Seafarers Log, official organ of the Seafarers International Union, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Soybean and rye futures tumbled into fairly good size losses again today on the Board of Trade as selling gathered speed shortly before the closing gong. They finished at or near their lows for the day.

RUMSON, N. J., Aug. 17 -- The Sears Cup national junior sailing champion, Kevin Jaffe of the Noroton Conn.) Yacht Club, and Bill Parke of the Point o' Woods (L. I.) Yacht Club were tied today after the first two races of the area semi- finals on the Shrewsbury River.

Sales of shares in mutual funds in July rose to $220,776,000 from $181,577,000 in June and $160,675,000 in July, 1958, the National Association of Investment Companies reported yesterday. This was the second time this year that volume topped $200,000,000 in a single month.

A second speed-up program to relieve the congested Federal Court calendar in the Eastern District of New York will get under way Sept. 14. It will be similar to the three-month program that ended last July, in which eleven out-of-town jurists disposed of nearly 700 cases.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 -The City of Angels re-staked its claim on the 1960 Democratic National Convention tonight in a comic climax to weeks of feverish backstage maneuvering in party circles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Senate agreed today to devote at least one week to seeking an agreement with the House of Representatives on a labor reform bill.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- The House gave final approval today to a compromise bill carrying $128,797,380 to pay Congress' operating costs in the current year.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Eight of the fourteen members of the editorial board of Philosophical Questions, a journal of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, have been removed in what appears to be a major shake-up.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- A few minutes after a Soviet court had dismissed his claim for royalties for the estate of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle today, Prof. Harold Joseph Berman lit a straight, unholmesian pipe and decided that he was not sorry he had traveled to Moscow twice in the last year to try to overcome the Soviet Union's reluctance to pay foreign authors whose works it publishes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -Tactical moves in the Senate today apparently assured a showdown on civil rights legislation before this session of Congress adjourned.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 17 -- In its sedate way, the West German stock market has gone wild this summer.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 17 -- The Town of Oyster Bay, which still has a potential of growth, is planning to retain its suburban atmosphere despite the possibilities for residential and industrial development.

WASHINGTON Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads said today that its members had overwhelmingly accepted a plan for insurance against financial losses from strikes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, said today that the Senate rackets committee should end the secrecy of its closed investigation of the United Auto Workers union.
ADEN, Aug. 17 -- The Imam of Yemen has dealt strongly with rebel elements who tried to overthrow the regime during his absence, according to reports from Yemen.

FRONT ROYAL, Va., Aug. 17 -- On the last day of a threeday registration period 186 white pupils signed up for classes at Warren County High School. In all, 298 white pupils and eighteen Negro students have enrolled for the next session, which is scheduled to begin on Aug. 31.
LITTLE ROCK, Aug. 17 -Students at Little Rock's public high schools began a second week of integrated classes today virtually without incident.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 17 -- Adios Oregon drew the pole position today for next Friday's Messenger Stake. Tom Crank, who will drive Adios Oregon in the $112,494 pace at Roosevelt Raceway, was not present at the drawing. If he had, he would have been most happy.
The tightening of money in the short-term borrowing area depressed the market for United States Government securities yesterday. The dip extended in a diminishing way to the long-terms.

The drive of American maritime unions against ships flying the flags of Panama and Liberia has benefited Great Britain's campaign to regain her position as the world's first maritime power. This was indicated yesterday in an analysis of tanker launchings and deliveries.

HOW to fit lots of belongings into little storage space is a current challenge to every family. But, when such a problem confronts the one-room apartment dweller, it seems destined to be a lost cause.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 18 -- President Eisenhower told Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India today that he hoped his exchange of visits with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev would help create better understanding between the United States and the Soviet Union.
The probable return of the International Longshoremen's Association to the merged labor federation next month produced at least two mysteries yesterday in waterfront circles here.
New York and Viriginia investment bankers are forming a syndicate to finance the construction of a seventeen-mile bridge and tunnel crossing at the mouth of Chesapeake Bay.

The city has called upon the Consolidated Edison Company to report today on the cause of the power failure that blacked out five square miles of upper Manhattan Monday night and disrupted the lives of 500,000 people.

After months of procrastination and delay the Board of Estimate has at last set the date of Aug. 20 for the final hearing on the Peter J. Warbasse Cooperative Housing Development, sponsored by the United Housing Foundation. Even though this worthy project was approved by the City Planning Commission more than a year ago, it is only now put on the calendar for the August meeting of the Board of Estimate.
A newly expanded committee of seventy-five leaders in the city's business, industrial and civil life acted yesterday to form the New York World's Fair 1964 Corporation.

Sales and earnings of the United States Plywood Corporation rose to record levels in the three months ended on July 31, the company reported yesterday. Earnings in the period, the first quarter of the company's fiscal year, rose 95 per cent above those of the period last year. Sales were up 35 per cent.
The Government's chief labor peacemaker acknowledged yesterday that the outlook in the national steel strike was "distinctly gloomy."
Slowly but surely the mutual funds have increased their proportionate holdings of the 299 billions of common and preferred stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Consumers Power Company, Jackson, Mich., sold yesterday $35,000,000 of 30-year first mortgage bonds to a group headed jointly by White, Weld Co. and Shields Co. The price was 99.5399 for obligations bearing 4 5/8 per cent interest coupons.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 18 -- Warner M. Willcox of the Orienta Yacht Club today qualified for the North American sailing championship. The final, for the Clifford D. Mallory Trophy, will he held at Kemah, Tex., next month.

Even before the advent of sound films, movie men have envisioned the possibility of adding another dimension to motion pictures -- that of smell.
