Every few years some adventuresome producer has tried it. But these early efforts usually have involved only one odor filtered crudely from a single source with unpromising results.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 (AP) -- "Frankly, I'm surprised." That was the reaction of Branch Rickey Jr. to the news that his father today had been named president of the Continental Baseball League.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- Ceteka, the official Czechoslovak news agency, said today that the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra has refused to appear at the Edinburgh Festival next month with a Hungarian soloist, because she has fascist ties.
PARIS, Aug. 18 -- The United States and France have successfully concluded negotiations designed to simplify and encourage reciprocal individual and corporate activity in the two countries.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- The United States notified the Latin-American delegations today that the Big Four needed additional time to work out the relationship between the proposed ten-nation committee on disarmament and the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Hawaii will become the Union's fiftieth state at 4 P.M. Friday, Eastern daylight time.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Moscow broadcast a warning today that missile-bearing Soviet submarines could enter Hudson Bay from under the Arctic ice and bombard the industrial heart of America.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 18 -- Dag Hammarskjold's plan for economic aid to the Palestinian Arab refugees was squelched by solid Arab resistance today.
Branch Rickey was named president of the Continental League yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A conference committee of the Senate and the House of Representatives disposed of the easier but necessary chores today in seeking agreement on a labor reform bill.

At noon on Monday Mayor Wagner, addressing graduates of the Police Academy, used the occasion to express "the fullest confidence" in Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy and to compliment him on the way his department was handling tense situations in the city. By mid-afternoon one of those "tense situations," not quite the kind the Mayor had in mind, had developed in the electric power failure that blacked out large areas of upper Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Eisenhower's request for authority to raise interest rates on Government bonds was shelved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.
The Maritime Administration announced yesterday that it had received only one bid for the purchase of the liner Leilani.
The owners of twenty-six slum tenements in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn have been haled into court as a result of a city inspection of the buildings.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Eisenhower has advanced the departure time for his European trip by half a day to permit an overnight stay at Bonn Aug. 26.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 18 -- A community effort to find homes for new teachers in the public schools here got under way today.

The directors of the Beryllium Corporation proposed a 2-for-1 split of the common stock yesterday. They called a special meeting of stockholders for Sept. 29 to consider an increase in the authorized stock to make the split possible.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The reorganized Railway Express Agency put before the Interstate Commerce Commission today plans for a self-sustaining operation designed to bring about solvency from improved small-shipment service.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he was "satisfied there was no collusion or any wrong-doing" in the designation of a business associate of New York racketeers as the sponsor of a slum-clearance project.
PAULSBORO, N. J., Aug. 18 -- Two children died in a fire today when they were trapped in a second-floor bedroom of a two-story apartment house.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 18 -- Maj. Raul Castro, commander in chief of Cuba's military forces, flew into Santiago late this afternoon, five hours after the adjournment of the conference of American foreign ministers here.

BLUE-JEANS, the most durable and once the most wholesome kind of American clothes, are getting a bad name. Through no fault of their own, these sturdy adjuncts to the family wardrobe have fallen into disrepute.
BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, held out hope today for the eventual introduction of some measure of personal justice in dictatorships.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The House of Representatives passed a bill today to exempt news programs from "equal-time" provisions of the Federal Communications Act.
Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons announced last night that he would ask the city to abandon plans to build a parking lot on Marion Avenue near Fordham Road.
WEST YELLOWSTONE, Mont., Aug. 18 -- A series of earthquakes struck here last night and early today, burying campers alive and trapping other vacationists between landslides and vanished roads.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange held steady yesterday. They closed 3 points up to 2 points off, compared with Monday's final levels. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.) Old crop months showed the most strength.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- The bookmobile, a major attraction for tens of thousands of Soviet visitors, was closed down today at the American National Exhibition here because there were not enough books left.

Federal mediators today will reopen the stalemated negotiations between the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America and the shipbuilding division of the Bethlehem Steel Company. The disputing parties have not met in a week.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 17 -- The Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland is experiencing an economic squeeze that is causing hardship in many quarters.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the power failure Monday emphasized the importance of public support for a hospital.

JONES BEACH, L. I. Aug. 18 -- A group of state budget officers from across the nation, who are attending a conference in New York City, came to the beach with their families today and heard a welcoming talk by Robert Moses.
A televised tribute to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is being planned on the occasion of her seventy-fifth birthday, although the intended guest of honor wants no part of the project.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy charged yesterday that police efficiency and law enforcement were being "seriously hampered" by the city's failure to replace dilapidated station houses and other outmoded police facilities.
LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 18 -- For thousands of families in suburban Long Island, summer living has acquired new dimensions through the beach club.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged yesterday that two brokerage houses here had violated securities regulations in promoting the sale of the stock of the Anaconda Lead and Silver Company, Denver, Colo.

STRATFORD - ON - AVON, England, Aug. 18 -- Charles Laughton broke new ground tonight by appearing as King Lear in the final production of this centenary season at the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre here.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- A treasury report on Britain's economic health in mid-1959 presented the picture today of a Government pleased with the present and encouraged at the future.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Administration decided today to make public the results of its fact-finding survey in the steel dispute, hoping the findings would speed a settlement of the five-week strike.
Civil Defense authorities and hospital directors were pondering yesterday the lessons of Monday's power failure in upper Manhattan.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Officials of Chicago hospitals, faced with strike threats, said today that they would not meet or bargain with union officials.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The grain futures market went adrift again today in the absence of sufficient influences to guide dealers on the Board of Trade.

A new book by Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr, "The Structure of Nations and Empires," will be issued next Wednesday by Scribner. It is a study of the perennial patterns, the recurring problems and varied "but similar" structures of the political order with reference to the perplexities of our nuclear age.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee began hearings today on a measure already passed by the House to halt the growth of savings and loan holding companies. The prospects for Senate passage are considered good.
DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia, Aug. 14 -- "Those who look for paradise on earth should come and see Dubrovnik."
The construction of a twelve-story teacher-education center is under consideration by the Board of Higher Education.
SOEGNE, Norway, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Nelson Rockefeller sailed to a tiny island today and saw the birthplace of Anne Marie Rasmussen.

Trading in a new issue of common stock of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation began on a "when-issued" basis on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The shares will continue on that basis until Jan. 3, 1961, when they will be issued in exchange for convertible preferred stock of the automobile manufacturer.
Plans of the Ford International division to build a truck assembly plant in Turkey were announced yesterday along with forecasts of improvements in American automotive exports.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The International Sugar Council ruled today that unsold sugar from 1959 export quotas could be added to the 1960 quota year. The carry-over is limited to 10 per cent of the 1959 quota.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- George Friedland announced today his resignation as vice chairman of Food Fair Stores, Inc. He will continue as a director, but has relinquished the vice chairmanship to devote more time to philanthropic and civic projects.

VICTORIA, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press) -- A. P. Davidson, chief of the Resources Division of the Northern Affairs Department, today described the discovery of oil and gas in the Yukon as "encouraging, perhaps a major development."
Short-term yields on United States Government securities rose sharply for the second successive day yesterday as a consequence of persisting stringency in the money market.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- A Soviet spokesman charged today that the United States had tried to use the inter-American foreign ministers' conference in Santiago, Chile, to overthrow the Fidel Castro regime in Cuba.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 18 -- A Soviet offer of a large credit to Bolivia's hard-pressed state oil company has blown up a political storm.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Another instance of the old order changing -- even here in the stronghold of turf traditionalism -- will be on view tomorrow with the running of the Saratoga Special.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Drew Pearson charged today that the General Electric Company's "inside influence" in the Pentagon was a major reason for the United States failure to beat the Soviet Union in launching an earth satellite.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Senate Rackets Committee reversed itself today and voted to admit the public to its investigations of the United Auto Workers Union.

Thirty-three inspectors of the Brooklyn office of the Department of Buildings submitted financial questionnaires "under protest" yesterday to the rackets grand jury that has been investigating graft and corruption in the office.
B. H. Gordon, realty operator, has sold the gasoline service station with three bays at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, Brooklyn.
HAVANA, Aug. 18 -- The civil courts of Cuba have begun trying the several thousand persons arrested in the conspiracy that was broken up last week by the Government.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 -- The Yankees, fighting desperately to maintain their slender hold on the American League's first division, turned back the Tigers tonight, 5 to 3, in the opener of a three-game series before a crowd of 37,353.

OTTAWA, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Discovery of oil and gas in the Yukon, about 200 miles northeast of the 1898 gold-rush town of Dawson, has been announced by Canada's Minister of Resources, Alvin Hamilton.
The Manassa Mauler pounded his fist on a table in his Broadway restaurant yesterday and announced that he was back in the fight business.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- In accordance with Davis Cup regulations the captains for the United States and Australia named their teams today, ten days before the challenge round match at Forest Hills, Queens.

On Aug. 7 you published a report on the findings of Dr. Harold F. Dorn, a Government research scientist, on the relation of smoking to the death rate. The study, according to your account, covered nearly 200,000 veterans whose smoking habits had been ascertained before their death.

Many dinner parties will precede the Boys Harbor benefit on Monday at the American premiere of the British comedy "Gilt and Gingerbread," at the John Drew Theatre, East Hampton, L. I. Hostesses will include Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson, Mrs. Stuyvesant Wainwright and Mrs. A. W. Baxter.

The Executive Council of the A. F. L.-C. I. O. has probably made a wise move in proposing a reprieve from banishment for the International Longshoremen's Association, subject to approval by the federation convention next month. But that the reprieve would be conditional shows the case for readmission has not been fully established.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Tropical storm Edith's weakened winds by-passed Puerto Rico tonight and caused a hurricane watch to be set for Hispaniola.

11 A. M.: "Dolls of Many Lands" and "Farm Animals," two films, will be shown at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place. Other films will be shown at 2 and 4 P. M. and again at these hours tomorrow, Friday, Monday and Tuesday.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Aug. 18 -- George Meany predicted today that Congress would pass a "killer" bill on labor reform. The president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial, Organizations virtually threw in the towel in the fight against the Administration-backed Landrum-Griffin bill.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 18 -- New Zealand had a big surplus with the dollar area in the trade year that ended on June 30. Unless dollar restrictions are eased, the surplus may be even larger in the present year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Senate sent to the White House today a bill to increase the pensions of 70 per cent of the veterans now receiving monthly payments for disabilities not connected with war services.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., Aug. 18 (AP) -- A gasoline storage tank, ignited by a burning filling station, exploded and speweed flames 200 feet into a group of firemen today.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 18 -- The Laotian Army reported today that Communist rebels were on the march again in the northeastern provinces.
DURBAN, South Africa, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- African women set up roadblocks and attacked workers in the fields today as a wave of anti-Government violence continued through its fifth day.
Were the Germans who participated in the July, 1944, abortive attempt to kill Hitler traitors or heroes of their country? No other question has been more actively debated in post-war Germany.

PARIS, Aug. 18 -- In a memorandum handed to President Charles de Gaulle Sunday the Soviet Government is said to have expressed sympathetic feelings for him and the opinion that France ought to have a place in the world commensurate with her importance.
THE Federal Government's announcement of the outside limits of duck and goose seasons for the four flyways brought from North Carolina yesterday a reaction of remarkable speed and vigor.

HACKENSACK, Aug. 18 -- A petition to recall Mayor Edgar P. Deuell and the City Council was filed today with City Clerk Ethel M. Hoyt. The election will be held in forty or fifty days, if the signatures of the petitioners prove to be valid.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Rip Repulski of the Los Angeles Dodgers drove in the winning run with a single in the Thirteenth inning tonight to defeat the Milwaukee Braves, 7 -- 6. The Braves had tied the cout twice, once when Don Demeter dropped an easy pop fly and the second time on Henry Aaron's second homer of the night.

A power failure of the magnitude that blacked out a 500-block area in upper Manhattan Monday could happen again, but the odds against such a recurrence are "infinitesimal," according to Consolidated Edison officials.

THE talk that goes on across a bridge table immediately after a hand has been played, known in the vernacular as a post-mortem, is often eloquent but is not always conclusive. Some of the arguments remind one of the jocular definition of positive: Wrong at the top of one's voice.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 -- The dust from the Democratic convention ticket dispute began to clear today, leaving a whodunit still unsolved.

Everybody has heard about the man who wore shoes a size too small because he felt so much better when he took them off. Well, that's the way it is with summer vacations. New York always seems so much more wonderful after one has been away from it.
Three young Europeans with a yen for the life of a United States Marine were sworn in yesterday for four years of service several thousand miles away from home.

Large-scale paralysis from the kind of power failure that hit the city Tuesday night is "unlikely" in many of the surrounding communities, according to a survey made yesterday of utility companies. However, most of the population in New Jersey could suffer a similar fate.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- The Franklin Institute announced today that Dr. Charles H. Townes, a physics professor at Columbia University, had been chosen to receive a Stuart Ballantine Medal.

A bank building with a glass facade will be constructed by Fred Rudinger just north of the intersection of Herricks Avenue, at Hillside Avenue, Herricks, L. I. It has been leased to the Hempstead Bank of Hempstead, L. I., for a branch.
HONG KONG, Aug. 18 -- Communist China is believed to be coping successfully with one of the worst droughts in mainland China in several decades.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Prime Minister Ibrahim Nasir of the Maldive Islands has turned down an invitation to visit London and work out an agreement on the construction of a British air base in the island group.

TRENTON, Aug. 18 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today that surplus funds of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority over the next ten years would be sufficient to put the state's commuter railroads "on their feet."

General Mills, Inc., will invest some $70,785,000 over the next three years for capital expansion and improvement, Charles H. Bell, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Minneapolis, Minn.
A four-engined plane carrying twelve passengers and five crew members from Buenos Aires landed safely at New York International Airport in Idlewild, Queens, yesterday with one engine dead.
DETROIT, Aug. 18 -- A redesigned high-compression engine that will operate on regular-grade gasoline will be featured by Oldsmobile in its lowest-priced 1960 line.

ROME, Aug. 18 -- Roman Catholic ecclesiastics and laymen here ahve formed a committee to promote the beatification of the late Pope Pius XII, it was learned today. No prominent churchman is in the group, but it is understood that it has found encouragement in high Vatican quarters.
New program were announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation to assist ballet dancers, creative writers and directors in the professional theatre and theatre architects and designers.
Merger talks between the International Longshoremen's Association and its rival of the last six years, the International Brotherhood of Longshoremen, will take place in Chicago next Thursday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 19 -- The Democratic candidate for Oyster Bay Town Supervisor asked Governor Rockefeller today to investigate "abuses" in the leasing of town-owned shorefront property to private individuals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Aug. 12:
UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Aug. 19 -- The high command of United States labor is split on whether to snub Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev when he visits this country next month.

Through news of the United Nations World Refugee Year The Times has helped its readers to visualize this great human problem, which calls for a human solution. Your fine editorial "A Year for Refugees," called it "an opportunity to make it even more successful and to reap an even richer reward of moral and human satisfaction."

POINT O' WOODS, L.I., Aug. 19 -- Stuart Brayshaw skippered his Babylon Yacht Club crew to three straight victories today as the six-race series for the Picken Trophy, emblematic of the Midget championship of Great South Bay, got under way.

The beagle is one of the smallest of the hound breeds. But he is the biggest --numerically -- in field trial work in America. This year there will be 420 American Kennel Club licensed field trials for this miniature foxhound, each sponsored by an individual club.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- Davey Moore retained the world featherweight championship tonight by stopping Hogan (Kid) Bassey in the eleventh round of their scheduled fifteen-round bout.
"Alas Babylon," a story adapted from the novel by Pat Frank, has been canceled as the opening "Playhouse 90" drama of the new season.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- A study of the diet habits of various peoples and their effects on infant mortality and other factors now has been launched here.
The American Museum of Natural History is hoping to use "instant animals" in some of its future exhibits.
ALBANY, Thursday, Aug. 20 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today the appointment of three members to the reconstituted State Harness Racing Commission.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that operating revenues had increased 6.9 per cent and net income 3.4 per cent in the twelve months ended JulyI 31. Electric operating revenues were 8.3 per cent above the 1958 level

SAMNEUA, Laos, Aug. 19 -- Fighting is going on in this area between the Laotian Army and dissidents led by Communists from North Vietnam. The dissidents are tribesmen and Communist-oriented Pathet Lao troops.

THERE are some sneaky knitters in Brooklyn. Among the more than 500 men, women and children who pour into Abraham Straus' Art-Needlework Department weekly are wives to whom knitting needles are as foreign as chopsticks. They do not knit; neither do they sew. They are merely picking up yarn for their husbands.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 19 -- Some movie studios here are becoming literary supermarkets for Europeans in search of bargains in scripts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, made public today statistical data bearing on the issues in the five-week-old steel strike. His report said that steel wages and prices were running ahead of those in industry generally.
I do not want to dispute the wisdom of your editorial of Aug. 18 on the power breakdown, but being one of those affected by it I have some questions to ask.
TO have a hat with a Paris label is an enduring dream of the American woman. Franklin Simon's millinery buyer has arranged to make that dream come true.
The Democratic reform group headed by former Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is planning to extend its operations upstate after the Sept. 15 primary.

The Board of Estimate will hold a public hearing today on competitive offers for building the $70,000,000 James Peter Warbasse Houses in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn. Since these houses have been under one form or another of official consideration for about two years, the board should act without further delay.

The Albany news conference which Governor Rockefeller called this week to dispel what he termed an "inaccurate" report of the tests on which he will decide whether to seek the Republican nomination for President next year can serve more than its immediate purpose for the Governor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Democratic leaders have quietly dropped plans for House passage of a civil rights bill at this session.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 14 -- The regime of Marshal Tito is planning to abandon the practice of uneconomically low rents.
DECORATING is a business. Just as a physician's diagnosis or a lawyer's advice costs money, so do pretty color schemes or floor plans for furniture.

The esteemed Times records on Aug. 15 that "twenty-seven administrators of rural schools criticized private and parochial schools as inherently undemocratic." The conference was held at Teachers College, Columbia University.
The construction of an $800,000 Chinese Community Center in modern style -- contrasting sharply with the decaying tenements surrounding it -- was begun yesterday in Chinatown.

"MAYBE I talk too much," said Branch Rickey, a compulsive talker. "Now that I think back on it I guess I did dominate the conversation with Ford Frick's joint committee yesterday. But we accomplished our objective."

The J. M. Tenney Corpora-tion, national realty investment company, has purchased the leasehold on the fifteen-story and penthouse, office building at 527 Madison Avenue. southeast corner of Fifty-fourth Street.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 -- Three capitalists went on display at the American National Exhibition today.
PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- The New York City Board of Education carried its campaign for public support of the $500,000,000 school bond issue upstate today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- The United States would be guilty of "the worst kind of folly" if it lowered its guard because of the exchange of visits between President Eisenhower and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, Neil H. McElroy warned today.

DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia, Aug. 15 -- Anyone seeking a cross-section of the performing arts in this country can find it here. Organized in 1950 for exactly that purpose, the Dubrovnik Summer Festival shows off the achievements in the nation's different republics in drama, music and dance.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The visit of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to the United States will last twelve days, and will begin and end in Washington.

BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- A chartered British airliner carrying students home from vacations in Spain crashed into a fog-shrouded mountain and exploded today. All thirty-two persons were reported killed.

ENNIS, Mont., Aug. 19 -Campers trying to rescue a New York minister's son who was trapped by logs in the path of flood waters two nights ago gave up as the water reached the boy's lips and all began to pray.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 19 -- President Eisenhower will appear with Prime Minister Harold Macmillan in a televised talk Aug. 31 during the President's visit to Britain, the White House announced today.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 19 -A special military court tonight sentenced five Iraqi Army officers to death by a firing squad and one civilian to death by hanging.
HONG KONG, Aug. 19 -- The last six months have brought extensive changes in Communist China's communes.

Two new passengers booked passage yesterday on the trans-atlantic air shuttle to Goteborg, Sweden. They were Archie Moore, the world light-heavyweight champion, and his manager, Jack Kearns, who want to arrange a Moore fight with Ingemar Johansson, the world heavyweight champion.

THE bluefish have come to rest again, at least momentarily, this time off Atlantic Highlands, N.J., in the neighborhood of The Cedars. A fisherman with plenty of foot might get there in time to take a few of them.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Varying in size and ranging in age from 9 to 20 years, a record field of ninety-four teed off in the Westchester County Golf Association's junior championship today.
Sales of Mohasco Industries, Inc., leading carpet and rug maker, rose $7,428,808 in the first half of this year from the 1958 level. Earnings increased $4,362,020, the company reported yesterday.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 19 -The defenders, Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century and Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Meadow Brook, failed to survive the opening round of match play in the thirteenth annual four-ball, best-ball championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today.

HONESDALE, Pa., Aug. 19 -- The $4,000,000 Dyberry Dam, first of several dams being built by the Corps of Army Engineers to protect Pennsylvania watersheds, was dedicated today. The project is three miles north of here.
The bond market was inactive yesterday. Prices tended to drift down.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Thursday, Aug. 20 -- The Alliance party was returned to power in Malaya yesterday with a strong mandate to lead the nation for the next five years.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Aug. 19 -- The largest tanker ever constructed for American-flag operation slid into the James River this morning.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Even under the new conditions, the Saratoga Special belongs to Eddie Arcaro. The excellent jockey won the $60,590 stakes today aboard the Pebblebrook Farm's Irish Lancer. The achievement marked Eddie's seventh triumph in the Special, which in the past was a winner-take-all event.
Admiral Arthur W. Radford, the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said yesterday that the forthcoming visit of Nikita S. Khrushchev could either endanger world peace or contribute to it.

BRIDGE would be a much less interesting game if the bidding were more accurate. Nearly every contract would be a dull play-off. A bit of overbidding creates opportunities for skillful declarer's play and careful defense.

The Anaconda Wire and Cable Company has leased space for a district sales office in rthe new building at 360 Lexing- ton Avenue, corner of Fortieth Street. Bertram F. French and Harold W. Cruickshank of Cush- man Wakefield, Inc., were the brokers.
IZMIR, Turkey, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Four United States servicemen accused of black-market currency operations went on trial here today before a civil criminal court.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 19 -A retired army officer who has become a radio commentator was arrested today for broadcasting a proposal that the sale of surplus arms to a Canadian concern be investigated.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Khrushchev visit to the Iowa farm of Roswell Garst will cause a housing problem. Coon Rapids has no hotel and only one motel. The population is about 1,700.

MOST, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 19 -- This is a town dominated by steaming heaps of coal slag, the sour smoke of chemical factories, the pounding at housing developments -- and the memory of a piece of paper signed twenty-one years ago.
City Administrator Charles F. Preusse was instructed by Mayor Wagner yesterday to determine the feasibility of surveying the "broad network of social and welfare services" within the city.
A would-be robber who tried to steal a $2,600 payroll was put to rout yesterday when he tripped over his own bullets and fell before an attack of feathers. It happened in Brooklyn.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Stock market prices continued their advance here today and gains of up to a shilling (14 cents) were common.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter and at least three other foreign ministers will discuss current international developments with the Permanent Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Sept. 4 during President Eisenhower's visit to Paris.
WEST YELLOWSTONE, Mont., Aug. 19 (UPI) -- Rescue workers, arriving by air and ground, joined the search today for victims or survivors of the series of heavy earthquakes that started last Monday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The State Department suggested "Soviet complicity" today in the Communist military activity in northern Laos.

New York State furthered the permanent financing of the Thruway yesterday by borrowing in the public market $50,000,000 on long-term and serial bonds secured only by the toll revenues and other earnings of the expressway.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points up to 1 point off yesterday, with near months strongest. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.)
TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Westchester County has discovered that its skunks have not adjusted to all the refinements of suburban living. Two of them fell into swimming pools here yesterday.

Residents who face the destruction of their homes in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn where the city has approved a $20,000,000 industrial park, sued the city yesterday. They contended that the 1958 state law permitting the development was unconstitutional.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds scored seven runs in the eighth inning tonight and whipped the Los Angeles Dodgers, 9-4, after a brilliant relief pitching stint by Orlando Pena.

The Mergenthaler Linotype Company, direct beneficial owner of more than 10 per cent of the common stock of the Electric Auto-Lite Company, increased its holdings in the latter concern last month by 27,000 shares, bringing the total to 327,500 shares.

QUONSET POINT, R.I., Aug. 19 -- Two crewmen on the aircraft carrier Wasp were killed and twenty-one were injured in an explosion and fire yesterday afternoon while the ship was on anti-submarine maneuvers in the Atlantic.
LONDON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- The National Council of Civil Liberties intervened in a case today to determine whether a person had a right to stand on a street corner.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The United States protested to Communist China and North Korea again tonight against the June 16 attack on a United States Navy patrol plane.

Houston Lighting Power Company, Houston, Tex., borrowed $25,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance construction. The utility sold first mortgage bonds maturing in 1989 to a banking syndicate headed jointly by Lehman Brothers, Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. and Salomon Bros. Hutzler.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Representative Frank Thompson Jr. was squirted with acid yesterday morning by a man who leaned from a truck at a stoplight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- According to a somewhat cynical aphorism, there are "lies, big lies and statistics." But the implications of that aphorism have never been applied to the man in charge of today's lengthy compilation of the facts behind the steel strike.

Marketing representatives of leading oil companies are interested in, but certainly not enthusiastic about, plans of a leading food store chain to open a group of gasoline stations in connection with its supermarket operations.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Aug. 19 -- The political arm of the merged labor federation held its quarterly meeting here today in an atmosphere of dismay much different from the elation that followed labor's "victory" in the Congressional elections last November.
State and city officials supported the Uniformed Firemen's Association yesterday in its campaign to win higher wages and better working conditions.

TRENTON, Aug. 19 -- The rie Railroad applied to the State Public Utility Commission today to increase its intrapate passenger fares. The request was similar to one filed by the railroad July 24 with the Interstate Commerce Commission on its interstate fares.

Fifty children chanting "save our homes" as they paraded along West Twenty-fifth Street last night opened a protest campaign by Chelsea residents against the Penn Station South slum-clearance project.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Government dropped conspiracy charges today against six Ohioans convicted three years ago of Smith Act violations.
A hold-up of a savings and loan association Monday was solved yesterday when the wife of a debt-harassed newspaper employe persuaded him to confess.
Each side in the steel dispute interpreted the economic data released yesterday by James P. Mitchell, the Secretary of Labor, as supporting its position.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee today approved legislation authorizing the sale of four American cargo vessels to Nationalist China at $778,000 each.

NEW YORK'S most colorful and perhaps most active fish market does not have sawdust on the floor. It is, instead, under a wide and sunny sky on a breeze-swept strip of piers off Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn.
Tax payments to Federal, state and municipal treasuries last year by the alcoholic beverage industry amounted to $4,089,932,776.

NEWARK, Aug. 19 -- The four-day Second World Congress of Sodalities of Our Lady will open here tomorrow with a solemn pontifical mass in Sacred Heart Cathedral. More than 5,000 delegates are expected, including representatives from twelve foreign countries.

The seasonal drain on the nation's inventories of gasoline eased sharply last week. The decline of 377,000 barrels compared with one of 3,015,000 in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. On last Friday supplies aggregated 183,104,000 barrels, compared with 183,481,000 a week earlier and 176,487,000 a year before.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A traveling salesman named Hans-Jochen Kehrl checks into a different hotel in Germany night after night. Every time he encounters the registration form that infuriates thousands of visitors to Germany.

The short interest position on the New York Stock Exhange was 3,022,530 shares on Aug. 14, the exchange reported yesterday. That figure represented a decrease of 243,066 shares from the revised position of 3,265,596 reported as of July 15.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Harness racing is booming in this popular vacationland, where the filet mignon is more plentiful than the hotdog and many a $2 bettor lives in a $30-a-day hotel.

Exploiting Premier Khrushchev's projected visit to the United States and some differences within the Western camp, the Soviets are stepping up their efforts to shatter the North Atlantic alliance by overtures to the individual allies for bilateral deals. The latest such overture is being made to France, where the Soviet Ambassador has just delivered a purposely dramatized message from Premier Khrushchev to President de Gaulle.

Today Ellen Beamish, a cheerful, gray-haired woman whose trim appearance belies her threescore and nine years, celebrates a half-century of what she terms "satisfying work" behind bars. The bars have protected her, over the years, from tens of thousands of exacting Broadway ticket buyers.
NEWARK, Aug. 19 -- The plans for a new highway to parallel the New Jersey Turnpike have been abandoned, it was announced tonight.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- An Illinois Circuit Court judge ruled today that four children should rejoin their parents in Moscow, thus ending a custody fight that had involved the Soviet Government.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 19 -- The Bergen County Board of Freeholders today directed County Councilman Milton T. Lasher to sue the village of Ridgefield Park for $63,005 in county taxes.

Directors of the Automatic Canteen Company of America recommended yesterday that the common stock be split two for one before the end of the year. The board also declared a 5 per cent stock dividend, payable Nov. 2, in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents, payable on Oct. 1.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 19 (AP) -The Discoverer VI satellite rose into orbit today. It carries a capsule the Air Force hopes to snatch from the air as it parachutes earthward near Hawaii tomorrow.
The Consolidated Edison Company reported to the city yesterday on Monday's power failure that blacked out five square miles of Manhattan. But there was a news blackout on the report.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- An unusual decline in public assistance case loads in June was reported today by the Bureau of Public Assistance.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- Winners of the title four times together between 1942 and 1948, William Talbert and Gardnar Mulloy demonstrated their doubles skill and cleverness anew today with younger partners, though Mulloy did it in a losing cause.
Hawaii, which recently succeeded in joining the Union, also wants to join the proposed third major league.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Following is the text of Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell's background report on the strike-bound steel industry, excluding references to charts:
Recommendations by the Federal Maritime Administrator on legislative controls over steamship tariff systems received scant support yesterday from spokesmen for steamship conferences.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 19 -A Brazilian spokesman said tonight that the police were following Brazilian law in deciding on the deportation of Mr. Birrell in as much as no treaty of extradition existed with the United States.

Kings County District Attorney Edward S. Silver said yesterday that his office had unearthed "concrete evidence" of graft and corruption in the Brooklyn office of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

Esso Standard (Libya), Inc., an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), reported yesterday that its Zelten No. 2 well in Libya had produced on a test at the rate of 15,000 barrels of crude oil a day.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -A light scattered demand limited the trading range of the grain futures market today and prices shifted no more than major fractions from Tuesday's closing quotations.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The Radcliffe report on the British monetary and credit systems unanimously recommended today changes in present procedures with the aim of guaranteeing the conformity of monetary policy to the general economic objectives of the Government.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The House of Representatives considered a bill today extending the program of disposal abroad of agricultural surpluses by barter.

There is something especially poignant and distressing about news we have been getting from Natal Province in South Africa. Hundreds of African women have been arrested since last Friday. All were sentenced to fines or jail, but since they cannot pay fines this invariably means prison terms.

The summer season, our own labor unrest and the struggles for human rights now going on in Africa and Asia recall fourteenth-century England and an obscure figure, William Langland, believed to be the author of "Piers Plowman."

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 19 -President Arturo Frondizi is working at mending his fences with the armed forces in anticipation of new trouble with labor unions over the Government's economic policies of austerity and stabilization.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation said today it would license four competing companies to produce two grades of stainless steel alloys that were in demand in the aircraft and missile industries.

A claim for $1,000,000 was filed against the city yesterday by Seymour Kroll, who charged that he was falsely arrested Aug. 9 by city detectives who mistook him for the missing husband in an abandonment case.
Two of the nation's leading electric and electronic products companies figured yesterday in the largest recent account switches in the trade.

GENEVA, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Soviet Union agreed today to some technical details of a Western plan for nuclear test ban inspections. However, Moscow raised a possible new obstacle to the operation of an effective control system.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild said today that it had asked the Justice Department to reopen its inquiry into whether the Hearst and Scripps-Howard interests have sought illegally to divide newspaper markets.

QUITE apart from its artistic merits, which have already been recognized as substantial -- it was awarded the Author's Club prize for the best English first novel of 1958 -- "Saturday Night and Sunday Morning"* represents, as far as I am concerned, a wry, curious literary phenomenon.

Korea deeply appreciates your warm and friendly editorial of Aug. 15. Such sentiments of support give us renewed strength for the trials ahead and reinforce our determination to remain free and continue the struggle for a united, independent and democratic Korea.

Directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company authorized a $250,000,000 issue of debentures yesterday, to be offered at competitive bidding. The company expects to open bids for the securities on Nov. 17.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 19 -- Traveling along the rail in the final quarter-mile, Winged Guy defeated favored Hal Reward by a neck in the Rutgers Purse before 25,363 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Jimmy Cruise drove the winner.
Wall Street salvaged some good news out of bad yesterday.
William Lombardy defeated Charles Kalme of Philadelphia in twenty-six moves last night and increased his lead in the Log Cabin Chess Club tournament at the Mary Bain Chess Studio.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19--State Department officials said today that every possible assistance had been given to New York authorities in their efforts to return Mr. Birrell to this country.

Mayor Wagner has made the correct appraisal of Controller Gerosa's argumentative statutory report of the city's fiscal position as of Aug. 15 that is one of the essential preliminaries to preparation of the 1960 Capital Budget. The Mayor accepts the Controller's estimate of city borrowing power; he accepts, "with equal sincerity," the City Planning Commission's estimates of the city's need for long-term improvements requiring capital budget funds.

TOKYO, Aug. 19 -- Japanese Socialists have seized upon the forthcoming meetings between President Eisenhower and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev as an argument for breaking off Tokyo's military alliance with the United States and converting Japan into a neutralist power.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 19 -- President Eisenhower will carry his fight for farm legislation to the people by radio and television before the next session of Congress, the White House announced today.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Former President Fulgencio Batista of Cuba left here today by chartered plane for Lisbon, Portugal, the Immigration Service reported.

Claims that tension in the Caribbean stems from two opposing spheres of influence are vehemently favored by the State Department. It is a mistake to regard Cuba's revolution as the flagrant example of the East-West struggle in the Americas.
PANAMA, Aug. 19 -- A story of the Yonkers and Manhattan of seventy years ago hurdled a language change this week to delight audiences here.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 19 -- A special investigating committee reported today that there was a widespread feeling among Jewish immigrants from North Africa that they were being discriminated against by Israelis from Western countries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- A New York business man told the Senate rackets committee in secret testimony made public today that his company paid about $70,000 to officials of the United Auto Workers and other unions for helping it get business.

Proxy material dealing with the proposed merger of the Erie Railroad and the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad has been prepared and is being sent to stockholders, both roads announced yesterday. Special meetings of the stockholders of both companies will be held in New York City on Sept. 22, to act on the proposal.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The House Ways and Means Committee today approved a bill which would grant income tax benefits to United States business concerns making capital investments abroad.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses has quietly asked the City Planning Commission to allocate $250,000 for the construction of a permanent Shakespeare theatre in Central Park next year.

An American edition of Randolph S. Churchill's "The Rise and Fall of Sir Anthony Eden" will be published Sept. 25 by Putnam. It is an analysis of Sir Anthony's political career and of the Suez crisis that wrecked it.

Appointed as a one-man commission to report on the facts behind the steel strike, Secretary of Labor Mitchell has produced an imposing document that adheres strictly to his assignment. This booklet, which centers around "Wages, Productivity, Prices and Profits," contains an enormous amount of factual material, much of it of necessity going well beyond the scope of the immediate controversy in the interest of providing the public with the economic background of the issue.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 -- The International Typographical Union proposed today to raise $1,000,000 to start a newspaper in Westchester County, N.Y.

DETROIT, Aug. 19 -- The Yankees, having solved the vexing problem of Detroit's Don Mossi by defeating the lefty twice after bowing to him five times this year, finally got around to taking care of another arch tormentor, Frank Lary, tonight.
UMZINTO, South Africa, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Army trucks transported 118 African women to Natal's provincial prison at Pietermaritzburg today. Many of the women had babies strapped to their backs.

At 1 P.M. yesterday a lithe, blond girl on ice skates climbed into a small rink next to the Army recruiting station in Times Square and began to twirl and spin. Hundreds of New Yorkers watched, motorists stopped, and a taxicab rammed into the rear of a Broadway bus.

The General Motors Corporation has been going full speed ahead as far as investors are concerned. In twenty-nine of thirty-three weeks ended last Sunday, its name appeared on the weekly list of the fifteen most active stocks on the New York Stock Exchange. Yesterday, one possible reason became apparent.
Cocoa futures were strong yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Prices advanced 23 to 52 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on a turnover of 394 lots.
BUTTE, Mont., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Miners and smeltermen today struck the Anaconda Company, one of the world's largest copper producers.
The United States Embassy in Brazil was accused yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of failing to cooperate with his office in its effort to return Lowell M. Birrell here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- The Army acknowledged to House investigators today that it had urged the Western Electric Company to increase advertising about the Nike-Hercules missile during a controversy in Congress over missile funds.
Revlon, Inc., producer of cosmetics, toiletries and other items, has increased its quarterly dividend for the fifth time since the company became publicly owned in December, 1955.

Repeatedly you have criticized the lamentable fact that the Metropolitan Museum of Art had to be closed on Mondays for lack of sufficient means. Without being able to judge whether this decision was really unavoidable, I do feel strongly that something could be done and that something should be done to overcome this predicament.
Governor Rockefeller said last night that the state would have plunged over "an economic Niagara Falls" without even a barrel for protection if taxes had not been raised this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter, just back from a conference in Santiago, Chile, on the uneasy situation in the Caribbean, said today that democracy could not be imposed on countries by force.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- Representative Frank Thompson Jr., Democrat of New Jersey said today that his wife and two daughters were being guarded by the police as a result of an acid attack on him.
WEST YELLOWSTONE, Mont., Aug. 20 (AP) -- More tremors shook southwestern Montana today, hampering the search for additional victims of Monday's earthquake.

A new code of ethics under which all 225,000 officials and employes of the city will be held to rigid standards of conduct was approved unanimously yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The City Council already has passed the code, acting after two years of study.

It is a harsh thing to say, but in the case of Gen. Fulgencio Batista we must say it: Good riddance! Many people will be breathing sighs of relief that the former Cuban dictator has at last gone out of this hemisphere and will spend what is hoped to be a long time on the Portuguese island of Madeira.
Suffolk County, N. Y. borrowed yesterday $3,019,000 in the bond market to finance construction and renovation of public buildings and other public improvements.

It is heartening to see that General Motors will support research or the medical aspects of air pollution While cancer-causing products are the ones of most obvious concern at the moment, there are indications that lung-destroying compounds may be present in air-pollution products as well as carcinogenic ones.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20 -- A model of Explorer VI, the paddle-wheel satellite that the United States shot into orbit Aug. 7, took a dominant place today in the galaxy of exhibits at the American National Exhibition here.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 20 -- Bill Perkins led the Hudson County high school football all-stars to a 12-0 triumph over the Essex County high school stars tonight in the first college scholarship bowl game at Roosevelt Stadium. Hot weather and the promise of equally hot football attracted a crowd of 18,394.
A Long Island building contractor was indicted yesterday on a charge of using the mails in an alleged $320,000 worthless-check scheme.

OTTAWA, Aug. 20 -- By playing hard to get, the Canadian Government, through its central bank, brought down the interest rates on Treasury bills today. The Government did not accept all the bids made this week for the bills and announced that it would offer a lesser amount of them next week.

Mayor Wagner has taken the unusual step of going outside the administration, even to the point of enlisting a Republican, for the direction of a survey of city policy and organization on housing problems. He has chosen for this task J. Anthony Panuch, a New York lawyer experienced in administration and governmental reorganization.

"Behind Enemy Lines," ten true stories of heroic deeds of World War II, told by James Dean Sanderson, will be published next Thursday by Van Nostrand. Among the accounts, some of which are new and others familiar, are those of Italian divers with torpedoes, British commandos, French maquis, a German flying ace, a Norwegian saboteur of a heavy-water plant, American guerrillas in Luzon and British sailors in midget submarines off Singapore.
The International Longshoremen's Association's wage-scale committee met yesterday to analyze a set of contract proposals put forward on Monday by the New York Shipping Association.
WARSAW, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- Music critics of leading Warsaw newspapers warmly praised the New York Philharmonic today for a series of concerts it is performing here under Leonard Bernstein.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Four Yugoslav stowaways arrived in New York harbor yesterday still unable, after more than five months, to leave their ship.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -Members of the House of Representatives who voted for the union-opposed labor reform bill were threatened today by a high union official with reprisals at the polls.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 20 (UPI) -- The Solar Aircraft Company announced plans last night to sell its facilities in Des Moines, where it produces jetengine components.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Aug. 20 -- Al J. Hayes, president of the International Association of Machinists, disclosed today that the union had dismissed an official accused of having taken $6,000 in payments from a New York management consultant.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 20 -A Government communique issued here today said that Communist rebel units had been spotted moving through six provinces of northern and southern Laos down to the South Vietnam border.
SLOW trade at meat counters seems to indicate that such food is proving too robust during the current hot spell. If this is not true of your family, look to the good supplies of pork and beef.

The Women's Auxiliary of the Presbyterian Hospital will benefit from an illustrated talk to be held at the Cosmopolitan Club, 129 East Sixty-fifth Street, on the afternoon of Oct. 27. Elisabeth Draper will speak on "Modern Trends and the Role of the Decorator.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- In a marathon of three and a half hours Barry MacKay and Myron Franks defeated Antonio Palafox and Gustavo Palafox of Mexico in the national doubles tennis championship today. The scores were 4 -- 6, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 2, 10 -- 12, 17 -- 15.
Directors of the Southern Pacific Company recommended yesterday a three-for-one split of the company's stock and raised the quarterly dividend to 84 cents on the outstanding shares.

As business booms, consumers continue to be in an appliance-buying mood. The result will be "a banner year for appliances and entertainment devices," according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia.
BOONESVILLE, Va., Aug. 16 -- "Once, twice, sold!" The auctioneer's arm descended and the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist here was sold yesterday to the highest bidder.

The United States Court of Appeals upheld the dismissal yesterday of a Government suit to recover $66,021,257 from a group of oil companies on the price paid for oil that was resold to foreign countries under the Marshall Plan.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 20 -- State laws should give classroom teachers "reasonable freedom" to control discipline, the American Federation of Teachers resolved today at the union's forty-third convention.

The Consolidated Edison Company has told the city that it does not know why seven electrical cables in the same network failed last Monday. The failure blacked out five square miles of upper Manhattan.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- For ten years 10,000 starlings have flown into Mount Vernon at twilight in August to settle in tree tops and disrupt lawn parties and besmirch walks, cars and houses.
NORWALK, Conn., Aug 20 -- The Board of Education is squaring off for a legal bout over the city's refusal to meet the board's payroll for the new fiscal year. It voted last night to hire a lawyer.
BERLIN, Aug. 20 (AP) George Byrd of Anson County. N. C. and Brooklyn, New York, tonight became the first American Negro to conduct the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra.
State Democratic leaders have agreed to put Mayor Wagner forward at the 1960 national convention at Los Angeles as a favorite - son candidate for Vice President.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Henry Cabot Lodge, the United States Permanent Representative to the United Nations, met today with dele- gates of twenty Latin-American countries to explain new moves being made toward a resump-. tion of disarmament negoraa- ticalz.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 20 -- William M. Birrell's Brazilian lawyer, today seized on charges by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York of a run-around in Brazil to strengthen his client's fight against expulsion.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Another attempt to recover a capsule ejected from a satellite apparently failed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- The Chicago Cubs were beaten, 8 -- 5, by the Philadelphia Phillies in the opener of a twi-night double-header, but routed a former team-mate-Taylor Phillips, 6 -- 4, tonight in the second game.
ROME, Aug. 20 -- Of the six countries that form the European Common Market, Italy is the one in which the average worker eats the least.

In the face of a noticeable growth of a new "Geneva spirit" of relaxation due to Premier Khrushchev's impending visit, the ten-man committee of prominent citizens headed by former Assistant Army Secretary Draper warns that the Communist leopard has not changed his spots and that we cannot cope with him unless we keep the free world strong.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A Federal Trade Commission examiner today recommended dismissal of one of two charges against General Mills, Inc.
It is definite that former President Harry S. Truman, who has displayed some talent as a quipster, will make a guest appearance Oct. 18 on Jack Benny's television show.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A Presidential committee took issue today with Senators who believe that the Administration attaches too much importance to military and not enough to economic aid in less-developed countries.
A breakdown of a westbound Long Island Rail Road train in the East River tunnel leading into Pennsylvania Stations delayed thousands of commuters yesterday evening.
Several make-believe ship collisions and sinkings took place yesterday in a demonstration on the thirty-fifth floor of the Downtown Athletic Club. Many collisions were averted, however.
THE defensive linemen awaited the next scrimmage play with amused tolerance. They jeered at the attacking unit, joshed with one another and obviously were having fun.
The city has had fewer cases of poliomyelitis this year than in the same period in 1958, despite the fact that the national total is higher, the Department of Health reported yesterday.

The Bowery Savings Bank, largest in the nation, has "no present plans" to quit the American Bankers Association, Earl B. Schwulst, president, said yesterday. Mr. Schwulst indicated that the matter had been considered recently after the association announced its support for a bill, now before Congress, to increase Federal taxes on the savings banks.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Mrs. Bernard Freeman and Mrs. Leon J. Weil of Inwood reached the final of the thirteenth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association four-ball best-ball championship at the Century Country Club today.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange scored their biggest gain in twenty-one months yesterday. Market values climbed some $4,800,000,000. Stocks opened with a gain and then continued to rally in a series of spurts.

When you think about it, it's really nothing to get surprised at that a thin book on English composition should make the best-seller list during the summer -- which is the happy fate that has befallen "The Elements of Style," by William Strunk Jr., with revisions and additions by E. B. White, one of the late Professor Strunk's prize students in English 8 at Cornell back in 1919.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 20 -- Jerome Robbins' "Ballets U. S. A." company won an ovation tonight in the first of eight performances in Yugoslavia.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Aug. 20 -- The merged labor federation resolved today to take a long look before authorizing any retreat from its policy of full support for the Government's reciprocal trade program.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Aug. 20 -- Potent new electronic eye, ear and brain-power for tomorrow's Army is on display at Fort Monmouth this week.
THE deal shown today is a tournament hand that offered unusual opportunities in both bidding and play.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 20 -- Edgar Allan Poe, for all the tragedy of his life, had an easy time with his writing compared to the problems of adapting a Poe story for the screen.

The Celanese Corporation of America announced yesterday that it had completed a multimillion-dollar expansion of its acetic acid facility at Pampa, Tex., doubling its capacity and making it the country's largest such plant.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants jumped on an old nemesis, Warren Spahn, and defeated the Milwaukee Braves. 5 3, tonight on the clutch pitching of Sad Sam Jones.
MOST of the potatoes now arriving here are the so-called "new" varieties. The difference between them and "old" potatoes is one home cooks would do well to recognize.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- A record performance spiced the running of the $13,975 Promise hurdles, the obstacle race for 3-year-olds that served as the feature on today's Saratoga program. Mrs. Walter F. Wickes Jr.'s Vendetta took the event of about a mile and five-eighths in 3:05, breaking the track record of 3:06 3/5, set by Chambourg last August.
Sales and earnings of the Procter Gamble Company in the fiscal year ended with June were the largest in its 122-year history, according to the annual report issued yesterday.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Aug. 20 -- Premier Joseph Smallwood was re-elected today as his Liberal party swept to victory for its third consecutive term.
A group of leading Soviet theatrical directors paused yesterday in the Fourth Street Theatre to help rehearse an American cast in a forthcoming production of Chekhov's "Three Sisters."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Federal Housing Administration reported today a drastic decline in applications in July for mortgage insurance on proposed new homes. However, a special factor accounted for most of the drop.

Bill Rosensohn, back yesterday from a Riviera vacation, told District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's staff that there had been no gambling money behind his promotion of the heavyweight title fight last June 26 at Yankee Stadium.
LONDON, Aug. 20 -- The advance in the stock market continued today but the pace slackened slightly. Demand was still strong but there were more sellers eager to take their profits.
DETROIT, Aug. 20 -- As far as the Yankees are concerned, there must be some magnetic force that keeps them glued to the .500 mark.
A Bronx Supreme Court hearing on a writ seeking the release from a sanitarium of Martin Rothstone, grandson of the late Samuel Levy, was postponed yesterday until Monday.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The aircraft carrier Wasp, damaged Tuesday by an explosion and fire 250 miles off Virginia, came into Boston today for repairs. Two men were killed and twenty-eight injured in the fire.
Soviet officials were reported yesterday to be eager for direct talks with Western business leaders on eliminating obstacles to greater trade.
OF the three Shaw plays put on at Provincetown Playhouse last evening, "The Dark Lady of the Sonnets" is the best known.
Manhattan leads all boroughs in automobile deaths, with 121 persons killed in the first seven months of the year, the Police Department announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller appointed today the three members of the advisory council that will help administer the state's new labor law.

Strong relief pitching yesterday helped Schenectady, N. Y., and Bridgeport, Conn., move into the Eastern championship final of the Little League at Hy Turkin Field, Staten Island. The New York State champions defeated Barre, Vt., 6 -- 3, and Bridgeport, champion of Connecticut and New England, ousted Chester, Pa., 12 -- 7.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Aug. 19 -- Japanese investments can be "very helpful" to Alaska's struggling economy and should be encouraged, according to Gov. William A. Egan.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- New transcontinental air service across the southern part of the nation was described as an urgent necessity today by Capt. Eddie V. Rickenbacker.

YONKERS, Aug. 20 -- The steel barrier that the Westchester Parkway Authority built in the center of the hazardous Cross County Parkway here this summer was criticized today by parents as a barrier to children going to school.
Mayor Wagner took a first step yesterday toward the eventual creation of a central agency to plan, coordinate and administer the city's housing, slum-clearance, urban-renewal and related activities.

MOTHERS whose nerves fray at the thought of sorting through umpty-ump sizes to find the one that suits their infant, pre-schooler or teen-ager will find shopping simplified at Lord Taylor. The store's entire seventh floor has been redesigned to take boys and girls from infancy through the age of 16.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A jet fighter was blasted aloft from an atomic shelter in a take-off distance of less than an inch yesterday.

An offering to the public of 115,000 shares of common stock of Air Products Inc., Allentown, Pa. industrial gas producer, was made yesterday by investment bankers headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co., Reynolds Co., Inc., and Drexel Co. The stock was priced at $46 a share.

Increased borrowing by metal companies and commodity dealers helped push business loans of sixteen large New York banks up $77,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The rise was the largest since the week to June 17, when borrowings were swelled by corporations making Federal tax payments.
JONES BEACH, L. I., Aug. 20 -- A huge program to expand state and local park and recreational facilities was outlined by Governor Rockefeller here tonight.
A grumbling Board of Estimate authorized the purchase of 226 new police radio patrol cars last night. The action was taken to avoid possible shortages caused by the steel strike.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Ed Bailey let a side-retiring third strike get away from him in the fifth inning tonight and the Los Angeles Dodgers went on to score seven unearned runs and defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 8 -- 5.

Diana Stores Corporation announced yesterday that it had acquired Ralph H. Miller, Inc., a chain of seventy specialty shops and self-service discount stores. The purchase was made for an undisclosed amount of cash. No exchange of shares was involved.
LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Two uninhibited London newspapers have strained British relations with France and West Germany.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Senate passed today a bill limiting the power of the states to tax interstate business.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (UPI) -The Baltimore Orioles batted against all but three of the Chicago White Sox' pitchers today. They reached seven hurlers for thirteen hits and a 7-6 triumph, cutting the league-leading Sox' margin over second-place Cleveland to two and a half games.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation and a large private industrial combine of India have organized a joint venture company to build a $30,000,000 integrated aluminum operation in that country.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- The Winged Foot Golf Club team won the annual Hoffhine Memorial competition at the Westchester Country Club today. Forty-two clubs were represented. Each had a squad of three amateurs and one professional who combined their scores for the aggregate in the team race.

A PORTABLE air purifier that is said to magnetize airborne dust, pollen and smoke is being introduced today at Hammacher Schlemmer. The store believes that the device, called Micronaire, will prove a boon to sleepless hayfever sufferers.
LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Moscow radio reported today that a Soviet submarine had completed a 10,000-mile underwater survey of the North Atlantic and the Barents Sea.
WESTBURY. L. I., Aug. 20 -- Ten top 3-year-old colts will pace in the $112,494.29 Messenger Stake at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night. The purse is a record for pacers of their age.
Roy Carlisi, a member of the Apalachin gangland gathering, was released from Civil Prison yesterday in $5,000 bail by Supreme Court Justice John L. Flynn.
RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 20 -- The leader of Morocco's conservative Istiqlal party accused France and Spain today of "maneuvers and plots" against Morocco's Saharan territories.

RHODES, Greece, Aug. 20 -- The Rev. Dr. Willem Adolph Visser't Hooft, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, said today that his organization would never join an ecumenical council of all churches unless all confessions were on an equal footing.
The directors of the New York World's Fair 1964 Corporation made a policy decision yesterday to shun business on political pressures in its hiring and purchasing.
LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 20 -Fulgencio Batista, former President of Cuba, arrived here today aboard a chartered plane for a new place of exile.

Following are the texts of three Code of Ethics bills unanimously approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday. The first defines the code itself. The second sets up a Board of Ethics. The third bars appearances before city agencies of former, officers or employes for two years after they leave city service.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- The Statue of Freedom at the top of the Capitol dome got its first examination in nearly 100 years this week.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Aug. 20 -- Following is the text of the resolution on Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's coming visit to the United States adopted today by the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations:
DETROIT, Aug. 20 -- The 1960 Pontiac line will be expanded from three to four series.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 20 -- Concern is growing in West Germany official circles over signs of disunity in Western Europe.
DOUGLAS, Ariz., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The strike-crippled copper industry suffered two more blows today.
The Kudner Advertising Agency, Inc., which experienced some lean days after it lost the Buick advertising account, may soon be back in the automotive business.

OH, to be young again and able to wear Ohrbach's back-to-school clothes. The store's new collection for scholars of both sexes starts with the kindergarten crowd and works its winsome way up to the high school set.
The Port of New York Authority should be given complete "management and governmental control" over all piers and waterfront facilities here, a group of New York University researchers said yesterday.
ERMA, N. J., Aug. 20 -- Every year at this season bright-eyed groups of men and women don sneakers, galoshes or boots and splash merrily off through a local bogland.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -The volume of grain futures trading expanded moderately today on the Board of Trade and price ranges broadened considerably with the bread grains under increasing pressure.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The railroad industry asked President Eisenhower today to set up a special commission to study alleged featherbedding.

IT is hard to say whose is the stronger influence -- that of the French designers on American fashions or the American woman's on the French designers. A case in point is Bergdorf Goodman's new fall collection of exclusive ready-to-wear fashions designed by Virginie and Carven.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 20 -- Maj. Raul Castro, Commander in Chief of the Cuban armed forces, left Chile this afternoon in the same cold atmosphere that greeted him on his arrival here Tuesday.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The first strong Negro bid for a City Commission seat collapsed tonight under the weight of a record-breaking vote.

THE hardest thing to teach a primitive man is the meaning of the phrase, "Keep It Simple." Ingeborg de Beausacq, a pale - haired German - born countess with eyes like chocolate gumdrops, discovered this when she undertook to establish the head-hunters of Australian New Guinea in business.

The bond market sold off slightly yesterday in a session marked chiefly by the price vulnerability of intermediate Treasury obligations. The offerings that put pressure on the market came mostly from commercial banks, which were short of reserves because of rising industrial loans.
TRENTON, Aug. 20 -- Most of New Jersey's commuter railroads have assured the state that they will not press for further curtailments of service or ask for fare increases at least until November.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20 -- Mark O. Hatfield, Republican Governor of Oregon, has advised Governor Rockefeller of New York to "come out of hibernation" and campaign in Oregon next spring if he expects to win the Republican Presidential nomination.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Authorities today ordered the arrest of Msgr. Francois Poirer, Archbishop of Port-au-Prince. He is the highest Roman Catholic church official in this predominantly Catholic country.
A cooperative housing development for 6,350 families on the 178 acres of the Jamaica race track in Queens has been approved informally by the Board of Estimate.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 20 -- Haitian Army units were said today to have mopped up the remainder of an invasion force that had fled into the mountains. The army first inflicted losses on the invaders in a surprise attack yesterday, according to unofficial reports here.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Aug. 20 -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations officially decided today to shun any contacts with Nikita S. Khrushchev when the Soviet Premier visits the United States next month.

For the past few weeks I have been passing the new "Park and Ride" facility at Westchester Square in the Bronx, as I drive my car to New York City each morning. Only a handful of cars are using this large lot.
A company advertising director and a new appointment at an association were announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -The Government began laying plans today for a ceremony of ratification of the new InterAmerican Development Institution.
Great ships of the sea, such as the Queen Mary, the United States and, of course, the Navy's aircraft carriers, have had Loran equipment for years.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 20 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist party has issued fresh instructions that all literature must be made to conform to party goals and that no "ideological ambiguities" will be allowed "to penetrate to the reading public."

BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- Walter Ulbricht, First Secretary of the East German Comunist party, and Otto Grotewohl, East German Premier, are scheduled to meet with Nikita S. Khrushchev prior to the Soviet Premier's trip to the United States, informed sources in East Berlin said today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -The Chicago White Sox were notified today by Commissioner Ford Frick that their make-up game with the New York Yankees here next Monday must be played by day.

The picture story of Junior Red Cross volunteers in Rockaway Beach Hospital carried by The New York Times on Aug. 11 was an interesting presentation. It is an illustration of the willingness of young people to accept responsibility and of their eagerness to work even without pay.

A Wagner-sponsored bill creating the new "meter-maid" force was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The measure previously passed the City Council. The Mayor is expected to sign the bill as soon as it comes to him.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- Spirited batting by the tailenders, Narendra Tamhane and Surendra Nath, saved India from a complete rout by England on the first day of the fifth and final cricket test at the Oval today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Kennedy-for-President strategy is aimed at an unbroken string of state primary victories with Oregon's free-for-all posing the toughest test.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 20 -- Town officials were faced today with the dilemma of what to do with a family of twelve that faces eviction from a threeroom house here.

The resumption by the Kremlin of foreign policy activities hostile to the United States has come after a very brief period during which this attitude was suspended in the Government offices and in the controlled press and radio centers of the Soviet Union.
The idea of a $50 fare to Europe is just a step away from reality.

Harold Rome easily could sit around and enjoy the prosperity of "Destry Rides Again," the current musical hit for which he supplied the music and lyrics. Instead, he has provided himself with the ambitious project of doing a musical version of "Providence Island," a novel by Jacquetta Hawkes, British archaelogist, poet and amateur geologist.

THERE certainly will be some rare shotgunning on Sept. 12 at the George Fremault Memorial Shoot, as well as some that is pretty sure to be well done. The problem of the managers will be to keep that rare stuff from running away with the shoot.
WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon's projected visit to New Hampshire has focused attention on flood control action since 1955.
PARIS, Aug. 20 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia announced today that his country had broken away from its customs union with France.
GENEVA, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- The United States, the Soviet Union and Britain agreed today to recess their ten-month-old talks on a treaty to end nuclear weapons tests.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Laos today laid the problem of armed Communist infiltration into its area before Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.
