HAVANA, Aug. 20 -- The Cuban Electric Company, an affiliate of American and Foreign Power Company of New York, was ordered today to cut rates 30.5 per cent. The basic rate will be reduced from 9 cents to a little more than 6 cents a kilowatt hour.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Democratic Advisory Council called the Administration's natural resources policies "spineless" today. It said they amounted to a "comprehensive breakdown" of past policies.

DURING the first half of the fifteenth century there lived in the town of Baildon in Suffolk an escaped serf named Martin Reed. In a fit of entirely justifiable but highly imprudent rage Martin had struck his lawful master and consequently had been beaten and left for dead. When he regained consciousness Martin asked the girl he loved, Kate the shepherd's daughter, if she would run away with him. Kate would.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 20 -- Pope John XXIII today hailed sodalities as the "shock troops of the army" of the Roman Catholic Church.
KRISTIANSAND, Norway, Aug. 20 -- Three members of the Rockefeller family arrived here today for a wedding that has focused world attention on this Norwegian community.
AKRON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Ted Kroll of Sarasota, Fla., shared the lead with Arnold Palmer and Bob Goalby today after the first round of the $22,000 Rubber City open golf tournament.

The time has come -- in fact, is well past -- for action on civil rights in both the Senate and the House in Washington and for public identification of those who are responsible for inexcusable delays.

FOR most of his adult life, Joseph Anthony Panuch has been "in the reorganization game." He has helped to reorganize corporations, Government agencies and Germany. His work in Germany came after World War II when he was a principal assistant to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, then United States Military Governor there, Mr. Panuch is a man of rich and varied speech.
Hides, wool and rubber climbed sharply yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Volume in the three items was heavy.

Consumption of newsprint in the United States reached another new high in July, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday. Newspapers reporting to the association used 400,102 tons, or 9.8 per cent more than in July, 1958. Total consumption for the month was estimated at 533,469 tons, compared with 485,982 a year earlier.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, told the International Typographical Union today that labor legislation being considered by Congress would be an "assistance to honest unions" in cleaning out racketeers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -The House of Representatives approved today an Administration-sponsored bill to continue the program of overseas disposal of agricultural surpluses. The vote sending the measure to the Senate was 305 to 53.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender said today that foreign-aid funds had been used to build up the Fiat and Renault companies "whose automobiles now flood the United States market.''
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -Democratic members of the House Public Works Committee revolted today against a proposed 1-cent increase in the Federal gasoline tax.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- After six hours of angry debate, the Senate went on record, 6 -- 29, tonight as opposing a budget - balancing device proposed by President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20--Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 543,844 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A Detroiter originally from Arkansas testified tonight that money he was required to pay into a United Auto Workers union fund was used to help finance the 1954 election campaign of a Senator from Iowa.
The new three-man State Harness Racing Commission will hold its first meeting here next week.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman said today that he would be glad to have Nikita S. Khrushchev visit him.

Gerry Mulligan, 32-year-old baritone saxophonist and jazz composer, was arraigned in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday on a charge of failing to report his narcotic record to immigration officials when he returned last June from a European concert tour.

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 21 -- Striking machinists at a plant here carried a grievance to President Eisenhower today. They accused Dudley C. Sharp, Under Secretary of the Air Force, of being a "strike-breaker."

A young United States physician who had refused to leave his hospital in northern Laos despite the threat of Communist guerrillas arrived in town yesterday. He had been ordered back for treatment of a serious and painful cancer.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -A Department of Labor expert is being lent to the Pacific Maritime Association to direct a year-long study of mechanization and its effects on West Coast dock workers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- The State Department expressed hope today that the departure of the ousted Cuban dictator, Fulgencio Batista, for a new place of exile in the Portuguese islands of Madeira would lead to greater stability in the Caribbean area.
HONOLULU, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Following is the statement issued today by William F. Quinn after taking the oath as Governor of Hawaii:
UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Aug. 21 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon got praise today from an unexpected source.
The fact that Graham Greene's new play, "The Complaisant Lover," has turned out to be one of London's biggest hits may delay plans for an early Broadway presentation.

Like its bigger brothers in the industry, the Carpenter Steel Company has scored a marked increase in its earnings over last year, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Unlike many other steel producers, the company is not strikebound.
William P. Rosensohn, boxing promoter, divided his day yesterday between the New York County Grand Jury investigating boxing and renewed questioning by aides of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- A couple of "old pros," Gil Hodges and Duke Snider, left the bench in the seventh inning tonight to spark a four-run rally that carried the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 6-5 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The grain futures market had its best general price advance of the week today on the Board of Trade, although oats and September corn slumped on late selling.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- One of Britain's largest trade unions called off today a rebellion against the Labor party's nuclear disarmament policy.

The United Steelworkers of America will send its two top bargainers back to the steel negotiations Wednesday after an absence of more than two weeks. David J. McDonald, president of the union, and Arthur J. Goldberg, its chief counsel, expect, however, that Wednesday will see no more basis for settlement of the five-week-old strike than there was when they left the sessions on Aug. 7.

HAVANA, Aug. 21 -- Telephone, radio and cable communications with the Dominican Republic were out today as the Confederation of Cuban Workers began an attempt to obtain a Latin-American communications boycott against that country.

Committee chairmen have been announced for the Tiara Ball, an annual benefit for the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 29. The ball was initiated by Mrs. Lila Tyng and Mrs. Robert W. Dowling to honor post-debutantes.

The major reconstruction of a two-block portion of Riverside Drive will be finished on schedule next month, despite the recent cement-truck drivers' strike, a spokesman for Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- President Eisenhower nominated J. Vincent Burke Jr. of Pittsburgh today to be general counsel of the Department of Defense.
PORT- AU - PRINCE, Haiti Aug. 21 -- Haiti suspended today a warrant for the arrest of the Archbishop of Port-au-Prince, Msgr. Francois Poirier.

KRISTIANSAND, Norway, Aug. 21 -Governor Rockefeller arrived here by air today to attehd the wedding of his son Steven. The overnor was surrounded at the airport by a pushing, sduffling crowd of a hundred or more photographers and reporters from over the world.
PORT SHEPSTONE, South Africa, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- One hundred eighty-six African women were arrested here and in a near-by African reserve today for defying authorities.

PHILAEDLPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Johnny Antonelli and Mike McCormick, the left-handed look-alikes and room-mates who often pitch alike for the San Francisco Giants, flattened the fatigued, futile Phillies twice at Connie Mack Stadium tonight.
Stocks drifted irregularly downward yesterday in slow trading. Thursday's sharp rally died after a brief flurry at the opening when prices were up a bit.

The introduction of brown milk bottles in Denmark, recommended by scientists there as a means of protecting the milk's vitamin C content, was regarded by major milk distributors here yesterday as "old stuff."
MOSCOW, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has been holding a series of informal meetings with friends and allies in the Crimean city of Yalta.

AFTER the sweltering day, the breezes that cooled Randalls Island last night were a soothing change. They provided a fitting setting for the fourth annual Randalls Island Jazz Festival, which this year will be the "coolest" of all the summer jazz fetes.

DENVER, Aug, 21 (AP) -- A strike of copper miners and processing workers spread today to big plants of the American Smelting and Refining Company. This practically shut down the industry in the United States.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., Aug. 21 (UPI) -- Associate Justice Jim Johnson of the Arkansas Supreme Court told a statewide segregationist rally tonight to "do what needs to be done" to prevent integration of the Dollarway School District next month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- An investigation to determine the extent of thefts from the Illinois Toll Highway Commission was begun today after two electronics technicians admitted thefts of tolls amounting to thousands of dollars.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -The Navy canceled its program to develop high speed jet seaplanes after having spent $400,000,000 and received nine aircraft. It attributed its move to economies and technical difficulties with the plane, the P6M Seamaster.

Milton Schapiro and Nathan C. Brodsky, realty investors, have contracted to buy the four buildings at 244-46 Waverly Place and 16-18 Bank Street. The William J. Irwin Company was the broker in the sale, the first involving the property in seventy years.

In all the turmoil of news from the Far East there is one calm, gratifying note. Malaya has now held its nation-wide election for the Assembly and the Alliance party has won a smashing victory and has a clear mandate for the next five years. And it will have the solid legislative majority to carry it out.
The newest Atlantic liner changed hands this week at a spot in the North Sea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -President Eisenhower nominated today a five-member United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly including George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 21 -- Eighty-five cars started today in the Berkshire Mountain Rally. It was the largest field in a national sports car rally in the East since the championship point system was established more than a year ago.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- Von Clay, an unbeater Philadelphia light heavyweight scored a technical knockout lover Sonny Ray of Chicago in the fifth round of a scheduled ten-round bout tonight.

SOUTH ORANGE, Aug. 21 -- Delegates to the second congress of the World Federation of Sodalities to our Lady, meeting at Seton Hall University here, were urged by a British delegate today to use "the power of propaganda to Christianize the modern world."

BONN, Germany, Aug. 21 -- A Duesseldorf criminal court sentenced retired Gen. Hasso von Manteuffel today to eighteen months' imprisonment on conviction of homicide.

Park Commissioner Moses may have surprised his public a little when he suggested that the City Planning Commission approve an allocation of $250,000 in his department's 1960 capital budget for the construction of a permanent Shakespeare Theatre for Central Park. Mr. Moses and his executive officer, Stuart Constable, feel that the temporary theatre setup in the park's Belvedere Tower area is unsatisfactory and that the city should replace it with something lasting.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -Hawaii was officially proclaimed as the fiftieth state of the United States today by President Eisenhower at bipartisan White House ceremonies.

Although the Duvalier Government in Haiti withdrew its warrant for the arrest of the Archbishop of Port-au-Prince, it is obvious that relations between Church and state are far from harmonious. On Tuesday the Government expelled two Roman Catholic priests "for reasons of internal security" and roughly broke up a silent demonstration of protest in the Cathedral of Port-au-Prince the next day.
HONOLULU, Aug. 21 -- William F. Quinn, wearing a four-foot pink carnation lei, was sworn into office today at 10:17 A. M., Hawaii time, as the first Governor of the State of Hawaii.
A strange five-month odyssey for four Yugoslav refugees who had been refused a haven in a dozen countries ended yesterday on a hopeful note.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- While two months do not make a trend, the significant rise in consumer prices in July for the second straight month, following smaller rises in April and May, has caused some political as well as economic distress within the Administration.
FLINT, Mich., Aug. 21 -- In hopes of regaining the prestige it once had in the mediumpriced field, the 1960 Buick has been modestly restyled.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Aug. 21 -- The Liberal party was returned to power today, only one man short of its majority of thirty-two in the last Legislative Assembly.

However, being a student of the Russian language at the present time, may I express a deep concern about the methodology that is being used.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Three professionals who have not won a golf tournament this year held the top spots today at the halfway mark in the $22,000 Rubber City open.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 21 -Another flossy paycheck was made out tonight to the owners of Adios Butler. With a strong down - the - stretch finish, the 3-year-old bay son of Adios captured the $110,994 Messenger Stake, adding $55,497 to the bankbooks of his owners, Paige H. West of Snow Hill, Md., and Angelo Pellillo of New York.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The industrials continued to advance in the stock market here today, unchecked by the usual weekend restraints.

The State of Connecticut announced yesterday that it planned to borrow $60,500,000 on serial bonds secured by general taxation. Of the total, $38,000,000 will be Greater Hartford Bridge System bonds due from 1961 to 1987 and $22,500,000 will be general obligations of the state due from 1962 to 1979. The sale has been set for Sept. 2.

KRISTIANSAND, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The white wooden church at Soegne where Steven Rockefeller will marry Miss Rasmussen tomorrow was being decorated today with pink roses, carnations, African lilies, gladioli and chrysanthemums. Carnations and roses will strew the center aisle.

BILBAO, Spain, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- Luis Miguel Gonzales, the top-ranking bullfighter known as Dominguin, was gored in the ring today for the second time this month and was carried from the arena in a stretcher.

ST. THOMAS, V. I., Aug. 21 -- The first chain supermarket unit in the Virgin Islands will open here on Sept. 15. A self-service store will be opened in a 30,000-square-foot building now occupied by Chinnery's Food-O-Mat, a grocery. The new store will be operated by Pueblo Markets, a five-year-old supermarket chain with headquarters in Puerto Rico.

Reflecting the rise in unemployment early in 1958, caused by the business recession, payments by private industry for employe welfare benefits last year were slightly below the 1957 level. This was the first year-to-year drop since 1933.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 21 -- Two alleged Communist Chinese incursions into India were reported today in The Times of India.

MANILA, Saturday, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- The Philippine Navy and Air Force joined an extensive search today for survivors of the sinking of the interisland ship Pilar II. The ship capsized off Palawan Island in the southwestern Philippines with at least 100 persons aboard.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox, aided by some sparkling defensive play, defeated Washington, 5 -- 4, tonight.

New financing in the public capital market is moderately active despite the distractions of the vacation season. Two of the summer's major offerings of corporate securities are scheduled to come to the market next week.

NEWARK, Aug. 21 -- Two youths who aped stagecoach bandits they had seen in a television Western and held up a De Camp bus near Secaucus last Feb. 24 were sentenced today. The people upstairs always are pounding. For all of that, so are the people downstairs, and those next door at the side. Everywhere, people are pounding. Upstairs they begin before daybreak, and pound until they must leave for work.

In his thought-provoking letter printed Aug. 10 Prof. George Yevick of the Stevens Institute of Technology goes to the core of a critical situation in education for the masses of Americans who are eager and curious but often confused in our so-called scientific age.

A 100,000-watt radio transmitter, capable of reaching all of Communist China and parts of the Soviet Union, is being constructed at Okuma, Okinawa, under the auspices of the Far East Broadcasting Company.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Still riding a current of optimism, the stock market continued its jubilant rise last week and again reached a new high.
PRINCETON. N. J. Aug. 23 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said tonight that the use of tranquilizing drugs was a major factor in this state's first net decrease in mental hospital patients.
I made my first trip to the Soviet Union in 1923. I have returned there for several extended visits since that time. A few days ago I completed my seventh journey through the U. S. S. R.
HAVANA, Aug. 23 -- Premier Fidel Castro's government by television has left the press in the dark. Newspaper readership is said to have declined sharply.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- Cornelius (Glit)with Shields Jr., with his international class sloop, Aileen, the Bill Corwin-Jack Starkweather 210 class Harpoon and Seth Corwin's 110 Rosie scored easy victories in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound program staged by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23---The sale by the l/earst Publishing Company of the ten-story Hearst Building at 326 Madison Street, !which is occupied by The Chicago American, sister newsipaper of The Chicago Tribune, has been announced.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Administration aides now prefer to have no civil-rights bill reach the floor of either the House or the Senate this session.
A sincere "amen" to Prof. Henri Peyre's letter published Aug. 16.
GOTEBORG, Sweden, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- New York apparently has lost the Ingemar Johansson-Floyd Patterson return bout for the heavyweight title.
FORT MADISON, Iowa, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Six convicts sawed their way out of the state penitentiary here this morning after overpowering four guards during church services.
HONG KONG, Aug. 23 -- Communist China said today it was staving off the worst effects of the most serious drought to hit the Chinese mainland since the Peiping regime was established ten years ago.

Record second-quarter earnings raised the net income of the Tennessee Corporation for the first half of this year by 41 per cent over the initial six months a year ago, according to the semi-annual report released today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Following are the introduction and summary from a report on "Fall-Out From Nuclear Weapons Tests" issued today by the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy:

The chief negotiator for the steel industry said yesterday that the companies were prepared for Government invocation of the Taft-Hartley Act to help end the fortyday-old steel strike. At the same time, R. Conrad Cooper, the negotiator, let it be known that the steel companies would not welcome the appointment of a public fact-finding board to deal with the dispute.
The city's two-week hot spell ended abruptly yesterday as a blanket of cool air from Hudson Bay slipped down over the Northeast.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 23 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower heard a minister pray today for the "great success" of his coming diplomatic missions to Western Europe and the Soviet Union.
New York State will speed payments of more than $2,000,000 to municipalities for property appropriated for highways and other improvements.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 19 -- Violent exchanges of accusations between right and left within the Government party appear to have opened the campaign for next spring's Presidential elections.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 23 -- The American Bar Association disclosed today a plan to investigate and possibly discipline lawyers accused of misconduct by Congressional committees.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Aug. 28 -- About 250 residents of the Town of Huntington met today to protest the recently chosen site for a $40,000,000 state school for the mentally retarded. The meeting was held in Half Hollow Hill High School at Huntington Station.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 -- At 4 o'clock this afternoon, over the public address system at Connie Mack Stadium, came the announcement, "The Phillies regret that today's double-header with the San Francisco Giants will not be played."

THE three-day Randalls Island Jazz Festival, which came to an end last night at Randalls Island Stadium, drew attention to a change that has taken place in jazz in the last year or two. Sixteen of the eighteen groups that played at the concerts were organized ensembles that play together regularly.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Five problems are unresolved as Congress begins the last week of August without an adjournment goal.
NON ALCOHOLIC drinks that might find favor at this time of year are fruit squashes and barley waters from England.

FEW things ginger the appetite better than the spice that gave rise to the expression. In this country, ginger is mostly associated with cookies and cakes; but it also lends zest to red as well as sweet meats. In fact, it is good in any dish, whether it be soup, entree, vegetable, dessert or beverage.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 -- Some steel users have lost their complacency over the adequacy -- of steel supplies. While emergencies are still in the future, there may be some serious spot shortages by early next month should the strike continue.
The entry of the nation's "Big Three" auto makers into the small car field is casting its marketing shadow before the first of the new entries has been sold.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 23 -- The Conference of State Chief Justices, which raised a storm a year ago with an attack on the United States Supreme Court, has just concluded an annual meeting devoid of fireworks.
A small vessel, built fourteen years ago in a Great Lakes shipyard, was headed for London yesterday well on its way to achieving acceptance as the prototype of a new class of ocean-going carriers.

Shepard Boneparth will be the auctioneer at a sale of surplus property of the Department of Defense on Oct. 7. The auction vill be broadcast to viewers in St. Louis, New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Boston and Co-I lumbus, Ohio.

Next week when Pakistan's President, General Ayub Khan, flies across the subcontinent on a trip to East Pakistan he will make what can be an extremely important "fuel halt." It will be in New Delhi, and the Pakistani President is expected to have the chance for some informal talks with Indian Prime Minister Nehru. This will be the first meeting of these two heads of government.

The Senate Judiciary Committee -- of which James O. Eastland of Mississippi is the chairman -- deserves a black mark for its inexcusable slow motion. Stalled in Mr. Eastland's committee are ten of President Eisenhower's appointments to important Federal judgeships which have been waiting for its approval for the past five months -- one since last January. Nine other judgeship appointments made more recently are also on the committee's docket of inaction.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- The atmosphere of harmony, which the Pan-American Games was expected to foster, was in danger of being shattered today -- five days before the big athletic carnival opens.
" NEW YORK FORUM," a news panel program with a group of lawyers, rather than reporters, asking the questions, began yesterday over Channel 2.
Senator Jacob K. Javits will ask today for public hearings by House and Senate committees on the rival aspirations of New York and Washington as the site for a world's fair in 1964.

A 15-year-old girl was shot dead last night and six other teen-agers were wounded in shootings and stabbings on the lower East Side. Forsythe and Stanton Streets at 8:30 P. M. There, a moment later, Manuel Cintron, 11, of 321 Jefferson Street, was shot in the face, and Julio Rosario, 14, of 163 Stanton Street, was stabbed in the back.

The Borden Foods Company will build a plant in Grafton, N. D., to turn out nearly 7,000,000 pounds of instant whipped potato flakes a year, Theodore O. Hofman, president, announced over the week-end. At a cost of $300,000, two buildings wil be erected on a five-acre tract being acquired from the Great Northern Railway.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- The Government has withdrawn a tentative plan to carry out a racial segregation measure in part of Cape Province, it was announced today.

Convinced, apparently, that to permit themselves to be identified in the public mind with legislation calling for higher interest rates, regardless of its merits, the Democratic majority of the House Ways and Means Committee, after weeks of vacillating on the President's proposal that the prevailing ceiling on interest rates for Government bonds be eliminated, did something last week that is a rarity in its history.

VIENTIANE, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A Laotian Defense Ministry spokesman announced today that the ministry had been ordered by the Foreign Ministry to issue no further communiques. The order presaged a possible news blackout over Laos' fight to maintain her independence.
A churchman's faith was questioned by a "seeking skeptic'' in a sermon yesterday at St. Luke's Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Parish, 487 Hudson Street, at Barrow Street.
Contractual investment plans, already growing at a record pace, got an unexpected pat on the back last week from one of Wall Street's most conservative houses.
An 8-year-old girl fell nearly three floors from a fire escape outside her Bronx home last night. A boy, 8, told the police he had pushed her and that she lost her balance and fell to her death.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 23 -- Bucharest celebrated the fifteenth anniversary of the World War II liberation of Rumania today with a five-and-a-half-hour parade.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- Britain and Singapore have agreed to set up a committee for consultation on defense and external affairs.

NEWPORT, R. I. Aug. 23 -- Easterner and Weatherly, the two 12-meter sloops that have been racing one another in Eastern ocean waters for a month, completed their series today, with Easterner the winner of the final event.
A power failure, the fourth here in seven days, left twelve buildings in East Seventy-third Street without electric current for several hours yesterday afternoon.

Some of the arguments now advanced against bringing out of the House committee, where it has stayed since May, the "Health for Peace" bill do not ring entirely true. It is now urged in some quarters that there may be Administration opposition unless the basis for the control of funds to set up an international medical research institute is modified.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers, sparked by a rookie, George Dixon, gained ,a 24-17 victory over the San Francisco Forty-Niners in a professional football exhibition today.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Aug. 23 -- The call money rate last week was lowered one-quarter to only 1 per cent, which is an extraordinary low rate.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians drove closer to first place in the American League today by sweeping a double-header from the Boston Red Sox, 1 -- 0 and 6 -- 2. It stretched the Cleveland winning streak to six games.
Cotton futures prices were narrowly irregular last week but closed with higher net changes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- The Treasury said today that customs agents would investigate charges that a law requiring complete markings on goods imported from East Germany had been violated.
The number of psychiatrists in the United States has increased 21.2 per cent in the last three years, the American Psychiatric Association and the National Association for Mental Health report.

The steamship charter market registered slight gains last week, principally in grain-cargo rates, moving the index up for the first time in four weeks. The volume of business, however, dropped again to sub-normal summer lows.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 23 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of Haiti have sent a strong protest to the Government against police brutality in dispersing the congregation at Notre Dame Cathedral last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Although only sixteen American high schools offered courses in Russian when the first Soviet sputnik went up twenty-two months ago, more than 400 schools will teach it this September.

A twelve-story office building will be constructed at the southeast corner of Queens Boulevard and Seventieth Road 125 feet west of Continental Avenue, in Forest Hills, Queens. It will be built by Louis, Harry, Nathan and Morton Licht, the: principal stockholders in thel Lane Realty Company, and will cost $3,000,000, including value of the land.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 23 -- Stirling Moss of England, driving a low, slim Cooper, won the Grand Prix of Portugal with ridiculous ease today and lifted himself back into the battle for the drivers' world championship.
LAUNDRY equipment manufacturers have washed another problem down the drain in their new 1960 appliances.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that he fafored inviting Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to address Congress provided the Soviet leader could be assured of "reasonable courtesy."

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Tom Nieporte of Bronxville, N. Y., won his first tournament today after six years of touring. He shot a 72-hole total of 267 to take the Rubber City open by a three-stroke margin over Bob Goalby of Crystal River, Fla.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- For some weeks, a backstage drama has been enacted here by a Hollywood director, a script writer, assorted Congressmen and State Department officials, Marlon Brando, Ambassador Gilbert MacWhite and a beautiful Eurasian girl, named Ruth Jyoto.
Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it would extend its jet service to six additional European cities starting Oct. 25.

MATTITUCK, L. I., Aug. 23 -- Two-thirds of the 3,000 residents of this eastern Long Island village turned out today to honor Dr. Stanley P. Jones, a general practitioner here for more than thirty years.
HAVANA, Aug. 23 -- The Cuban Boy Scout organization was attacked today by Hoy, the Communist party newspaper, as an "instrument of the church and imperialism."
HAVANA, Aug. 23 -- The Cane Planters Association has asked the Government to take over forty-three of Cuba's 161 sugar mills on the ground that they have not paid their debts.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 23 -- Usually, when art is mentioned unashamedly here, the reference is not to what goes on a movie screen, but to what hangs on a wall.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 23 -- Pro - Communist insurgents have attacked and infiltrated parts of Vientiane Province, Western military sources said here today.

OSWALD JACOBY of Dallas was captain of the team that won the contract bridge Masters' Team Championship in the national tournament at Chicago earlier this month and, with his teammates, he won the right to play for the United States in the world-championship tournament next year.

Art Carney will do a solo performance in a one-hour television play next season over the National Broadcasting Company network. It is titled "Call Me Back," the story of an alcoholic who finds himself in desperate circumstances.

The surprise decision of the House Ways and Means Committee to shelve the President's request for removal of the archaic interest rate ceiling on Government bonds should not be dismissed lightly. It is doubly inflationary and it will cause an increase in the servicing cost of the national debt.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- (AP) Henry Kearns, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs, said today he believed the sharp slump in American sales abroad had touched bottom.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Mrs. James Mertz of the host American Yacht Club held a one and one-quarter point lead for the women's North American sailing championship after the first three races in a seven-race round-robin were sailed today.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 24 -- The Protocol Division of the West German Foreign Ministry has solved a ticklish problem in connection with President Eisenhower's forthcoming visit to Bonn.

Seaboard Finance Company, Los Angeles, and Montgomery Ward Co. Chicago, have announced new moves in the consumer credit field. RHODES, Greece, Aug. 24 -- Orthodox church leaders told the Central Committee of the World Council of Churches today that their meeting last Friday with two Roman Catholic clerics was "an absolutely informal contact."

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- The Yankees, still hopeful of making their presence felt in the American League pennant race, cut a father sorry figure today. They just rattled around a bit and wound up doing nothing as they bowed to Al Lopez' hustling White Sox, 4 to 2, in the series finale.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- A state labor leader charged here today that "big business" was holding back improvements in protective legislation for injured and unemployed workers. He cited advances made in other states.

JIM LEE HOWELL blinked in mild astonishment at the Dallas airport on Saturday morning when he spotted for the first time this year the wife of one of his stars. He had to look twice to recognize her because she had become a platinum blonde. Not even a 28-3 drubbing by the Baltimore Colts the night before could blunt the Howell sense of humor.

A series of weekly radio reports to the public by Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, will begin next month over WNYC, the municipal radio station.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A photograph of a Chinese child holding an empty rice bowl has been removed from Edward Steichen's "Family of Man" display at the American National Exhibition here.

TRENTON, Aug. 24 -- A gift of matches to a prisoner in a padded cell was blamed today for the disastrous fire that swept the Ocean County jail at Toms River yesterday. Eight prisoners lost their lives in the blaze.
WASHINGTON, Aug 24 (UPI) -- Grocery products containing coupons redeemable in United States Savings Stamps went on sale here today. But a Congressional investigation clouded their future

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Rocky Nelson hit two homers tonight in sparking the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 6-0 victory over the league-leading San Francisco Giants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A House-passed bill to tighten the requirements for the subsidizing of ship operations was opposed today by the Maritime Administration at a hearing by a Senate subcommittee. It was endorsed by some American-flag ship operators and opposed by one of them.
BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Order of the Sons of Italy in America adopted a resolution today condemning screen and television productions based on the alleged existence of Mafia in this country.
ROME, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Eugene Cardinal Tisserant, dean of the College of Cardinals, said today that the Ecumenical Council called by Pope John XXIII would seek only to unite Roman Catholics.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 24 -- The Country Art Gallery, a converted Methodist church, will be the setting for three weeks, Sept. 20 to Oct. 10, for a benefit show of paintings by well-known amateur and professional artists for the Cerebral Palsy Treatment Center at Roosevelt. Mrs. William C. Langley and Miss Anita Colby are co-chairmen of the benefit.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- Half-pint Mickey Cohen savored his joke today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Senate passed today a bill liberalizing the lending and borrowing powers of national banks.

Watching Congress at Work With the Eighty-sixth Congress now nearing the end of this first session, and the hot summer weather taking vacationers far from their homes, it is not surprising to see license plates adorning autos from every state in our Union parked in every possible space surrounding our nation's Capitol.
ANEO-ROMAN church is not a very likely place for a Mozart comic opera, but "The Impresario" made a big hit in one last night.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Irish Jay of the Wheatley Stable was moved up to victory in the $79,900 Spinaway Stakes today after finishing second to the Windfield Farms' Natalma. The six-furlong event for 2-year-old fillies was decided by the stewards, who revised the order of finish after a jockey's objection against Natalma, a 9-1 shot.

Fear of a meat packers' strike when contracts expire at the end of the month caused some short covering in the hides market on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Prices rose 50 to 95 points (hundredths of a cent). A total of 142 lots (40,000 pounds each) changed hands.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 24 -- The noncompulsory saying of the morning prayer in the public schools was held constitutional by the State Supreme Court here today.

A 17-year-old youth-gang leader was charged yesterday with killing a 15-year-old girl in Sunday night's outburst of shootings and stabbings on the lower East Side. Three other teen-agers were arrested as a result of the violence.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen declared today that "the Republican party doesn't play politics with civil rights."
A four year-old dream of Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore for redevelopment of the area about the Long Island Rail Road Terminal has been revived in modified form as a Title I project.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that he despaired of further efforts by Congress to provide adequate financing for the Development Loan Fund "without Executive backing."

A city report to Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that responsibility for the power failure that blacked out five square miles of Manhattan on Aug. 17 "rests squarely with the Consolidated Edison Company."

The five-story apartment building at 347 East Fifty-first Street has been sold by the Day-fell Realty Corporation, represented by Emanuel Pearlman, to the Danfred Realty Corporation, of which Fred H. Hill is president.

BRANCHBURG TOWNSHIP N. J. Aug. 21 Two construction workers were killed today when an eight-ton section of pipe rolled on top of them in a ditch. A third man narrowly escaped.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The average traffic court was depicted today as an unimpressive cubby - hole that does nothing to acquaint citizens with the majesty of the law.

Governor Rockefeller held his first meeting yesterday with his newly appointed Harness Racing Commission. He announced that the commission's first act would be to set up a code of ethics for itself and for state personnel at the tracks.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Britain demonstrated a fuel cell today and announced that she had another in development that promised wide commercial application.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 24 -- A statistician, amateur or pro, could go wild here at the National Rifle Matches but no statisticians were hanging around here tonight. It was a pity; what a dazzling job of digital dancing could be done here!

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 24 -- The Dalai Lama estimates that Tibet's struggle for freedom from Communist China has cost 80,000 lives. He says his country is heading toward extermination.

ALBANY, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller today appointed James O'Malley Jr., a New York City lawyer and former assistant district attorney under Thomas E. Dewey, as New York's member of the bi-state Waterfront Commission.

COOKING with roses may not appear to be a subject with enough scope to fill a whole cookbook. But Miss Jean Gordon has come up with a 100-page volume that is bound, as might be expected, in a rosy-red cover.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- The fat scrapbooks of press clippings are of little value now to the rookie quarterback at the New York Football Giants training camp here.

Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company, Atlanta, Ga., plans to sell $70,000,000 of 35-year debentures to finance construction, it was announced yesterday. The debentures will be sold at competitive bidding on Oct. 20.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 24 -- The drama program of this year's Edinburgh Festival was opened tonight, with the chief contribution being the customary visit of the Old Vic company in a preview of one its autumn productions.

Seaboard Air Line Railroad sold yesterday $4,470,000 of equipment trust certificates to finance the purchase of box cars. The certificates were purchased by a group of investment bankers headed by Halsey Stuart Co., Inc., at a price of 98.15 for a 4 1/2 per cent interest coupon.

"Spinster," the novel by Syl a Ashton - Warner describing r experiences teaching Maori ildren, has been acquired by atro - Goldwyn - Mayer. The ama will be produced for the adio by Julian Blaustein's inpendent company.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan received yesterday what he called a "harrowing" report on relocation practices for the Penn Station South Title 1 housing project.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Six civil suits, charging thirty-five defendants with defrauding the Columbus Rexall Oil Company and its stockholders of $12,589,024, are on file here in United States District Court.
DURBAN, South Africa, Aug. 24 (Reuters) - Club - swinging policemen charged 200 stone-throwing African women and made one arrest today as anti-Government violence continued in Natal Province.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 24 -- The American Legion convention appeared today to be headed toward an open clash on the racial issue.
A truce of sorts was declared yesterday between Carmine G. De Sapio and Charles McGuinness in their battle for the Democratic leadership of the First Assembly District South.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The captain of a Cunard ocean liner, scheduled within months to become master of the Queen Mary and then the Queen Elizabeth, has been dismissed.

The election of three directors of the General American Oil Company of Texas was announced yesterday by A. H. Meadows, chairman. They are Rushton L. Ardrey, William L. Kistler Jr. and Charles W. Lewis.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 24 -- Leaders of the American Bar Association were fuming today over an appearance by Mickey Cohen, West Coast mobster, at a seminar on legal tactics.

LISBON, Aug. 24 -- It is not uncommon in bullfighting for a bull to hurdle the barrier into take callejon, the passage between the barrera and the grandstand. What is rare is for the animal's leap to carry it over barrera and callejon into the first row of seats.
HONG KONG, Aug. 24 -- There will be no let-up in Communist China's production drive and no slackening in the political pressures that go with it.

There will be a two-hour-and-forty-minute period today when Customs officials will be faced with an incoming passenger every two seconds, according to calculations by the trans-Atlantic steamship lines.
Dishes fit for kings as well as tidbits to take the dullness out of dieting were offered in lavish variety yesterday at the fifth annual Fancy Food and Confection Show at the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower nominated twelve National Guard and Army Reserve officers for promotion to major general today. He also nominated ten Guard and Reserve colonels to be brigadier generals.

Reflecting, the substantially larger sales transacted by the Associated Dry Goods Corporation in the second quarter, six and twelve months ended on Aug. 1, earnings exceeded those of the corresponding periods a year earlier.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The stock market began the week on a cheerful note today. Business expanded and the industrials scored far more minor gains than losses, raising the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary stocks .9 point to 256.3, to reach the seventh high in as many days of trading.
Subway riders and Long Island Rail Road commuters were affected yesterday by a variety of transit delays.

STONE HARBOR, N. J., Aug. 24 -- People go bird watching even in the early moonlight in this South Jersey community. And with good reason. For here, in the opinion of ornithologists, is the largest heronry in the North.
William P. Rosensohn indicated yesterday for the first time that there was "underworld money" involved in his promotion of the June heavyweight championship fight.
Store owners and buyers snapped up thousands of wholesale offerings yesterday at the semi-annual Gift Show in the New Yorker Hotel and the New York Trade Show Building.
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, Aug. 24 -- The government announced today that African representation in the Legislative Council would be increased from five to seven members.
Decision was reserved yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court on a writ seeking the release of Martin Rothstone, grandson of the late Samuel Levy, from a sanitarium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today control and interlocking relationships embracing the Atlas Corporation, of which Floyd Odlum is chairman, two airlines and other aviation companies. The board said the relationships would not create monopolies and, by enabling, Transocean Air Lines, Oakland, Calif., to stave off bankruptcy, would be consistent with the public interest.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Gus Triandos hit two home runs and two singles, driving in seven of the Baltimore Orioles' runs in a 11-0 rout of the Detroit Tigers today.

Of the eight prisoners who died in the fire in the Ocean County jail in Toms River, N. J., on Sunday, only one was charged with an offense as serious as murder. We do not know how guilty any one of them was. One of them was thought to be mentally deranged.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Sandra Clifford of Mexico City won an opening-round match in the women's United States amateur golf championship today that held international interest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter told foreign policy leaders of the Senate and House today that he regarded the situation in Laos, where Communist forces are fighting Government troops, as "very dangerous."
MUSSOORIE, India, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- The Dalai Lama said more people were joining the 50,000 Khamba tribesmen who were fighting the Chinese in the Chamdo and Giamda areas of eastern Tibet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Representative Francis E. Walter has written to President Eisenhower advising him study the facts of Communist espionage and subversion before he talks with Premier Nikita Khruschchev.
CHICAGO, Aug, 24 (AP) -- Sunny Blue Farm's Venetian Way scored an upset victory over ten highly regarded 2-year-olds today in the $18,225 Prairie State Stakes at Arlington Park.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 24 -- Haiti will demand that the Vatican recall the Most Rev. Francois Poirier, ranking Roman Catholic prelate here, for having criticized the Government of President Francois Duvalier.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 24 -- A merger of the First New Haven National Bank and the Union and New Haven Trust Company was approved today by the directors of both banks. The new name would be the First Union New Haven National Bank.

Scheduled airlines of the International Air Transport Association carried more passengers over the North Atlantic in the second quarter of this year than in the same period of 1958, the association reported yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 -- Pleas were made here today for a space and rocket program with achievable goals, simple equipment and reliable performance. The pleas keynoted the opening of a national conference on missile and space technology.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Senate Education subcommittee unanimously approved today a two-year $1,000,000,000 bill for Federal aid for school construction only.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- Mr. Nehru told Parliament that India had sent some notes to the Peiping Government concerning the sitation in Tibet. He said "we expect a formal reply from them."
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 24 -- A Government spokesman denied today that plans had been abandoned for segregating the races in the Ciskei area of eastern Cape Province.
FRANCONIA, N. H., Aug. 24 -- Two young climbers died today on a rain-swept cliff a few minutes after a rescue team had reached them.

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- The dismissal of Eduards K. Berklavs, a Latvian Deputy Premier, was disclosed to Moscow readers today. He had been accused of having put Latvian interests ahead of those of the Soviet state.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- The Chrysler Corporation will have a production capacity of 880 units a day for its new lightweight car, the Valiant, when its assembly begins this fall.

The New York City Housing Authority is planning the sale of $21,470,000 of temporary loan notes on Sept. 1 for the financing of five State-subsidized projects. The developments are Redfern Addition, Queens; Butler Houses, the Bronx; Stapleton Houses, Staten Island; and Hamilton Houses and Wilson Houses, Manhattan.
Steel producers not affected by the six-week-old strike turned out 321,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Machinists struck West Coast shipyards from San Francisco to the Canadian border today in a demand for higher wages.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24 -- One of the most important Protestant groups on the West Coast has attacked American movies for their overemphasis on sex and violence.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The first solid bullish influence to hit the wheat futures market in several weeks raised prices of that grain sharply today on the Board of Trade.

Steven Rockefeller brought his Norwegian bride of two days home to the United States yesterday and promptly "disappeared" with her as he had promised, for a honeymoon planned to last at least a month.

WEST YELLOWSTONE, Mont., Aug. 24 (AP) -- A list of persons unreported since last week's Montana earthquake was made public by the Red Cross today -- and almost immediately many of those listed were found to be alive and well.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- England completed a sweep of its five-match cricket test series against India today, defeating the visitors by an innings and 27 runs at the Oval.
Robert Moses asked the city yesterday to take an important step toward making the vision of a 1964 World's Fair a reality.

If all goes well today the first sections of two 24-inch concrete encased pipes, 6,200 feet long, will be laid for underwater crossings from Staten Island to Brooklyn. The operation was to have begun yesterday but was postponed to permit regrading of the entry slope.

A committee of 100 has been appointed to plan for a theatre party at "Gypsy" at the Broadway Theatre on Oct. 1. The event will benefit Irvington House at Irvington-on-Hudson. N. Y., a research and treatment center for children with rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease.

When President Eisenhower leaves for Europe tomorrow to consult with our allies before meeting Premier Khrushchev he will be confronted with a situation that will test his personal diplomacy to the utmost.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Congress today seated three members from Hawaii, which was proclaimed the fiftieth state Friday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The report today's livestock markets here by the Dpartment of Agriculture follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 -- The Los Angeles Dodgers, it developed tonight, didn't "die" in Pittsburgh over the weekend. In the words of one of their own men, they were "only half-killed," and by way of proving it, Walter Alston's lads battered the Phillies, 8 -- 2, at Connie Mack Stadium.
The largest domestic miner of lead, the St. Joseph Lead Company, yesterday advanced the price 1 cent a pound to 13 cents
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 -- The news from Sweden that Los Angeles was in line for the world heavyweight championship fight next year came as a surprise to everyone.
Stocks declined yesterday in the slowest trading in almost a year and a half.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- The Ford Motor Company announced today the incorporation of a wholly-owned credit and financing subsidiary.

Plans for a music salon on the ground floor of the Union Carbide Building, now rising at 270 Park Avenue, have been announced by Frank Freimann, president of the Magnavox Company. Negotiations for a long-term lease for the showroom were completed yesterday by Mr. Freimarm and George Miller, president of the Union Carbide Realty Company.

From the deserts to the mountain tops, wilderness in America, big and little, is in tragic retreat. Those of us who have lived close to it these last fifty years have a glimpse of what is in store for the fifty years ahead.
A musical adaptation of Eugene O'Neill's romantic and satiric pageant, "Marco Millions," is being prepared for the Broadway stage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A conference committee of the Senate and the House agreed on three changes in the Taft-Hartley sections of the labor reform bill today.
Two certified checks totaling $122,766 are being held by the New York State Athletic Commission for Ingemar Johansson.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- The White House announced today the following schedule for President Eisenhower on his trip to Germany, Britain and France (all times are regional):
Miles Davis, a leading jazz trumpet player, was arrested in the assault of a patrolman early this morning.
The Commissioner of Marine and Aviation yesterday sharply criticized the City Planning Commission for "failing to consult me" about future plans for pier developments on the East River.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Wheat Cleveland of Fair Hope, Ala., today won the first race in the national Thistle Class sailing championship series. A fleet of 54 craft sailed.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 25 -- A high Government source said today that the widening split between the regime of President Francois Duvalier and the Roman Catholic hierarchy would be healed by mediation.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 25 (AP) -- A Polaris test rocket shot over the Atlantic today but failed to achieve all its goals because of trouble in the second stage.

IF you are frugal enough to sit in the southern seat ranks at Theatre-in-the-Park, the view across the stage is less distracting. The trees of Central Park disappear into a general darkness that provides some sort of background to the performance.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- The House passed today and returned to the Senate legislation temporarily limiting states' powers to tax the income of businesses that cross state lines to seek sales.

The 1959 racing and rallying season of the Sports Car Club of America is moving into the final stages: Six more national rallies are on the calendar. Five national races remain to be contested. Except for some of the smaller classes in the racing divisions, there are no clear-cut decisions for championships.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation achieved record net sales of $90,812,353 in the quarter ended July 31, first of its fiscal year. This was 6 per cent, or $5,253,171, above the 1958 figure, John R. Kimberly, president and chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting held yesterday in Neenah, Wis.

HAVANA, Aug. 25 -- The state has asked a civil court in Santiago de Cuba to sentence three women and ten men to death on charges of participating in the recent counterrevolutionary plot, it was reported today.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25 -The country's 250,000 metalworkers struck today for higher wages.
OLDWICK, N. J., Aug. 24 -The neighbors were dumbfounded early this summer when William R. Whitehead set up a railroad-crossing sign on Whitehouse Road near his house.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress on debt management:

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- With new arrivals checking in hourly, the University of Chicago's sylvan campus swarmed today with the athletes who will begin competition Thursday in the third Pan-American Games.
The W. T. Grant Company, one of the nation's largest retail store organizations, has a new president. He is Louis C. Lustenberger, who was formerly executive vice president and general manager.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The flow of private capital from the United States to other countries has slowed this year, the Department of Commerce reported today. It said the tight money situation was partly responsible.
The Transit Authority contended yesterday that there had been no increase in subway disruptions thus far this year as compared with recent years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Government announced today agreements relieving it of obligations to buy about 26 million pounds of nickel from the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., (Inco) for the national stockpile.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 25 -- It is sad to have to record that the only new play to be offered officially during this year's Edinburgh Festival should be a disappointment but there the fact is.

GOODING, Idaho, Aug. 25 (AP) -- John Hunt Jr., 37 years old, a faculty member at Yale University, was found shot to death in his foreign sports car today. Sheriff Keith Anderson said he had probably been murdered.

ATLANTA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- A nation-wide search for a 43-year-old handyman wanted for the slaying of a prominent Washington woman ended today with the arrest of Larry Lord Motherwell. Motherwell was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation at the Atlanta Airport as he was about to board a plane for Cleveland.

BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., Aug. 25 -- American Motors, the compact car champion, demonstrated its Sunday punch today to counter the challenge by the big three automobile companies in the small-car arena.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 25 -- This capital was thrown into confusion today by a drastic devaluation and a freezing of assets.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25 -- Henry Sargeant, president of American and Foreign Power Company, flew to New York today to consider the power rate cut decreed in Cuba for the company's affiliate, Cuban Electric Company.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Aug. 25 (UPI) -- The rhythmic beat and instrumental wails of a nineman jazz orchestra echoed through a Purdue University auditorium today and 1,000 young persons at a religious conference bowed their heads in reverence.

Directors of the Zenith Radio Corporation increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock yesterday with the declaration of 40 cents a share for payment on Sept. 29. The preceding payment was 25 cents in June, following a three-for-one stock split.

In view of his interest in the preservation of Greenwich Village I think Whitney North Seymour Jr. need look no further than the provisions of the Residential Rent Control Law to determine why Greenwich Village is being transformed as he claims it is.
The underworld figure behind the Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson title fight was identified yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

Alexander L. Guterma, financial wizard, and Lowell M. Birrell, fugitive financier, were linked yesterday to a stock-fraud scheme in which each is said to have profited by more than $1,000,000 at the public's expense.

A report that interests in Casablanca had purchased Cuban raw sugar at prices well below quotations in the futures market depressed world sugar prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

The schools of New York City and its suburbs will teach more Russian courses this fall than did all the schools of the United States in pre-sputnik days. Two years ago there were sixteen such courses, given for credit, across the country.
President Eisenhower re-emphasized yesterday that he would not intervene in the steel strike unless the national health and security were endangered.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- An immediate and vast speedup in the study of the oceans is needed for America's defense and for better understanding of the weather, a Yale University oceanographer testified today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Strategic Air Command disclosed today that one of its aircraft commanders had flown a $2,500,000 jet bomber under the Straits of Mackinac Bridge, which connects Michigan's upper and lower peninsulas.

It has been my practice periodically to complain to the city Air Pollution Control Department about the thick black smoke belching from most of the chimneys in this area -Central Park West and Sixty-eighth to Sixty-ninth Street. Customarily, too, I receive a form reply stating that the complaint has been received. And there it ends.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- A General Electric engineer said today he was on a secret Defense Department committee that had picked a G. E. engine for the first launching of a United States satellite. He denied having used improper influence.
Cargo transportation by jet planes has become a priority item for the Civil Aeronautics Board.

MOSCOW, Aug. 25 -- Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic gave Moscow music lovers a traditionshattering concert of new musical sounds tonight. It was not merely a tremendously successful performance but also one of the most exciting events in Moscow's recent musical history.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- An orthopedic surgeon and a Roman Catholic priest urged today that patients with incurable cancer be told the truth about the disease.

RHODES, Greece, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- The Central Committee of the World Council of Churches decided today to hold a full debate next year on the problem of religious liberty in Roman Catholic countries.

The Rev. Etienne Grienenberger, one of two French priests expelled from Haiti last Thursday, has charged another priest, the Rev. Hubert Papailler, with being responsible for the expulsion order. Father Papailler is the Haitian Minister of Education.

THE cheerful voice of Carmen Basilio bridged the miles yesterday from San Francisco where the craggy-featured little guy is training for Friday's fight with Gene Fullmer for the virtually undisputed middleweight championship of the world. The winner will be recognized as the champion in almost every state except New York, where Ray Robinson mesmerized the State Athletic Commission into letting him keep New York's version of the crown in his personal deep-freeze locker.

VIENTIANE, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Communist guerrillas were ac tive today in eight of the twelve Laotian provinces, according to reports received here. But the only skirmishes reported were between Laotian troops and rebels near Pak Seng, thirty-five miles northeast of the city of Luang Prabang.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- A third major singer has been lost to the San Francisco Opera Company's forthcoming season. Eleanor Steber, American soprano, today notified Kurt Herbert Adler, the opera's general director, that she was ill and was entering a hospital.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -A compromise school construction bill is being drafted by two Senate Republicans.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Conservative party leaders called today for the expenditure of 7,000,000 to 10,000,000 ($19,600,000 600,000 to $28,000,000) a year to $2,000,000) a year to assure a "creative use of leisure."

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 25 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon, with President Eisenhower's approval, revived today the "captive nations" issue that caused the Vice President many unpleasant moments during his recent visit to the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Aug. 26 -- Under bright stars and a silvery half moon, President Eisenhower headed toward Newfoundland and Bonn, Germany, at 3:57 A. M. today in the first jet-powered aircraft flight by a President.

Diebold, Inc., will go to court seeking to complete its purchase of the Herring-Hall-Marvin Company, Raymond Koontz, president of Diebold, announced yesterday. On Monday, the Department of Justice filed a civil antitrust suit in Federal Court in Cincinnati to stop the proposed acquisition and obtained a ten-day restraining order blocking the transaction.

Prices of United States Government securities continued to decline yesterday, but less than on Monday. There even was some slight improvement in yields among the special bill issues due in April and July of next year.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 25 -Cleveland's pennant drive moved apace tonight as the Yankees, who seem to be getting stepped on by everybody, once again failed to cause even minor ripple in the American league race.

THE FLAME TREES OF THIKA: Memories of an African Childhood,"* by Elspeth Huxley, is an entrancing book, the best-written and most-appealing book about Africa that I have read since Isak Dinesen's "Out of Africa," which was published twenty-one years ago. Mrs. Huxley is a gifted writer with a phenomenal memory, not only for the factual past but also for the past as it seemed to be to the child she once was.

The first of 108 new public lash trays was unveiled yesterday in the middle of Times Square. Fifty of the aluminum buttcatchers have been helping to keep the streets clean throughout the city since April, 1958.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -Barnett International Airfreight, New York, and Air Dispatch, Inc., Memphis, Tenn., will affiliate, the two companies announced today.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 25 -This little university city, which became a political capital almost by chance, prepared excitedly today for the coming of President Eisenhower.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 25 -Prime Minister Nehru denounced the Communist party's techniques and ideology today.
Three operators of tenements were fined a total of $200 yesterday in the Manhattan Housing and Buildings Court, 455 West 151st Street, for insanitary conditions.

IN today's hand the widely played Fishbein convention was used. This convention is a defense against opponents' pre-emptive bids. A double of a pre-emptive bid is for penalties and a no-trump overcall may be passed, but an overcall in the next-higher suit calls upon partner to bid.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- Archbishop Makarios summoned today a special meeting of the Greek Cypriote Consultative Assembly to discuss the current crisis between Greeks and Turks on constitutional issues.

PRICE, Utah, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Edgar Bloom Stern, a New Orleans civic and business leader, died here last night after he became ill aboard a train and was taken to a local hospital. He was 73 years old.

The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $25,900,000 on temporary loan notes yesterday to finance the development of Castle Hill Houses, a state-subsidized project in the Bronx. The borrowing was accomplished at an interest cost of 2.63896 per cent.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Ross Barnett, a 60year-old lawyer who advocates open defiance of the United States Supreme Court desegregation rulings, won nomination tonight as the Democratic candidate for Governor of Mississippi.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Late this fall a new and vital phase is due to open in a race against time that partakes of the epochal. The goal is the economic stabilization of the Mediterranean region, sometimes dubbed the cradle of civilization.

Sales promotion coupons that may be exchanged for United States Savings Stamps will be introduced in this area next week. The plan, approved by the Treasury Department, is being promoted under the name of National Own a Bit of America Program.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- A thinly veiled call upon President Charles de Gaulle to assume dictatorial powers to consolidate the French Community and settle the Algerian problem has been published by a high French official.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Prices of British Government securities fell sharply on the stock market here today. Industrials also weakened after setting highs for seven sessions in a row.

Youth crime has risen 14 per cent in the city in the first half of this year, according to police statistics. But municipal officials and social workers said yesterday that this was the result of individuals' crimes, and that gang violence had actually decreased in recent years.

Circle in the Square finally has resolved its pressing need for a new home. The group, which over the years won for itself one of the finest artistic reputations in legitimate theatre circles, has obtained a long-term lease on the Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a resolution designed to force an early decision on a proposed United States site for a World's Fair in 1964.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -President Eisenhower warned Congress today of the "very serious implications" of failure to pass legislation removing interestrate ceilings on Government securities.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., Aug. 25 -- A decision on whether to continue a private segregated school was postponed last night by the Warren County Educational Foundation.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Otto Standke, the professional bird chaser, said tonight that he was sure he could get rid of the starlings here if he could only get rid of the people first.

Randall J. LeBoeuf Jr., senior partner in the law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb Leiby, has been named a Special Assistant Attorney General to handle New York's case against Illinois pending in the United States Supreme Court.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman warned Democrats yesterday to guard against overconfidence on next year's Presidential election. "It will be a real fight," he predicted.

Consumers spent $45,580,000,000 on foods and non-foods in the nation's supermarkets and grocery stores in 1958, an increase of $2,540,000,000 over the year before, the Topics Publishing Company reported yesterday in its twelfth annual study on "What the Public Spends."

HONG KONG, Aug. 26 -- A North Vietnamese spokesman warned today that if the Laotian Government continued to "toe the line of the United States in expanding the civil war," and if the "United States imperialists continue their military interference in Laos," the two countries will meet with "bitter failure and will have to bear the full responsibility for all disastrous consequences."

Transportable classrooms and convertible schools may be in prospect for this city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Legislation to finance continuation of the interstate highway program encountered more trouble today. The dispute began to take on aspects of a stalemate. Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point off to 3 points up yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Sellers taking profits went to work in the wheat futures market today, but prices on the Board of Trade held steady.

The Equitable Leasing Corporation, which recently opened offices in the Equitable Office Building, 120 Broadway, announced yesterday that it was processing $11,000,000, in leases covering a wide range of equipment to be used here and abroad.
