WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Aug. 25 -- Suffolk County Air Force Base, charged with defending New York City against enemy air attack, is being equipped with F-101B Voodoo jet fighter-interceptors.

The master of the giant ocean liner Queen Elizabeth testified yesterday that she was sailing out of the harbor on the "right side of the channel" when she collided July 29 with the freighter American Hunter.

Has the almost uninterrupted post-war rise in consumer prices resumed the upward march that carried the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics from an average of 59.9 for the year 1940 to 124.9, the figure just reported for July of this year ?
The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway reported yesterday for the seven months that ended on July 31 a net income of $37,445,029, or $1.39 a common share. Net income for July was $6,745,445.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 25 -- A South African research team has developed a vaccine that it hopes will prove effective in combating trachoma, a severe form of conjunctivitis that frequently causes blindness.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The compromise housing bill made important progress in the House today with prospects good for passage before the end of the week.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- All Hands of the Cain Hoy Stable and James G. Brady's Brickwork waged a thrilling stretch duel in the six-furlong race that featured the program today, with the former winning.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 -The type of eater you are could affect your adaptability as a space traveler.

Ernest J. Simmons, Professor of Russian literature at Columbia University, admitted that "there was some truth" in the charge made by the spokesman of a group of visiting Soviet journalists that American publishers fail to print Russian books other than those which are unfavorable to the Soviet Union or Soviet policies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee today approved the nomination of James Smith Bush, Missouri banker and brother of Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, to be a director of the Export-Import Bank.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- James R. Durfee, now chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be a judge of the United States Court of Claims.
Julio Rosario, 14 years old, who was stabbed during the outbreak of violence on the lower East Side Sunday night, died at 11:30 P. M. yesterday in Gouverneur Hospital.

A Marine Corps pilot yesterday told what it's like to be ejected from a disabled plane nine miles above the earth, drop seven miles without a parachute, shiver down through a thunderstorm, bang into a pine tree, stagger onto a highway, wave to a motorist for help -- and have the motorist wave back.
In a transaction that is thought to involve more than $3,500,000, The Conde Nast Publications, Inc., has purchased Street Smith Publications, Inc.
Men's fall suits will rise about $1 a garment at the wholesale level, according to Jerome I. Udell, president of Max Udell Co., Inc., clothing manufacturer.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 25 -Israel asked the Universal Postal Union in Berne, Switzerland, today to recover mail impounded by the United Arab Republic in the Suez Canal.

It was homecoming day on the waterfront yesterday as more than 6,000 passengers arrived from abroad. But not all the day's travelers were those coming home. As the peak return tide from Europe started -- foreshadowing the really big week around Labor Day -- a new outgoing tide was developing under the impetus of thrift season rates.
Atlas Corporation declared yesterday a 5 per cent stock dividend on the common shares, to be paid on Oct. 15 to holders of record of Sept. 15.

American audiences soon will have a chance to judge the socalled "new wave" of French film-makers that have caused such a sensation in Europe. These are the young directors who have been heralded in their own country as the successors to established artists such as Marcel Carne, Rene Clement, Julien Duvivier and Rene Clair.
The next-to-last Brooklyn link in the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway was opened yesterday in a ribbon-cutting ceremony near the Manhattan Bridge.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The league-leading San Francisco Giants hammered Pittsburgh pitchers for fifteen hits tonight and trounced the Pirates, 12 -- 5. The Giant southpaw, John Antonelli, went all the way, allowed ten hits and walloped a two-run homer.

Draft indebtedness of LatinAmerican importers to United States exporters was reduced $200,000 in July, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported. According to the bank's survey of thirteen large commercial banks, collections outstanding on Latin - American countries dropped to $147,900,000 at the end of July.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 25 -- Short, gray-haired Mrs. Nicolina Castagna, who is 89 years old, had a ticket to sail from New York at 11 o'clock this morning aboard the Olympia for her native Italy. Instead, at 11 o'clock, she was standing in Municipal Court here before Magistrate Irving W. Rubin, charged with obtaining money under false pretenses.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Aug. 26 -- President Eisenhower took off by jet plane at 3:57 A. M. this morning for conferences in Bonn, London and Paris.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:
AN informative study of the problems and achievements of American education was offered last night over Channel 4 in "Back to School -- '59."
Stocks rose moderately yesterday in slow trading.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 25 -- The old-time campaign hat is the mark of the shooter, civilian or military, here at the national rifle matches, and the hat makes it simple to separate the contestants from the spectators. That is about the only simple thing here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -The United States has under urgent consideration an appeal from Laos for money and equipment to help combat Communist infiltration.
FRANCONIA, N. H., Aug. 25 -- Seasoned rock climbers recovered today the bodies of two inexperienced climbers who died in an attempt to scale Profile Mountain. The recovery operation took five hours.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Mrs. James M. Mertz of the American Yacht Club retained her lead in the women's North American sailing championship today. She finished second, fourth and first in a fine sailing day on Long Island Sound.
TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 25 (AP) -- A group of the state's leading insurance companies, banks and industrialists has asked permission to start a corporation designed to attract industry to New Jersey.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP) -A son of J. Paul Getty, one of the world's richest men, has been arrested in Saudi Arabia following an automobile accident.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower was supported today in his appraisal of a certain "pressure group."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee approved a "food for peace" bill today. It would expand and broaden the sale and distribution of surplus farm commodities overseas.
ATHENS, Aug. 25 -- President Eisenhower congratulated the American School of Classical Studies in Athens for "significant contributions to ties which bind Greece and the United States."

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (UPI) -Billy Goodman's tenth inning double scored Sherm Lollar tonight to give the Chicago White Sox a 5 -- 4 victory over the Boston Red Sox and keep the Chicagoan's American League lead at two games.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 AP) -- A group of United States Senators took time out today to send telegrams to cheer a lonely football player.
Stewards, stewardesses and pursers of Pan American Airways have ratified terms of a new contract, the Transport Workers Union announced yesterday.
Once again Mayor Wagner has backed away from mid-Manhattan traffic relief by failing to advance conversion to one-way operation of Fifth, Madison, Lexington and Third Avenues.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- The first-place Chicago White Sox, seeking more power, acquired Ted Kluszewski from the Pittsburgh Pirates today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- The three-man board of teamster monitors has tentatively voted to recommend the suspension of Joey Glimco, boss of the union's taxicab drivers Local 777 in Chicago, informed sources said today.

ABOUT $500,000 in French fashions for fall and winter are winging their way to America today. This one planeload of coats, suits, dresses and ball gowns from about ten Paris couture houses are the styles that American stores, manufacturers and dress designers are hoping American women will be unable to resist and will buy by the carload.
DETROIT, Aug. 25 -- It begins to appear tonight that a prized international speed boat trophy may go back to the British Commonwealth of Nations for the first time in 39 years.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The Labor party proposed today the expansion and revision of Britain's eleven-year-old National Health Service.

Twenty-four television programs covering President Eisenhower's trip to Europe and subsequent exchange visits by the President and Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev were announced yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N. J., Aug. 25 -- Five collegiate actresses have returned from the road. Behind them were more than 7,000 miles and thirty performances of Moliere's comedy, "The Doctor in Spite of Himself."
NORTH LONG BEACH, N. J., Aug. 25 -- Three hundred bathers at the United Service Organization Beach here were waved out of the water by lifeguards this afternoon when sharks were discovered offshore.

Before leaving at dawn today on his trip to Europe in preparation for his equally historic meeting with Premier Khrushchev, President Eisenhower took pains, in one of the strongest statements he has ever made, to dispel the fog created around his extraordinary plunge into personal diplomacy.

Harold Menowitz, builder, has purchased a plot of vacant land in Rego Park, Queens, for improvement with an eight-story office building. The site fronts 146 feet on Queens Boulevard, 110 feet on Fifty-ninth Avenue and fiftyone feet on Sixtieth Avenue.
PARIS, Aug. 25 -- France's progressive change-over to a new franc nominally worth 100 old francs, primarily a prestige operation, has tempted some Frenchmen to cheat on prices.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- James B. Carey, president of the International Electrical Workers Union, wrote to another Congressman today, accusing him of being a "mouthpiece" for business.
Mayor Wagner will interrupt his vacation today to look into charges of "harrowing" relocation practices on the site for the Penn Station South housing project.

Two accounts of the San Francisco earthquake and fire of 1906 are scheduled for publication a week apart. Tomorrow, Coward-McCann will issue "The Damndest Finest Ruins," by Monica Sutherland, a "tourist" from England.

The House Ways and Means Committee did not find it easy to get on the right track of responsible financing for the interstate highwaybuilding program, but now it shows signs of standing firm against further compromise. It voted yesterday, 16 to 9, to reaffirm its support of a twenty-two-month imposition of a 1cent increase in the Federal gasoline tax.
The new Baltimore and Ohio railroad bridge across Arthur Kill went into operation yesterday.

Stockholders of the Ampex Corporation at their annual meeting in Redwood City, Calif., yesterday approved the proposed merger with Orr Industries, Inc., manufacturer of magnetic tape for audio, computer and television applications.

A first mortgage loan of $3,800,000 has been made by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn on the twelve-story industrial building at 360 Furman Street, southwest corner of Joralemon Street, Brooklyn. The loan is for eighteen years at 5 3/4 per cent.
A garment manufacturer here will send 200 of his dress styles to another manufacturer -- a move that might startle the Seventh Avenue garment trade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Paul M. Butler will ask the Democratic National Committee to readopt a 1956 rule that conceivably could bar from the 1960 nominating convention any state omitting names of party nominees from its ballot or electing uninstructed electors.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Two Republican Senators moved today to take civil rights legislation out of the hands of the Judiciary Committee where it has been stalled for weeks.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 25 -- A move to reject a committee report defending Supreme Court decisions in the internal security field was unsuccessful today at the American Bar Association's annual meeting.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Mickey Thompson buzzed his speed car over the Utah desert today at 332,809 miles per hour, the fastest ever driven by an American.

Net premiums written during the first six months of this year by the Federal Insurance Company and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Vigilant Insurance Company, were $36,263,685, it was announced yesterday. This was 4.7 per cent more than the $34,631,002 written in the first half of 1958.

Geographically, Laos and Tibet are far apart; politically they are in the same picture. When Secretary Herter told Congressional leaders on Monday that the situation being created in northern Laos is "very dangerous" and when Prime Minister Nehru told Parliament yesterday that India would defend Bhutan and Sikkim, they were talking about the same thing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Senate Government Operation Committee approved today a bill to create an agency to handle some payments by the Federal Government in lieu of taxes to local governments.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Arnold Stang, the little twangyvoiced comedian, underwent plastic surgery today after he had suffered a broken nose and deep facial cuts when his auto went out of control.
An attempt to obtain a greater share of oil import cargoes for United States-flag tankers will be made by a newly formed joint labor and management association, it was announced yesterday.
The city fathers of London missed an excellent opportunity in 1951. They could have organized an international exposition to celebrate the centennial of the first international exposition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -Henry J. Friendly, New York lawyer, was approved by a Senate judiciary subcommittee today for the Second Federal Circuit Court of Appeals. The Circuit Court is just below the Supreme Court.

THE New York City Ballet is back home again at the City Center. It slipped in last night with a minimum of advance fanfare to open a fourweek season that will take care of the remainder of the summer.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 -- The Carmen Basilio-Gene Fullmer fight cleared an official roadblock today, but the California Athletic Commission remained discreetly silent on a proposed rematch between Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -Anne Quast of Marysville, Wash., the defender, led the favorites through the second round of the women's United States amateur golf championship today.

The sharp rise on Monday in the interest rate on the latest issue of ninety-one-day United States Treasury bills apparently is attracting funds from Britain. The jump in the rate to 3.824 per cent, the highest level since March, 1933, is credited by foreign exchange dealers for a sharply increased spread between spot sterling and sterling futures (sterling bought now for future delivery).

Pacific Gas Electric Company sold yesterday $65,000,000 of first refunding mortgage bonds, due in June, 1991, to finance construction. Blyth Co., Inc., and associates purchased the issue on a bid of 99.36 for obligations carrying a 5 per cent coupon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The nation's electric utilities produced 59,839,908,000 kilowatt hours of electricity during June, a record for the month.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 25 -Dr. Raymond J. Saulnier, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, asserted today that the country could not achieve general price stability unless some industries cut their prices.

Commercial and finance paper outstanding in the United States increased $151,000,000, or 4 per cent, in July from the June level, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Both directly placed and open market paper outstandings rose, whereas they fell in the preceding month.

PARIS, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -An Austrian woman journalist, Maris Kastner-Srubar, 37, has been detained by the police here following complaints by Paris fashion houses that their styles have been fraudulently copied in the United States, Ministry of Justice sources said today.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 25 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that India would go to the defense of Bhutan and Sikkim if they were attacked by any foreign power.
AMONG the maze of exhibits at the National Fancy Food and Confection Show, now taking place at the Astor Hotel, are edibles that should find appeal in a majority of homes.

WHAT do you do after you acquire an island retreat? The same furnishing problem now facing Mrs. George Washburn, whose husband's purchase of North Dumpling Island was reported yesterday, was solved imaginatively and inexpensively a year ago by the owners of Wood Island, shown here.
"A MUSCULAR Christian, that's what I would Call him," said a newsman who was once hustled out of closed meeting in Geneva by the Rev. Dr. Willem Adolf Visser 't Hooft.
A new issue of $125,000,000 of 5 per cent debentures of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation is being offered to the public today by 227 investment banking concerns led by Morgan Stanley Co.

Two four-story buildings containing seventeen apartments at 1423-27 Flatbush Avenue and 2702-20 Farragut Road, Brooklyn, have been purchased for investment by the Bristol Corporation, represented by Orenstein Levine, lawyers.

HONG KONG, Aug. 25 -- Confirmation that Communist China will pursue a tough political and emonomic line for the rest of 1959 was provided at a meeting of the Supreme State Conference in Peiping yesterday.

The reduction ordered on Aug. 20 by the Castro Government in Cuba in electric power rates charged by the American and Foreign Power Company has thrown a cloud over a $15,000,000 financing just carried out for the utility company in the public market of the United States.

MOSCOW, Aug 25 (AP) -The Soviet trade union newspaper Trud chided the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations today for deciding to snub Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev on his visit to the United States next month.
The American Hospital Association was urged yesterday to take the lead in organizing a nation-wide "American Blue Cross."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -Ray Boone, an American League cast-off, saved Milwaukee with a two-out, game-tying pinch single in the ninth. Then Joe Adcock singled home the winning run in the tenth as the Braves defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 -- 1, tonight.

David B. Solove, realty operator, has purchased the six-story walk-up apartment house at 211 to 219 Edgecombe Avenue, south of West 145th Street. The deal was negotiated by Arthur Eckstein, Inc., and Curtis Solove, co-brokers.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Susan Hodgman, a 19-year-old Kalamazoo (Mich.) girl, scored the first upset of the thirty-second Essex Country Club invitation tennis tourney today. She defeated fourthseeded Gwyneth Thomas of Shaker Heights, Ohio, 8 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, in an opening-round match.

The death on Aug. 8 at 85 of the Right Rev. Henry St George Tucker has undoubtedly stirred memories and reflections of an uncommon kind in the minds of many who knew him and came under the quiet power of his personal influence. Distinguished as missionary, educator, theologian and ecclesiastical statesman, it was as a Christian man that he most forcefully and ineffaceably impressed himself upon his contemporaries in church and society.
Manhattan Borough President Hulen E. Jack has prepared a plan for Washington Square Park that would call for removing all public streets. In effect, the streets would be added to the park area.

Directors of the American Electric Power Company have authorized the sale of 1,200,000 additional shares of common stock, valued at $61,000,000 at present market prices, to underwriters at competitive bidding on Oct. 22, Philip Sporn, president, announced yesterday.
The chairman of the Transit Authority threatened yesterday to take 540 "obsolete and broken down" subway cars out of service next year if the city did not give him funds to replace them.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 25 -- Some of the coolest ballplayers in the world and the most overheated parents collaborated today to make the opening of the Little League world series a success.
Some forms of cancer in mice have been arrested by a toxic agent isolated in sea cucumbers by biologists at the Aquarium at Coney Island, it was reported yesterday.

HARRISONBURG, Va., Aug. 25 (AP) -- A New York concern filed a $2,225,000 suit against the General Electric Company of Waynesboro, today, alleging patent infringement, unfair competition and violation of antitrust laws.

Army, Navy and Air Force surplus valued at nearly $3,000,000 will he auctioned off Oct. 7 over closed-circuit television to bidders in six cities, it was annouced yesterday by TelePrompTer Corporation.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., Aug. 25 (AP) -- A group of white students threw stones at newsmen and called them "nigger lovers" today. The incident took place during registration at the nearby Dollarway school where integration of three Negroes has been ordered to begin Sept. 8.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 25 -- A company of Communist rebels was reported today to be cutting through Luang Prabang Province toward the city of Luang Prabang, the royal capital of Laos. Hysterical women and children were said to be fleeing southward.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, Aug. 25 (UPI) -- Ingemar Johansson, the world heavyweight champion, signed contracts today for a return title fight with Floyd Patterson in the United States between March 1 and June 15, 1960.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 25 -- Because of the increased danger of Soviet submarines a new command has been created to defend the West Coast against submarine-launched missiles, the commander of the Pacific Fleet said here today.
Rise Stevens, opera singer, said yesterday on her return from the Soviet Union that the Russian people were "thrilled" over the impending visit to the Soviet Union of President Eisenhower.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 26 -- Fifteen teen-agers were joyriding in a convertible. A policeman in Harrison only smiled when the car stopped in front of him at a red light. Minutes later and a mile down the road the car crashed into a free, killing two of the girls.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev is determined to meet President Eisenhower on an equal footing when he visits the United States next month.

The Board of Elections decided yesterday to use paper ballots instead of voting machines in the Queens Democratic primary on Sept. 15. It attributed its action to the refusal of rival factions to abandon various court actions they have started.
The Waterfront Commission is expected to hold public hearings this fall on two major unsolved harbor-policing problems.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 26 -- The American Legion's national convention refused today to permit voluntary racial integration in local units of the 40 8, the Legion's "fun and frolic" subsidiary.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Southern Democratic leaders were incensed today by Paul M. Butler's plan to deal with any Southern revolt at the party's 1960 national convention.
A 74-year-old public accountant filed a claim for $1,000,199 against the city yesterday. He charged false imprisonment, assault and withholding of personal property.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Vice Chancellor William Marvel of Delaware Chancery Court disapproved today a proposed settlement of a minority stockholders' suit against the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.
John Houseman announced yesterday his resignation as artistic director of the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre at Stratford, Conn.
A new attempt was made yesterday to block the scheduled transfer of 400 Negro pupils from Brooklyn to predominantly white schools in Queens.

Mayor Wagner, in one of his recent statements supporting the proposed $500,000,000 liberalization of the city debt limit for school construction, said every member of the Board of Estimate was aware "that in recent years school construction funds were made available only by the resort of starving every other city activity." He added that the time had come when this "no longer could be done."
Trading in shares of the first Israeli-incorporated company to be listed on an international securities exchange in the United States began on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 26 -- Electronic devices gave an Air Force sergeant a continuous physical examination at Mitchel Air Force Base here today while he reacted to the severe stresses of simulated high-altitude flight.
The time has come for Protestant groups to speak out against Hollywood movies that overemphasize sex and violence, an official of the National Council of the Churches of Christ said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- President Eisenhower got two noes and a qualified yes today to requests laid before Congress yesterday in special messages.

Back from Sweden yesterday as the impresario of the second Johansson - Patterson world heavyweight title fight, Vincent J. Velella said he would sue Bill Rosensohn, the promoter of the first fight, for $5,000,000 for defamation.
HONG KONG, Aug. 26 -- Communist China announced today that its 1958 production figures, issued earlier this year, had been grossly overstated. It also reduced output goals set for 1959.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 26 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus expressed reluctance today to intervene in the school integration dispute at Dollarway. But he declared that he would not dodge his responsibility.

European buyers yesterday took notice of the New York market for defaulted dollar bonds of the Russian Government for the first time since the 5 1/2 and 6 1/2 per cent loans floated here in 1916 were de-listed by the American Stock Exchange in 1956.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 26 -- President Eisenhower was hailed as a hero on his arrival in West Germany today.

WORTH-WHILE world - wide cookbooks are far scarcer than hummingbird tongues. That is why the most recent edition of the United Nations cookbook should find an appreciative audience among amateur chefs with an interest in international cuisine.
Two important changes in procedures for relocating tenants displaced by Title I slum-clearance projects were promised by Mayor Wagner yesterday.

Strong differences of opinion on procedure as well as on major policy between a former President and his successor of the opposite party have been routine in American history. And sometimes, as when Theodore Roosevelt emerged from retirement to prevent the renomination of President Taft, who owed his first nomination to Roosevelt, the eminent disputants have belonged to the same party.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed Walter C. Dowling of Georgia as an Assistant Secretary of State today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Mrs. Paul Klinefelter Jr. of Philadelphia, the mother of three children, scored a surprising victory in the women's United States amateur golf championship today.

A stylish dog is the terrier with the salt and pepper whiskers -- the miniature schnauzer. His square, compact proportions, added to his gaiety and courageous loyalty, make him one of the most popular of the small breeds. Distinctly a pet, he much prefers the house to roaming the countryside.
The $15,000,000 public financing of American and Foreign Power Company, arranged last week, was canceled yesterday.
About 13,000 Connecticut and Westchester commuters were up to fifty-eight minutes late arriving at Grand Central terminal yesterday morning as a result of a delay on the New Haven Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The national capital, plagued by a rise in violence and crime, asked Congress today for 100 more policemen this year and 400 more next year to strengthen its 2,500-man force.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Thousands of Americans were busy today making sure the President would travel in comfort, keep all his appointments on a tight schedule and remain in constant touch with the home office during his ten-day European trip.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 -- Mayor George Christopher telephoned the State Department today that he planned to hold a civic banquet the evening of Sept. 21 for Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev. He noted that Walter P. Reuther and four other labor leaders had announced they would dine with the visiting Soviet Premier here that night.

NEWARK, Aug. 26 -- More than 100 of approximately 300 supervisory and administrative employes of the Newark Board of Education face the loss of their jobs by Jan. 15, 1961, unless they become residents of the city.
Changes in the top management of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, a leading producer of paper and cellulose products, were announced yesterday.

An article in The New York Times on the efforts that had made the airlift of 2,800 books to Moscow possible, published on Aug. 22, erroneously mentioned Combined Book Exhibit, Inc., as the sponsor of the Bookmobile. In fact, the American Library Association is the sponsor.

EXCEPT for a few tables of probabilities that can easily be learned and remembered, mathematics plays little part in bridge skill. Even when mathematical reasoning can be applied, it seldom goes beyond schoolboy arithmetic.
The Maritime Administration has invited proposals for the charter of the 18,298-gross ton Leilani, now idle in San Francisco.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Wilfred J. McNeil, Assistant Secretary of Defense for fiscal operations, said tonight that he was "seriously considering" resigning to enter private industry.

The case of the unwanted dictator of Venezuela, General Perez Jimenez, entered a new phase on Tuesday. The former military ruler, one of the most discredited figures in Latin America, was arrested by United States marshals in Miami and held several hours until he appeared before Judge Emett C. Choate of the Federal District Court.

A three-year study of the relations between the executive and legislative branches of the government will be started Sept. 1 by the Woodrow Wilson Foundation under a grant of $25,000 provided by the Rockefeller Foundation, it was announced yesterday.

The Government filed a civil anti-trust suit yesterday in Federal Court against Audio Fidelity, Inc., manufacturer and seller of high fidelity and stereophonic records and tapes, and its president, Sidney Frey.

A 19-year-old youth, who had been swimming with friends from a barge tied up at a midtown West Side pier, was shot and seriously wounded last night by a barge captain who had tried to chase the group away, the police reported.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 -- The vice president in charge of production at Columbia Pictures spoke up today on behalf of the movie business in reply to criticism by Protestant leaders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) -- Queens Borough President John T. Clancy appealed to members of Congress today to curb the noise made by jet airliners at International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, and at La Guardia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The United States will speed additional aid to Laos to help that small, strategically placed Southeast Asian nation cope with Communist subversion and infiltration:
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 26 (AP) -- A Jupiter missile was fired over the Atlantic tonight in a short-range accuracy test.
PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 26 -- The Haitian Government sent a "fully documented report" on the Aug. 13 invasion from Cuba to the Inter-American Peace Committee in Washington today.

The trustees of the American Hospital Association voted yesterday to recognize hospitals that permitted osteopaths to practice, provided the osteopaths worked under the general supervision of doctors of medicine.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Henry Cooper, the British heavyweight champion, tonight retained his Empire title when the referee stopped his fight with Gawie De Klerk of South Africa in the fifth round to save De Klerk from further punishment.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 -- Cleveland's inspired Indians went roaring to their eighth straight victory tonight as they brought down the Yankees in an exciting battle, 5 to 4.
Threats of picketing and protests to newspapers brought action yesterday for forty Puerto Rican families who have been wrangling with their landlord in Brooklyn for ten months over rent and service.
Two young nurses who came to New York a year ago with high expectations are quitting the big city in disillusion.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Darlene Hard, co-favorite in the Essex County Club women's invitation tourney, won two matches today to catch up with the field and reach the quarter-final round of the thirty-second annual tennis event.

THE sign on the door still bore the lettering, "Rosensohn Enterprises, Inc." But Bill Rosensohn, halo slightly askew, had long ago departed, leaving the enterprise and the Inc. to Irving B. Kahn and Vincent J. Velella, each with tarnished angel wings. A clerk answered the door for an inquiring reporter yesterday.
Fire in a basement kitchen led to the temporary evacuation of a small private hospital in Brooklyn at noon yesterday.

CZESTOCHOWA, Poland, Aug. 26 -- Poland's Roman Catholic primate said today that the Church would overcome any attempts to "undermine" it or any efforts to make the Polish people lose interest in their religion.
A three-man syndicate, headed by Roger L. Stevens of New York, yesterday bought Tanforan race track at San Francisco for five million dollars. The sale will be effective Nov. 2.

A Pan American airliner departed from London at 6:58 P. M. (New York time) on Tuesday with seventy-four passengers en route to New York. It landed at Gander, Nfld., at 6:12 A. M., yesterday, with seventy-six.

While the mills of the Wheeling Steel Corporation remained closed by the strike, good news in the form of an increased dividend went out to stockholders yesterday. Directors authorized a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock for payment on Oct. 1. It was the seventy-fourth consecutive quarterly dividend to common stockholders and represented an increase of 25 cents from the quarterly disbursements of 50 cents paid since April, 1958.
VIENTIANE, Aug. 26 -- Laotian military sources reported today that approximately four thousand enemy troops were active in five provinces of the country.
Five big railroad unions called on President Eisenhower yesterday to stand by his "wisely chosen" policy of keeping hands off labor disputes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming said today that Federal aid for building classrooms under the Eisenhower fiscal policy could only be given under a long-term payment plan.

Out of a cloud of dust and thundering hoofbeats in the Bronx yesterday rode two cowboys, four showgirls, a bulldozer ballet and a posse of press agents -- all hired to publicize what they called the "greatest outdoor entertainment center in the history of man."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Treasury has decided, after this week's sharp rise in the bill rate, not to tap the money market for the last $100,000,000 of the $1,700,000,000 cash financing planned for August.
Following is President Eisenhower's schedule for the rest of his European tour (all times are regional).

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons sent out another Alabama Stakes winner today. The 85-year-old trainer put the Wheat-lay Stables' High Bid into the $58,200 event and High Bid responded by scoring a clean victory.
CHICAGO. Aug. 26 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Miles Davis, a jazz trumpet player, was released in $1,000 bail yesterday in Felony Court on charges of third-degree assault and disorderly conduct.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- President Charles de Gaulle began today an intensified search for a solution of' France's most urgent problem -- the rebellion in Algeria -- by polling his Ministers on their views.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 26 (UPI) -- Groups opposing transfer of the New York State Barge Canal to the Federal Government charged today that the plan was a "give-away" that could have repercussions throughout the state.
The Police Department said yesterday that there was no truth to a charge that it had forced seventeen members of the William E. Sheridan Police Post of the American Legion to resign their offices.
A 22-year-old Manhattan man received a ten-day sentence for littering and for failing to appear in court to answer the charge. The normal littering penalty is a $2 fine.

The whole tragedy of our time was summed up by the statement that it is believed inevitable in Vientiane that the Laotian province of Samneua would go under Communist control, except for the capital city.
European katydids have turned up in Little Neck, Queens -- apparently for the first time on record in this country.

The State Department has seen fit to refuse visas to two Danish representatives to the International Conference of World Medical Associations, a conference partly sponsored by the United Nations World Health Organization.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Secretary of Commerce offered for sale to the Russians today most of the items at the American National Exhibition in Moscow.

Product on of electric power soared last week to a record 14,003,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 13,648,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The previous high, 13,775,000,000 kilowatt-hours, was set in the week ended Aug. 1.
An attempt by the Federal Maritime Board to fight what it describes as "discrimination" against United States flag ships has been challenged as unconstitutional.

The Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance asked for $10, 000,000 yesterday to make payments in the coming year on the city's share of land-acquisition costs for eight Title I projects now in the advanced planning stage.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Army's defending Eastern football champions opened fall practice in hot, humid weather today. Fifty-eight candidates went through a double workout.

The C H and Hedgerow Apartments, a garden apartment development for 468 families in Dallas, Tex., has been purchased by Robert K. Lifton, Ira Hechler and Howard L. Weingrow, New York realty investors. The buyers were said to have paid about $3,000,000 for the twenty-six acre property.
The American tanker National Peace ran aground in the Arabian Sea in clear weather on Aug. 11, her master said here yesterday.
Generally favorable business conditions are reflected in the operating results of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, which made substantial gains in the quarter and six months ended on June 30.

New York City has borrowed $80,000,000 on tax anticipation notes bearing interest of 2 1/2 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday. "ONE should lay out color in a room as one does furniture," says Melanie Kahane, prominent New York interior designer. "The most important step in establishing a color scheme is to have a plan. Just as a pattern is usually necessary to cut out a dress, a layout should be made to determine what color to use where."
RHODES, Greece, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Protestant leaders said today they had reached new areas of understanding with representatives of Eastern Orthodox churches.
Less than five-and-a-half hours after President Eisenhower's plane touched down at an airport in Bonn, Germany, yesterday, films of the arrival were being shown on television here.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers of America started a sitdown strike today that resulted in closure of the Reynolds Metals Company aluminum plant at near-by Troutdale.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 26 -- The question arose today whether all this target shooting here at the National Rifle Matches had any real and considerable relation to hunting. Nobody challenged the thesis that it was good for the shooter and good for the country, but, just as an academic matter, was target shooting only theoretically related to hunting?

A two-story office building on a plot 125 by 138 feet at 89-09 Sutphin Boulevard, northeast corner of Eighty-ninth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by Paul Paulson through John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker. Held at $400,000, it was bought by Joseph Slifka for investment.
A four-alarm fire almost destroyed the Davis Tire Company at Merrick Road and 222d Street in Laurelton, Queens, yesterday.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. Prices closed 10 points (50 cents a bale) higher to 4 points (20 cents) lower than on Tuesday, with the extreme gain in old October.

The battle for the Ardennes sector during December, 1944, and January, 1945, is reconstructed in a new book by John Toland called "Battle: The Story of the Bulge." Mr. Toland's story of the dramatic and controversial battle covers both sides and is told in terms of many of the individuals, both soldiers and civilians, who were caught in the titanic struggle.

The Pennsylvania Railroad reported yesterday that it incurred a net deficit of $974,000 in July. The road said the deficit reflected the loss of freight business caused by the nationwide steel strike, which started on July 15.

AMERICAN women who have become blase about buying clothes made somewhere else -- for example, France, Italy, England, Hong Kong or Switzerland -- have something new in store for them. They can now purchase, reportedly for the first time, clothes made in India.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, instituted new strategy today to get action in the House on civil rights. Meanwhile, both sides in the controversy claimed victory in a move to get the Senate to act on the legislation.

Volume in cottonseed oil futures trading on the Produce Exchange yesterday reached 28 tank cars (60,000 pounds to tank car). This was the largest volume since March 22, 1957, when 940 tank cars were traded.

If American women spent as much time, money and care on their feet as they do on their faces, hair and hands, they would not only be more attractive but much happier, according to a foot specialist.

The industrial building at 801 East 136th Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Darmon Tool and Machinery Company for occupancy next month. The structure contains 22,000 square feet of space and has inside loading docks for trailer trucks.

The 16,704 - deadweight - ton tanker National Peace was abandoned five hours after the vessel ran aground on an island in the Arabian Sea, Alexander G. Baidin, the ship's first mate, testified yesterday.

J., manufacturer of soluble coffee products, a joint statement of the two companies disclosed yesterday.

A high-flying stork overtook another airliner yesterday for the second time in a row. A baby boy was born on an Easttern Airlines' DC-6, two hours after the plane had left San Juan, P. R., for New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- First reactions from Democratic members of the Senate Judiciary Committee to Attorney General Rogers' proposal were mixed today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Ken Boyer drove in four runs and Joe Cunningham collected four hits today in leading the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-4 victory over the Milwaukee Braves. The Cards had seventeen safeties, five for extra bases.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The Communist advance in Laos and the ways to meet it are expected to be taken up tomorrow in the first working session connected with President Eisenhower's visit to Britain.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., retail chain, set records in sales and earnings for the quarter, six-month and fifty-two-week periods that ended on Aug. 1. Among units in the organization are Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- A little boy in Roanoke, Va., thinks Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev should see an American football game.

For the last few days, persons visiting the Museum of Modern Art have been watching structures of unusual dimension and shape rise in the museum garden, which fronts on Fifty-fourth Street, west of Fifth Avenue.

CHICAGO, Aug 27 -- Adlai E. Stevenson disagreed today with former President Harry S. Truman's assertion that President Eisenhower's forthcoming trip to the Soviet Union might dissipate "the power and leadership of the Presidency."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Langton Breeze of the Tower Hill Farm was all alone at the finish of the Lovely Night Hurdle Handicap today. The feature event attracted only four jumpers and only three completed the course of about two miles.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 17 -- Six miles from the center of Salisbury, capital of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, a new shopping center recently has risen. The proprietors of the dozen modern shops are Africans and their customers are Africans.
A lawyer long active in the hospital field urged hospitals and staff medical specialists yesterday to come to terms on the method of payment for the specialists.

The Southern Pacific Company, operators of the Western railroad, sold $6,000,000 of equipment certificates yesterday to finance the purchase of rolling stock. Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates purchased the securities at a price of 98,583, stipulating a 4 3/4 per cent coupon.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Rescue missions using planes and boats rushed help today to southern Mexico, battered by an earthquake yesterday.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 27 (AP) -- The nation's first Air Force Secretary received today the first National Defense Award presented by the American Veterans of World War II.
WARSAW, Aug. 27 -- Politicians from all over the world sat today in the chamber of Poland's Parliament and heard one of the strangest collections of speeches ever made in a Communist country.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Most corn contracts finished barely above their lows for the season on the Board of Trade today as general weakness again seeped through the grain futures market.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Another shot at the moon between Oct 2-4 was reported in the making today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- A Democratic Congressgressman asked a Federal Court today to order the State Department to grant him a visa to visit Communist China.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 27 -- The pilot of a small private plane denied today that a jet airliner on a training flight had been trying to miss his craft when it crashed in a field near here Aug. 15.

The sharp rise in business borrowings at the big New York City banks continued in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Loans to business were up $54,000,000, compared with a decline of $10.000.000 in the 1958 week. A week ago they rose $77,000,000.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Cheap interplanetary exploration by joint effort was the theme of the symposium's first day.
PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 27 -- A bank teller here has developed poliomyelitis, so his bank has acted to destroy $46,000 he may have handled.
ALBANY, N. Y., Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission said today it would begin its investigation of Consolidated Edison Company's electric rates with a public hearing in New York Sept. 22.

CAIRO, Aug. 27 -- An Arab League delegation will leave for Casablanca tomorrow "fully confident" that a session of the League's Council opening in the Moroccan city Tuesday will adopt "strong, unanimous" resolutions demanding that Palestine Arab refugees be restored to their former homes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- A spokesman for the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development denied today that a loan to the United Arab Republic to widen and deepen the Suez Canal was all but settled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Opponents of a bill to permit Chicago to divert more water from Lake Michigan for its sewage disposal system stressed today the argument that it would imperil relations with Canada.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- General Ike returned to his old command tonight.
LONDON, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of speeches by Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and President Eisenhower at London Airport tonight:
HONG KONG, Aug. 27 -- Communist China put the best face possible today on its admission yesterday of inflated production claims and lowered output targets.

The stock market shook off its summer lethargy yesterday and scored a good advance in fairly brisk trading. The rise was led by steels, electronics, motors, drugs and oils. In all, values increased by more than $3.100.000.000.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 27 -- Thousands of depositors jammed Jakarta's banks when they reopened today after a two-day shutdown that followed sweeping financial reforms.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Senator Clifford P. Case charged today that the Senate Judiciary Committee was damaging the Senate's reputation by failing to act on judicial nominations.

On your church page of Aug. 24 you published an excellent account of the "dialogue sermon" preached by Mr. Trevathan and Mr. Flory at St. Luke's Chapel. In this account of so interesting an event you say that "several dialogue sermons have been presented in New York in the last five years."

BALMORAL, Scotland, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth II staged a ball for her servants tonight only hours before she was to welcome President Eisenhower to her Highland home tomorrow morning. It was the traditional Gillies' Ball, a hard-drinking, fast-dancing Highland Fling started by Queen Victoria.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Maria Bueno of Brazil and Angela Mortimer of England won their quarter-final matches today to give the semi-finals of the Essex County Club's women's tennis tournament an international hue.
LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Britain affirmed today that her ban on nuclear-weapon tests would continue as long as talks on a test-suspension treaty showed some prospect of success.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The International Atomic Energy Agency made modest but significant progress last year in taking the benefits of peaceful uses of atomic energy to member nations, President Eisenhower reported today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Glass Container Manufacturers Association submitted a money offer today to the American Flint Glass Workers Union in an effort to reach agreement on a new contract before the strike deadline Monday.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 27 -- The Navy's Polaris missile was fired for the first time today from a ship at sea. This was a big step in the missile's development as a nuclear weapon for submarines.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A House subcommittee said today an argument with Development Loan Fund officials over producing records had ended with investigators getting the papers they wanted.

FOLKESTONE, England, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Alfredo Camarero, a 28-year-old television salesman from Argentina, battled nine-foot-high waves today and easily won the annual swimming race across the English Channel.
ROME, Aug. 27 -- A private bill now before the Chamber of Deputies proposes new penalties against juvenile delinquents who band in gangs to break the law.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., Aug. 27 -- Hunterdon Medical Center, a 120-bed hospital, announced yesterday it had closed its nursery on Monday for one week because of "a definite rise" in the number of staphylococcus germs detected there in the last few weeks.
LONDON, Friday, Aug. 28 -- The London newspapers responded this morning with warmth and enthusiasm over President Eisenhower's arrival yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) --. The American Veterans Committee asked Congress today to revoke the Congressional charter of the American Legion and to investigate its tax-exempt status and other Federal privileges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A Senate-House committee completed today a compromise bill that would exempt television and radio stations from having to give equal time to political candidates on news programs.
TITUSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 27 -- The petroleum industry today celebrated the 100th anniversary of its birth -- the day on which "Drake's Folly" brought in the world's first commercial oil well.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Tonight was Otto Standke's deadline to rid this city of 10,000 starlings, and he wouldn't even try. The birds remained.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 6 points (10 to 30 cents a bale) yesterday in quiet trading.

A CLOUD has appeared over Seventh Avenue, the hub of America's fashion industry. It bears the name, "Foreign Ready-to-wear." At this moment, the cloud is no larger than a husky wisp of smoke, but storm warnings are being hoisted.
The question of relocation payments for some of the tenants dislocated from the site of the Penn Station South Title I cooperative housing project retained unsettled yesterday.

ONE of the temperamental differences between the expert and the average player in bridge is that the expert considers it no disgrace when he does not make his contract. He knows that often he will fall a bit short and sometimes he will miscalculate completely and lose a slew of points.

"90' South," by Paul Siple, is planned for publication on Oct. 30 by Putnam. Mr. Siple gives a first-hand account of how and why eighteen American scientists and Navy men spent a year at the South Pole, wintering in minus-100-degree temperatures. He was the expedition's scientific leader.

DENVER, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Profits of copper companies have increased "beyond the most fantastic estimates," the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers said today. The union outlined its reasons for having struck against major producers in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- World steel production rose sharply to a record rate of 346,000,000 tons a year in the first half of 1959, the Department of Commerce reported today. Bigger output by American mills was largely responsible.

MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP, N. J., Aug. 27 -- Applicants for probationary jobs on the police force of Middletown Township will take psychological tests to determine their emotional stability.

CHICAGO. Aug. 27 -- In blazing sunlight and 90-degree heat, the third Pan-American Games opened today before some 40,000 spectators at Soldier Field.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Barry Latman pitched six-hi-ball for eight and one-third innings and his catcher, John Romano, drove in three runs and the Chicago White Sox whipped the Red Sox, 5 -- 1, today. The companies in the Royal Dutch Shell group in the first half of this year had a combined net income of u82,705,000, or $231,574,000 at the official exchange rate of $2.80. For the similar period last year the net was u71,487,000, or $200,163,600.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- More babies were born first in this country in the first half of 1959 than in any previous first half of a year.

The Monsanto Chemical Company announced yesterday price reduction of about 15 per cent on fumaric acid, effective with 1960 contracts and on a spot basis after Jan. 1. The new price will be 22 3/4 cents a pound in drum carloads, or about 4 1/2 cents below the present list price.

Directors of the Reynolds Metals Company recommended yesterday a three for-two split of the common stock. After opening at 106 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the stock climbed to 111 1/4, following the announcement, and closed at 109 for a gain of 3 3/4 points on the day in active trading. The stock has ranged from a high of 122 3/4 to a low of 65 1/2 this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -President Eisenhower has vetoed the $1,200,000,000 civil works appropriation bill -- traditionally called the "pork barrel" bill.

It may now be possible, at long last, to persuade some of the doubters that Communist China is still the predatory enemy of any free states that can come within the clutch of the Peiping oligarchy. Red China, in Winston Churchill's words, is still the "unpurged aggressor."
Sixty young men from the metropolitan area were sworn into the Army at City Hall yesterday. They will serve in the Air Defense Command system here.
Stockholders of the Aetna Life Insurance Company will receive eight shares of new stock for each three shares the ynow own as a result of board actions taken in Hartford, Conn., yesterday.
Patti Page, the singer, has been signed to play a dramatic role in Bernard Smith's production of "Elmer Gantry," which Richard Brooks will direct.
New Yorkers sweltered again yesterday as the temperature soared to 91.1 degrees. It was the eleventh day this month that the mercury had reached 88 degrees or higher.
Forty-one Soviet scientists who will attend the International Oceanography Congress here arrived yesterday aboard a sleek, white Soviet ship, the Mikhail Lomonosov.
Marine insurance underwriters face the prospect of paying out $1,610,000 on an abandoned ship whose current market value is less than a third of that amount.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The pack of frozen orange concentrate set a record at more than 80 million gallons during the 1958-59 season, the Department of Agriculture said today. Most of the pack was made in Florida, and took more than 60 per cent of the crop.
CAIRO, Aug. 28 -- The diplomatic colony in Cairo has been informed that the Government of the United Arab Republic expects it to keep propaganda activities here friendly and within bounds.
A patrolman was beaten and robbed in Harlem last night and one of his alleged assailants and a bystander were wounded slightly in an exchange of six shots. Three men were arrested.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -An 8-year-old Philadelphia boy is dead from polio in what is said to be the first death here of a person who had received three injections of the Salk vaccine.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- The Soviet Union said tonight that it would not conduct any nuclear weapons tests as long as the Western powers did not resume theirs.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A Federal judge dismissed today a $12,075,000 antitrust suit against four major steel companies.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants increased their National League lead to thre games tonight by defeating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5 -- 0.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Government contracts were awarded tonight for the development of a space-age system of military radio communications.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey urged President Eisenhower today to seek a "greatly broadened" person-to-person exchange program with the Soviet Union when Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev visits here next month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -Broad general selling clipped more than a cent a bushel off all soybean contracts today and left them within a few cents of their low prices for the season on the Board of Trade.
HAVANA, Aug. 28 -- Premier Fidel Castro warned the nation last night that hard work and patriotism would be needed to overcome Cuba's economic problems.
The combined forces of city and state rested in the shadow of defeat yesterday as twelve mothers continued to resist the construction of an overpass alongside their houses in the East Bronx.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Army riflemen swept the national trophy rifle team match today -- the riflemen's biggest prize -- at the 1959 national rifle matches here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 -- Gene Fullmer, a good big middleweight, defeated Carmen Basilio, a good little middleweight, for the National Boxing Association version of the title by a knockout in the fourteenth round tonight.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 28 -- Something like 10,000 red-blooded Americans of all ages straggled and sweltered on the grounds of the American Trapshooting Association today and about 2,400 of them shot hopefully in the Grand American Handicap.
The most delicate casting problem of the new Broadway season was solved yesterday with the signing of four blind children to play roles in William Gibson's drama "The Miracle Worker."

GENERALITIES are usually dangerous things in bridge, but perhaps a good one to adopt would be this: When a low trump is unlikely to be of value for any other purpose, one might as well ruff with it whenever he gets the chance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -Engineers for the New York Telephone Company have invented an automatic awakener for hotel guests. Instead of individual calls placed by an operator, who must wait for an answer and say what time it is, there will be a wholesale ringing of everybody who wants to get up at the same time.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 28 -Two United States Senators have joined an American Bar Association committee to plan international conferences of lawyers on extending the rule of law.

The Aluminum Company of Canada (Alcan) has decided to stop making its own magnesium metal. It will get what magnesium it needs henceforth from the Dow Chemical Company -in exchange for aluminum of equivalent market value -- and also will buy some from a Canadian magnesium concern.
An apparently effective cancer vaccine for arresting the growth of malignant tumors has been developed by a husbandand-wife team of scientists at the Roswell Park Memorial Institute in Buffalo.
The explosive properties of mistletoe are by no means limited to Christmas parties, scientists have found.
LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Industrial shares continued to move strongly ahead in the stock market here today, spurred by the strength of Wall Street on Thursday and some good company statements.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- The United States had two winners and Argentina one tonight in the first men's track and field finals of the third Pan-American Games. Each victor set a record for the Hemisphere championships.
PARIS, Aug. 28 -- The Municipal Council asked Parisians today to bedeck the city with flags and to line the streets to greet President Eisenhower Wednesday.

Rochester, N. Y., is planning to borrow $9,720,500 on bond anticipation notes dated Oct. 1, 1959, and maturing in one year. The sale will be held on Sept. 17. The financing covers school and highway construction, slum clearance, and the erection of )ublic buildings.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Robert J. Norwood, head of the Arkansas States Rights Council and one of those arrested during a segregationist march on Central High School Aug. 12, was picked up by the police today in a Negro night club.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru accused Communist China today of aggression against India.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (UPI) -The United States baseball team, one of the favorites, was upset in first-round play by Venezuela today in the Pan-American games. But in tennis and fencing United States teams swept through without defeat.

We are sorry Carol Kerrigan, 22 years old, and Betty Lou Fuchs, 23, nurses who came to New York a year ago, are leaving, disillusioned about the city. DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP) -Twelve plants will begin production of 1960 model cars on Monday, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 -James R. Hoffa was asked today to come to San Francisco "immediately" to settle a threeweek-old strike of Teamsters Local 85.

Governor Rockefeller has voiced support of Robert Moses in the controversy over the payment to George E. Spargo of large fees by two agencies headed by Mr. Moses. The fees were paid to Mr. Spargo while he was receiving $40,000 a year salary from a third agency headed by Mr. Moses.

A contract for the construction and operation of a chain of gasoline service stations and marine outlets throughout Florida has been signed by the Arvida Corporation, one of the state's largest landowners and developers, and the Gulf Oil Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- An examiner of the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended today that the Post Office be authorized to increase rates on fourth-class mail by $88,000,000 annually. Fourth-class mail includes parcel post and catalogues.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Senate leaders indicated today that Congress would still be in session when Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev arrives Sept. 15.
The American Cyanamid Company has announced the appointment of two European scientists as group directors at its Cyanamid European Research Institute in Geneva, Switzerland.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP) -Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, today denied reports that Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev had hinted the Berlin crisis might be solved by giving West Berlin to West Germany, along with a connecting corridor through East Germany.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 28 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer left by plane today for Milan to resume the Italian vacation at Cadenabbia on Lake Como that he had interrupted to receive President Eisenhower here.

Last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center introduced four more ballets by George Balanchine to the season's repertory. Among them was an outstanding presentation of "Firebird" with Patricia Wilde dancing superbly in the title role.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -Barbara McIntire defeated Mrs. Paul F. Klinefelter Jr. of Philadelphia in an extra-hole semifinal in the women's United States amateur golf championship today.

The Long Island Rail Road will appeal a State Supreme Court ruling that it must obtain Public Service Commission approval before raising fares, a spokesman said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Americans paid $98,300,000,000 in taxes to Federal, state and local governments last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

A. Edward Miller has been named publisher of McCall's magazine, effective Oct. 1. He is now assistant to the publisher of Life magazine, Andrew Heiskell.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -Several Milwaukee Braves' regulars complained before today's game that they had not had enough batting practice, so they extended it into the game and battered the Chicago Cubs. 9 -- 3. The third-place Braves collected fourteen hits.

HOME accessory departments in New York stores are gaining added momentum as fall draws near. Some stores are expanding their departments; others are adding new ones.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 -California authorities are investigating reports of extensive corcuption and profiteering in the importation of temporary farm workers from Mexico.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The seizure of an Indian outpost by Chinese Communist forces may have at last plunged Prime Minister Nehru into a depth of hostility toward the Peking Government that he has long tried to avoid.

EACH year some Congressional or state committee stages a public investigation of the twin problems of narcotics addiction and the illegal traffic in the drugs. There are the same procession of witnesses at the hearings -- police and correction officers, doctors, psychiatrists, public health officials, social workers and the addicts themselves.
SWITZERLAND is a country of, among other things, four languages, 600 glaciers, 200,000 hotel beds, 880,000 cows, and about 2,500,000 female inhabitants who do not have the vote.

SEOUL, Korea -- According to one American who knows this country well, having spent the war years here jeeping between Seoul and Pusan, Korea has three things that beat the rest of the world its fall weather, its apples and its music.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The atmosphere surrounding the visit of President Eisenhower to Britain from the outset was subtly different from that of the presidential visits to other nations. The issues that he and Prime Minister Harold Macmillan must discuss are just as complex and important here as they were in Bonn and will be in Paris.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 29 -- A squall from the southwest came close to clearing just about everyone off the Sound today as the Knickerbocker Yacht Club ran the regular Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound program.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- The second day of track and field competition in the third Pan-American Games produced an unbroken succession of United States victories today.

Except as a Broadway hit, the phrase "la plume de ma tante" may soon survive only as an epitaph to a dead language. The dead language is not just school-French but school-any-language. WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The annual Federal civilian payroll has risen past $12,000,000,000 for the first time.

TO ease the job of driving long, heavy screw into hard woods -- or for other heavy screw-driving jobs, -- home handymen should remember that special bits are available which can be fitted into an ordinary auger bit brace.
A 3-year-old boy was killed yesterday and his mother was severely injured after three youths in a stolen car had crashed into their automobile on Staten Island. Six others were also hurt.
Business for concerns that supply food for home freezers is booming.

The stock market righted itself last week. Selling pressure lifted and, as a result, prices were up for the first time this month. But the market's action at times was not unlike that of a seesaw. Aircraft shares, which dipped earlier in the period, followed the steel, motor and electronic issues in imparting a firmer tone to the list.
Former Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy said yesterday that he had asked for the cancellation of a farewell party scheduled to be given in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Sept. 14.

BOSTON, Aug. 29 -- The vast oceans are still the richest source of food in the world -but the day may be rapidly approaching when there will not be "lots more fish in the sea." If it does come, it will probably be the fault of man, not nature.

Department store sales in the nation fell in the week ended on Aug. 22 below the 1958 level for the first time in more than four months. The Federal Reserve Board reported that the decline was 1 per cent, compared with a 6 per cent gain in the preceding week.

It is statistically well established that elevated blood levels of cholesterol, the fatty substance present as a normal and essential part of the human body, are found to be associated with the most deadly type of arteriosclerosis (hardening of the arteries).

The new 38,645-ton liner Rotterdam, the fifth Holland-America Line ship to bear the name, will sail for New York on Thursday on her maiden voyage. Streamlined, modern in design, with no smokestack and only a mast to vent fumes near the stern, the new liner will offer the Atlantic travel trade accommodations for 1,400 passengers, chiefly in tourist class.
DETROIT, Aug. 29 (UPI) -Maverick, the unsuccessful United States Harmsworth Trophy defender, won the fourteenth running of the Silver Cup races on the Detroit River today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 -- Applying the steady pressure of an almost airtight defense, which sort of subdues the opposition by slow strangulation, Chicago's "Go-Go" White Sox brought added grief to Cleveland today.

LONDON. Aug. 29 -- The suggestion that the best trio in a long space flight lasting several years would be two men and a woman, had scientists at the Commonwealth pace flight symposium here today rolling in the aisles.

WALT DISNEY believes the cast he has assembled for "Pollyanna," now being filmed in and around Santa Rosa, about fifty miles north of San Francisco, is the best he has ever presented for a motion picture. It includes some unusual assignments.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 United States diplomats who have been trying for ten months to get Soviet agreement on a treaty suspending nuclear weapons tests are back in the capital this week-end.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 29 -- Steamin' Demon, driven by George Phalen, scored a three-quarter length victory over Jean Laird in 2:05 4/5 before 36,230 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight in the $15,000 Diamond Purse for trotters. The winner paid $16.60.

A new look at the problem of fallout from the testing of nuclear weapons, and its potential dangers to present and future generations, is presented in a report released last week by the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy. It is based on the testimony last May by some thirty scientific witnesses and statements presented by other scientists.
BOSTON, Aug. 29 -- The Rodman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston has purchased Loew's State Theatre to show religious pictures.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- A defense contractor has begun work on an atomic clock so accurate it will neither gain nor lose a second in a thousand years, it was announced today.

Thoroughbred racing returns the metropolitan area when Belmont Park opens a two-week meeting tomorrow. After our weeks of turf activity at upstate Saratoga, local race- goers will again have a chance view the runners.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Navy volunteers, submerged in a cushion of water, have set records in withstanding tremendous gravity forces, the kind men might experience in space flight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Two rival dockworkers' unions recessed negotiations today after two days of talks had produced "good prospects" of a merger or working agreement.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- More than two-fifths of the world's population over 15 years of age is illiterate, a United Nations publication reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- School and college enrollment is expected to reach 46,480,000 in September it was announced today by Dr. Lawrence G. Derthick, Commissioner of Education.

Sales volume in Southwestern department stores last week dipped slightly below the level of the week before, but they still were well ahead of 1958 levels. Sales in metropolitan Texas were as much as 11 per cent above those in 1958.

SCHOOL days, as delineated by the 250-plus photographs in Jack Engeman's "College: The Life of a Student," are truly golden days. This picture survey of student life -- recorded, mostly by Mr. Engeman, at more than fifty academic groves throughout the land -- is aimed at the prospective freshman.

THE Polaroid Land Camera last week entered the field of available-light photography with the announcement of a 3,000-speed film a new record. Any of the nearly two million Land cameras will take the film, Type 47 for the large size, Type 37 for the small, at $2.29 and $1.79 per eight-exposure roll, respectively.

HONOLULU, Aug. 29 -- William Francis Quinn, an Irish-American born in Rochester, N. Y., was inaugurated today as the first Governor of the State of Hawaii in a forty-five minute ceremony on the grounds of Iolani Palace.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug, 26 -- Two Roman Catholic Bishops in southern Africa have spoken out strongly against racial discrimination.
YELLOWKNIFE, Canada, Aug. 26 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's vision of a Greater Canada through northern development is causing some mixed reactions in that remote region.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Pentagon, the world's largest office building, is no longer big enough for the Defense Department. Another large building is now proposed for its activities.
LONDON, Aug. 29 -- President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan agreed today on the tactics for handling a number of problems caused by recent Communist moves against the Western world.

TELEVISION'S canines are going to the dogs. Rin Tin Tin lost its Friday evening sponsor last week after a palship of five years. Effective next month, Lassie will initiate a homo-sapiens guest-star policy. Lassie apparently believes that a famous person is a dog's best friend when the television rating shows signs of withering.

AMERICANS read almost daily now that business men should go into politics. This has been said before, but not so often or so broadly. A few years ago, business leaders were being urged to work at the local political level. Now, every salaried employe in some companies is being called upon to select the party that best represents his point of view and work for that party in his neighborhood.

CAMBRIDGE BAY, Canada, Aug. 16 -- This tiny community, an important element in the Distant Early Warning Line, lies well within the Arctic Circle. It is also an important observatory of Arctic weather, and its radio broadcasts help air and sea navigation.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 29 -- The British universities sailing team took the only race held today as its match with American collegians got under way. The visitors totaled 22 1/4 points to 14 for their rivals.
The Nuclear Power Group and Atomics International announced plans for a detailed study to determine the feasibility of an advanced type nuclear power reactor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Labor Department reported today that up until mid-August the steel strike had had relatively little economic impact on thirty-one steel-producing and consuming areas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI ) -- President Eisenhower nominated Henry E. Stebbins, a career diplomat, today to be this country's first Ambassador to Nepal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Senate ratification of two international radio broadcasting agreements will apparently wait until next year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -The approaching adjournment of a Congressional session marked by a dramatic resurgence of President Eisenhower's control of legislation finds six major topics still on the unfinished list -- civil rights, labor, foreign aid, housing, highways and public works, the last being a measure which he unexpectedly vetoed on Friday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 29 -- Talent Show won the Boardwalk Handicap at Atlantic City today. He scored by a neck over Scotland in the mile-and-a-sixteenth race with the following developments.

MANAHAWKIN, N. J., Aug. 29 -- Townsfolk from Warren Grove to Cedar Run braved a persistent drizzle today to attend the dedication here of Stafford Township first municipal building.

BOBBY BURNS' MERRY MUSES OF CALEDONIA (Elektra). Paul Clayton, accompanied by Fred Hellerman, rambles through some racy songs collected or written by Burns. The Scottish dialect has been anglicized, some short words bowdlerized, but there's enough left to scandalize. Solid work-manlike performances.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Bo Wininger of Odessa, Tex., blistered the Tripoli Golf Club course with a six-under-par 64 today for a 54-hole total of 195 and a three-stroke lead in the $35,000 Miller Open.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits urged the newly elected commander of the American Legion tonight to take the lead in reversing the Legion's stand against Negro members in its fun-seeking 40 8 affiliate.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 -- Charley Conerly sparked a second-half drive by the New York Giants tonight and the Eastern Division champions swamped the Detroit Lions 38 -- 0 in a pre-season National Football League game at Briggs Stadium.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 29 -- Army sources said today that Indian troops were on the way to man all of the border separating Tibet from India's Northeast Frontier Agency. Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has accused Communist China of committing aggression there twice this month.

RHODES -- This is the largest of the Dodecanese Islands, an archipelago that curves round the southwest corner of Turkey. Although preponderantly Greek in population, it was under Italian jurisdiction until 1945. Upon union with Greece after the war, the island was endowed with a special statute relieving it of most of the taxes collected on the mainland.

LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters) -- Arsenal and the champion Wolverhampton Wanderers fought to a 3-3 draw before 46,000 in the English Soccer League's first division feature today.
