Retail business last week inched ahead of year-ago levels but at a rate well below the average of the first six months. A combination of hot weather which slowed the movement of fall wearing apparel and the effects of the steel strike had a share in holding down the comparative gains with 1958.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- Striking teamsters and four employer groups reached agreement today on a contract that might end a twenty-four-day-old strike.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars suggested today the formation of a new United States fleet to fill "the tremendous power vacuum in India and Southeast Asia."

THE leek, the national emblem of Wales, is now in season. Because of its limited use in menus on this side of the Atlantic, this mild-flavored vegetable is not available at all counters. One source, however, is the B M Fruit Market, 201 East Fifth-ninth Street.
BOSTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Three men were captured and the police sought a fourth today after an attempted bank robbery that was bungled all the way.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev declared today that he was going to the United States next month with a "burning desire" to do his bit to relieve inter national tensions, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported.

THERE are three things that impress even the most impervious tourist in Burma. They are the scenery, the pagodas and the women. Any foreigner who imagines that the women of Burma are downtrodden drudges is in for a pleasant jolt.

The Calypso, the famed French undersea research ship commanded by Capt. Jacques-Yves Cousteau, put into New York yesterday. She is here in connection with the International Oceanographic Congress, which opens at the United Nations Building today.
More hot, muggy weather moved toward the city last night with a threat of renewing a week-long heat wave.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 30 -- The combined British university sailing team won four races today and swept the British-American University Trophy series held on Manhasset Bay.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Dick Stuart, Elroy Face and Bob Skinner led the Pittsburgh Pirates to 2-1 and 7-6 victories over the Philadelphia Phillies today. The second game went ten innings.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The stock market demonstrated its underlying strength and buoyancy last week by faltering only briefly on the news of the rise in the United States Treasury bill rate and then returning to form to reach another record.

CARLTON, England, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Eighty shouting teenage boys, armed with knives and chisels, took over a reform school here for three and a half hours today. Tonight they stormed out in a mass escape.

AUSTRALIA and the United States were last seen struggling for possession of the Davis Cup at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday. Then everything went black as nightfall descended on the embattled heroes.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 30 (AP) -- About 20,000 people rioted today in Nagpur, Central India, demanding the formation of a new state. Nine officials, including the district magistrate, were slightly injured.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- Two West German political leaders urged the German people today to face their guilt for Hitler's era of warfare, which began twenty years ago Tuesday with the 1939 invasion of Poland.

Steamship travel between the United States and Europe set a post-war record last week. According to the Trans-Atlantic Passenger Steamship Conference twenty-three ocean liners sailed from United States ports to Europe with 16,524 passengers -- a record number of departures in one week.

Leaders of major United States Jewish groups have formally requested the Soviet Embassy in Washington to arrange a meeting between them and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to discuss the status of Soviet Jews.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) has sold abroad $100,000,000 of bonds, payable in United States money. The sale was negotiated privately with sixty-two institutional investors in thirty-four countries.

A bid by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company on a tract on Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, for improvement with a shopping center has been accepted by the city, Robert V. Tishman, executive vice president, has announced.
Arthur Godfrey and Danny Kaye will help celebrate Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's seventy-fifth birthday on television but Mrs. Roosevelt will not be among those on hand.

ZURICH Aug. 30 -- The triumphal welcome given to President Eisenhower in Bonn last Wednesday, so soon after the overwhelming reception to Vice President Richard M. Nixon in Warsaw, is being given as the explanation for the immense volume of stock exchange business done in Zurich last week, mostly at boom prices.

Juan Jiminez' appeal in The Times of Aug. 25 for freedom of personal correspondence with Soviet nationals should also be addressed to the United States Post Office. This department makes a regular practice of intruding itself between Americans who receive publications from the Soviet Union and the senders with a demand that the Americans tell how come they are receiving same.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- The Dalai Lama's appeal to the United Nations was viewed here today as a bid for Security Council action on the Chinese Communist invasion and occupation of Tibet.

The second volume of Isaac Deutscher's study of Leon Trotsky, which began with "The Prophet Armed, Trotsky, 1879-1921," will be published by Oxford University Press on Sept. 24. Called "The Prophet Unarmed," the book covers the years of the great struggle between Stalin and Trotsky, from the end of the civil war, 1921, to Trotsky's banishment from Russia in 1929.

Net earnings of Montgomery Ward Co. for the twenty-six weeks ended July 29 were $10,66,832, or 78 cents a common share, the big mail order house and retail chain reported over the week-end. For the similar period of last year, net income was $8,638,488, or 62 cents a share.
Cotton futures prices, after Fluctuating irregularly most of last week, turned moderately firmer in the final day's session on increased short covering.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz "hails" a decision by Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Schirick in Albany sustaining the constitutionality of a 1958 amendment to railroad law that withdrew from the Long Island Rail Road the right granted in 1954 to put increased fares into effect prior to investigation and approval by the Public Service Commission.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas and former President Herbert Hover received awards from AMVETS today in recognition exceptional service.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers pushed over two unearned runs in the ninth inning today and defeated San Francisco, 7 -- 6, cutting the Giants' National League lead to two games.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs pounded Milwaukee for five runs in the eighth inning and whipped the defending National League champions, 6 -- 2, today.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 30 -- A group of grateful summer residents paid tribute today to a small, but sturdy oak tree, which they credit with having saved them from drowning five years ago.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 30 -- A 28-year-old Chinese student of the University of Michigan was found today leading a hermit-like existence in the attic of the First Methodist Church, where he had hidden for four years.

CAIRO, Aug. 30 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser and King Saud of Saudi Arabia this week will discuss ways of forcing the Iraqi regime to reveal whether it is going to defend Arab nationalism or let the Communists take over the Government.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 30 -- Although anti-Government violence by Africans in southern Natal has diminished in the last week, much attention is being given to the causes of the disturbances.

A solemn high mass yesterday in St. Joseph's Church, 404 East Eighty seventh Street, marked the opening of a week-long convention of the Roman Catholic Kolping Society of America.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 30 -- A vast body of data on young ball players has been assembled here by a physiologist who devises electronic gadgets to test pitching speeds and batters' reactions.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Prime Minister Nehru, worried by Chinese Communist incursions on India's frontiers, has scheduled a week of conferences with leaders of neighboring states.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright, in a formal statement, prodded the State Department today to take a new look at Middle Eastern policies.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Angela Mortimer England today became the first foreigner to win the singles final in the Essex County women's invitation tennis tournament. She defeated Mrs. Barbara Green Weigandt of Alexandria, Va., 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3.
Harry Belafonte's long-felt concern over the dearth of imagination in the legitimate theatre field is primarily responsible for his becoming a Broadway producer this season.

James R. Dumpson, the city's new Welfare Commissioner said yesterday he intended to "tighten up" on the requirements for welfare assistance to eliminate any padding of the relief rolls.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Gene Littler capped a brilliant stretch drive with a 6-foot putt for a birdie on the final green today to win the $35,000 Miller open golf tournament. He had a 72-hole total of 265, 15 under par.

Almost sixty years ago a young Columbia University student penned the opening musical phrases of a two-act comic opera, "The Governor's Vrouw (Wife)." The composer was the late John Erskine, who achieved distinction as a teacher, author and musician.
A NEW plan for a vacation or retirement cottage offers some solutions to that ever-present problem for today's families -- making space on a budget.
SUMMERTON, S. C., Aug. 30 -- Fifteen Negro students have applied for reassignment to white schools in Clarendon County, where original integration suits were filed.

Within a few days the "back to school" movement will be getting started again. As we look forward to another school year the national Commissioner of Education, Dr. Lawrence G. Derthick, has given out some interesting and significant figures. It is a good thing to see our whole educational structure in some sort of focus.

Dr. Thomas Dooley has been in this city during the last week or so when his services were badly needed at the hospital he has been operating in Laos, near the border of Communist China. He came here because that was the only way he could hope to be cured of a cancer which was operated on last Thursday.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 -- Steel consumers are resigning themselves to the longest steel strike in recent history. Many users are attempting to make plans that will reduce their difficulties to a minimum. But there were signs last week that many steel customers soon would be caught in spot steel shortages that might cause them to reduce their own operations.

The letter and statement for officials of Freedom House publish in your recent issues merit car examination. They bring into for basic questions concerning the turn taken in American-Soviet Nations, and, in fact, the whole "East-West" problem.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Larry Berra, Yogi's 9-year-old son, who aspires to be a sportswriter, watched today's game between the Yankees and the Senators from the press box at Griffith Stadium. "I helped Cookie Lavagetto make out the Washington line-up," he confided after the first three Yankees had been retired.

The editorial "Studies in Economic Growth," in the Aug. 24 Times ignores some important facts concerning both the Nixon committee report and the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations views on economic growth and inflation.
Three youths were held by the police early this morning as "prime suspects" in the slaying yesterday of two teen-agers in a West Forty-fifth Street playground.

The old saying that "all roads lead to Rome" is being revised with the establishment in the Eternal City of a permanent international exhibit center known as Permindex. The center, believed to be the first large showplace for continuous display of the world's newest products, is in the last stages of completion.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Spokesmen for the United States and British Governments heard angry protests from reporters tonight over the bottling up of information on the talks between President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Italy, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Pope John XIII said today Roman Catholics would welcome non-Catholics to a conference on church affairs if they wanted to come.

A group calling itself the Bellevue South Preservation Committee has asked Governor Rockefeller to reconsider his stand regarding the payment of $243,000 to one of Robert Moses' financial consultants.
The reappearance last week of advertising on the outside of buses in this city caused some curious people to dig back to learn what caused their departure fifty-two years ago.

In recent weeks the news from the subway system has been mostly bad.

The Independent - Socialist party got more than $150,000 in free radio and television time in the 1958 state election campaign because of Federal broadcasting rules.

A newly-developed cable-film system will enable American television viewers to see a minute of the Eisenhower-Macmillan TV discussion in London tonight soon after it takes place. The method was used successfully during Queen Elizabeth's recent visit to Canada.

As the reopening of schools for the fall term draws near, children experience varied reactions ranging from hostile rejection and grudging acceptance to joyous anticipation. Adults would be both amused and amazed if they could somehow peep into children's minds and understand what goes on there when the word "school" is mentioned.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 30 -- The Dalai Lama appealed today to the United Nations and the non-Communist world to support Tibet in her fight for "freedom and justice" against Communist China.
Small improvements in cargo rates were recorded last week in the steamship charter market, but volume remained very low.
Thoroughbred horse racing will be back on the metropolitan scene starting today, when the Belmont Park late summer meeting begins.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Three women from the United States and one from Mexico gained the semi-finals today in the Pan-American Games tennis championships.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- The Indian Communist party expressed "fervent hopes" today that India's border troubles with Communist China would be settled by discussion.
BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 30 -- Joe Neiner's Pokey of the Raritan, N. J., Yacht Club won the open division honors today in the Blue Jay Class invitation regatta of the Long Island Yacht Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Senate may settle the fate of the labor-reform bill this week.

His friends call him "Doc, the blue-coated midwife" -- and with good reason.

The men who are ascending to leadership in Africa today have been influenced by missionary work and have a background in Christian philosophy, the Rev. Dr. John R. Wilkins said in a sermon here yesterday.

A precocity of high school students and a cogitation of scientists trooped to the second floor of Yeshiva University's science building every morning last week to talk about biomedical research.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Bert Bell, the commissioner of the National Football League, today pushed aside the "reserved" signs hung on Houston and Dallas by the newly organized American Football League.

A floor in 415 Madison Avenue has been leased by the Columbia Broadcasting System for its radio spot sales office, now at 460 Park Avenue. James Cookson and Bruce Colen of Collins, Tuttle Co. were the brokers.
HAVANA, Aug. 28 -- The bright spot in the generally dim economic picture of Cuba is provided by the good business of the small merchants and the manufacturers of low-priced products.
ANYONE who believes that oil and water do not mix would consider green olives. In favor, they represent the perfect fusion of the two liquids.
BONN, Germany, May 30 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer appealed today to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to resume negotiations directed at controlled international disarmament.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 30 -- Despite objections by Protestant leaders to pictures that over-emphasize sex, Twentieth Century-Fox is proceeding with what promises to be one of the most thorough sex discussions ever made on film in Hollywood.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 -- Another promise of a baseball miracle virtually vanished today.

Diplomats of this and other nations who used to feel a certain concern when they saw the slightly stooped figure of Dr. Raphael Lemkin approaching them in the corridors of the United Nations need not be uneasy any more. They will not have to think up explanations for a failure to ratify the Genocide Convention for which Dr. Lemkin worked so patiently and so unselfishly for a decade and a half.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Monday, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The governing National Revolutionary Movement (N. R. M.) party swept to an early lead today in South Vietnam's second national legislative elections.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Economics Minister Ludwig Erhard opened the Frankfurt International Trade Fair today by sounding an optimistic note on the further development of West Germany's economy.

NEW YORK'S chief of detectives, James Brennan Leggett, is a gruff, hard-bitten 59-year-old policeman who enjoys the professional respect of the 3,200 men and women under his command. In typical fashion, he was on the job early today directing the search for the assailants who stabbed to death two teenaged youths early yesterday in a West Side playground.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- Delegates to the Western Young Democrats Conference voted today in favor of trade and diplomatic relations with Communist China.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 30 (UPI) -- Mr. Chheng said in an interview today that he was seen only once during his retreat. A cleaning woman surprised him stealing food in the kitchen.
MOST of the excitement on last night's "Ed Sullivan Show" over Channel 2 was caused by the appearance of a young soldier-pianist named Peter Duchin.

Referring to the editorial "Broken Traffic Promise" appearing in your paper Aug. 26, Mayor Wagner should be commended for his reluctance to convert to one-way operation Fifth, Madison, Lexington and Third Avenues.

Two Republican Senators called yesterday for a prompt settlement of the steel strike, warning of a "dug-in struggle" if it is found necessary to invoke the national emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law.
NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 30 -- The body of a 13-year-old boy was recovered last night from a pond off Perry Avenue here about seven hours after he had failed to appear after a dive.
LIMA, Peru, Aug. 30 -- Peru's new Government would like to halt its money-printing presses to keep them from increasing the pace of inflation as the costs of running the country mount.

The Domain Realty Company has sold the five-story building containing eighty-five apartments and occupying a plot 187 by 100 feet at 1181-87 Walton Avenue, the Bronx. TODAY funeral services will be held for George Washington Meyer, who died on Friday.

St. Augustine's Chapel is trying to teach the youth of the lower East Side that it takes "real heart to be a coollie" -- real courage not to belong to a fighting gang.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Audiences here last night saw and applauded performances both in Spanish and English of "Los Soles Truncos," by Rene Marques, Puerto Rican playwright.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- How Daniel Webster used a sharp practice to help his admittance to the bar has just come to light here in his handwriting.

The State Education Commissioner said yesterday he expected to rule this week on the transfer of 400 Negro pupils from Brooklyn schools to predominantly white ones in Queens. Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the Commissioner, declined to discuss the issue until then, because it was before him in a judicial form.

IT was a busy and bright week-end for the New York City Ballet at the City Center; busy because it consisted of four performances and bright because of the characteristic quality of the company and its direction.

The chief artisan of the American victory in the challenge round in Australia last December, Alex Olmedo, kept the United States in the running in its defense of the Davis Cup yesterday with one of his finest performances.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy presented today a frightening picture of the death and destruction of homes that would result from a surprise nuclear attack on the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Lawyers attending last week's meeting of the American Bar Association at Miami Beach had a chance to observe a demonstration of the supremacy or infallibility of the Supreme Court.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A way of growing winter grains in the winterland tropics, thus opening a non-source of food for millions, was announced today by the California Institute of Technology.

American ship operators are looking forward to further legislative relief from the high costs of building their vessels in United States shipyards.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- Despite continuing controversy over the European economic community versus a free-trade zone, there are at the same time many examples of industrial and financial cooperation between the two opposed European groups.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Senator Herman E. Talmadge of Georgia called today for a Senate investigation to determine whether Federal welfare payments might be encouraging an increase in illegitimate births.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 30 -- A spanking southerly that arrived in mid-afternoon saved the day for Dr. Charles M. Hanisch and his Knickerbocker Yacht Club race committee today. And one of the top winners was a home club sailor, Dr. Harvey Lincoff, with his Luders-16 class sloop Hotspur.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The United States and Britain are moving toward a joint policy envisaging a series of high-level meetings with Soviet leaders, accompanied by detailed East-West negotiations on disarmament, nuclear tests and such other key issues as the future of Berlin.

FROBISHER BAY, Baffin Island, Aug. 19 -- Between the small Canadian weather station at Cambridge on Victoria Island within the Arctic Circle, and Churchill on Hudson Bay lie more than 1,000 miles of tundra, uninhabited except for nomadic Eskimos and a tiny weather station at Baker Lake in the District of Keewatin.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The near-by futures contracts of wheat and corn finished strong today on the Board of Trade in a late rally which appeared to be mainly short covering. Oats and soybeans were mixed, rye mostly weak.

HONOLULU, Aug. 31 -- Hawaii's first State Legislature convened at 10 A. M. today to begin organizing the machinery of government for the changeover from territory to state. The task will undoubtedly take longer than the allotted five weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Senator Stuart Symington criticized the Defense Department today for blocking the publication of a controversial book on national defense by Gen. Thomas S. Power, chief of the Strategic Air Command.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed legislation today liberalizing disability compensation for veterans who suffered total deafness or lost an eye and one or more limbs while on active service.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The creation of an International Academy of Astronautics was urged today at the opening of the tenth annual congress of the International Astronautical Federation.
With a fusillade of gunfire, the Staten Island police yesterday captured a Manhattanite who had commuted to Staten Island to work.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- President Eisenhower rejected today requests that he hold a news conference during his London visit. The decision angered British newsmen.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- The movie industry was faced today with the possibility of a strike by screen writers.
The directors of the General Motors Corporation approved yesterday a series of organization changes and high-level executive appointments.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Otto Standke of Kansas, whose critics charge he has not gotten rid of the starlings here, said tonight that he would "talk it over" tomorrow with city officials, who retained him to rid the city of the pests.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Aug. 31 -- Dean Henry P. Brandin of the University of North Carolina Law School resigned tonight from the Chapel Hill school board because it refused to admit a Negro to a segregated public school. The board accepted his resignation.

Copper prices spurted again yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. The rise, ranging from 44 to 62 points (hundredths of a cent a pound), occurred as a major custom smelter increased prices from 30 cents to 33 cents a pound. A total of 470 lots (50,000 pounds
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 1 to 8 points (5 to 40 cents a bale) off yesterday. The distant October and December contracts were weakest.
A campaign for $2,500,000 to complete the new building of the Columbia University Law School on Morningside Heights will be conducted in the fall.
MONTREAL, Aug. 31 (Canadian Press ) -- Antonio Barrette, Quebec Labor Minister, said today that the provincial Government would not allow overproduction in the pulp and paper industry.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- President Eisenhower visited today the American Memorial Chapel in St. Paul's Cathedral, a memorial to 28,000 United States servicemen who lost their lives in World War II while based in Britain.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 31 -- Rain washed out tonight's scheduled game between the Yankees and the Orioles. Since both clubs had an open date, the visiting New Yorkers were held over for a 2 o'clock contest tomorrow afternoon. Several thousand fans were in the stands at Memorial Stadium when the postponement was announced, shortly before game-time.
Anderson Fowler Hewitt is resigning as a senior vice president at Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., according to an informed source.

The investment banking concern of Lehman Brothers will open a European office in Paris on Oct. 1. An announcement by the company said the office would undertake further development of the concern's steadily growing financing activities in Europe.

LENINGRAD, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic scored another triumph last night with a Stravinsky program. KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 31 The Foreign Office here was completing preparations today for tomorrow's meeting between President Mohammed Ayub Khan and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- President Eisenhower's European visit has already produced one healthy effect: it has given assurance to a good part of Western Europe that someone, after all, is minding the store.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- One of the leading opponents of President Eisenhower's request to raise interest-rate ceilings on Government bonds said today that bigger budget surpluses rather than "tight money" were the best way to stop inflation without slowing economic growth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The House Elections Subcommittee today unanimously approved a formal resolution recognizing the right of Representative Dale Alford, Democrat of Arkansas, to hold his seat in Congress.

Fairbanks, Alaska, is planning the sale of $7,500,000 of municipal utility revenue refunding and improvement bonds on Sept. 10. Dated Sept. 1, 1959, the securities will come due serially on Jan. 1 and July 1 from 1960 to 1981.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Bluechip industrial shares were in demand on the stock market here today and small gains predominated. However, the demand was fairly selective and offset by a good deal of profittaking which gave the principal lists a ragged appearance. Changes were generally in pennies.

Frank E.(Jimmy) Kilroe did an excellent job of rating the forty-sixth Fall Highweight Handicap for yesterday's opening day program at Belmont Park. Although the winner, C. DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 31 -Hickory Pride, one of the prerace favorites for the thirtyfourth Hambletonian, will not start Wednesday in the world's richest harness race.

The West Side Association of Commerce declared yesterday that Hell's Kitchen had "not existed for more than half a century" and decried the use of the term in reports on the slaying of two boys early Monday morning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- An Agriculture Department official said today that deterioration had been the main reason for a $170,000,000 "loss" on Government-owned cotton since 1956.
A current strategy in New York City's fight against slums involves what Deputy Buildings Commissioner Harold Birns calls "a new approach in the effort to prevent neighborhood deterioration."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Difficulties are inherent in all aid projects to underdeveloped countries. An American date expert in the Sudan since 1957, however, has weathered a series of disasters which sets something of a record in the annuals of the Food and Agriculture Organization.

The General Waterworks Corporation plans to enter the industrial market through the proposed acquisition of the Frick Company, a Waynesboro, Pa., manufacturer of ice-making refrigeration, air-conditioning, farm and saw mill machinery.
LONDON, Aug. 31 President Eisenhower said tonight that Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev must recognize that 'peace is imperative" if there is to be a profitable summit meeting.

Scoring his second triumph on his mission to Europe, President Eisenhower has reached broad and basic agreements with Prime Minister Macmillan on the aims and purposes of their policies, which they expounded in an unprecedented radio and television dialogue from 10 Downing Street, London, yesterday. These aims and purposes form a solid foundation on which the whole Atlantic community can unite in meeting the Soviet challenge.

Hostility between the captain and his chief engineer may have played a part in the abandonment of the tanker National Peace on an island in the Arabian Sea on Aug. 11. This was indicated yesterday at a Coast Guard hearing that took testimony from Tony Bruscella, chief engineer on the American-flag tanker.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev will leave military and technical advisers behind when he goes to the United States.

Sporadic outbreaks of warfare between youth street gangs in New York have resulted in many killings in the last decade. In 1959 alone ten young persons have met their deaths in violence either directly stemming from gang feuds or involving members of youth gangs.
Two 7-year-old boys were burned, one critically, when a can of cleaning fluid was ignited in an abandoned tenement at 158 West 105th Street, the police reported yesterday.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Several dozen members of the Operating Engineers Union, A. F. L.-C. I. O., set up picket lines at the Air Force Missile Test Center today and halted construction activity at the base.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives voted today to make amends to Dr. Samuel Alexander Mudd, the physician who gave medical aid to Lincoln's assassin.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 31 (AP) -Half a century of illegal whiskey drinking in Oklahoma will end and drinking will become legal at 10 A. M. tomorrow.

The problem of juvenile delinquency which afflicts New York and other urban areas is no less disturbing in our nation's capital. The highly transitory population and the steady influx of low-income families have aggravated Washington's problem.

A HAND played by Mrs. Oswald Jacoby of Dallas was reported in this space last week, and it was mentioned that Mrs. Jacoby seldom played bridge nowadays, except for occasional games of the social variety.

All was quiet on the Pennyfield Avenue front in East Bronx yesterday. No city bulldozers challenged the housewives who kept vigil under gently swinging effigies of Mayor Wagner, Borough President James J. Lyons and Construction Coordinator Robert Moses.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A West German exportimport concern and its director today were barred from handling American exports for the duration of the United States export control program.
To be or not to be Hamlet is no longer the question with Henry Calvert, actor.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco sent word to President Eisenhower today that he, as an anti-Communist, was in full accord with the President's decision to meet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The Air Force disclosed today that a camera in the nose cone of an Atlas intercontinental missile had photographed one-sixth of the earth from an altitude of 700 miles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Senate-House conferees agreed today on a bill limiting the states' power to tax interstate commerce.
Net profit of the Philips Incandescent Lamp Works, Ltd., in the first six months of this year rose to $33,591,500, from $24,069,500 in the 1958 period.
The slow blight of the steel strike on the national economy was reflected yesterday in a Government report on factory sales in July.

Yesterday's State Department announcement has made it official. When Premier Khrushchev arrives here two weeks from today it will be a family party he will be heading and Mrs. K., his two daughters, his son, and even a son-in-law will be along. If American newspaper men show their traditional enterprise we should soon know more than we have ever known before on such matters as Mme.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The American Legion's new national commander assured Senator Kenneth B. Keating today that he would do everything possible to eliminate a restriction barring Negroes and Orientals from the 40 8, the Legion's fun-making affiliate.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 31 -- Nearly 400 armed Chinese Communists were reported tonight to have invaded the Himalayan state of Bhutan and occupied several square miles.
TRENTON, Aug. 31 -- The State Senate gave final legislative approval today for a referendum on commuter railroad relief.

Directors of the Royal Crown Cola Company have elected to the board Clarence B. Hanson Jr., publisher of The Birmingham (Ala.) News, it was announced yesterday by W. H. Glenn, president of the Columbus (Ga.) maker of soft drinks.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 31 (AP) -- A group from the Democratic State Central Committee moved today to force Gov. Earl K. Long to resign before the committee takes up the question of his qualifying for another term as Louisiana's Governor.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 31 (UPI) -- A Chinese student who hid in a church attic for four years in shame over his grades was offered a chance today to redeem himself.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Silent sound from space rockets and jet airplanes poses a new health hazard of the space age, a scientist said today.
Scanty selling and less buying depressed the bond market again yesterday, with securities of the United States Government the point of most sensitivity.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 31 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer declared tonight that "the new Germany will some day be a good neighbor of Poland." His address was broadcast to his nation on the eve of the twentieth anniversary of Nazi Germany's attack on Poland, which began World War II.
A ramp vehicle resembling a bulldozer has been developed by Pan American World Airways to carry passenger baggage from planes to the customs area at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
THE duck seasons selected by New York State from the dates offered by the Federal Government are not going to please all of the duck hunters.
DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Auto production in the nation hit rock bottom for the year last week and is now on the way up with 1960 models in production.

The property at the corner of Mott Street and Chatham Square, in the Chinatown area, has been sold by the Henry Bergh estate. It had been acquired more than fifty years ago. It was sold to Chatham Mott, Inc., in a deal negotiated by Maxwell L. Scott, vice president of Cross Brown Company, broker.

Urgent pleas for approval by the voters in November of the $500,000,000 school construction bond issue were voiced yesterday by City Council President Abe Stark and Hulan E. Jack, Borough President of Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The American Bankers Association announced today a new program aimed at promoting economic growth without inflation.
PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 31 -- The Paterson Chamber of Commerce has proposed a plan to raise $1,000,000 in private capital to rebuild the downtown district of the city.
Alarmed at the sharp increase in deaths and injuries from fires last year, the Fire Department is planning a citywide campaign in fire prevention education.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 31 -- The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors acted on three fronts today to meet needs of the county's burgeoning population.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 31 -- A plea of not guilty by reason of insanity was entered today for Francis H. Bloeth, 27-year-old ex-convict charged with three murders and four armed robberies on Long Island.

For most of the session yesterday, the stock market seemed to be "sitting on the fence," undecided which way to go. In the final half hour of trading, stocks got off the fence and staged a moderate rally. With steels and motors leading, prices closed irregularly higher.

CLOTHES are not the only imports that are tempting shoppers these days. For women who like to have their clothes made, bolts of fabric from France, Italy and Switzerland are arriving daily in the stores' fabric departments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston said today the Supreme Court would give segregated schools a better grade than integrated ones if it re-examined the quality of each type throughout the nation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Eleven nonoperating railroad unions announced today that they would seek a 25-cent hourly wage rise and welfare concessions. A nation-wide strike could result if management refused the demands.

" The Tailor's Maid," an Italian-made romantic comedy with Vittorio De Sica, Lorella De Luca and Marcello Mastroianni, which arrives at the Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux on Lexington Avenue, is today's sole film newcomer.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists said today that 2,334 persons had been killed, injured or left missing by Typhoon Iris, which hit the coast of Fukien Province, opposite Taiwan, Aug. 20.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 31 -- As the Edinburgh Festival swings into its second week it becomes increasingly plain that on the dramatic side, at any rate, the standard of the offerings this season is unusually low.
NORTHVILLE, L. I., Aug. 31 -- Harold Rosenblatt told today of swimming fifteen hours after a fish nudged him off his course as he trained for a swim across Long Island Sound.

The Union Carbide Corporation has formed a new operating division for its consumer products business. The division, to be known as the Union Carbide Consumer Products Company, will market products bearing the Prestone and Eveready brands.
Despite the recent economic recession, corporate aid to education set a record last year, the Council for Financial Aid to Education reported yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Felic Naccarelli, 46 years old, of Pittsburgh, has $2,000,000 and less than a year to live.

Cooler weather is coming along, when presumably the cook will get off this kick she's on for salads. When the humidity drops, and the temperature, a man again may eat. For weeks now, months -- it often seems like years -- he has not so much eaten as nibbled.

Expanded services to the bowler by the American Bowling Congress, the Women's International Bowling Congress, the American Junior Bowling Congress and many more available lanes are in prospect for the winter season.

ANYONE who ever has visited a lemon grove finds it difficult to forget its almost overpowering fragrance. And the trees, which are so generous of perfumed white blossoms, offer, at one and the same time, green and ripe lemons.

A 45,000-square-foot parcel in Brooklyn, including the former site of Joe's Restaurant and the Mechanics Bank Building, was acquired yesterday by the Brooklyn Savings Bank at a public auction on the steps of the Brooklyn Borough Hall.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 -- Diplomats here believe that a new approach is being made to Soviet-West German negotiations on a number of vital issues.

Six little girls sat around a table on the stage of a Broadway theatre yesterday, learning their lines for a play in which they will portray blind children in a Boston school. For four of them it was not play-acting -they have little or no vision.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -Tommy Kono of Honolulu won the middleweight title in the Pan-American Games weight lifting championships today, earning another gold medal for the United States.

JUST as advertised, the concluding fragment of the Davis Cup competition was an anticlimax. The hectic drama of the third day of the great international tennis show had been halted by encroaching dusk on Sunday, postponing the concluding phase of the decisive match between Neale Fraser of Australia and Barry MacKay of the United States until yesterday.
Steel production increased slightly last week as the nationwide steel strike dragged on. The strike enters its eighth week at midnight tonight.
New financing in August was marked by an increase in stock flotations and a decline in bond offerings from the July level, but both types of issues exceeded those of August, 1958.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- The engines of commercial jet airliners are proving to be twenty times more reliable than conventional piston engines, a study of the Federal Aviation Agency showed today.
A portion of the televised conversation between President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan in London yesterday was available to American audiences last night.

In May, 1957, Peter Thorneycroft, then Chancellor of the British Exchequer, appointed a committee under the chairmanship of Lord Radcliffe "to inquire into the working of the monetary and credit system, and to make recommendations."

Starting today, the Weather Bureau will stop telling New Yorkers how uncomfortable they are.

Whatever developments might be imminent in the situation created by Communist Chinese pressures in the Himalayan region it is now confirmed by the latest reports that a very real threat exists in the whole area extending from Ladakh to India's Northeast Frontier Agency.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Sept. 1 (AP) -- An article in The Middlebury College Alumni News Letter, analyzing the problems of oceanography, was praised today by Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of Naval Operation.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- President Eisenhower wined and dined old friends of World War II tonight at a reunion that apparently melted some post-war antagonisms.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 1 (Reuters) -- Canadian Transport Minister George Gees said here today that the Canadian Government did not plan this year to help ships caught in the St. Lawrence Seaway by the winter freeze-up.

The city's Youth Board, criticized for giving recognition and status to juvenile gangs through its program of assigning counsellors to them, contended yesterday that this technique had eliminated major clashes between gangs.
The machine-tool industry, a bellwether for the economy's advance planning, lost ground in July from the month before, but operations continued at a rate well above recent months.
As the new Douglas DC-8 jet airliner slipped through the overcast above Long Island, the project engineer explained the problem of bald men in aisle seats.
It isn't so much the heat, but the lack of something to do that causes the city's youngsters to commit more crimes in the summertime, social scientists and social workers said yesterday.
The Man from the Middle West said he wanted to file a mild complaint about the manner in which some natives of New York City and New England generally misuse the "r" in their speech.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 1 -- A chemical compound that appears to augment dramatically the killing effects of radiation on human cells was described here today at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Biological Science.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover was disclosed by Congressional sources today as having given little if any aid to a search for a "munitions lobby" manned largely by retired high-ranking military officers.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that "when organized gangs invade playgrounds and blindly and wantonly commit murder, the handling of the matter has passed from the social agencies and into the hands of the police." Having settled that question, the Mayor now faces the logical next question whether he will provide New York City with a police force of sufficient strength to do the job.

The police arrested early today a youth suspected of being the actual killer of two teen-agers in a midtown playground Sunday morning. The arrest came shortly after Governor Rockefeller had summoned two emergency meetings to intensify efforts to combat the city's rising juvenile violence.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa accused Budget Director Abraham D. Beame yesterday of favoring the proposed $500,000,000 school construction bond issue only because Mayor Wagner favored it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Indian Ambassador warned today that "China will be making a terrible mistake if she thinks that because we are pledged to peace we will not fight in defense of our country."
LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 1 Columbia's gallant football team -- punchless in losing eight of nine games last year -- may not win a single contest in 1959.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Otto Standke, the professional bird chaser from Kansas, received another chance today to drive 10,000 starlings from this city.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 1 -- A first-inning offensive against Jerry Walker and a ninth inning knockout of Arnold Portocarrero figured in the 5-0 victory of the Yankees over the Orioles today. As a result of Whitey Ford's triumph at Memorial Stadium, the Yankees' "magic number" became twenty-three.
Four men were arrested here last night in two raids aimed at "driving the underworld element out of the securities business'' in the United States and overseas.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 1 -- The Government of Ghana will start work immediately on the Constitutional changes involved in making Ghana a republic. Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah said in a broadcast tonight.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 1 -- The Press Trust of India reported today that V. K. Krishna Menon, India's Defense Minister, had submitted his resignation to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Three wavy white-striped light blue flags with centered orange circles fluttered proudly from the medal poles at Soldier Field tonight.
LONDON. Sept. 1 (AP) -- The United States is re-examining its entire policy of limiting imports of woolens, James C. Hagerty indicated tonight.
Most teen-age boys and girls who smoke probably pick up the habit from their parents, a scientific study has shown.

TRENTON, Sept. 1 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner is planning an active campaign to rally the state's voters behind the bill for commuter railroad relief. He said today he would sign tomorrow the measure providing for a referendum on the plan.

The Federal agencies whose men handle thousands of steamship travelers homeward bound in this late summer season are preparing for the peak that will come around Labor Day. Meanwhile the recent morning when more than 9,000 passengers arrived or sailed from the Hudson River passenger piers will suffice as a measure of what this job entails.

Plans for a three-for-one stock split and an increased dividend were proposed yesterday by directors of the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company. The proposed split came as no surprise since B. E. Bensinger, president, had stated on Aug. 4 that the matter would be considered by the board on Sept. 1.
WARSAW, Sept. 1 -- It began to rain today in Warsaw just as the sirens sounded.

Many persons will entertain at the formal reopening of the Embassy Club of the Sheraton-East on Sept. 14. Mrs. George H. Pride is chairman for the event, a benefit for the Judson Health Center. A special gourmet dinner will be served.

DENVER, Sept. 1 (AP) -- In proportion to the world's population gains, Christianity is losing ground. This fact, and action and ideas to counter it, occupied the International Convention of Christian Churches (Disciples of Christ) today.

On Aug. 26 The Times printed a letter from Mrs. Ethel S. Cohen in which the writer states that after complaining about air pollution on several occasions to this department, "I received a form reply stating that the complaint has been received. And there it ends."
The country-wide steel strike cut earnings of the big coal-carrying Chesapeake and Ohio Railway about 50 per cent in August.

NOROTON, Conn., Sept. 1 -- David Miller, a 15-year-old helmsman from the Royal Vancouver (B. C.) Yacht Club, took lead in the North American, junior sailing championship as the third and fourth races of the Sears Bowl regetta were sailed, mostly in heavy rain, today.

Offering of $50,000,000 of 5 1/8 per cent debentures, due on Aug. 1, 1979, of Associates Investment Company, is being made today by an underwriting group led by Salomon Bros, Hutzler and Lehman Brothers. The debentures are priced at 100 and accrued interest.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 1 -- If the fairways of your club, once lush and green, have a tired, worn look, don't put the blame on the course superintendent.

PARIS, Sept. 1 -- France awaits the arrival of President Eisenhower early tomorrow with growing confidence that his visit will go far to dissipate French - United States differences centering on Algeria and Allied strategy.
When "failure to appreciate the South's emotional problems" is given in Congress as a reason not to consider civil rights measures, issues are blurred to unrecognition.

One of four teen-agers accused of the two fatal stabbing in a West Side playground told reporters yesterday that he was ready to talk about the killings. He said the actual killer was not in custody then.

DALLAS, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Bishop Richard C. Raines of Indianapolis called last night on the forthcoming General Conference of the Methodist Church "to remove any question as to whether we have segregation written into our discipline."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Senate Republican leader said today that it was "a good guess" that President Eisenhower's veto of the civil works bill would be overridden tomorrow in the House of Representatives and later in the Senate.
Substantial increases in both gasoline consumption and motor vehicle fuel taxes have brought $30,170,225 additional into the state treasury thus far this year.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Harold C. Evans of Binghamton defeated Dr. Erich W. Marchand of Rochester in the third round of the state chess championship today in sixty-eight moves.

CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The police fired tonight into Communist-led bomb and arson mobs that seized parts of India's biggest city and set fire to police vans, government cars and other property.
DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Three British crew members of the Swedish freighter Signeborg jumped ship last night. One of them nearly drowned in an attempt to swim across the Detroit River to Canada.
A program to rehabilitate 200 old and obsolete BMT subway cars within a year will start on Tuesday, the Transit Authority announced yesterday.

Eleven big railroad unions have offered to scrap the cost-of-living escalator clauses in their present wage agreements. But their proposal has brought no acclaim from the railroads. The situation is ironic because the carriers are aligned with the strikebound steel companies and employers in other major indutstries in seeking to wipe out escalator provisions. The United Steelworkers of America and labor generally are fighting to keep them.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 1 to 4 points (5 to 20 cents a bale) yesterday after moving narrowly.
Heavy showers caused brief local flooding in parts of the metropolitan area yesterday.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 1 -- The immediate lowering of tariff barriers and eventual free trade throughout Central America was urged today by the Finance Ministers of six countries.
CHICAGO, Sept 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The Weather Bureau's Temperature -Humidity Index system for measuring discomfort appeared yesterday to be proving popular at many points throughout the country.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Britain consigned to the past today two important elements of her history: the Third Battalion of the Coldstream Guards and the Lee-Enfield rifle, which the guards have carried for seventy years.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 1 -- Several disputes between the Netherlands and West Germany are nearing settlement in negotiations here.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept 1 -- President Ayub Khan and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru expressed agreement today that relations between Pakistan and India should be conducted on a "rational and planned basis and not according to day-to-day emergencies."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Army abandoned today the rotation of troops by units between the United States and Europe. Simultaneously, it ordered a similar system applied to the forces in Korea.

THE uncluttered silhouette, dominant in the French collections for fall, brought accessories into important play. Deviating from the familiar tone-on-tone effect of black-with-everything, there was great color contrast between clothes and their accessories.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Atlas is the United States' first ICBM. The Soviet Union said in August, 1957, that it had developed one. United States officials now concede that the Soviet possesses such a weapon.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A story about a woman cancer victim's being the sole heir to a $2,000,000 fortune began to look like a hoax today.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- More than 400 Spanish political prisoners are in a grim prison outside Burgos under shockingly harsh conditions, according to an article yesterday in The Times of London.

Alex Olmedo was seeded first and Neale Fraser second yesterday in the draw for the men's national tennis championships. The tournament starts Friday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, with an entry of 128 players.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- If India is today the leading Asian exponent of democracy, it may well be because of men like Ambassador Mahomed Ali Currim Chagla.

The opening of the Bureau of Labor Standards North Atlantic area office here at 325 West Forty-fourth Street was announced yesterday. The appointment of Earl J. Krotzer as regional director was also announced by James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor.
The bond market was caught off balance yesterday by the decision of the nation's major commercial banks to raise their lending charge to prime customers from 4 1/2 per cent to 5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- A Florida banker said today that he was blocking the withdrawal of $400,000 in Teamsters Union funds from his bank. He said the union president, James R. Hoffa, had agreed to leave the money on deposit as collateral for a loan.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) President Eisenhower signed today a $977,345,608 appropriations bill that provided nearly 20 per cent less than he had requested for a number of Federal agencies.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Columbia Gas System protested today to the Federal Power Commission against proposed rate increases for the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company.

EASTCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- A motorist who jumped from his car at the scene of a fatal accident here last night and directed traffic with a flashlight was arrested later as the hit-and-run driver who had caused the accident.

LOS ANGELES, Sept 1 (AP) -- Larry Jackson held the Los Angeles Dodgers to two hits tonight in pitching the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-0 victory before 19.425. The loss dropped the Dodgers one and one-half games behind the league-leading San Francisco Giants, who were idle.
Negotiations for a new dock labor contract stalled yesterday as the Waterfront Commission stepped up its drive to expose alleged criminal domination of the International Longshoremen's Association.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Racial integration was increased today in near-by Arlington County, Va., without incident.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The installment debts of all Americans increased $500 million in July to a record $36,500,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Brotherhood of Russian Bath Rubbers, the only union advocating sweat shops, appeared yesterday to be heading for its last rubdown.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Fourteen-year-old Ann Warner, the youngest girl on the team, led the United States swimmers in another assault on the Pan-American Games records today.

News that an agreement on a new labor contract had been reached by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers Union was a factor in raising prices of rubber futures yesterday on the Commodity Exchange.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Jay Manufacturing Company and Western Precipitation Corporation of Los Angeles announced today that they had agreed to transfer the net assets of Western to Joy in exchange for Joy in exchange for Joy common stock.
LONDON, Sept. 1 (Reuters) An American space scientist said here today that his company would be ready to launch a manned space satellite within eighteen months.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A Senate-House conference committee on the labor-reform bill appeared tonight to have reached an agreement in spirit on all but one item.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee overwhelmingly approved today proposed constitutional amendments to repeal the two-term limit on the Presidency and to outlaw the poll tax in Federal elections.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 1 -- A remarkable round by Paul Kelly, the metropolitan champion, marked the metropolitan district's qualifying trials for the United States amateur golf championship today.
The six-story store and apartment building at 108-10 Eldridge Street, near Grand Street, has been sold by G. F. A. Affiliated, Inc., after an ownership of fifty years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Three former officers of the Mutual Broadcasting System were accused today of having accepted $750,000 from the Dominican Republic to broadcast its propaganda.

A lawsuit to stop the Board of Education from giving sick pay to two teachers whose illnesses had been certified by chiropractors will be withdrawn as a result of an explanation by the Superintendent of Schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The Federal Aviation Agency announced today it had hired a New York engineering concern to figure out the best way of supplying thirty jet airplanes with fuel at the new Dulles International Airport that will serve the capital.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The House Committee on Government Operations recommended today a merger of the Army and the Air Force.

Central and South West Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains of 9.9 per cent in first-half gross revenues, 10.3 per cent in industrial and commercial revenues, 7 per cent in residential and rural revenues and 16.5 per cent in net income.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 1 -- "Then the scene was changed to a dining room, where you saw * * * a table in the most splendent manner set out with a great variety of dishes all served up in the most elegant way."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- About 100 Russians will travel with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev when he visits the United States later this month.
The Jacob Ruppert Brewery is talking to agencies about possibly getting a new one to "knock for Knick."

September has long been known as a month of changeable weather. In Wall Street the month has a reputation for fickle market action, too. Yesterday, September began in the New York area in dramatic fashion with drenching showers and a plunging stock market.
BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 1 -- It's what's up front that will probably count most for or against Princeton's 1959 football chances.
The League of New York Theatres has deferred until the season of 1960-61 its plan to experiment with a 7:30 P. M. curtain time for Wednesday evening performances.

It must be that racing fans in the metropolitan region are saving up for the opening of the Aqueduct track a week from Monday. Otherwise, how explain that there were only 16,623 customers at Belmont Park yesterday?
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, argued for seven hours against a Chicago water bill today. He quit with a promise to continue tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- The House passed today, 209 to 4, an Administration-opposed bill to cut in half the 20 per cent tax on night clubs.
Service on the BMT subway was disrupted for two hours in last night's rush hour after a Fourth Avenue local train broke down in the Sixtieth Street tunnel under the East River.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 1 -- The economic policy of President Arturo Frondizi has failed to win approval from the Argentine Chamber of Deputies after the longest debate of the year.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 -- The Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile, the nation's prime weapon of the rocket age, moved formally today from experimental to "operational" status.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 1 -- Weather permitting, fifteen of the nation's best trotters will start here tomorrow afternoon in the thirty-fourth Hambeltonian Stake. It will be the richest harness horse event in history, with a gross purse of $125,283.98.

PONTIAC, Mich., Sept. 1 -Counsel for a former racket-inquiry witness hinted in court today that his client might have been expelled from the barbers' union as a reprisal for testimony in which he had criticized James R. Hoffa, head of the Teamsters Union.

The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $21,470,000 yesterday on temporary loan notes to continue the financing of five State-subsidized projects. The cost incurred by the transaction was 2.97253 per cent. This compares with a cost of 2.63896 per cent incurred in similar financing on Aug. 25.

MONTREAL, Sept 1 -- The police seized 300 vials of Salk vaccine today in what was described as the first possible break in the theft of 75,000 shots of the vaccine from the University of Montreal's Microbiology Institute early yesterday.

The stock market, which has been drifting in a vacuum recently, received a sharp jolt yesterday and suffered a major decline. The jolt came in the form of an increase in money rates. Prices had the largest loss, on average, in three weeks.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 1 -- As the finale to an active summer season in this resort community, amateurs and professionals will combine their talents for the sixth annual Labor Day week-end musical revue, "The Village Vanities."

Though his army chiefs have succeeded in rebuffing an outright Communist bid for power, President Sukarno of Indonesia has now embarked on his own road to "socialism" as the goal of his "guided democracy," with the immediate result that one of the richest countries in the Far East has been thrown into a financial crisis and economic paralysis.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Two leading scientists said today that life might have begun ashore, rather than at sea, as has been supposed.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- President Eisenhower decided today to spend a long week-end at Culzean Castle in Scotland after he confers with President Charles de Gaulle of France.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's nominees for the United States delegation to the next United Nations General Assembly won swift approval today from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
The blood bank of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross received 9,082 pints in August. The total for July was 8,637 pints of blood.

A survey of six large cities in the United States shows that a curfew for teen-agers can be useful in combating juvenile delinquency, but that it falls far short of being a cure-all for violence and crime.

Water, water, from practically everywhere was poured into the Hudson yesterday in a Meeting of the Rivers celebration. Consuls and pretty girls in national costumes from fifty-nine countries attended.
Two men described as suspects in the slaying. Aug. 10 of a 65-year-old restaurant owner on the lower East Side were in custody last night at the Clinton Street police station.

The Murray Hill Theatre on Thirty-fourth Street between Third and Lexington Avenues, which will be the latest addition to New York's first-run art-house circuit, is slated to open its doors on Oct. 9.

Major commercial banks here and around the nation raised their prime rate -- the lending rate to their customers with the best credit standing -- yesterday from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. This brought the rate to the highest level in twenty-eight years.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 1 (AP) Sources close to the official residence of President Rajendra Prasad said today that Mr. Nehru might announce a Cabinet shake-up that would oust Mr. Krisha Menon or give him another ministerial post. Official confirmation was lacking.

IT was a program of season's "firsts" last night at the City Center, where the New York City Ballet began the second week of its engagement. Added to the repertoire were Birgit Cullberg's "Medea" and Balanchine's "Waltz-Scherzo" pas de deux and "Bourree Fantasque." The fourth number was a repetition of "Swan Lake," but this time with Allegra Kent in its central role.

Stockholders of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad, at a special meeting on Sept. 25, will be asked to approve the company's previously announced plans for absorbing the Chicago Heights Terminal Transfer Railroad, a wholly owned subsidiary.

A New York exporting concern, the Omni Products Corporation, announced yesterday it had sold to the Soviet Union an American-made plant for the production of plastic pipe to be used in Russia for irrigation purposes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A bill to maintain construction of the interstate highway system on a pay-as-you-build basis was reported to the House today by its Public Works Committee.
A special musical show starring Andy Williams, Doretta Morrow and Alfred Drake will be televised Friday, Nov. 13, by the National Broadcasting Company.

CAIRO, Sept. 1 -- Some new twists were added today to the gyrations of the United Arab Republic's trading policy. A ban was placed on all direct barter export transactions, the export tax on long staple cotton was removed and premium rates available to foreign buyers offering hard currency for Egyptian cotton were changed.
Seven New York Central commuter trains were delayed or cancelled yesterday by two mishaps.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Providing for the aged was described today as the newest challenge facing veterans of foreign wars.

Sales in August of the eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area fell below the 1958 level. According to a survey yesterday by The New York Times volume last month was 3.3 per cent below that in 1958.

All of the "big boys" in the East and some from farther places who are factors in national championships in various classes will be at the Thompson, Conn., course over the Labor Day week-end. Sept. 5-7, for the Sports Car Club of America races.

Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens announced yesterday that he would ask the Fair Campaign Practices Committee to look into charges of racial bias that he said were being unfairly used against him.
Passengers aboard the vessels of four American steamship lines and crews aboard many American-flag tramp ships will face an uncommonly exotic variety of food choices on Oct. 24.

The article captioned "West Side Slums Scored in Report" in your issue of Aug. 25, with the subheading "1,000 Violations. Found," quotes statements of certain city officials that can only be described as amazing.

SUFFERN, N. Y., Sept. 1 -The Rockland County Community College will open on schedule Sept. 28 in the former county welfare home in Viola, it was announced today, as six faculty appointments were made known.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The industrial shares extended their gains on the stock market here today.
IT appears now that some bluefishermen are complaining that albacore are sometimes fouling up some of the best bluefishing ever seen around here. Oh, life can be bitter!
Reflecting the rise in sales, net income of the Marlin-Rock-well Corporation for the fiscal year ended on June 30 increased to $3,072,439 from $1,938,729 cleared in the preceding fiscal year.

Some 39,000 employes of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., will begin receiving today more than $20,000,000 in Treasury bonds and du Pont common stock -- the first distribution to be made under a thrift plan set up by the company four years ago.

I read with considerable interest The New York Times report of Aug. 15 quoting an article by a Soviet Jew, Solomon Rabinovich, which the Soviet Embassy in the United States has been distributing. In that article Mr. Rabinovich denies the persecution of Jews in the U. S. S. R.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) The Detroit Tigers blanked the Chicago White Sox tonight, 4 0, on the three-hit pitching of Jim Bunning. Detroit's victory snapped a five-game Chicago winning streak.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Some wheat futures contracts hit new high prices for the season on the Board of Trade today as the market generally reversed its recent bearish trend.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- President Adolfo Lopez Mateos appealed today for public confidence in his nine-month-old administration.
A checkered pattern of strikes and settlements accompanied September's arrival yesterday.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 1 -- The Laotian Army has regained control of Samneua and Phongsaly provinces from Communist rebels, Foreign Minister Khamphan Panya announced today.
HAVANA, Sept. 1 -- The United States was accused today of approving hostility by Haiti against Cuba. The latter two nations are near a complete break in diplomatic relations.

In 1931, Eric Collier took his quarter-breed Indian wife and 2-year-old son to the primitive wilderness 250 miles north of Vancouver. B. C. There the young Englishman had been granted sole trapping rights to 150,000 acres.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A bill giving the Postmaster General new powers against allegedly obscene mail passed the House of Representatives today with just one dissenting vote. The dissenter was Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican of Manhattan.
Alojzije Cardinal Stepinac, Archbishop of Zagreh, Yugoslavia, who has been in jail or under police surveillance since 1946, was described yesterday as being in "good spirits and fairly good health."
CASABLANCA, Morocco, Sept. 1 -- King Mohamed V called today for a meeting of Arab chiefs of state to solve domestic and foreign problems facing the Arab world.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- A warning was sounded here today against too much dependence on drugs and a "preoccupation with the financial aspects of medicine."

TOKYO, Aug. 30 -- Exports of Japanese transistor radio sets will reach 4,000,000 units in 1959, or twice as many as last year, according to the latest estimate of the Electronic Industries Association of Japan. More than half the radios are expected to be sold in the United States.
A legal move to compel the city to take title to the sites of the projected Seaside Houses and Hammels Houses slum-clearance projects was held in abeyance yesterday.
TORQUAY, England, Aug. 27 -- In Sean O'Casey's simple little flat on Trumlands Road overlooking this English Riviera, an air of anticipation is evident.

The Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd., announced yesterday that it was extending its worldwide paper-making operations to New Zealand through the acquisition of an interest in the Tasman Pulp and Paper Company of Auckland, New Zealand.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The rocket engine designed to blast a man to the edge of space has successfully undergone its first test here. It is the XLR-99-RM-1, which later this year is expected to power the X-15 rocket plane 100 miles high at 4,000 miles an hour. The test was last week. The Air Force announced it today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Dr. Lawrence G. Derthick today hailed the first year's record of the National Defense Education Act as "really impressive.
MOSCOW, Sept. 1 -- Schools reopened in the Soviet Union today, marking the start of a nation - wide reorganization of the school system.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 1 Raulston Schoolfield, former Criminal Court judge, today raised through counsel a technical question to the proceedings brought to disbar him from the practice of law in Tennessee.

RHINELANDER, Wis., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Frederick J. Meyer of Madison, Wis., president of Red Dot Foods, Inc., announced yesterday the purchase of Rold Gold Inc., of St. Louis, Mo., one of the country's largest pretzel manufacturers.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Christian A. Herter have rejected British suggestions for an early summit conference in their talks with Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 1 - Grants totaling $800,000 have been made by the National Science Foundation to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard University for research on fusion power and space problems.

Leo M. Kahn will celebrate his hundredth birthday today. He took occasion yesterday in his five-room apartment at 19 West Fifty-fifth Street to disclose the secret of his longevity. It was this: "Sheer luck, boy, just plain sheer luck."

Electric power production in the nation passed the 14,000,000,000 kilowatt-hour mark for the second straight time last week, breaking all previous output records. Production, the Edison Electric Institute reported, totaled 14,109,000,000 kilowatt-hours, as against the previous high of 14,003,000,000 set in the week before, and 12,272,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the similar 1958 week.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- President Eisenhower, jaunty and grinning, climbed aboard his plane at London Airport this morning for Paris this morning to end a visit that was almost completely successful in the eyes of the British Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's nominations for the United States delegation to the Fourteenth session of the United Nations General Assembly were confirmed today by voice vote of the Senate.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- August E. Rankis of New York and Dr. Milton Finkelstein of Long Island City, Queens, tied for first place today at 3 1/2 -- 1/2 in the fourth round of the tournament for the championship of the New York State Chess Association at the Y. M. C. A.

The Yankees returned to the Stadium for their long-awaited September home stand last night with nothing more exciting to offer a crowd of 15,010 than a battle for third place.

SAPPORO, Japan, Aug. 25 -Sparsely settled Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost main island, is experimenting hopefully with a conservative government after twelve years of Socialist rule.
In a bid for a greater share of the medium-priced and luxury market here the Germanbuilt Mercedes Benz cars have been sharply restyled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Court-appointed monitors of the Teamsters Union asked James R. Hoffa today to remove the presidents of teamster locals at Chicago, Miami and Hoboken, N. J., on charges of corruption. Hoffa is president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
Plans for consolidating all principal affiliated companies in the United States into a single, nation-wide organization were announced yesterday by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

A rumor that coffee producing countries could reach an export quota agreement in the near future spurred heavy buying yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Juvenile crime continued to rise sharply in 1958, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.
The Bangor and Aroostook Railroad yesterday halved the dividend on its common stock to 20 cents a share. The reduced dividend is payable on Sept. 30 to holders of record of Sept. 14.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- The Russians are transplanting northern herring to the Antarctic and the British are preparing to put flounder out to pasture in waters rich with plankton.
A 16 per cent rise in sales enabled the Celotex Corporation to increase its net earnings for the nine months ended July 31 to $2,898,467 from $1,506,599 for the corresponding period a year earlier.

The fact remains, however, that the warnings of those political skeptics who opposed its adoption or accepted it with very grave reservations have already been justified by events.

WARSAW, Sept. 2 -- Two members of the United States Congress made the same point today in speeches before the Inter-Parliamentary Union: It is one thing to talk about the values of parliamentary government and another to carry them out.
LAKEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 2 -There have been strange happenings recently in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Salomon in Whitesville.

Dividends, those close relatives of corporate profits, are heading for a record this year that should warm stockholders' hearts. August cash payments strengthened the trend that followed the improvement late last year in earnings.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 2 -- A Communist offensive in which regular troops from North Vietnam are participating is closing in on the city of Samneua, Laotian military leaders disclosed today.
The table pounding that traditionally accompanies the negotiating of a new pier labor contract here was resumed yesterday after a day of unusual excitement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- The House approved a compromise bill today to prohibit states and localities from levying income taxes on out-of-state companies which merely solicit orders within the states concerned.
A novel savings bond campaign was sent on its way yesterday from the steps of Federal Hall Memorial, Wall and Broad Streets.

OTTAWA, Sept. 2 -- A surprise victory for the Progressive Conservatives in Prince Edward Island's provincial election heartened members of Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's Federal Government here today.

The election of Glenn C. Bassett Jr., James W. Bergford and James W. Watts as vice presidents in the international department of the Chase Manhattan Bank was announced yesterday by George Champion, president. All were formerly assistant vice presidents at the bank's head office.

IN the dawn's early light just one week ago, a plane loaded with samples from the latest Paris fashion collections landed at Idlewild Airport. Immediately after Labor Day, women will be able to buy copies of the French couture originals, two of which are pictured on this page.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -Surgeon General Leroy E. Burney said today that a high percentage of the cases of paralytic poliomyelitis reported this year had been persons not protected by Salk vaccine.

G. Russell Clark, New York State Superintendent of Banks, approved yesterday the application of the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank and New York Trust Company to join forces in a single institution.
