YORK, England, Sept. 2 -York had a homecoming air tonight as 3,000 persons gathered for the 121st annual meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science. The "B. A.," as Britons call the association, was founded at York in 1831.

Owners and operators of oil-burning equipment throughout the city should heed the advice of Dr. Leonard Greenburg, Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, to have their installations cleaned and repaired now before the fall heating season opens. During fall and winter the major source of air contamination in New York City is heating equipment.

UNITED NATIONS N. Y., Sept. 2 -- The heads of the United States and the Soviet delegations expressed hopes here today that good might come from the visit of Premier Khrushchev to the United States. Their remarks were made during a meeting of a committee to consider possible revision of the United Nations Charter.

Nine neighborhoods beset by juvenile delinquency may lose their Police Athletic League recreation centers for lack of operating funds.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 2 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru reiterated his support of Defense Minister V. K. Krishna Menon today and disclosed that Lieut. Gen. K. S. Thimayya had withdrawn his resignation.
The Board of Education asked the City Planning Commission yesterday to approve a $104,700,000 school building budget for next year.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A twin-engined plane crashed last night in a storm, killing six girls on a magazine subscription tour, their crew chief and the pilot.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The House passed today a compromise bill to protect television and radio stations from demands for equal time on news programs by candidates for office.

Twentieth Century-Fox has set a forty-picture, $60,000,000 production program for 1960-61, one of the most ambitious schedules in the company's history. This was announced here yesterday by Spyros P. Skouras, president, in a speech to Fox branch and advertising-publicity managers.

ALBANY, Sept. 2 (AP) -Governor Rockefeller appointed a six-member panel today to study the possibility of expanding the di ability benefits' program so that all workers in the state would be insured against major medical expenses.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 2 -The Board of Education signed a group contract last night with the Norwalk Teachers Association calling for a 172-day school year. State statutes prescribe that the school year be at least 180 days long.

The residence at 43 East Seventy-fourth Street has been sold by the estate of Harriet K. Welles to the 43-74 Corporation, an investing client of Harry A. Reffelt, who was co-broker with the Cruikshank Company in the deal.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 2 -- A leading protectionist spokesman forecast today greater foreign competition for many industries in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee cleared the way today for House consideration tomorrow of a bill to raise the Federal gasoline tax another penny for the next twenty-one or twentytwo months. Passage of the bill is expected.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -Department of State officials said today that the Government was taking a "more fundamental look" this year at the controversial woolen goods tariff quota question.

Firmness reappeared in the bond market yesterday after a fortnight of weakness.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The idea of the Federal Government as a saver is probably a strange one to most people, but new figures published by the Federal Reserve Board illustrate dramatically the crucial role played by the Government in the national savings flow.

Without waiting for other remedies for juvenile delinquency and violence that city and state conferences may produce, Mayor Wagner has announced his determination to bring the New York police force up to "quota" strength of 24,508 members. This is a delayed response to demonstrated need, but it is, in our opinion, putting first things first.

The Navy icebreaker Atka has come out second best in a brush with a tough polar ice pack off the east coast of Greenland. She suffered bow damage, ruptured a forward fuel tank and lost a blade of one of her two three-bladed propellers.

Police Detective Francis Dowd, a biologist, will leave the musty laboratories of criminal investigation next week for the spacious groves of academe. By trading his shield for a lectern, Detective Dowd will immediately lose $2,500 a year in pay. He will also forfeit his right to retire at half pay when he is 42 years old.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A supposed cancer victim's story of inheriting $2,000,000 from her rich Scottish uncle fell completely apart today.
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The stock market here today reversed its buoyant trend and prices declined in most of the important sections.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 2 -- Among college football coaches there's a saying that goes something like this: "You lose a game for every sophomore you start."

Striking steel workers got a "first down payment" yesterday of $1,000,000 in aid from other industrial unions. The donation came as the steel shutdown entered its eighth week with no settlement in sight.

Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that the Police Department would be brought to its fully authorized strength of 24,508 men by diverting funds at once from other city services. The force is now 1,080 men short of the quota.

MILAUKEE, Sept. 2 (AP) -The last-place Philadelphia Phillies belted four Milwaukee pitchers for eighteen hits and scored an 11-5 victory tonight that dropped the Braves four games behind league-leading San Francisco.

ONE of the zaniest, gayest and most charming gift shops in town is Jonathan Winters' Treehouse, 4 West Fiftysixth Street, which opened earlier this year. Quite properly, it occupies rooms at the top, as a treehouse should.
DURHAM, N. C., Sept. 2 (UPI) -- North Carolina completed its token integration for the current school term today with quiet "acceptance" of Negro students into white schools here and at WinstonSalem.
ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- William R. Rose, formerly the town banker, came back to this village in the foothills of the Catskills today after having spent twenty-one months in prison.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Complete agreement on a labor-reform bill was reached today by a conference committee of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 2 -The Commander in Chief of the Argentine Army was relieved of his post today in a new outbreak of the service dispute that shook the Government of President Arturo Frondizi two months ago.
Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev will be honored at an official luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel as the guest of the city Thursday, Sept. 17, it was announced last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -"Cash" savings by individuals rose $3,600,000,000 in the second quarter of this year, about the same as in the first quarter, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.
Levitt House, a middle-income apartment community for 1,024 families in the Beechhurst area of Queens, has been sold by Arthur Levitt, the builder, for about $15,000,000.

Dr. John O. Frayne has been named the winner of the Samuel L. Warner Gold Medal Award of the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers. Dr. Frayne, who retired as engineering manager of the Westrex Corporation and is a past president of the engineers society, received the award for his contribution in engineering a 70-mm. stereophonic, six-track magnetic film system and test films.

The nation's inventories of gasoline increased by 1,660,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This was contrary to the seasonal trend and reflected, in part, an increase in refinery operations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated that the net income of Class I carriers dropped to $32,000,000 in July. It said that the drop reflected the loss of business caused by the steel strike that started in mid-July.

On Sept. 11 Random House will publish "No Stone Unturned: An Almanac of North American Prehistory," the work of Louis A. Brennan, an amateur archaeologist. It traces prehistoric man on the North American continent from the earliest mammoth hunters to the complex and mysterious Mound Builders.
" THAT Van Gogh print is just what I want, but could I order it in green?" a customer in Bloomingdale's Picture Department asked.

The first of the Big Three's small cars, the Ford Motor Company's Falcon, made its debut yesterday.
A Hebrew private school in Brooklyn was closed yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. Inspections showed several violations representing potential fire hazards.

Public offering of 1,000,000 shares of common stock of the New York Capital Fund of Canada, Ltd., is being made today by Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co. and associates.

After a sharp decline on Tuesday, stocks were back again yesterday in the unexciting rut in which they have been mired during most of the last few weeks. Prices closed irregularly lower in lackluster trading.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick warned Congress today that there would be fewer and fewer minor league games unless a reasonable "blackout" was applied to major league telecasts.

Dandy Blitzen "shipped down" from New England with her jockey, Phil Grimm, and she won the Vagrancy Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The 4-year-old daughter of Bull Dandy opposed some of the best of her sex in the sevenfurlong race for fillies and mares and she won clearly for her owner, B. A. Dario, the president of Lincoln Downs track in Rhode Island.
LEIPZIG, Germany, Sept. 1 -A warm sun and buildings full of sleek and shiny objects to use or enjoy have fostered a mood of good spirits in Leipzig this week.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 2 -- Oil companies in this country began today to study a 165clause contract that has been proposed to them by the National Federation of Oil Workers. Discussions between the companies and the federation probably will begin next week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized American Airlines today to offer non-stop jet service between New York and San Francisco. The decision was 3 to 2.

PEIPING, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- Marshal Chen Yi, Foreign Minister of Communist China, accused the United States tonight of instigating "civil war" in Laos. At the same time, he denied that China had ever encroached on other countries and warned other countries against encroaching on China.

Peru seems to have found the man of the hour in her new Premier and Minister of Finance, Pedro Beltran -- and it was the eleventh hour. The dispatches in The Times from our correspondent Tad Szulc in recent days have indicated how close Peru was to a financial and economic collapse and how desperately the country needed the vigorous and courageous leadership that Dr. Beltran is now providing.
A 19-year-old girl was wounded yesterday when two men stole a $2,500 payroll from a millinery company. An hour later a window cleaner was taken into custody as a suspect.

HINSDALE, Ill., Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Trish Galvin, petite brunette from Santa Barbara, Calif., brought the United States an individual gold medal in equestrian dressage in the third Pan-American Games today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Government estimated today that more than 70,000,000 vehicles were licensed for use on the nation's highways -2,000,000 more than in 1958.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- The Giants had broken their game with the Detroit Lions wide open last Saturday and had a 24-point lead in the fourth quarter. Jim Lee Howell turned to Allie Sherman, his backfield coach.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -Bills to revise two Supreme Court decisions -- on passports and industrial security -- have come to life in the House of Representatives.
A teen-ager was stabbed and three others were beaten in Brooklyn yesterday. It was the city's third case of juvenile violence in - eleven days.

ELEVEN lectures on "How the Fashion World Works" will be held Tuesday evenings from Sept. 15 through Dec. 1 at the Engineering Auditorium, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street The lectures are under the sponsorship of the Fashion Group, Inc., and will include instruction from fifty-three experts.

A would-be bandit's flesh was willing last night but his spirit quailed before an unrelenting cashier at the Tivoli Theatre, Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street. He told his intended victim before he fled: "If you'll forget about this, I will."
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 2 -- Harry F. Oppenheimer, South Africa's leading industrialist, resigned today from the Opposition United party.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 -Navy units have been alerted in the crisis in India.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 2 -- Dr. Jean F. Piccard, noted aeronautical engineer, was honored today by the American Meteorological Society for his work in the development of balloons for atmospheric research.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 2 -This appears to be the year the University of Pennsylvania has been waiting for. It could be a football season of good luck and much accomplishment resulting from experience and a new attack.

Budget Director Abraham D. Beame branded as "absolutely untrue" yesterday a statement by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa that Mr. Beame favored the $500,000,000 school construction bond issue only because Mayor Wagner was for it.

Webb Knapp, Inc. and subsidiaries showed a loss of $6,680,926 in 1958 in contrast to the $3,199,435 cleared in 1957. Last year's loss was the first since the concern began operating in the real estate field in July, 1952.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- A writ on behalf of James David Armstrong has been issued against the Cunard Steamship Company claiming damages on the ground that he was wrongfully dismissed as master of the liner Britannic.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (UPI) -The Chicago White Sox exploded for eleven runs in the fifth inning tonight for an 11 -- 4 victory over the Detroit Tigers in the second game of a twilight-night bill. The triumph stretched their league lead to five and one-half games.

TWO more ballets by George Balanchine were introduced into the season's repertoire of the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night, both of them charming. They were "Scotch Symphony," set to three movements of the Mendelssohn work of that title, and "Square Dance," which makes brilliant use of music by Corelli and Vivaldi.

R. Carl (Hap) Chandler, former chairman of the CrowellCollier Publishing Company, who sold 11,500 shares of the company's common stock in July, has sold an additional 500 shares and no longer is a stockholder in the company, according to the latest insiders' list of the American Stock Exchange.
The city's attitude toward juvenile gangsters was denounced as "coddling" yesterday at the funeral of one of the teen-age youths stabbed in a playground on West Forty-sixth Street early Sunday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Jaunty Johnny Kelley jogged into Soldier Field in solitary splendor today to give the United States its first international marathon title since 1908.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 -- Ship construction and repair work in yards from San Francisco Bay to the Canadian border had come to a virtual standstill today.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- Hundreds of thousands of Parisians came out of their shops, offices and factories today to cheer and applaud President Eisenhower and President Charles de Gaulle. But no one went wild, despite much official encouragement and a press that used some of its biggest headlines to hail the occasion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Existing controls of radioactive waste resulting from industrial experiments with atomic power have protected the people from noticeable damage, Congress was told today.
I am a daily reader of The Times and appreciate the world-wide coverage of news, almost always impartial and factual.

State Senator Thomas J. Mackell paraphrased Shakespeare yesterday to reply to a charge that he was inciting racial prejudice in his campaign for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Queens.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 2 (AP) -- A Bomarc-B flashed over the Atlantic Ocean and a Cree rocket soared above the Gulf of Mexico today as missile tests were made from both Florida coasts.
Approximately 8,500 union painters, decorators and paper-hangers have been ordered to participate in next Monday's Labor Day parade here or be subject to fines.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 2 -Diller Hanover won the thirtyfourth Hambletonian Stake, America's premier event for 3year-old trotters, in straight heats here today. The victor earned a record purse of $73,666.98.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Hudson Valley business leaders were displeased today because of the experimental reduction of the postmarks of Tarrytown, Irvington, Dobbs Ferry and Ardsley-On-Hudson. Instead, this mail is being postmarked Yonkers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that the United Nations must maintain its "primary responsibility" for situations threatening world peace despite negotiations carried on outside its framework.

MADAME GRES often has been labeled the designer's designer. When she presented her new fall fashions last month, she once again justified this definition. Not only was it one of the outstanding collections in Paris, but also one of the finest in this couturier's long and distinguished career.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The agreement on the labor-reform bill by a Senate-House conference committee today brought some criticism from organized labor, qualified endorsement from members of Congress and a pledge from the Secretary of Labor.

ELMER RICE has been in the theatre four and a half decades. His first Broadway play, "On Trial," a success, was produced in 1914. He is full of years and honors. His fine "Street Scene," a drama of tenement life in New York, was turned down by every knowledgeable management on Broadway, but it won the Pulitzer Prize for 1929.

A COUPLE more giant tuna were brought into Montauk Point yesterday, building up a run of big stuff that has been going on for a week or more. These, with bluefish and school tuna in the neighborhood, are making a fine late season out there.
At a meeting of angry residents of Manhattan's Chelsea district last night they agreed to withhold rents from their landlord, I. L. G. W. U. Houses, Inc.
John Houseman's recent resignation as artistic director of the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre at Stratford, Conn., has produced an aura of concern within the ranks of the acting company.
Columbia University opened a newly renovated residence Hill yesterday exclusively for graduate students who have wins, one child but not two -and no animal pets.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The White House made public today the texts of a warm exchange of letters between Generalissimo Francisco Franco and President Eisenhower.
The State of Connecticut borrowed $60,500,000 in the public market yesterday on serial bonds due from 1961 to 1987. The securities were sold at public bidding at an interest cost of 3.7299 per cent.
IZMIR, Turkey, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A Turkish court trying four United States sergeants on charges of having violated Turkey's currency laws banned any further reporting on the case today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -Secretary Arthur S. Flemming today listed by name and maker twenty-seven products and devices that he said had been fraudulently "foisted on the public as weight reducers."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- The Senate throttled the Chicago water-diversion bill today by referring it to the Foreign Relations Committee. The vote was 54 -- 34.

The Alleghany Corporation, holding company that controls the New York Central Railroad, plans to borrow $15,000,000 on ten-year collateral notes, with a maximum interest rate of 5 per cent, from a group of seven banks led by the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank of New York.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The House of Representatives failed by a one-vote margin today to override President Eisenhower's veto of a $1,216,000,000 civil works appropriation bill.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- Ken Boyer's three-run homer led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight. The game was delayed in the third inning by an argument during which both teams poured onto the field.
American Motors Corporation in the first half of 1959 maintained its position as the most active stock on the Big Board.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 3 (AP) It is "Mike Owens Day" in this glass-making center in honor of the coal miner's son whose inventions revolutionized the glass industry early in this century.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 3 (AP) -The 113th New York State Fair will open with a flourish tomorrow, on a cue from outer space.
Two southbound IRT trains carrying 350 passengers sideswiped each other at an uptown switch track last night. Traffic was blocked and four persons were slightly injured.

NO wonder thousands of people regard the "Ice Capades" as a staple part of their entertainment schedule.

Policeman Day, fit and ready over a rest of more than a year, won the Charles L. Appleton Memorial Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday. The 7-year-old son of Challedon had only four others to beat in the thirty-seventh running of the race and he beat them clearly.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Senate approved tonight the final draft of what is to be the Labor Reform Act of 1959.

OTTAWA, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press) -- The Bank of Canada's interest rate swung upwards today to 5.89 per cent from 5.58 last week, with the sale of a less-than-normal $100,000,000 in 91-day Government treasury bills.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- President Eisenhower will leave France tomorrow richer by two pieces of sculpture and an elephant.
STE. ANNE DE BELLEVUE, Que., Sept. 3 (Canadian Press) -- The Anglican Church of Canada concluded sixteen years of labor today on a revised Book of Common Prayer.

EVER since Joseph Wood Krutch retired nine years ago as Professor of Dramatic Literature at Columbia University and went to Arizona to become a philosopher and sage it has been apparent that he has not been feeling exactly cheery. Of course, philosophers have rarely been notably cheerful.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 3 -- The powerful Cordoba army garrison defied Secretary of War Elbio C. Anaya today, creating a new military crisis for President Arturo Frondizi.

OBERLIN, Ohio, Sept. 3 -- If the country church is to survive, it will have to shift its sights from the dirt farmer to the pushbutton farmer and from the farmhand to the rural non-farm worker, 400 rural church leaders were told here today.

Rafael Angel (Blue Eyes) Rios, a 21-year-old unemployed busboy, was held without bail yesterday on a homicide charge in the killing of Philip Schickler, a lower East Side restaurant owner.
The city's new Code of Ethics for its 225,000 employes became law yesterday with Mayor Wagner's signature. The code is designed to hold all city officials and employes to rigid standards of conduct.

Favorable operating results, with all divisions showing a profit, have prompted directors of Loew's, Inc., to resume the payment of dividends. Yesterday the company declared a quarterly dividend of 30 cents a share for payment on Oct. 14. The latest earlier distribution was a 25-cent quaterly dividend on June 30, 1957.
Mayor Wagner and Governor Rockefeller held separate planning conferences with top city and state officials yesterday on ways to counter the rise in juvenile delinquency.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Moscow radio said today that any talk of discrimination against Jews in the Soviet Union was nothing but falsehood.
More than half of the Roman Catholic nuns of the New York Archdiocese streamed into hospitals yesterday, bared their left arms and received their first Salk anti-polio shots.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 3 -- King Baudouin accepted today the resignation of Maurice van Hemelrijck as Minister for the Belgian Congo. The move followed a Cabinet dispute about how fast democratization should go among the Congo territory's 13,000,000 Negroes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -The House of Representatives approved a 1-cent increase in the Federal gasoline tax today by a vote of 243 to 162.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Robert Joseph Wade Sr., a prominent scene designer for television productions, died yesterday at his home after an operation. He was 51 years old.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 3 -- Dr. Louis S.B. Leakey, a leading British anthropologist, reported today that a recently discovered skull was the link between man and the South African ape man.
Mayor Wagner's backing for legislation and money appropriations needed to eliminate or relieve slum housing was sought yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.

TRENTON, Sept. 3 -- An extensive program to improve and expand New Jersey's mental health, correctional and welfare services and to reduce juvenile delinquency was recommended in a report to Gov. Robert B. Meyner today.

Average borrowings by member banks increased $25,000,000 to $965,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Excess reserves decreased $35,000,000 to $432,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The State Department urged the Soviet Union today to print a statement of United States foreign policy by a "prominent American official" in one of its leading magazines. It proposed that the article be printed before President Eisenhower travels to Moscow later this year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A special grand jury ordered an investigation today of Teamsters Local 107. The local is already under attack from the Senate rackets committee, which charges that it is led by men who have resorted to blackmail and violence.

PARIS, Sept. 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower was host to President Charles de Gaulle at lunch today. He offered his guest a menu prepared by the United States Embassy's French chef.

In Garden City. L.I., in 1923, a bright-eyed 17-year-old boy stared at a Jenny Flying Coffin warming up at the end of an airfield. He paid $5 for an observation flight and was taken aloft on his first trip.

Sears, Roebuck Co., Inc., had record sales and the most profitable first fiscal half-year in its 73-year history, according to the semi-annual report of the nation's biggest mail order and retail merchandiser.

In a seven-column advertisement printed in the Aug. 28 issue of The New York Times the Vivisection Investigation League makes a plea against the use of animals for medical research, with special reference to the virus diseases, and creates the impression that such studies have not led to advances in medical knowledge.

THE Knickerbocker Championships, most popular of the sectional tournaments played annually in New York City, will begin today at the Statler-Hilton Hotel and will continue through Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- Senator Estes Kefauver's Antimonopoly subcommittee voted today to put professional football, basketball and hockey on a more equal footing with baseball by exempting certain of their operations from the antitrust laws. The Waterfront Commission agreed yesterday to postpone until Sept. 30 the taking of testimony from longshore union leaders in connection with its current investigation of pier hoodlums.

It will be possible to live high off the hog this Labor Day week-end. Hams once again are bargains in supermarkets. Pork chops and legs of lamb also are specially priced.

Roberto Iglesias and his Spanish ballet will open a two-week season under the management of S. Hurok at the Winter Garden on Sept. 22, Performances will be given nightly, including Sunday, through Oct. 3, with matinees on both Saturdays, the one Sunday and the final Wednesday.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 4 (Reuters) -- Senior Indian army and air force officers have flown to the Indian-Tibetan border in Ladakh, Kashmir, for discussions with local commanders, it was learned here today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 4 (UPI) -- Len Matthews, the young Philadelphia lightweight contender, outpointed Rolando (Chico) Morales of Cuba tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) -- The Democratic assistant Senate leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, called today for United Nations control of both East and West Berlin as part of a new approach to East-West negotiations over the German capital.

Nasomo of the Pine Tree Stable broke the track record for a mile and a sixteenth at Belmont Park yesterday in winning the feature race. Ridden by Rogelio Trejos, the 3-year-old colt covered the course in 1:40 4/5 and scored by more than two lengths over Frederick Gagel's Reinzi.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- Plans have been formulated for the second visit to the United States of the Comedie Francaise. This was disclosed today by S. Hurok, New York impresario.

The Huntington and Smith-town Union Free School District 10, L.I., is planning the sale of $2,349,500 of bonds on Sept. 17. The issue will be dated Oct. 1, 1959 and will come due serially on April 1 from 1960 to 1989.
A small energetic 13-year-old boy yesterday began his own personal drive against juvenile delinquency and for adult recognition that "all kinds aren't bad."
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 4 (AP) -- The fourteen automobile, dealerships owned by the late! Don Alien have been sold to aI Lnew company, of which his Iwidow has been named vice,

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) -- Southern Democrats denounced today the proposal of the Democratic national chairman, Paul M. Butler, that the 1960 Democratic convention readopt its 1956 compromise "loyalty" rule.
HAVANA, Sept. 4 -- The United States Ambassador to Cuba, Philip W. Bonsal, conferred with Premier Fidel Castro for six hours last night. It was the first time they had met since June 9.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) An airlines group and the Railway Express Agency announced today the signing of an agreement designed to improve handling of air express cargoes.

THE sharp cry of the barker, the lure of the Ferris wheel, the plump porkers and the homemade pies will have new competition at the New York State Fair, which opened in Syracuse yesterday. For the first time two fashion shows will be televised in color daily over six receiver sets spotted about the fair grounds.
Stocks rallied yesterday in a partial recovery from Thursday's broad decline. On average, almost half of the preceding day's losses were regained.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 4 -- The Argentine Army imposed its will on President Arturo Frondizi today.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Sept. 4 -- The president of the Standard Oil Company of California vowed today that if commercial deposits of oil should exist in Alaska, oil men would find them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -Two House subcommittees will hold a public hearing Mon!day at 10 A. M. in New York Ion aircraft noise at two airI ports there.

Announcement that five unrestricted fellowships for foreign students will be available this fall at the New School for Social Research indicates a refreshing attitude toward education. It comes at a moment when education is beset by the new scientism and the hurried pleas that the United States gain ascendancy at all costs over the Russians in matters scientific and technical.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 5 -- A $21,000,000 medical center under construction at Stanford University here will be dedicated Sept. 17-18.

Some correspondents for British news media have complained that neither the public relaions secretary for President Eisenhower nor Prime Minister Macmillan's press officer has been willing to tell what Mr. Eisenhower and Mr. Macmillan have been talking about.
NOT since the days of Sean .O'Casey's earlier Dublin plays has there been such commotion in the theatre here as that evoked by John B. Kean's "Sive."
AMONG shrimp enthusiasts September and October, when there is an abundance of fresh shrimp, are considered the nicest months of the year.

THIS summer has been an uneasy one for American parents. The disease they had thought dead, paralytic poliomyelitis, appears to be disturbingly alive. In some communities it has reached epidemic proportions.
Although stock prices declined last week, many investors found their cash-at-hand increased by higher dividends.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The crisis that has caused this little Asian kingdom to ask the United Nations for military help appears to much of the world to have developed almost overnight.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 -- Transit-poor Los Angeles was smitten suddenly this week with an embarrassment of at least theoretical riches.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 -- An effort by St. Louis University to expand its campus by purchasing twenty-two acres of land in a redevelopment area is headed for a court fight.

A LOT of people drink a lot now because they make a lot of money but things are going to get worse, according to a survey of the recent Summer Institute of Scientific Studies for the Prevention of Alcoholism in Vienna, Austria. The delegates from twenty (hard-drinking) nations must have made some first-hand research in Vienna's Heuriger inns where new wine and zither music are offered all year round.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Accidents in the third and fourth races marred the afternoon card of Monticello Raceway's day-night double-header program today.
The Port of New York last month continued its drive toward a new annual ship traffic record for ocean-going vessels. During August a total of 2,321 American and foreign vessels entered and left.

The selection of about 120 paintings by Chaim Soutine (1894-1943), mostly drawn from private collections and now showing in Paris at the Galerie Charpentier, makes the biggest Soutine exhibition to have been held since his death.

The current issue of Surgery, Gynecology and Obstetrics publishes a preliminary report on the effects of a vaccine on cancer patients. The vaccine was developed by Dr. John B. Graham (M. D.) and Dr. Ruth M. Graham (Sc. D.), husband-and-wife team, of the Roswell Park Memorial Institute, Buffalo, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Representative L. Mendel Rivers, Democrat of South Carolina, urged the House today to "kick out" the Civil Rights Commission, which expires in November unless Congress extends its life.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 5 -- Burial sites for low-level radio-active waste in seven Western states are being sought by the Stanford Research Instiute under contract with the Atomic Energy Commission.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Dr. Frank J. Recio's Noble Sel, paying $151.20 for $2, captured today's Atlantic City Handicap. He slipped through on the inside in the final twenty yards and gained a two-and-a-half length victory over Idle Hour Farm's Julmar.

" It seems to be foolish for the [Communists] to function this way," India's Prime Minister Jawarharlal Nehru said the week before last after announcing Chinese Communist incurions along India's northern frontier. "* * * It is a little difficult to understand what lies behind these incidents."

THREE of these five books are from England. "The Buttercup Children" is titled from children named Robin and Elfrieda interchangeably "linked in a summer game." The verse is just that; august Victorianism, sentimentalized in a soft lyric landscape.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5 -- A Harvard psychologist who has been employing juvenile delinquents to "cure themselves" in Cambridge for the last year and a half proposed today to move his "business" into New York City.
CAMDEN, Ark., Sept. 5 (UPI) -- A 21-year-old Texan who said he was the fattest youth in the world died in a hospital here yesterday.

Along the hot, somnolent side streets of the Forties, west of Broadway, the theatre is stirring. Casting, rehearsing, rewriting, opening -- these are words that agitate the hearts and minds of dedicated producers, actors, playwrights (and playgoers). Out of their emotion, energy and activity will soon come a spate of productions, a few to flourish, most to flop.

AS indicated in some of the photographs on this page, the 1959-60 television season is now with us. Within the next few weeks almost all of the summertime re-run programs will be replaced by new attractions or new installments of shows that have survived from last year.

The House Foreign Affairs Committee has approved a bill that would in some respects override last year's Supreme Court decision that the Secretary of State was not authorized to deny passports because of an applicant's associations or beliefs. But the bill does not give the Administration all it asked. It seems to deny the Secretary of State the right to act as a sort of papa, giving or refusing his children permission to go abroad.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Government this week announced plans to sell about 7,488 tons of magnesium and cadmium-magnesium scrap.

DU QUOIN, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Fred Lorenzen of Elmhurst, Ill., today won the United States Auto Club's 100-mile stock car race at the Du Quoin State Fair for the second straight year. Bob James of Akron. Ohio, was second.

BELLPORT, L. I., Sept. 5 -- Loring Catlin's Stampede led a fleet of thirty-nine across the finish line today in the opening race of the Star Class competition for the Picken Trophy. The race was part of the annual Labor Day week-end invitation regatta, with a total of 270 assorted craft taking the starting gun.

PRODUCER - DIRECTOR Stanley Kramer apparently has an unusually persuasive way with song-and-dance men. Having successfully talked Fred Astaire out of terpsichore for the nonce and into a straight dramatic role in the forthcoming Australian-made "On the Beach." he now has accomplished the same with Gene Kelly.
States Marine Lines Inc. won another bitterly contested round last week in its four-year battle to become a subsidized United States flag operator.

Ed Lubanski, a 30-year-old former minor league pitcher, and Mrs. Marion Ladewig of Grand Rapids, Mich., yesterday were named the man and woman bowlers of the year. It was the first time that Lubanski, a Detroit star, had received the honor and the eighth time that Mrs. Ladewig had been chosen.

ALMA ROUTSONG'S first novel, "A Gradual Joy," was, despite some rough experiences to which the characters were subjected, fundamentally an agreeable book, permeated with an uncloying sweetness. Her new book, "Round Shape," though quite as well written, and showing equally good control of the material, is downright unpleasant.
Fewer than one-third of New York City employers are willing to hire the physically handicapped who possess the necessary job qualifications.
ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The traditional passenger-railroad service that helped build the Empire State is disintegrating rapidly and there is a growing belief it will vanish.

I was interested in your comments on the reaction to movies at an island off the coast of New England. We, too, are in a resort area where many people go to see pictures that they missed in the bigger cities. I would like to add my comments on these movies, for they differ from your results.
Your review of "The Big Fisherman" didn't begin to recount that film's many faults.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- President Eisenhower scored a personal triumph on his visits to Britain. France and Germany that has no precedent in the post-war years. Americans may be justifiably proud of the affection and admiration showered upon the President.

TWENTY-SEVEN years ago Adolf A. Berle, with Gardiner C. Means, published "The Modern Corporation and Private Property," a book which immediately became famous for two striking conclusions. One was that a comparatively small number of large corporations -- including such great giants as American Telephone and Telegraph, Standard Oil of New Jersey and General Motors -- had become responsible for a very large share of all economic activity.

PORT WASHINGTON. L. I., Sept. 5 -- Edgar P. Dunlaevy, with Anne Marie, came up with a victory in the International Class today in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta staged by the Port Washington Yacht Club.
Neale Fraser of Australia lost his opening set yesterday as he began his bid for the tennis championship of the United States at Forest Hills.

MONTREAL -- The Laurentian Autoroute, proudly described by its builders as the finest piece of highway in the Province of Quebec, opened its entire 28.9-mile length a few days ago. and is already carrying thousands of resort-bound vehicles to the Laurentian foot-hills and beyond.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 5 -- Legal liquor was flowing in Oklahoma this week for the first time in fifty-two years but, surprisingly, it created more curiosity than excitement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5 -- Willie Mays, Eddie Bressoud and Willie McCovey crashed home runs as the San Francisco Giants defeated the St. Louis Cardinals today, 3 -- 2. The victory lifted the Giants' league lead to two and a half games over the idle Los Angeles Dodgers and to four and a half over Milwaukee. The Braves were defeated by Cincinnati today, 5 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- What influence will the Eisenhower trip to Western Europe have on the next phase of the President's venture into individual diplomacy -- the coming visit to these shores of the leader of the Soviet Union, Nikita S. Khrushchev?
TWELVE composers should about now be getting busy writing new works for performance in New York in 1960 and 1961.
HONG KONG, Sept. 5 -- Communist North Vietnam voiced strong objection today to the Laotian Government's appeal to the United Nations to send an emergency force to Laos.
GENEVA, Sept. 5 -- The World Federation of United Nations Associations called today for the abolition by stages of nuclear and other weapons of mass destruction.
MIAMI, Sept. 5 -- Gen. Laurence S. Kuter, until recently the Air Force commander in the Far East, described the crisis in Laos today as characteristic of Communist probing efforts throughout Asia.
DETROIT, Sept. 5 -- Michigan's seven-and-one-half-month tax deadlock was broken a week ago. but the key levy in the $128,500,000 program is already under attack in the courts.

THE amount of bridge played in the United States will increase sharply this week. The increase is strictly seasonal but has nothing to do with the weather. Bridge always shows an upturn when the colleges reopen.

TODAY the average teen-age girl looks forward as a matter of course to the rights to vote, to acquire higher education and to try for success in any one of dozens of careers. It is doubtful if she has any idea how recently those privileges have been available to women or how hardly won.

ITALY has raised the minimum age at which anyone, including foreign tourists, can drive a car from 16 to 18 years. Thus Italy falls in line with many other European countries in which legal permission to drive is granted only after the eighteenth birthday.
The Yankees still have a few thrills left even if everything else is running out on them in these waning days of the 1959 season.

WASHINGTON, Sept 5 -- Money and "cold war" politics -- a limited amount of the former and an abundence of the latter -- were cited by Government officials today as the factors that determine whether the United States participates in an international trade fair.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Dr. Milton Finkelstein of Long Island City gained the undisputed lead in the New York State chess championship when he defeated Harold C. Evans of Binghamton after sixty-seven moves today. The Long Islander had a score of 6 -- 1 on five games won and two drawn.

TWO resident theatres that faced homeless futures a month ago are in better spirits today.Circle in the Square, due to be evicted at the end of October, has found suitable quarters in Bleecker Street. Washington's Arena Stage, due to be evicted next spring, has reason to believe that it can lease a suitable plot in the southwest area, only a five-minute drive from the present location.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 5 -- A Bronx youth was held and two other young men were sought today as armed robbers who waged a running gun fight with a policeman on the Bronx River Parkway today. The three were accused of holding up a supermarket here at 7:30 A. M.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept 5 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates, still battling for the National League pennant, came from behind three times today and then pushed over the winning run in the ninth inning. They snapped a three-game losing streak with a 7-6 victory over the Phillies.
The possibility that the city may be plastered with posters denouncing Nikita S. Khrushchev when he visits here later this month was being investigated by the police last night.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 -- Settlement of the five-month strike by three waterfront unions against tugboat companies in Los Angeles and Long Beach harbors was reached yesterday.

Will they, when so inclined, be able to enjoy a fishing trip, a tramp through the woods, a mountain climb or a picnic in uncrowded surroundings of natural beauty not too far from home? WHEN an old paint or varnish finish must be removed prior to applying a new coat, a chemical paint and varnish remover is usually employed. CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Home runs broke the spell today that the White Sox have cast over the Indians. Cleveland hit three of them, good for four runs, in beating Chicago, 6 -- 5, before 26,920 fans at Comiskey Park.

FAR HILLS, N. J., Sept. 5 -- Perhaps after what happened today somebody will get the idea that the way for a dog to get high show honors is to be bitten on the tongue by a bee. The Airedale terrier, Ch. Bengal Sabu, was stung just before he entered the best-in-show class at the twenty-fifth anniversary event of the Somerset Hills Kennel Club.

A NEW model of the 35mm single-lens reflex Asahi Pentax camera (H2), with an "appealing personality" and, for its features, the moderately low price of $179.50, was introduced here last week as the first in a new series to be distributed in the United States exclusively by the Heiland Division of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company.

Officials of the United States Military Academy at West Point denied yesterday that they planned to cut their football activities down to an Ivy League status, as reported from Washington.
Willis J. Tewksbury of Clearwater and Orlando, Fla., will defend his American Lawn Bowling Association singles championship at Spalding Inn, Whitefield, N. H., next Saturday and Sunday.

TRENTON, Sept. 5 -- The 1958-59 fiscal year was termed the best period in the history of the New Jersey state police in a special report released today by Col. Joseph D. Rutter, police superintendent.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 5 -- The Government's practice of refusing passports to critics of the Nationalist Administration's color policies has been extended to an Anglican priest.

WITH the recent announcement by Hyman B. Cantor that financing of construction of two 90,000-ton ocean liners for his Sea Coach Transatlantic Lines, Inc., has been arranged, it is now possible that the company's much-heralded $50 one-way fare to Europe could become a reality by the middle of 1962.

COON RAPIDS, Iowa. "CORN is sausage on the stalk, corn is beefsteak, it is bacon, it is butter -- that's why I am a booster for corn," said Nikita Khrushchev in a recent speech. The remark sounds like a quotation from Roswell (Bob) Garst, whose farm near here the Soviet Premier will visit Sept. 23 -- and it may well be, for Garst has talked about corn with Khrushchev several times.

LONDON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Prof. Leonid I. Sedov, chief policy adviser on the Soviet sputnik program, was elected today president of the twenty-six-nation International Astronautical Federation. He is the first Russian to hold the post.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 20 -- Yugoslav officials and enterprises are beating the bushes for customers like so many Yankee traders.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- Bob Goalby of Crystal River, Fla., produced a 66 -- six under par -- for a 135 and the 36-hole lead in the $20,000 Kansas City open today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 5 -- The Stamford Yacht Club's twenty-fifth Vineyard race loomed as one of the slowest on record today.

General business in Pennsylvania reached a record high in July, while industrial activity rose to its highest point for the month since 1953. The index kept by the Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University showed that bank debts also reached a new high, while July records were set by industrial power sales, life insurance sales, postal receipts and telephones.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 -- The ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach expect 1959 to set a record in traffic.

AMONG the happiest events of any publishing season must be reckoned the appearance of one of the historical mysteries of John Dickson Carr. Well-researched and evocative, they have all the charm and interest of a period piece, with the added attraction of a faultless formal puzzle in detection.

PARIS, Sept. 5 -- Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville expressed the hope tonight that United States and French policies in North Africa would henceforth be "better coordinated" as a result of President Eisenhower's meeting with President Charles de Gaulle.

THE first White Sox team to win a pennant was the 1906 collection known as "The Hitless Wonders." Their batting average was .228 and they hit nine home runs all season. The slugging leader was Frank Isbell with a .279 average and three round-trippers.

Business and Industry gave the nation's schools and colleges a record total of $136,000,000 last year, the Council for Financial Aid to Education reported last week. This was $27.000,000 more than the amount contributed in 1956.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- In Latin America, the shape of things to come in the next decade and a half has been assuming a visible outline for eighteen months. In the present and still unclear projections, the emerging pattern indicates "a large and stable market for heavy industrial equipment."

To those who recognize Carl Mydans only as a master of the camera who helped make Life magazine, "More Than Meets the Eye," his first prose work, will come as a surprise. For it is difficult to credit the evidence that one whose eye could capture the stark and flaring photographic images Life made famous should, simultaneously, be able to hear the rhythms that have produced these pages of cadenced prose.

Dr. Louis S. B. Leakey, British anthropologist, reported last week at the Pan-African Congress of Prehistory at Leopoldville, Belgian Congo, that he and his wife had discovered, in the Olduvai Gorge, Tanganyika, the skull of a youth which he regards as the long-sought-for link between the South African near-man or ape-man and man.

The Department of Commerce and Public Events has announced that Mayor Wagner has issued nineteen certificates of appreciation to organizations and persons whose plantings added to the success of the city's Salute to Spring.

BASEBALL The Yankees scored two runs in the ninth to defeat the Orioles, 3 -- 2, yesterday at the Stadium. Yogi Berra tallied on Marv Throneberry's single and then Elston Howard drove in the winning run. The Giants beat the Cards, 3 -- 2, with three homers.

Last Wednesday afternoon the House was debating a minor bill when Rep. Graham A. Barden, North Carolina Democrat, rushed In and announced, "I take this moment to inform the House, believe it or not, that we have agreed on a labor bill; and, may I. add, all of the conferees survived." There were loud cheers from both sides of the aisle.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 5 -- Jay Hook, a rookie, dealt another blow to Milwaukee's pennant hopes today as he held the Braves to four hits and hurled the Reds to a 5-1 victory.
HARTFORD, Sept. 5 -- The State Board of Education declared in its annual report today that public school education costs in Connecticut had jumped more than 60 per cent from 1953 to 1958.

RED BANK, N. J., Sept. 4 -- More than 1,000,000 cars use the Garden State Parkway from noon Friday to noon Monday on an average summer week-end. Some break down, overheat, run out of gasoline or get a flat tire. It is the state trooper's job to get help for stranded motorists.

Sanford B. Cousins has been named to succeed H. Randolph Maddox as personnel vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Mr. Maddox will retire after 38 years of service. James W. Cook was named public relations vice president.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Chris von Saltza, a 15-year-old blonde from Saratoga, Calif., splashed to her third Pan-American Games gold medal in swimming today. She anchored the record-setting United States women's 400-meter free-style relay team.

AMERICAN and Soviet workmen are scurrying just as furiously today to clear away the last vestiges of Americana from the American National Exhibition, which has just closed in Moscow's Sokolniki Park, as they were six weeks ago to get the glittering display opened.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 -- A major shift in the 1960 Presidential campaign strategy of Vice President Richard M. Nixon was indicated by developments in his home state this week.
WASHINGTON, Sunday, Sept. 6 -- The Senate approved a 1-cent rise in the Federal gasoline tax late last night after fighting its way through a maze of parliamentary traps.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- The Federal Government and the State of Texas were in official agreement today that Walter G. Williams is the last surviving Civil War veteran.

A 20-year-old youth, arrested twice in the last two years. was in custody again yesterday after his parents preferred criminal charges against him "to teach him a lesson."

WITH a Labor Day weekend before us and a deliberately non-sensational season by the New York City Ballet in progress at the City Center, there would seem to be Nothing more appropriate to do this morning than ramble relaxedly through some more of those impressions of a pleasantly familiar repertory and that chameleon-like process known as performance.
I found your comments entitled "Contender Rockefeller" that appeared in the Aug. 23 "News of the Week in Review" interesting in several respects.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 28 -- The 1959 Minnesota Legislature has amended its tax laws in this seventy-fifth anniversary year of the state's iron-ore industry to encourage development of certain low-grade ores euphemistically called "semi-taconite."
PARIS, Sept. 5 -- Spain has made considerable progress in the last few days in breaking out of twenty years of diplomatic isolation, according to Spanish diplomatic sources.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- The quietest squad that George (Lefty) James has had in his thirteen football seasons at Cornell may make a big noise in the Ivy League this season. The one factor that could cause deathly silence hereabouts is injury to one or two key players.

A GAP in the recorded opera repertory has been closed (the old Cetra version not always being easy to obtain) with a new Gianni Schicchi made in Rome last summer under the direction of Gabriele Santini (Capitol, stereo).

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Jim Lemon's two home runs in a ten-run third inning drove in six runs, tied two major league records and gave the Washington Senators a 14-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- The five leading customers for United States agricultural exports cut their purchases by 1S per cent in 1958.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 5 -- If a group of West Orange citizens can gain local support, future boards of education here will be chosen by the residents, not appointed by the Mayor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Larry Jackson, who had lost three straight decisions to the San Francisco Giants, blanked the National League leaders, 1 -- 0, on five singles today for the St. Louis Cardinals.
PANCHO GONZALES walked out on a professional tennis commitment in Europe a little more than a week ago and the immediate future of amateur tennis through the world may be affected by his default.
The Secretary of Labor announced yesterday that he would urge President Eisenhower to intervene in the steel strike if it continued into October and created a national emergency.
WITHIN the Dakota apartment house, a dinosaur of a building at 1 West Seventy-second Street, toil three estimable women.
PATERSON, N. J., Sept. 6 -- Public school enrollment in Passaic County is expected to jump from last year's total of 63,137 to 65,847, continuing an upward spiral.
A recorded interview with Dr. Andrew C. Ivy, advocate of the controversial anti-cancer agent Krebiozen, was cut off the air last night on WNTA-TV (Channel 13) after it had run about seven minutes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A bill to set up a youth conservation corps has been held up in the House of Representatives by the battle over labor legislation.

DURBAN, South Africa, Sept. 6 (AP) -- More than 1,000 Africans met here today to discuss a plan for non-violent resistance to South Africa's segregation policies. Boycotts were one possibility suggested.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 -- The Right Rev. James A. Pike, Episcopal Bishop of California, said today that he was disappointed that the White House had ignored his proposal that a church service be included in Nikita S. Khrushchev's American tour.

BERLIN, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Former Secretary of State James F. Byrnes, one of the men who drew up the Potsdam Agreement on the occupation of Germany, arrived in. Berlin today and defended the agreement. However, he said some points in it should have been different.

WARSAW, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -- Wladyslaw Gomulka said today that Polish farmers had failed to achieve planned increases in output this year but added that the Government had no plans to force them into state cooperatives.

The Rev. Dr. Dan M. Potter, director of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, urged churchgoers yesterday to join in special prayers during the visit of Nikita S. Khrushchev. The Soviet Premier will arrive in this country on Sept. 15. Dr. Potter was guest speaker at the Broadway Congregational Church at Fifty-sixth Street.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 6 (UPI) -- Dow Finsterwald of Tequesta, Fla., scored a three-under-par 69 today that tied Bob Goalby at 206 for the 54-hole lead in the Kansas City open golf tournament.
Eugene Donahue, 23 years old, of the Roxbury section of Boston, suffered a concussion and a lacerated scalp yesterday when he fell from a roller coaster in the amusement section of Coney Island.

Although every minute the world's rivers carry tons of dissolved minerals into the ocean, it was reported last week that the composition of sea water has apparently not varied substantially for 250,000,000 years.

NEW PALTZ, N. Y., Sept. 6 -- A group of Labor Day weekenders with a touch of the adventurous spent their holiday laboring up and down and up and down some cliffs near here.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 6 -- The increasingly perplexing problem of financing rising school costs under existing tax structures will face Nassau County educators and taxpayers this year as a record estimated total of 298,000 pupils start school this week. This is an increase of about 19,000 over last year.

ONE of the greatest hazards in slam bidding is a long. weak side suit such as Ace-x-x-x-x in declarer's hand (-)posite two or three small cards in his partner's hand.
Governor Rockefeller indicated yesterday that the state's youth-camp program might be extended as a result of the juvenile delinquency crisis.

BUFFALO, Sept. 6 (UPI) -- Maverick widened her lead for the national high-point unlimited hydroplane title today when she won the eleventh annual Buffalo Launch Club international regatta.

HACKENSACK, N. J. Sept. 6 -- The post - war population growth of Bergen County will again be reflected with the opening of the school term this month. There will be more pupils, more buildings, more teachers and higher budgets.

I have read with concern a recent letter in your column deprecating the effects of local ragweed elimination in hay fever alleviation. This erroneous conclusion was based upon the well-known fact that ragweed pollen can be airborne for great distances.
In a Labor Day sermon at the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, the Rev. John Papandrew, associate minister, noted that labor's philosophy had changed over the years.

The Unity Center of Practical Christianity held its first Sunday services yesterday in new quarters at 143 West Fifty-first Street. The old quarters at 1 West Forty-seventh Street had become too small because membership had tripled in the last year and a half, the Rev. J. Sig Paulson, minister, said.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. 6 Hudson County's public schools will have an estimated increase in enrollment of 1,665 over last year, a survey of the twelve municipalities indicates.

THE five-day delirium is a well-known tourist symptom here, and no one wants to be cured of it. Women are always susceptible. Despite the thick heat, they rise early, begrudge time for a leisurely breakfast, forsake their air-conditioned hotel room and rush into the streets to go on the most compelling shopping spree of their lives.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Congress starts a week of intensive activity tomorrow with five major issues and Senator Wayne Morse standing in the way of adjournment by Sept. 12.

THE Tilletts, a talented textile-designing family, have expanded to the Caribbean. This time it is Jim Tillett who is in the public eye. It is the result of a new enterprise, Jim Tillett Caribbean, Inc., which opened last month.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Two Italian films -- Roberto Rossellini's "II Generale Della Rovere" and Dino de Laurentiis' "La Grande Guerra" -- tied tonight for top honors in the annual Venice Film Festival.

MELBOURNE, Sept. 6 -- Clothes made of new drip-dry norion fabrics will be on sale throughout Australia early next year. This was announced today by William Archer Gunn, chairman of the Australian Wool Board, at a ceremony in wich processing details were released to manufacturers.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 6 (AP) -- During the celebration of All Nations Day at an amusement park today a crowd attacked pickets who were protesting the exclusion of Negroes from the park.

The Associated Hospital Service has shown a welcome responsiveness to the needs of its subscribers and the public in the New York metropolitan area through the appointment of an eighteen-member "public advisory committee." The timing of its announcement -- just before the 26.5 per cent increase in its rates went into effect -- was excellent public relations.

Timothy V. Hartnett, in his letter in The Times of Aug. 28, says that the Tobacco Industry Research Committee of which he is chairman will continue to speak up in the public interest when there is danger of misleading the public about the significance of research reports.

NEWARK, Sept. 6 -- In many of Essex County's twenty-one school districts, officials are striving, so far vainly, to provide adequate facilities in the face of continued expanding school enrollments. The steady climb of the county's school population since World War II continues.

Cotton prices in the domestic market fluctuated narrowly last week, closing the period in mostly lower ground. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 5 to down 23 points from the week previous.

A six-story store and office building and two apartment buildings at 2071-77 Broadway and 200-10 West Seventy-second Street, the southwest corner, have been sold by Phillip P. Zipes, realty operator, to an investor.

Princess Beatrix, the 21-year-old heiress presumptive to the Dutch throne, is scheduled to attend next Sunday's morning service at the West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue and Seventh-seventh Street.

Milton Fried and others have sold the six-story apartment house for forty families at 959 Park Place, Brooklyn, to Miller Hirsch for investment. Leon J. Weinstein, broker, negotiated the sale for cash over mortgages amounting to $260,000.

Records will fall by the wayside when the annual back-to-school movement starts tomorrow in the suburbs. Most suburban schools will reopen this week, but others will resume classes next Monday along with the New York City schools.

The resignation of Maurice van Hemelrijck as Minister for the Belgian Congo does not necessarily mean that Belgium will slow down the democratization of her vast African colony. The Brussels Government has moved already to show that no such retreat is in prospect. But the fact remains that the florid, snowy-haired and forthright M. van Hemelrijck had pressed for the swiftest possible implementation of the plan to increase democracy.

AYR, Scotland, Sept. 6 -- President Eisenhower has decided to leave Scotland tomorrow morning for the United States. There was no official explanation of what appeared to be a change in his departure plans.

The idea caught on and spread fast across the country.

Your article on "West Side Slums" in The Times of Aug. 25 underscores the failure of rent control really to control rents. Because the loopholes which were not closed permit renting single rooms in apartments to families, we have slums renting for $400 per month for a six-room apartment.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 6 -- There is one description for the Stamford Yacht Clubs Vineyard race being held for the twenty-fifth time this week-end -- no wind.

MORE than sixty years ago a little Dutch girl called Rick lived with her parents in a big house in the interior of the island of Java. The house had white columns, long galleries and floors of white marble. In the walled garden gorgeous tropical flowers bloomed and deer crossed the lawns early in the morning, their tracks making patterns in the dew.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- The Security Council, which under the United Nations Charter has the primary responsibility for the maintenance of international peace and security, is composed of eleven nations -- five permanent members and six elected for two-year terms.
MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 7 -Five Long Island youths were charged with disorderly conduct today after a disturbance on a Long Island Rail Road train.

Ramanathan Krishnan of India and Richard Savitt were beaten in the tennis championships of the United States at Forest Hills yesterday and Alex Olmedo lost the opening set before eliminating Straight Clark.

In 1925, Dr. Raymond A. Dart was at the University of Witwatersrand in South Africa when he announced the discovery of remains that he called Australopithecus prometheus. From other discoveries of the early man, Dr. Dart reasoned that the human species might have originated in Africa.

The Citizens Union issued a list of endorsements yesterday in political leadership contests in Manhattan that will be decided in the primary next Tuesday, Sept. 15. Significantly, it omitted a recommendation in the Democratic race in the First Assembly District South.

TOKYO, Sept. 7 -- Heated arguments marked the opening today of a series of hearings before the Japanese Supreme Court to determine whether the presence of United States military forces in Japan is unconstitutional.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 7 -Eighty-one African students from Kenya left by air today for the United States. The students have $2,000 scholarships raised for them by Tom Mboya, African nationalist leader, during his recent tour of the United States.
LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) -Buckingham Palace made public a farewell exchange of messages today between President Eisenhower and Queen Elizabeth II.
MIAMI, Sept. 7 -- Florida approached the beginning of public school desegregation tomorrow in an outward air of casualness.

Two hundred delegates to the annual Chinese Catholic conference yesterday adopted a series of resolutions to further the cause of Catholicism among Chinese people.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- According to evidence from many parts of the world, presented here today, some 6,000 years ago the oceans rose forty-five feet within a few centuries.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, Sept. 7 -- The Arab League council took four decisions here today aimed against Israel and Zionism.
Tea for two has become a growing pastime, according to data of the tea industry.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 7 -Wayne (Red) Hardin, Navy's new football coach, and his wife, Pat, spent the week-end in New York running the entertainment gantlet with a lot of other tourists.

ROME, Sept. 7 -- Ten days of handshaking, lunching and negotiating in Paris, Munich and Rome have served to solidify harness racing on an international basis, Alvin L. Weil, secretary of Roosevelt Raceway, reported today.

Through Mayor Wagner's signature the city now has a new Code of Ethics characterized by City Council Majority Leader Sharkey as "the toughest of its kind in the country." The new code, developed by a committee headed by Councilman Morris J. Stein after a study of more than two years, is described generally as designed to hold all city officials and employes to rigid standards of conduct.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 7 -- A psychologist said today that Villanova University had been pressed to dismiss him for his views on race.

The New York Herald Tribune announced yesterday the appointment of Dwight E. Sargent as editor of the editorial page. Mr. Sargent is editorial director of the Portland, Me., newspapers.

The national steel strike became the longest in the industry's history at 12:01 A. M. today.
Nineteen policemen were promoted yesterday for their work in apprehending suspects in the recent wave of juvenile violence and other crimes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Big Four formally set up today a ten-nation committee to begin new disarmament talks early next year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee set out today to learn why the State Department was subsidizing the visit of eleven school teachers from France to the Highlander Folk School at Monteagle, Tenn.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- A general election in Britain next month was considered a virtual certainty in political circles tonight.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP) -This is the last week of limited auto production before the big surge of 1960 model cars.

Alexander P. Chopin, chairman of the New York Shipping Association, renewed a request to the Waterfront Commission yesterday that it tighten its regulations governing port watchmen.

A 28-year-old man was pursued and stabbed to death on a downtown street last night after a heated argument with a teenager.

The Treasury, as a debt manager, has no realistic alternative but to pay competitive market rates of interest in financing the public debt, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. A study, "Treasury Debt Management," published in the September issue of the New York Reserve Bank's monthly review, said that efforts to avoid paying market rates must involve inflation of the money supply or interference with the freedom of investors' decisions.
American churches and synagogues had more members last year than ever before. The National Council of Churches reported yesterday that 109,557,741 Americans had religious affiliations in 1958.

Y., Sept. 7 -- One of the principal subjects debated in the Security Council today was the usefulness of the International Control Commission established in 1954 to supervise the Geneva armistice agreement ending the Indochina War in Laos. The commission has suspended its operations.
