ALBANY, Sept. 8 -- Figures released by the State Health Department today showed that there were eighty cases of paralytic polio in the area outside New York City through last Thursday, twenty of them involving persons with three shots of Salk vaccine.
MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- Potato beetles, which were spawned in the United States more than a century ago, are threatening Soviet potato crops.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Bertha Ragan of the Raybestos Brakettes pitched a two-hitter tonight for her third straight shutout, a 1-0 triumph over the Orange (Calif.) Lionettes in the women's world softball tournament.

I don't want to belabor the truth about oil for heating and air pollution, but I would like to make clear, in connection with your Sept. 3 editorial "Time for a Check-Up" that oil for home heating (No. 2 fuel oil) does not contribute to air pollution in this city or other cities.
NEW YORK players dominated the Knickerbocker Championships, held over the Labor Day week-end, for the first three days; but in the last of the major contests the out-of-town contingent came through.
Industrial Enterprises, Inc., is entering the film storage service business through the purchase of the Bonded Film Storage Company, Inc.; Bonded TV Film Service, Inc., and affiliated companies.
ON April 9, 1865, at Appomattox in southern Virginia Gen. Robert E. Lee surrendered the Army of Northern Virginia to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The following table of Negro and white voting eligibility in the South was adapted from statistics in the Civil Rights Commission report. The figures, not previously available, were compiled by the commission from official and unofficial sources.
Following is the text of a program of action proposed yesterday by Governor Rockefeller to combat juvenile delinquency:

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Most wheat futures hit highs for the season on gains of fractions on the Board of Trade today. But they finished mostly below last Friday's closes, after a late, moderate flurry of selling.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A Negro, home in LeFlore County, Miss., after receiving his honorable discharge as an Army sergeant, went to the court-house to register as a voter. The clerk said she was too busy and asked him to leave his name and address.
A total of 438 persons died on the nation's highways during the Labor Day week-end as the city, state and nation recorded higher tolls this year than last.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Seven men were indicted on charges of involuntary manslaughter today in connectin with a cave-in that killed twelve coal miners last Jan. 22. Three of the group were accused of conspiracy.

A report of a reduced European beet crop touched off heavy buying yesterday in world sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Volume reached 60,500 tons, the highest since Jan. 2, when 103,600 tons changed hands.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- Robert L. Myers Jr., State Secretary of Banking, today authorized Pennsylvania banks to raise interest rates, effective on Oct. 1. The new limit on time deposits and savings accounts in commercial banks will be 3 per cent. Savings banks and employes mutual banking associations will be able to pay interest up to 3.5 per cent.

CHICAGO, Sept, 8 (AP) -- Luis Aparicio's run - scoring single in the tenth inning lifted the Chicago White Sox to a 3-2 triumph over the Kansas City Athletics tonight, and increased the White Sox', lead over the idle Cleveland Indians to five games.

EBORACUM, Britannia, VIL Septembris -- About forty archaeologists searched today for relics of a Roman legion that disappeared almost completely more than 1,800 years ago. The legion was the famous Ninth of North Britain.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- The Senate rackets committee's investigation of the United Auto Workers union erupted today into a verbal battle among Senators, lawyers and witnesses.
A television channel here has completed plans to advertise to consumers in supermarkets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee charged today that President Eisenhower had "used the full power of the Presidency" to thwart Congress attempt to give him the necessary means to strengthen the United States in a time of national peril.
CASABLANCA, Morocco, Sept. 8 -- The Arab League foreign ministers' meeting ended here today with a decision to modernize the League's charter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The House passed a moderate travel-control bill today after beating down proposals to let the Secretary of State rely on confidential informants in denying passports.

The evening performance of "Take Me Along" at the Shubert Theatre on Nov. 18 will benefit the Institute of World Affairs, Inc., 527 Madison Avenue. The new musical, with score and lyrics by Bob Merrill, stars Jackie Gleason, Walter Pidgeon, Eileen Herlie and Robert Morse.

11 A. M.: "Animals That Never Were" is the subject of a gallery talk to be given by Helen Snider in the Junior Museum of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Fifth Avenue and Eighty-second Street. At 1:30 P. M. on Sunday, a half-hour film, "Craftsmanship in Clay," will be shown. Admission is free. For information, call TRafalgar 9-5500.

The continuing annual deficits of the United States in its balance of international payments, with the accompanying drain on the nation's monetary gold reserves, reports Edwin L. Dale Jr. of our Washington bureau, has of late given rise to some soul-searching within the Administration.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- A group within the National Academy of Sciences that hopes to drill down and see what the earth's interior is made of, appealed today for $2,500,000 for the initial, phase of the project.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed into law today a bill making it a Federal offense to hunt wild horses on public lands or ranges from an airplane or a motor vehicle.

An encouraging development in the legal profession is the growing interest in "refresher" courses for lawyers after they are in practice. Other professions have long understood this need; no doctor believes he can rest on what he learned at medical school. But the bar has lagged.

No one talks back to Nikita S. Khrushchev any more. That is the way one observer describes the metamorphosis of Soviet rule from "collective leadership" to domination by Mr. Khrushchev in the last two years.

The transformation of demoralized destroyer units into one of the greatest squadrons in United States naval history is told by Ken Jones in "Destroyer Squadron 23." It is the story of Commodore Arleigh Burke, commander of the squadron, and of the heroism and bravery of his units in the South Sea naval battles that culminated in "the perfect battle of Cape St. George."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -President Eisenhower is seriously considering a visit to India after his trip to the Soviet Union later this year.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., Sept. 8 -- School integration began in Warren County today. There were no incidents.

The recent outburst of juvenile violence in New York, starkly tragic for the families and children directly involved, has become a cause of grave concern for the entire community. In the wake of these lamentable events, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy has earned the high commendations of all his fellow-citizens for his reasonable and sound approach to "stereotyping" and juvenile delinquency.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 8 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today that the survival of West Germany's ten-year-old democracy depended upon an ever closer alliance with the West.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 -- It seems unlikely that Nikita S. Khrushchev, in his visit here Sept. 19 and 20, will have even the superficial exposure to the real life of the area afforded annual hordes of preoccupied conventioneers.

Another first-run motion picture theatre, the Astor, Broadway and Forty-fifth Street, will undergo extensive modernization. Loew's State was renovated earlier this year and the Capitol is about to be.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee had praise today for the Government's handling of the crisis caused by Communist attacks in Laos.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Following are excerpts from a report issued today by the Federal Commission on Civil Rights:
The Port of New York yesterday received 9,111 passengers aboard eight liners from Europe and the West Indies, and on two troopships.

SOPHIE of Saks Fifth Avenue is a maverick among designers. Secure in a demanding clientele who snap up her designs almost as fast as she can create them. this Texas-born couturier hues to an independence of line that has envious colleagues all but eating their tape measures.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 8 -- The race for 120 seats in Israel's fourth Knesset (Parliament) was officially under way tonight with twenty-six political parties submitting lists of candidates.

THE approach of fall has not resulted in any curtailment of vegetable supplies. For example summer varieties of squash are still available in abundance. And this is the peak season for the purple eggplant.
Three members of Sergeant Bilko's platoon are going to star in a new live variety show on WABC-TV (Channel 7).

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The first application for a commercial license to manufacture live-virus poliomyelitis vaccine has been filed with the Division of Biological Standards of the Public Health Service's National Institute of Health.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Radioactive fall-out from nuclear tests apparently has passed its peak, the Atomic Energy Commission reported today.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Mrs. Theodore S. Hirtz gave a tea at the Scarsdale Golf Club today in honor of the eighteen young women who will be presented at the Holly Ball there on Dec. 26.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 8 -- This city's police department still had two commanding officers today.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 8 -- A move to unseat the Interior Minister, Alfredo Vitolo, who has been the strongest civilian Cabinet member, was launched today from within President Arturo Frondizi's own party.
Governor Rockefeller announced a wide state move against juvenile delinquency yesterday.

Carleton Palmer's Irish-bred Tharp won the New York City Hudson Celebration, the turf race that served as the feature attraction at Belmont Park yesterday. Although ten horses competed for the purse, the crowd of 16,380 had every confidence in Tharp and he returned the short price of $3.80 for $2.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 8 -A new Beethoven Hall was opened today to music the great Bonn composer wrote for the opening of a Viennese Theatre in 1822. The work was "The Consecration of the House" Overture.
Agreement appeared near last night on a formula for granting relief to nonresidents who are subject to New York State income taxes.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 8 -- Three young women, all provisional members of the Junior League of New York, made their formal bows to society here last evening. They are the Misses Delia Blake, Cathleen Miller and Deborah Platt, who were honored at a dinner dance given by their parents at the Round Hill Club.
HONG KONG, Sept. 8 -- Premier Pham Van Dong of Communist North Vietnam made a new appeal to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India yesterday on the situation in Laos.
Followers of the New York Football Giants will see something new this fall: A man-in-motion series. Its purpose is to slow defensive pursuit.

WARSAW, Sept. 8 (Reuters) -- About 200 scientists from twenty-seven conntries attended the opening sessions here today of the first international conference on the uses of atomic radi-I ation in industry.

Tammany district leaderships are being contested in a solid block of Manhattan's East Side from Twentieth to Ninety-fourth Street. Six leaderships and an equal number of co-leaderships (female) will be settled in the primary election Sept. 15.
The International Longshoremen's Association is acting to remove the last internal obstacle to a return to what it calls "the house of labor."
CINCINNATI, Sept. 8 -- What kind of man makes the best soldier? What makes one man fight and another hide or run away?

Arnold Bergson Co., general insurance brokers, leased space for an office in the building completed recently by Samuel Rudin at 355 Lexington Avenue, corner of Fortieth Street. Richard J. Doherty of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., was the broker.

A Reform Jewish temple that intends to make its worship an intellectual and musical experience as well as a religious one will begin services Sept. 18 in the Community Church, Unitarian, on Thirty-fifth Street between Park and Madison Avenues.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- The Security Council's newly appointed subcommittee of four members will leave for Laos by the end of this week to inquire into Laos' charge of aggression against the Communist Government of North Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Congress finally came to terms with the White House on a housing bill today, but refused to tailor its civil works bill to avoid a second Presidential veto.
One of the most successful "specials" ever built for racing on sports-car courses was among the victors last week-end in the Sports Car Club of America national meet at Thompson, Conn.

A temporary firehouse will be constructed by Jan 1 in a parking lot on Fiftieth Street at Third Avenue. It will house one engine and one ladder truck, and will replace the fire-house at 165 East Fifty-first Street that was abandoned in 1957 to make way for new construction.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The pace of racial desegregation in schools has slowed almost to a halt, the Civil Rights Commission says in its report released today.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. set as a political goal yesterday the appointment of Negroes or Puerto Ricans to one of every three elective or appointive offices in Manhattan.
Three producers have raised the price of refined copper 1 1/2 cents a pound, to 31 1/2 cents, effective today.

The proposed 1964 New York World's Fair will be different from the 1939 fair in at least one respect, according to its chief spokesman. It will not have burlesque shows, bubble dancers or similar displays.
LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The old dispute between London and Dublin over the art collection of the late Sir Hugh Lane may be near an end.

John R. White, a vice president of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., realty concern, will teach a course on "The Theory and Practice of Real Estate Appraising" beginning Sept. 23 at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty - ninth Street.
WINDSOR, Ont., Sept. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Chrysler Corporation of Canada, Ltd., today announced two appointments at management level.
The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith urged yesterday that the United States Civil Rights Commission be continued.
The Honest Ballot Association said yesterday that it was going to re-examine the ballots it had counted Friday in a seamen's union referendum.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that unfavorable weather over the last month in a few areas had reduced this year's cotton crop forecast by 137,000 bales to 14,678,000 bales.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 8 -- J. H. Black's Sara Black from Sea View, Va., made it nine victories in a row tonight by winning the Kiwanis Club Trot before 17,501 fans in 2:05 2/5 at Roosevelt Raceway. Bob Walker drove the winner, who paid $2.70 for $2 in the mile event.
Several thousand printers, many of them accompanied by their families, spent most of yesterday taking a look at the latest advances in their art.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Sir Robert H. Scott, British Commissioner General in Singapore, has been dispatched to Vientiane, capital of Laos, to begin a fact-finding mission, the Foreign Office announced today.
LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Britain's general election will be held Oct. 8.
By virtue of saving four match points in the third set against Ronald Holmberg yesterday, Earl Buchholz remained in the running in the tennis championship of the United States at Forest Hills.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 8 -- The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization celebrated its fifth anniversary here today as it faced its first real test in defense of a Southeast Asian country threatened by communism.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 8 -- William C. Doherty, president of the National Association of Letter Carriers in the United States, called on British trade unionists today to beware of the "false promises and propaganda campaigns" of international communism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A parliamentary strategem to extend the life of the Civil Rights Commission was unveiled in the Senate today, shortly after the commission had given its report to President Eisenhower.
A new testing program intended to give colleges a broader evaluation of applicants for admission was announced here yesterday by the State University of Iowa.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 7 -- India took issue officially with the Dalai Lama today on the question of the legal status of Tibet.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Theodore W. Kheel, president of the National Urban League, called on Congress today to pass immediately a bill to guarantee Negro voting rights.

LAST night the New York City Ballet chose to revive its former production of "Jeux d'Enfants" in a somewhat revised form as the only novelty of its current season at the City Center. Just why it undertook to do so is not clear.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev will need all of his renowned vigor on his tour of the United States.
The United States chess champion, Bobby Fischer, ran into tough competition last night in the second round of the world championship challengers' tournament in Bled, according to Yugoslav sources.

A growing army of gossipers -- numbering several thousand across the country -- face a crackdown by the Federal Communications Commission if they do not curb their hours of rambling chitchat on the airwaves.
A 4-year-old boy was revived in Brooklyn Jewish Hospital yesterday after his heart had stopped when he fell four stories to a concrete pavement.
New Orleans filed a formal application yesterday for one of the three berths remaining open in the new Continental League.

THE exhibition season is not quite fully upon us, but the warm-up this week includes a spate of gallery group shows, several one-man exhibitions and two museum openings. The gallery exhibitions are designed to give a foretaste of future events, presenting new work by regular exhibitors, many of whom will have one-man exhibitions later.
From across the border comes word of an unusual plan for financing a utility. It entails cash at hand and delayed dividends
BONN, Germany, Sept. 8 -- The actors for the leading roles in the 1960 renewal of the Oberammergau Passion Play were chosen today by the city fathers with procedures rich in tradition.

An unwritten law observed by many women stipulates that fall clothes are in order after Labor Day. Although the weather, rather than the calendar, appears to be ruling dressing habits, cottons that are bare or light in color should be put away.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 8 -- Public indignation in Little Rock rose today over the bombing of two buildings and a city-owned automobile. The Chamber of Commerce offered a $25,000 reward for the solution of the crimes.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 8 (AP) -- A Federal judge ruled today that if Montgomery's historically segregated city parks ever reopened, the racial barriers must be taken down.
HALF the fun in shopping is the atmosphere. The other half is in locating a genuine "find."

THERE is really no excuse at all for the Theatre East revival of "East Lynne" last evening. A new off-Broadway troupe has condensed the 99-year-old-melodrama, furnished it-with a blase narrator and, from some inspired source, drawn for it an "improved" title -- "Boo Hoo! East Lynne" -- because otherwise people might not realize that it's a tearjerker and that it is being spoofed.

The Coast Guard in Washington has closed the books on its inquiry into the collision between the American. Export liner Constitution and the Norwegian tanker Jalanta last March 1 off Ambrose Lightship.
The American Opera Society will open its seventh New York season with a performance of Donizetti's rarely heard "Il Duca d'Alba" on Oct. 20 at Carnegie Hall.

Following are the texts of a letter sent by President Eisenhower yesterday to both sides in the steel strike, a reply by David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, and comments by R. Conrad Cooper, chief negotiator for the steel companies.
DETROIT, Sept. 8 -- The Detroit News failed to publish today because of a dispute with members of Local 13 of the Printing Pressmen and Assistants' Union.

The Pillsbury Company plans to build a flour mill in Maracaibo, Venezuela. It is the company's first capital investment outside of the North American continent, Paul S. Gerot, president, told stockholders in making the announcement at the ninetieth annual meeting in Minneapolis yesterday. The cost will be $2,000,000 to $2,500,000.

Stocks made the second widest one-day break yesterday since last November and the widest since Aug. 10. The New York Times average of twenty-five rail stocks hit a new 1959 low. Market values on the New York Stock Exchange shrank 1.4 per cent, or about $4,500,000,000.
EDISON, N. J., Sept. 8 -- An estimated total of 10,000 persons attended the official opening of Bamberger's department store at the Menlo Park Shopping Center here this morning.

Mississippi is planning the sale of bond issues totaling $12,000,000 on Sept. 30. One issue will consist of $5,000,000 of highway revenue obligations dated Aug. 1, 1959, and due serially on Feb. and Aug. 1 from 1963 to 1979. The remaining $7,000,000 will be bridge revenue bonds dated Oct. 1, 1959, and due either on Oct. 1, 1999, or, optionally, on April 1 and Oct. 1 from 1961 to 1999.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- A new French film with heavy doses of sex and adultery was postponed this evening just before its scheduled premiere showing to a select audience in a movie house on the Avenue des Champs Elysees.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

United States universities involved in the student exchange program with the Soviet Union have sent a virtual ultimatum to Moscow implying an end to the exchanges if Russian treatment of American students in that country does not improve radically.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7 -- The possibility that the Matson Navigation Company planned to dispose of a large segment of its assets was disclosed today by Randolph Sevier, its president.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A strike against the Prudential Insurance Company of America was postponed early today, pending a vote by more than 10,000 agents on a new contract.
ALBANY, Sept. 8 -- A permanent research agency to assist members of the Legislature has been recommended by leading Republican lawmakers.
A bench warrant was issued yesterday for the arrest of a Wall Street banker who failed to appear in court for pleading.

MOSCOW, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Nicholas Petrulli of Valley Stream, L. I., said today that he had done a "stupid thing" in renouncing his United States citizenship in hopes of becoming a Soviet citizen. He said he wanted to come back to the United States.
A collection of eighteenth, nineteenth and twentieth century vermeil (gilded sterling silver) lent by Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower will go on view at Tiffany's today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 8 -- Storm, the thirty-nine-foot molded plywood sloop that sailed without a mainsail and, for that matter, without a main boom, was confirmed as the winner of the Vineyard Trophy in the Stamford Yacht Club's distance race today.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 8 -- The manager of a leading hotel here, a great mass of red brick in unabashed "beachfront baroque," furrowed his tanned brow and said the call for a general election would probably cost him "thousands of pounds."
Your lead editorial of Aug. 26, "The Peace We Seek," expresses American foreign policy in its weakness and its strength.

All sixteen families, consisting of fifty-two persons, in a firetrap tenement at 21 Monroe Street on the lower East Side were evacuated from the building yesterday by order of Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.
The business recovery, an expansion and improvement program and higher profit margins paid off for the Keystone Steel and Wire Company of Peoria, Ill., in the fiscal year ended on June 30.
The American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical and Petroleum Engineers has announced the election of Dr. Joseph L. Gillson as president for 1960.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., Sept. 8 -- Now that the summer nonsense is officially over, the hardened salt-water addicts of this shore can settle down to some good, steady, undistracted fishing. Some of them were doing it today with pretty good effect.

Atomic Development Mutual Fund, Inc., reported yesterday net assets of $62,663,938, equal to $5.69 a share of 10,993,718 shares outstanding on June 30. This compared with $51,387,042 or $4.61 a share on 11,138,327 shares outstanding a year earlier.

A movement in American agriculture, spreading to every state, is the so-called bracero program. This is the practice of using Mexican nationals as laborers on farms for periods of up to one year, by international agreement with Mexico. About 500,000, of these men are now employed throughout the nation under this "emergency" program begun in 1942.
Two new Kings County grand juries were urged yesterday to be cautious about recommending youthful-offender treatment for teen-agers they indicted.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Two packinghouse workers unions today rejected as "a bad bargain" a new offer by Swift Co. to settle a strike of 17,000 employes in thirty-four cities.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The logjam of judicial nominations in the Senate Judiciary Committee began easing today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Not a single Negro has been able to register or vote because of the Civil Rights Act of 1957.
Many smokers of non-thinking men's butts have been having a grand time picking their favorite brands out of the city's new public ash trays.
Footprint identification will be mandatory for all babies born in hospitals here beginning Oct. 1.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- Premier Michel Debre confirmed today before the Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committees of the National Assembly that President Eisenhower had given no commitment for United States support for France on the Algerian question.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -President Eisenhower will report on his European tour in a radio-television address Thursday night.

On a recent visit to her home state of Louisiana, Mary Drayton, the actress-turned-play-wright, was struck by what was happening to people of the small Southern community over the question of school integration. She found that friends of long standing and members of the same family were breaking apart.
National Bellas Hess, Inc., mail order concern, announced yesterday that it would ask its stockholders to authorize an increase in common stock to 4,000,000 shares at a special meeting on Sept. 29.
THE last invasion by the Western clubs begins at the Stadium tonight as the Yankees prepare to clinch their twenty-fifth pennant in -- whoa! Who has been monkeying with the script?

The United Nations Security Council equipped itself with added muscle when it overcame a Soviet obstruction that has so often paralyzed it in the past. In a dramatic midnight session yesterday the Council voted ten to one to respond to Laos' appeal for help against Communist aggression by appointing a subcommittee of its own members to inquire into the situation.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 8 -- A strike by 900 union electricians halted work today on $200,000,000 worth of projects in Bergen and Hudson Counties.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 8 -- Down here in this once-mighty bastion of the block, the tackle and the touchdown, Tom Nugent is practicing some of his magic to restore Maryland to the football elite.

THE world could never be too much with Judah Cahn. He sees it as a political and sociological, as well as a religious, challenge to any rabbi worth his salt. When he was preparing for the rabbinate, he decided that a man who was going to lead people and evaluate events should have a background in all three fields, and acquired it.
A 67-year-old woman was charged with homicide yesterday after the police said she had unleashed a powerful dog on three boys on a Bronx roof, causing one to die from a six-story fall.
Bernard Newman, New York County Republican leader, told a group of party officials yesterday that the Republicans were off to a running start for the 1961 Mayoral election.

THE housecleaners are busy at work these days, getting things in shape for the imminent arrival of the members of baseball's exclusive Twenty-Game Club. There probably won't be more than a half-dozen pitchers qualifying for admission, the elite of their craft. The super-elite of the Thirty-Game Club disappeared with Dizzy Dean in 1934 and now seem as extinct as the dinosaur.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The board of directors of the National Baptist Convention commended Little Rock, Ark., today "for the constructive things it has achieved" in the fight to end racial segregation in the schools.
Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., has switched from Channel 7 to Channel 2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Earl W. Kintner, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today the commission was conducting a "vigorous" campaign against discriminatory advertising allowances to favored customers.
Schools of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will enroll 215,800 pupils when the 1959-60 year opens Monday, Msgr. John Paul Haverty, the superintendent, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Railroad officials testified today that a proposal, for government regulation of railroad maintenance cars would lead to more featherbedding without adding to employes' safety. Featherbedding is the use of more workers than a job requires.

Herbert H. Lehman told a Greenwich Village Democratic rally last night that the party could not hope to win a top city or state office until Carmine G. De Sapio was dethroned as the leader of Tammany Hall.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Four of the five corn futures contracts closed at new lows for the season on the Board of Trade today as the market turned weak.

Bubbling with enthusiasm over their experiences as amateur diplomats, the models who participated in this summer's American National Exhibition in Moscow returned to the United States yesterday.
A strike against the seven boats of the Sixty-ninth Street Brooklyn Ferry threatened for midnight last night has been averted temporarily.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Hugh Gaitskell said today that Nikita S. Khrushchev had indicated to him that the Soviet Union might be ready to accept a British Labor party formula for settling the Berlin issue.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Engineers at Deere Co. this week introduced a ten-ton farm tractor.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -The report of today's livestock marketshere by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad raised $3,150,000 yesterday through the sale of equipment certificates to finance the purchase of 500 steel hopper cars.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Quebec Lithium Corporation has filed a $4,500,000 breach of contract suit in United States District Court here against Lithium Corporation of America.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Prices continued their advance on the stock market here today, although the demand was more selective than on Tuesday. Gains, generally a shilling (14 cents) or less, were interspersed with a sprinkling of minor declines on profit-taking.
Arnold Constable announced yesterday that it had signed a lease for a branch store in the Essex Green Shopping Center in West Orange, N. J.
DETROIT, Sept. 9 (AP) -Negotiators conferred around the clock today in an effort to end a pressmen's strike that has halted publication of the city's three daily newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- The streaking Chicago White Sox took advantage of three Washington errors in the seventh inning to score four runs tonight and beat the Senators, 5 -- 1, behind Bob Shaw's seven-hit pitching.

Directors of the Commonwealth Edison Company declared yesterday a 2 1 3 per cent stock dividend -- seven shares for every 300 held on Sept. 23 -- on the common stock, in addition to the quarterly cash dividend of 50 cents a share.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., Sept. 9 -- Attendance by white students rose substantially on the second day of integrated classes at the Warren County High School.
PARIS, Sept. 9 -- President Charles de Gaulle will address the French nation by radio and television Wednesday on Algeria's future.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Square D Company, manufacturer of electrical equipment announced today that it would establish its corporate offices in the Chicago area by next summer. The company's headquarters have been in Detroit since it was founded in 1903.
The Bank of Montreal, now observing its hundredth anniversary in New York City, will move its New York Agency from 64 Wall Street to 2 Wall Street next Monday.
The city is planning an elaborate welcome for two royal figures from the Netherlands.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Prompt and continued Senate investigation into the outbreaks of crimes by teen-agers in New York was urged today by Representative Seymour Halpern. Republican of Forest Hills.

MIDORI is a young Nisei with the face and figure of a Japanese doll. Asked her age she blushes prettily and admits to being "between 24 and 30." This is not a vast store of years, but in them Midori has crammed a stint in Seventh Avenue design rooms and a feeling and sensitivity for beautiful clothes.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Bobby Avila's bases-loaded home run with one out in the ninth inning lifted the Milwaukee Braves to a 5-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 9 -- The heads of the two largest commercial banks on Long Island charged yesterday that the State Banking Department and legislative leaders were following the dictates of the largest bank in New York City in seeking a revision of the state banking law.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives unanimously passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to curb the use of the Virgin Islands as a tax haven.

THE Museum of Modern Art has made a stunning exhibit out of items that most families cannot wait to throw away. The subject is packages, and these range from a toothpaste tube to a cardboard house.

Soviet maps of the Chinese-Indian border follow the Chinese rather than the Indian version. As a result, thousands of square miles claimed by India are shown in Soviet maps as belonging to Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Henry J. Friendly of New York was confirmed by the Senate today as a Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which covers New York, Connecticut and Vermont.

" The Best of Everything," a romantic comedy about young women who find their fortunes in New York, has been selected as the official motion-picture presentation of New York City's Henry Hudson festival. The announcement was made yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 9 -- Five young women I made their initial bows to society tonight at two parties on the North Shore. They will take part in the holiday dances in town during the recess of their various colleges and schools. All the debutantes were graduated in June from preparatory courses.
A garden of flower prints is one of the themes of the new fabric collection at Arthur H. Lee, 501 Madison Avenue.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 9 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru is expected to reject Premier Chou En-lai's reply yesterday to his protest against Chinese encroachments along India's northern frontiers.

NO less than the entire American Airlines passenger terminal, now approaching completion at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, is the subject of the exhibition, "Art in Architecture," opening today at the I. B. M. Gallery, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street.

A distinguished group of experts on labor-management relations, meeting at Arden House two days before the steel deadlock began last May, warned that appeals by Government officials for restraint and responsibility in collective bargaining seldom accomplished much.
CAPE CANAVERAL. Fla., Sept. 9 -- A test version of the space capsule slated to carry an American astronaut into orbit was safely rocketed more than 1,500 miles into the Caribbean today.

DOVER, Del., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Delaware's public school system mixed white and Negroes officially today in first-grade classrooms. The Federal-ordered integration was peaceful, but many parents grumbled.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Stratford remained undefeated in defense of the women's softball title tonight with a 2-0 victory over Portland, Ore., in thirteen innings.

The high rate of auto production and the general economic recovery contributed to sharp gains in sales and earnings of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for the nine months that ended on July 31. The results set a record for the period.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- The House passed a bill today allowing Hawaii and Alaska to share equally with the forty-eight other states in discretionary funds under the Federal airport aid program.

TORONTO, Sept. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's first large nuclear power station will be built on the shore of Lake Huron, nine miles north of Kincardine, Ont., it was announced today by James S. Duncan, chairman of the Ontario Hydro-Electric Power Commission.

OTTAWA, Sept. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Canada rolled up a trade deficit of $459,800,000 in the first seven months of the year more than datable the level of a year before as import trade expanded at a rate of 10 per cent.

The Battle of Gettysburg is the subject of two books that will be issued a week apart next month. Chilton Company of Philadelphia will publish on Oct. 1 "The Shaping of a Battle: Gettysburg," by James Stuart Montgomery.
In steaming heat and rain, Victor Seixas was beaten in the tennis championship of the United States at Forest Hills yesterday after winning the first two sets from Bernard (Tut) Bartzen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- J. Vincent Burke Jr. of Pittsburgh was confirmed by the Senate today as general counsel of the Defense Department.

BOB BUGNAND is out to replace the suit. This youthful French designer, whose third collection to date was shown yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel, introduces tiny, tea cosy-shaped capes for fall. Brief, carved affairs that end at the elbow, these capes go over small-waisted, bell-skirted dresses for a look that is as fresh and round as a little apple.

Directors of Keystone Custodian Funds, Inc., voted yesterday a 200 per cent stock dividend on the common shares of the $485,000,000 mutual fund management company. Commission house profit-taking and trade buying resulted in mixed world sugar prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Predominantly reduced prices were termed a technical reaction to recent highs.

The nation's supply of gasoline fell 1,573,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies dipped seasonally to 181,509,000 barrels from 183,082,000 a week earlier.
In Greenwich Village the stakes are high in this year's Democratic primary election.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 10 -A theatrical training school will be established here to develop new talent for all branches of the professional theatre.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Roger Craig pitched a three-hitter tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers shut out the Philadelphia Phillies for the second straight night, 5 to 0.

TRENTON, Sept. 10 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner plans to name Raymond F. Male State Commissioner of Labor and Industry. Mr. Male, president of the State Civil Service Commission, would succeed Carl Holderman, who died May 20.
Reports of crop damage in Idaho and the Red River Valley triggered active buying of potato futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- A friendly unofficial visitor from an officially unfriendly country arrived in Britain tonight.

Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, and Luis Ayala of Chile gained the two remaining men's quarter-final berths in the tennis championship of the United States at Forest Hills yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Total crop production less than 1 per cent below last year's outstanding record now seems likely for this year, the Department of Agriculture said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The United States endorsed today the Dalai Lama's appeal to the United Nations for a hearing of his charges that Communist China had invaded and mistreated Tibet.

The New York State Harness Racing Commission disclosed yesterday that a "large amount" of procaine had been found in Speedy Pick after the 6-year-old gelding's victory in the $50,000 National Pacing Derby at Roosevelt Raceway last Friday night.

OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- The interest rate of the Bank of Canada increased today to 6.05 per cent from 5.89 last week with the sale of $100,000,000 in ninety-one-day Treasury bills.

In his talk to the nation last evening President Eisenhower described again his reasons for inviting Premier Khrushchev to visit the United States and called upon him to bring some constructive ideas with him. The Port of New York last month continued its march toward what promises to be its best year for customs revenues, according to statistics released yesterday by Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers vaulted to within a halfgame of first place -- and smashed the amazing winning streak of Elroy Face in the process -- as they swept a doubleheader from the Pittsburgh Pirates before 48,526 tonight. The score were 5 -- 4 and 4 -- 0.
DALLAS, Sept. 11 (UPI) -Bo Wininger rolled home in subpar fashion and tied Bob Rosburg for the opening-round lead of the $25,000 Dallas open golf tournament today with a 3-under-par 67.

Caleb Boggs of Delaware, chairman of the Governors' Conference, after the President had opened the door for such a meeting.

WASECA, Minn., Sept. 11 (UPI) -- A mother and her six children were killed today when a freight train smashed into their school-bound station wagon. It was the nation's third such tragedy in two days and raised the combined death toll to fifteen.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., has proposed thirty-six employes as stockholders, it was announced yesterday. The company, formerly a partnership, became a corporation in January of this year.

Stocks staged a general rally yesterday that wiped out about a third of the losses recorded earlier in the week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI). -- Congress completed action today on a bill liberalizing immigration laws to make it easier for aliens to join close relatives in this country. The bill was backed by the Administration.

"Doctor Purgatory," by Jan Marks, M. D., is an account of how the author became a narcotics addict and eventually freed himself. Dr. Marks discloses the degradation the addict endures and indicts the various "cures" now in effect.

WINNIPEG, Man.. Sept. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The suspension of a trainer at the Assiniboia Downs race track resulted from his use of a liniment sold at the track drugstore by the track veterinarian, the veterinarian said today.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 12 -- Dr. Mason W. Gross, president of Rutgers University, charged tonight that New Jersey was educationally "impoverished'' and culturally "almost bankrupt."
IT is not always easy to love lgor Stravinsky the man, but it is impossible to ignore Igor Stravinsky the musician.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The United States has decided that newsmen from East Germany, Communist China, North Korea, North Vietnam and Albania will be denied visas to come here to cover the visit of Preimer Nikita S. Khrushchev.

ONE of the most rewarding literary developments of the last eight years has been the discovery, through belated translations, of the lovely wealth of contemporary Greek writing. It began with the late Nikos Kazantzakis' ebullient "Zorba the Greek," his broodingly tragic "The Greek Passion" and, finally, the widely acclaimed "Odyssey: A Modern Sequel." We have had, also, the lyric beauty of Ilias Venezis' "Beyond the Aegean."
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa. (Science Service) -- An antiseptic paint may soon be available for the home gardener's wounded trees.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 12 -- Spyros P. Skouras, head of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, is a principal figure in fierce competition to run a commercial television service in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
ANCON, Peru, Aug. 30 -- The cosmic chatter of man-made earth satellites fills the desert observation post here with an eerie monotone of radio beeps.

BEDFORD, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- A dinner dance was given in the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club this evening to honor four debutantes, the Misses Annie Hegeler Botzow, Diana Ferguson Chapman, Letitia Darlington and Hester Huguley.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 12 -Rising economic nationalism caused a dispute at the annual assembly of the National Chamber of Commerce which ended here today. As a result the organization's largest chapter, the Mexico City Chamber of Commerce, walked out of the meeting.
Maurice Mogulescu makes his living from other peoples' places of business.

NO truer statement about books was ever made than Robert Pitman's observation: "It is the books we read before middle life that do most to mold our characters and influence our lives." That is why the matter of teen-age reading is of such critical importance in the United States today,
Union and management negotiators in the national steel strike held their first Saturday meeting yesterday since the walkout started July 15.

THIS autobiography could be many a man's life. The hero grew up in Brooklyn, went through high school, then City College, where he became a member, then captain of the wrestling team, took postgraduate work at Columbia University, became a teacher in the history department at City College, met a young woman, fell in love, was married and had a daughter.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Although dedicated to a minimum of official interference in private business, the Government was obliged today to impose price or profit ceilings on a wide variety of consumer goods.
The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York voiced "concern'' yesterday over the visit of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, which is to begin Tuesday.
WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Sept. 12 -- A nine-day celebration marking the hundredth anniversary of the founding of Weehawken started this afternoon.

AT the end of her book, Marchette Chute writes, "George Herbert and Robert Herrick were both somewhat alien to their own century. They were gentle men in an age that was not gentle, and they refused to interfere with their neighbors at a time when interference was almost a duty.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Sept. 12 -- In this area, the Air Force Academy has become a greater tourist attraction than Pike's Peak.

POETRY is "a magic thing and has more keys than doors," quotes Gerald D. McDonald, and his collection of poems for boys is proof The compiler, chief of the American History Division of the New York Public Library, has collected familiar poems and many not previously labeled "for boys."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Early in this century Europe's lovely, leisurely Danube, celebrated in poetry and melody, was harnessed as a working river. Present indications are that its busiest era lies directly ahead, with its potential as a producer of electric power barely tapped as yet.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 9 -- Tires and toasters, refrigerators and roasters are back in the shop windows of Istanbul.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Wisconsin, Purdue and Ohio State stand out today as the prospective leaders of the Big Ten football race that soon will get under way.

The first jet liner capable of regular nonstop service between New York and London will go into operation Nov. 23. Charles S. Thomas, president of Trans World Airlines, made the announcement last week.

Strontium 90 from nuclear bomb tests is now being deposited in the bones of every human being on earth. This radioactive element damages the bones and bone marrow in such a way as to cause bone cancer and leukemia, and perhaps also other diseases.

A favorite theme of articles in the Soviet press by Soviet citizens who have been to the United States is the misconceptions, and sometimes elementary ignorance, they say ordinary Americans have about their country.

PARIS, Sept. 12 -- President Charles de Gaulle faces next week what may be the most crucial period of his fifteen months in power in France. On Wednesday he is scheduled to go before microphones and television cameras to tell France and the world his plans for bringing peace to Algeria after almost five years of nationalist rebellion and costly repression in the North African territory.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Sept. 12 -- Publicly scorned, misunderstood yet proud of some firstclass achievements of the Navy's Project Vanguard is about to fire its last satellite vehicle.
In the search for quantity plus quality in education, small city school systems are keeping up with metropolitan areas. News from many parts of the country illustrates significant progress.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Sept. 12 -- The mixed-pairs championship in the New York-New Jersey regional tournament here was won early this morning by Mrs. Janice Stone of New York and Andrew Gabrilovitch of Washington, with 396 1/2 match points.
HONG KONG, Sept. 12 -India was the target for a crescendo of attacks in Peiping today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- The images of world events that are assiduously and extravagantly projected for the Soviet public on the widest possible screen and in the most stereophonic of sounds are even sharper this week than usual..

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 12 -Enrolled voters in Nassau County's political parties will vote in the primary Tuesday to select candidates for forty state, county, town and city offices in the November elections.

Every voter in the state of New York will have something to say next November as to whether the children of the City of New York shall have safe and adequate school buildings in the years to come. This is the meaning of the proposed $500 million school bond issue which the City Planning Commission discusses in a letter to Mayor Wagner released today.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 12 -- The Iceland public appears to be satisfied over the reaction in Washington to Ambassador Thor Thors' protest yesterday about incidents involving United States troops here.

TWO Bellport, L. I., gardeners -- Barbara M. Capen and Mrs. Mary Louise McChesney -- succeed in capturing the vivid colors of late summer in their dried flower arrangements. Working as a team for the past three years, they have created many glowing designs.

Traders returned from their Labor Day holiday last week with no change of heart about the stock market. Selling pressure was renewed as stocks recorded the second widest break of the year. Prices were pushed back to June levels in the second successive weekly decline. Several reasons were offered for the market's action.

KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Sept. 12 (AP) -- The International Association of Governmental Labor Officials recommended today that the Federal minimum wage be raised from $1 to $1.25 an hour.

TEN - YEAR - OLD Mike, his friend Mud and Murgatroyd, a pet frog. find themselves accidental stowaways on the rocket ship bearing Mike's father and his co-pilot to a space sta tion where they will board a spaceship for the moon. Instead of being promptly returned from the space station, the trio are allowed to continue the trip to the moon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A new plan for allocating votes at the 1960 Democratic National Convention was offered today by Paul M. Butler, National Committee Chairman.

CHICAGO (Science Service) -- The demand for general practitioners "has been largely ignored by some of our medical schools," the former president of the American Academy of General Practice charged here.

Assistant Secretary of State Parsons, in charge of Far Eastern affairs, gave us a splendid phrase in an interview last week. He spoke of the blasts that are coming out of Hanoi, Peiping and Moscow as "orchestrated" propaganda. The whole story is told, to those who have sensitive ears, in those words.

EMMAUS, Pa., Sept. 12 -- S. Edward Simon of Chatham, N. J., piloted his bloodhound, Ch. Black Tommy of Huguenot, to best-in-show laurels today at the Lehigh Valley Kennel Club's thirty-first annual event.

BRAHMS: Violin Concerto: Arthur Grumiaux and Concert-gebouw Orchestra conducted by Eduard van Beinum (Epic). A strong, musicianly performance of the oft-recorded score. What keeps it from rising to the heights is a rather sentimental slow movement, where Grumiaux is a little too sweet.

IN his lively and revealing introduction to "Yesterday's Children," John Morton Blum tells us that the first purpose of his anthology is "entertainment." He does not need to add that "putting it together was an entertaining task," for this fact is richly evident.
ROSENDALE, N. Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Seven New York City residents were injured, two seriously, in a two-car collision today on the New York Thruway south of Kingston.

The Eighty-sixth Congress convened last January for its first session in a mood of buoyant confidence. The Democrats had won big new majorities in both houses and they were committed to a program of economic expansion. Convinced that the lame-duck President could not assert his leadership in domestic affairs during his last two years in office, the Democrats moved quickly to take the lead in shaping national programs -- labor, housing, civil rights, agriculture.

OF all literary critics who might have been expected to see merit in Walt Whitman's first (1855) "Leaves of Grass," Charles Eliot Norton would seem most unlikely. The son of Prof. Andrews Norton, who denounced the transcendentalism of Emerson, his former student, as "infidelity," he was a true Cambridge Brahmin, educated at Harvard, heir of a gracious patrician home called "Shady Hill," intimate friend of the New England poets Longfellow.
The final break has occurred after long dissension in the $4,000,000,000a-year office equipment industry. It will become evident a week from Tuesday in Washington.

A careful reading of Arthur H. Richter's article, "Plan for Cut-Rate Ship Service," gives rise to certain misgivings. Just how much of a bargain will the prospective traveler on the $50 lines to Europe actually receive?

THE National Congress of Parents and Teachers has decided to review television programs with an eye to their suitability for youngsters and teen-agers. In its initial sortie into video criticism the mother organization bestows its blessings on "Captain Kangaroo" and Dick Clark, among others, and tidily demolishes "Mighty Mouse" and "Howdy Doody."

Much of the credit for the reopening of Little Rock's schools must go to the woman who led the resistance to the Faubusmen long before most men of the community found their voices. She is 76-year-old Mrs. Adolphine Terry, a gentlewoman of sparkling eyes and young spirit who lives in an ante-bellum house filled with Civil War portraits.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Bob Gibson, a rookie right-hander, fanned ten and limited the Cubs to six hits as he pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

PRINCESS BEATRIX of the Netherlands will plant the first tulip at Sterling Forest Gardens on Thursday. The gardens, which are now being created near Tuxedo, N. Y., will cover 125 acres in a setting of hills, meadows and woodland.

LATE September and all of October are an especially lovely period for touring to and into the picturesque wildness of Letchworth State Park in New York's western highlands where fifty-two years ago man and nature combined to organize one of the state's finest play areas.

Jimmie Dykes, the Detroit manager, yesterday reported a conversation he had with Casey Stengel Friday evening.

Prices of Douglas fir plywood skidded last week for the fourth time in two months. The reason, according to one industry spokesman, was simply "too much plywood." In the midst of this plenty and its consequences, plywood manufacturers are staging one of the biggest build-ups of new productive capacity in the industry's history.

Many of this year's college freshmen may feel like rush-hour subway riders: they barely managed to squeeze into the car as the doors were closing behind them. Actually, if they had looked farther down the platform, they might have found that the traffic jam was confined to a few doors -- the so-called "name colleges."

DETROIT -- A lively controversy in what promises to be a generally exciting automotive year was touched off recently when Ford showed its new small car, the Falcon, with a conventional front engine, at a closed circuit television press conference.

THROUGHOUT known history the area at present called the Middle East has been of great importance. The oldest civilizations of mankind and two of its great universal religions, Christianity and Islam, originated here.
A seven-state conference to expand local participation in the urban-renewal program was called last week by Walter S. Fried, regional administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency.

THIS account of a long and hazardous voyage in a small boat eastward from Australia through the Roaring Forties is different from many of its kind in point. The first difference is its greater intensity, and the second is an admiring foreword by the well-known novelist, Nevil Shute. Mr. Shute thinks that Miles Smeeton just about "charts the limits of the yachting sport." With this estimate most readers will agree.

A PROCESS of special photography and laboratory work that turns fantasy into realism has finally made it possible to bring to the screen Jonathan Swift's "Gulliver's Travels," without having to resort to animated drawings, cartoons or puppets.

Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands continued her genial conquest of New York yesterday. Although she did not have time to see many of the "regular Americans" whom she wanted to meet, many of them saw her.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Cantelo, a bay filly who was beaten as an odds-on favorite in a race Thursday, came back today to win the St. Leger Stakes in an upset that brought boos and jeers from many in a crowd of 100,000.
New York unveils its ultrafashionable model of thorough-bred racing tomorrow at the new Aqueduct, the sparkling many-hued creation with a $33,000,000 price tag.

Heavenly Body of the Cain Hoy Stable finished first by eight lengths in the $94,230 Matron Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. But her rider, Manuel Ycaza, had some trying moments before the result of the six-furlong test for 2-year-old fillies became official.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Britain's politicians are girding themselves, with a certain uneasiness, for the appeals they will make to the new television masses in the forthcoming election campaign.
City and Federal officials yesterday faced the prospect of not having a satisfactory place in which to entertain Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev at Mayor Wagner's luncheon on Thursday.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 12 -Thousands of miners demonstrated over a coal surplus crisis in the Ruhr mining cities of Essen and Gelsenkirchen today. They cheered a union leader's demand for nationalization of the industry.

IF he had been born in Iowa, he probably would have been "Nick" to his friends and neighbors. Doubtless he would have been a successful farmer and an active member of the Grange. It would not have been strange if he had taken part in local politics and perhaps won a seat in Congress.

Toy manufacturers are gearing their operations for a record year. As producers enter the period of heavy production to meet demand for Christmas playthings, industry leaders forecast a retail volume of about $1,650,000,000.

WHEN the Takarazuka Dance Theatre opens its eighteen-day engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday, under the management of Albert B. Gins, we shall be seeing the third type of Japanese dance company to visit this country since the war.

THE summer tourist season Is ending but resort areas in the northeastern states are carrying through with a number of varied events of interest to visitors during this month and next. The news this week from spokesmen for these regions is not fall foliage but house tours, antiques shows, anniversaries and the like.

THE International Folk Music Council has recently concluded its twelfth annual conference in Sinaia, a delightful resort town in the Carpathian Mountains and once the summer residence of Rumania's kings.
MADRID, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Two of Spain's leading matadors have been fined 25,000 pesetas (about $420) for bad behavior yesterday in the bull ring at Albagete, in southeastern Spain.
DALLAS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Julius Boros of Southern Pines. N. C., carded a four-under-par 66 today to move into first place at the halfway mark in the $25,000 Dallas open.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The British election campaign began this week with all the frenzied activity of a life and death struggle whereon the fate of the Kingdom hung.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 12 -A two-year delay in the construction of a new high school here has caused sessions to be staggered so that high school students arrive at four different times.

New light on the mystery of photosynthesis, one of nature's greatest riddles, is presented in the British scientific journal Nature by Prof. Daniel I. Arnon, plant physiologist of the University of California, at Berkeley.

Net earnings from operations of Knott Hotels Corporation this year should rise to $2 a share, from $1.32 a share in 1958, Willard E. Dodd, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts last week.

THE formal, repetitive rhythms and stylized movements produced by men at work have long been noted by artists, photographers, writers, composers, motion-picture makers, choreographers and even anthropologists. The latter have found innumerable examples of tribes whose daily labor has been sublimated into the rituals of the dance.

AFTER a Golden Age and a Silver Age, the art of bullfighting seems in danger of entering upon a Leaden Age. Luis Miguel Dominguin, the finest matador still fighting, declared recently that few Spaniards now know what they really see and feel at a corrida, but wait to be told next day on the radio or in the newspapers what they should have seen and felt
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 2 -- United States research into possible methods of game preservation in Rhodesia may lead to a plan to provide meat for the growing population of Africa.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The most favorable aspect of President Eisenhower's forthcoming meeting with Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev is that it has come at the peak of the President's career. He is firmly exercising the great powers of his office in both foreign and domestic affairs. To those who watched him closely on his recent trip abroad and since he came home, the President seems possessed of full vigor of body and mind.

FOR THIS WEEK: Decide on locations for hardy bulbs and make lists of varieties and quantities needed to estimate costs. . . .Be sure that the newly seeded lawn is kept most for proper germination. . . . ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 12 -- A 20-year-old girl from Natchez, Miss., Lynda Lee Mead, won the Miss America 1960 title here tonight. It was the second year in a row that a Mississippi girl was the winner.

THE twentieth annual Venice Film Festival, with fourteen films from ten countries being shown in competition, more than forty pictures from twenty-two countries screened out of the running, and a goodly number of movie classics seen in interesting retrospective shows, ground to a weary halt here last Sunday amid the approbation and dissent that characterize all such gatherings.

METAL wall tiles come in a wide variety of colors and finishes and can be easily installed by do-it-yourselfers wherever a highly decorative wall surface is desired. The slick, hard finish is exceptionally resistant to scratching and cracking, and the colors will not fade under normal home conditions. In addition, metal tiles will not support combustion and are unaffected by heat -- hence, they can be safely used around stoves, radiators and heater grilles.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 12 -- One thing that a fairly unsatisfactory sailing afternoon accomplished today was to reduce the number of unbeaten boats in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Race Week from five to none.

A fleet of thirty-three cruising yachts headed out of Eastchester Bay shortly before noon yesterday in the City Island Yacht. Club's twenty-fourth annual overnight race. This is a round trip of seventy miles which has Stratford Shoal as the turning point.

A proper copy of the official flag of the Borough of Queens was issued today by the Queens Chamber of Commerce to acquaint the borough's citizens, and especailly its 315,000 pupils, with the history and design of the flag and to sustain community spirit.

FOR vacationists whose aversion to the seasonal rush is equaled only by their aversion to seasonal rates, September is a fine time to take a holiday. Most summer resorts offer handsome reductions to Visitors who come after Labor Day and most winter resorts still have their low summer rates in effect.

NORWICH, Conn., Sept. 12 -- The fate of a proposed $1,593,000 urban renewal project here will be determined at a referendum Tuesday. The vote will decide whether the city will float a $400,000 bond issue to provide the municipality's share in the project.

PALERMO, Sicily -- This big, sprawling, outdoor museum of an island off the toe of Italy is surely the most piquant and neglected of Mediterranean islands. The coastline is enchanting, even breath-taking on occasion, the archaeology approaches the unbelievable and the high cost of tourist living has not yet reached the place.

HARTFORD, Sept 12 -- The ratio of Negro students who left school in Connecticut before graduation is 60 per cent higher than that of white students, the State Commission on Civil Rights reported this week.

The Giants defeated the Phillies, 9 -- 1, at San Francisco yesterday and increased their National League lead to one game. Sam Jones hurled his twentieth victory for the Giants. Lew Burdette of the Braves kept pace with Jones by downing the Reds, 4 -- 3, as Milwaukee tied the idle Dodgers for second place. In the American League, the White Sox defeated the Orioles, 6 -- 1, with Early Wynn posting victory No. 20.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- In 1921 when military pilots flew by luck and the seat of their pants, there was a major crackup for every 197 hours in the air.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 12 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that India's dispute with Communist China involved a "much more serious" question than that of petty border incursions.

Like a family breadwinner who must resort to a personal loan because of increasing drains on his bank account, the nation's banks are being forced to increase their borrowings from the Federal Reserve Banks.
Prices of fresh Florida citrus fruits are expected to be "more attractive" to the consumer from now on. The quality of the fruit also will be better and there probably will be more of it.
TRENTON, Spet. 12 -- Wesley L. Lance, president of the State Senate, warned today that tax relief would in no way help to solve the problem of keeping commuter railroad services in operation.

A SWISS baker first had the clever notion of beating egg whites and sugar together, then baking the white fluff that resulted His name was Gasparini, he lived in the eighteenth century, his tiny village was Mehrinyghen and the delicate confection he invented was meringue. This basically simple preparation has been important in baking ever since.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- Year after year for almost ten years, according to a current first-grade arithmetic book, little Annie has been going to the store with 50 francs in hand to buy three buttons at 12 francs each. For just as long, Annie's 6-year-old fellow-citizens have had to discover how much change she received.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- The Chicago White Sox will start taking applications for world series tickets on Monday, Bill Veeck, the club president, said today.

The coastline is enchanting, even breath-taking on occasion, the archaeology approaches the unbelievable and the high cost of tourist living has not yet reached the place.

Lew Burdette of the Braves kept pace with Jones by downing the Reds, 4 -- 3, as Milwaukee tied the idle Dodgers for second place. In the American League, the White Sox defeated the Orioles, 6 -- 1, with Early Wynn posting victory No. 20.
