Little Rock, Ark., Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Arkansas Supreme Court today canceled a state law designed to hamper the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 14 -- Members of the Amalgamated Lithographers of America heard a new program outlined today for their union from their president, who has announced his plans to retire. They also heard praise for their democratic proceedure from Gov. Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon.
PARIS, Sept. 14 -- Senegal and French Sudan, two autonomous African republics in the French Community, have informed President Charles de Gaulle that they wish to become fully independent.
Huge quantities of West Virginia coal for fueling electric utilities in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania soon may reach them through a pipeline.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 14 -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Whippoorwill, who won the last two championships, took a three-stroke lead in the first round of the twenty-six Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy golf tournament today. She carded 37, 38 -- 75, one over par for each half, at the Innis Arden Golf Club.
HOUSTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A Massachusetts skipper piloted his sloop to victory in an almost nonexistent wind today in the first race of the Mallory Cup national small-boat sailing championships.

For all of its $33,000,000 finery, New Aqueduct had a run-of-the-turnstile opening-day crowd yesterday -- some well-heeled, some down at the heels, some gorgeous, some plain and many, no doubt, who should have been at work in factory, home or office.
HUNTSVILLE, Ala, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. John B. Medaris said today that the United States could not now match the Soviet moon shot.
IN the last event of the big regional tournament held at Asbury Park over the last week-end, a favorite team finally won.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The first Russians to come here in connection with the visit of Premier Khrushchev have been ordering Scotch whiskey, not vodka; ice cream, not caviar; steak, not beef Stroganoff.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14 -- A tasteless, harmless, seaweed cocktail that had prevented peptic ulcers in experiments was described here today to the American Chemical Society.
The steel industry's chief negotiator denied yesterday that management was "out to break" the striking United Steelworkers of America.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The labor reform bill, signed by President Eisenhower today, contains in substance many of the President's proposals.
Mrs. Margaret du Pont of Wilmington, Del., and Neale Fraser of Australia won the mixed doubles championship of the United States for the second successive time yesterday at Forest Hills, Queens.

A story of Machiavellian tricks, big business rivalries and underworld pressures was unfolded yesterday as the New York State Athletic Commission opened its investigation into the Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson world heavyweight title fight of last June 20.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson introduced today a "work now -- pay later" program to provide loans for college students.

The Colgate-Palmolive Company is considering changes for three television shows it sponsors on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network. They are "The Big Pay-Off," "The Millionaire" and "Top Dollar."

A look at the past winter season's records of a small segment of the nation's millions of women bowlers showed that, within this group at least, notable improvement over the previous season was achieved by only about 16 per cent of the bowlers.
YONKERS, Sept. 14 -- Seven hundred parents won a campaign today to have the Westchester County Parkway Authority reopen a school crossing on the busy Cross County Parkway here at Seminary Hill.
Staten Island will have just one primary battle today for a public office -- the Republican nomination for district attorney.
Seven hundred young men at Columbia College will don light blue freshman beanies today, each cap emblazoned in white with "'63."
The nation's privately owned shipyards gained a slight respite last month from the downward trend in shipbuilding orders that has prevailed for the last three years.

Since the young women who will be honored at the Debutante Ball of the New York Junior League on Nov. 25 will not be in town again as a group until the day of the ball, they will rehearse the presentation ceremony this afternoon.

BONN, Germany Sept. 14 -- The West German Government has told the United Arab Republic that it will adhere to its policy of breaking relations with any country that establishes formal ties with Communist East Germany.
BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Sept. 14 -- John Krumbiegel, 11 years old, is counting on the serenity of an Iowa farm to make his wish come true.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The Soviet Government called tonight for an international conference to consider the situation in Laos.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 -- George Meany asserted today that three-quarters of the Southern Democrats in Congress were "more reactionary" than any Republican.
The decline in United States Government securities continued an at an accelerated pace yesterday as Treasury bonds continued to be offered in from light to moderate volume, with few takers.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 15 -- Premier Khrushchev left Moscow this morning on his first visit to the United States. It will last almost two weeks.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- Premier Khrushchev's address is expected to be the outstanding event of the 1959 session of the General Assembly, which will open tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 -- The head of the world's largest Zionist organization declared today that Israel and Jewish communities the world over were "distinct and separate entities." And, she said, there must be no Zionist interference in Israel's political life.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed today a bill designed to bring the Custom Bureau's definition of art up to date.

CLAYTON, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- Everywhere the visiting dude looks around this town, a large torpedo-like fish seems to be hanging on a wall and staring viciously at nothing in particular. These are notable muskellunge, caught in the St. Lawrence near here in former years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Average wholesale prices at the primary market level rose 0.2 per cent to 119.5 per cent of their 1947-49 base during the week ended Tuesday, Sept. 8, 1959, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
GENEVA, Sept. 14 (Reuters) -- Cancer specialists have concluded that the transplanting of human bone marrow can arrest the spread of leukemia, and, perhaps, stabilize the blood disease.
BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Boston hammered White Sox pitching today in a crushing 9-3 victory that slowed the Chicago march toward the American League pennant.
Shortly after launching a moon rocket Saturday, the Soviet Union sent information on its weights and radio frequencies to the World Warning Center at Fort Belvoir, Va.

WOMEN who have been clapping their hands over the return of the waistline and the bosom will be taken aback by the custom-made fall collection at Hattie Carnegie. These are not the clothes for those who proclaim their feminine assets to the sound of trumpets. They are intended for those who understand, appreciate and can afford true elegance.

BERLIN, Sept. 14 -- Someone protested the other day that it was a waste of money sending brochures and posters to New Zealand to advertise the Berlin Festival of the Arts, whereupon its managing director, Gerhart von Westerman, snapped:
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker said today that man had an unlimited opportunity to spread peace and humanity through the development of commercial travel through space.

Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's arrival in the United States today represents a new turn in the tangled course of relations between the Soviet Union and this country since the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917.
HAVANA, Sept. 14 -- The former Camp Columbia, the Army headquarters now known as Camp Libertad, was turned over to the Ministry of Education today for an educational center.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A Los Angeles civic-host committee will make a $100,000 down payment on its contract with the Democratic National Committe for the 1960 Democratic convention.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept 14 (AP) -- Harvey Gaylord, president of the Bell Helicopter Corporation, Fort Worth, Tex., has been elected president of the Bell Aircraft Corporation, effective tomorrow, it was announced today.

Two pieces that appeared in the financial pages over the week-end, when considered together, point up the weakness of the widely heard charge that the Federal Reserve Board is the villain behind the recent general rise in interest rates.

" The Bashful Genius" refuses to go unnoticed. First heard of in 1955, the Harold Callen comedy, based on the courtship of George Bernard Shaw and Charlotte Payne-Townshend, originally was held by Rita Allen and later by the Theatre Guild. Both found the play a difficult one to cast.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Administration plans to bring Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen home from the Philippines and use him as an adviser on Soviet policy, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- This is the eve of the big game of the year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- President Eisenhower signed the labor-reform bill today and the Labor Department announced that it had set up a bureau to administer it.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- Mount Vernon's bird-man left today with his pancake flappers and other noisemakers. Now, only starlings disturb the evening quiet in Chester Park and Kingsbridge Gardens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Certain passages in the speech Vice President Nixon made in New York today to the American Dental Association, and the President's assignment of Ambassador Lodge as Premier Khrushchev's official escort around the United States, strongly imply that the Administration plans to challenge him on the spot if and whenever he repeats here some statements he has made on controversial issues between the Communist and non-Communist nations.
The first installed completely automatic electronic bank bookkeeping system was shown in operation yesterday by the General Electric Company.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 14 -- India's Ministry of External Affairs reacted sharply today to anti-Indian charges placed before the Standing Committee of the Chinese National People's Congress at a meeting in Peiping last week.
Roger Baldwin, chairman of the International League for the Rights of Man, urged yesterday that the United States grant the Okinawans more self-government and broader contact with Japan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- On the eve of Premier Khrushchev's arrival, State Department officials made it clear today that there was no intention of satisfying his requests for United States credits and the removal of present restrictions on Soviet-United States trade.

MONZA, Italy, Sept. 14 -- When Stirling Moss' Cooper won the Grand Prix of Italy here yesterday it clinched the grand prix auto manufacturers' championship for the Cooper factory, which employs only twenty-five men and is almost as small as the Coopers themselves.

ALTHOUGH Harold Altman is only 35 years old, he has already established his reputation as a distinguished draftsman. He is, in fact, one of two draftsmen from the United States chosen for the first Biennial in Paris in October.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Sept. 14 -- A group of academicians on a pilgrimage today to this island paid tribute to the memory of Maria Mitchell, Nantucket astronomer of a century ago. She was the first woman to be elected an academy fellow.
News that the Government would open negotiations for a revision of the wool tariff quota system touched off selling of wool futures on the New York Cotton Exchange.

A group of Israeli performers scheduled to open next week at the Radio City Music Hall will be excused from appearing on the Jewish High Holidays. This was announced yesterday by Russell Downing, managing director of the theatre.
A spokesman for the steel scrap industry said yesterday that railroad freight rates on iron and steel scrap were "discriminating" against scrap dealers while favoring imported iron ore.
ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Police scuffled with a group of jeering pickets outside the plant of Ithaca Textiles, Inc., today.

The Citizens Budget Commission has now published as a public service a new edition of its small but fact-packed pamphlet, "Pocket Summary of New York City Finances." More than two billion dollars will be invested in Italian industry by the end of 1962 by the Industrial Reconstruction Institute, Aldo Frascetti, president, disclosed yesterday.
The teaching of theology in Jesuit colleges was criticized yesterday as ineffective and outmoded by a Jesuit educator, the Rev. John L. McKenzie.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The General Services Administration announced today a plan to dispose of 470,000 long tons of natural rubber from the national stockpile over the next nine years.

The high cost of money came home yesterday -- with interest -- to Canadians with the announcement of the new terms on Government bonds. The issues, totaling $550,000,000, will yield about 6 1/2 per cent and will be used to refund an equal amount of bonds maturing on Oct. 1.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Truman Clevenger tossed a four-hit shutout and Jim Lemon socked his twenty-second homer tonight as the Washington Senators whipped the Detroit Tigers, 5 -- 0.
The continuously growing popularity of ocean-going pleasure boating has given the Coast Guard an extremely busy time this summer.
Mounting community protests threatened yesterday to upset the timetable for construction of the proposed $100,000,000 West Side urban renewal project.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver said today that he was not running for the 1960 Democratic Presidential nomination.

M. at the Forum, Broadway and Firty-sixth Street, and the Baronet, Third Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Atlanta, Ga., postponed yesterday for an indefinite period a scheduled sale of $12,510,000 of bonds secured by general taxation. Bids were to have been received today. The unsettled condition of the bond market was the reason given for putting off the borrowing.

Record sales and earnings were achieved by the J. C. Penney Company in the six months that ended on July 31, the department store chain reported in its statment issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Court-appointed monitors accused James R. Hoffa today of three violations of a Federal court consent decree.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed today the bill to exempt radio and television newscasts from "equal time" demands of political candidates.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 -- Jim Brosnan, a burly right-hander who has been pushed around in the National League for a number of years, did a little pushing himself today. RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 12 -- Bolivia authorized two private Brazilian companies this week to start a search for petroleum in eastern Santa Cruz Province, thus reviving a once-forgotten treaty signed by the two nations more than twenty-one years ago.

The letter of Julius Hallheimer published on Sept. 5 on the subject of rent control and housing deterioration needs to be corrected. Mr. Hallheimer insists that slum conditions are produced by owners of property, "largely, if not solely." He also denies that residential rent control has contributed to these conditions.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 14 -- The rebel siege of Muong Son, in northern Laos, has been lifted in the last twenty-four hours, military sources reported here today.

PARIS, Sept. 14 -- Premier Khrushchev shocked British Labor party leaders during their recent meeting with his assessments of German reunification and "disengagements," according to reports reaching here from Eastern Europe.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Twelve surgeons, including Mother Anna Marie Dengel, superior general of the Medical Mission Sisters of Rome, will be made honorary fellows of the International College of Surgeons Thursday.

DUBLIN, Sept. 14 -- The second Dublin International Theatre Festival opened here tonight.

DENVER, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A quota system among nations of the free world to share markets for metals was advocated today by Gov. Steve McNichols of Colorado in an address to the American Mining Congress.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- All soybean futures were under heavy selling pressure on the Board of Trade today and closed with losses as much as 2 1/4 cents a bushel in a generally weak market.

DR. FRANCES HORWICH, principal of television's "Ding Dong School," returned to the local scene yesterday morning in a recorded version of her program designed for pre-school youngsters. She will be seen at 11 A. M., Mondays through Fridays, over Channel 13.
International dental leaders were told here yesterday that 43,000,000 out of 170,000,000 Americans were now getting teeth-protecting fluorides in their drinking water.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 13 points (65 cents a bale) up to 4 points (20 cents) off yesterday. The new October contract showed the most strength as tight supplies of raw cotton firmed the near October and December, particularly the former.

" INTEGRATED modern," a new decorating style, is expected to arrive in 1960. This forecast was made yesterday at the first autumn meeting of the Home Fashions League. The meeting was held at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Two Negro leaders charged yesterday that the "timidity of government agencies and collusion between the union and employers" had helped to perpetuate discrimination in waterfront hiring practices.

IN recent years, Ohrbach's has achieved a well-deserved reputation for its reproductions of Europeon haute couture fashions. This year's carefully executed plans copies of imports from Paris, Italy, London and Madrid, previewed for the press yesterday, uphold this reputation in a collection that is outstanding.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday a six-point program designed to break through a logjam of court cases resulting from the city's drive against youth crime.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses rejected yesterday a proposal by the City of Yonkers to buy or lease part of the northern end of Van Cortlandt Park. He termed the request "manifestly absurd" and "a preposterous idea."

Patrons for the annual Debutante Assembly and New Year's Ball, to be held on Jan. 1 in the Waldorf-Astoria, have been announced by the fete's chairman, Mrs. Thomas W. Edgar.

A list of twenty-three proposed sewer and highway projects for Queens has been submitted to the City Planning Commission, Borough President John T. Clancy announced yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Prices moved indecisively in the stock market here today. Movements among the industrials seldom exceeded a few pence. Shipping, electrical equipment, brewery and rubber shares scored minor gains, but most insurance, newspaper, motor and store stocks drifted lower.

He proved himself an energetic visitor, mingling with both rulers and common people, and visiting factories, hospitals, public buildings and other installations.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation will move its headquarters into 320 Park Avenue, the thirty-three-story building now under construction on the west side of the avenue between Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets. The structure will be named after the company, the principal tenant.

VERGENNES, Vt., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Norman Erbe, Iowa's Attorney General, urged other states today to take measures similar to laws recently enacted by Iowa in a fight against obscenity in publications. Mr. Erbe described the operation of the Iowa statutes, which are two weeks old, and expressed optimism regarding the outcome.
DALLAS, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Julius Boros shot a par 70 today to win the $25,000 Dallas open golf tournament as young Jon Gustin wilted under the pressure of his first big chance.

" Musical Talent in Our Schools," sponsored jointly by The New York Times and radio station WQXR, will begin its tenth annual auditions early next month. Participants for the broadcast series next spring will be chosen.

I noted with some dismay a letter published in The New York Times of Sept. 11 from James H. Waters, who questions the legislation introduced by Senators Magnuson and Butler which, if enacted, would increase the construction differential subsidy for shipbuilding above the present 50 per cent limitation.
The real crisis in highway transportation is not being met by the Federal interstate road-building program, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley declared yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd said tonight he could not remember remarking that the Soviet moon rocket was unlikely to interest people.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 14 -- Darn Safe, the leading money-earning harness horse, drew the rail position today and France's international champion, Jamin, got the second slot for Friday's $50,000 invitation American Trotting Championship at Roosevelt Raceway.
AN extraordinarily good company of off-Broadway actors last evening lavished a great deal of talent on a revival of a far-too-familiar play.

Those who plan the accommodations for vacationers are now developing a new service for next year, the boat motel, or boatel, as the trade is calling it. To go along with motels and trailer camps in meeting the needs of families that combine travel with their summer sojourns, the boatel will offer many facilities that are not now available to those who use the waterways to get from point to point.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Following are official State Department lists of the party aboard Premier Khrushchev's plane arriving at Andrews Air Force base tomorrow, the Soviet party arriving on an earlier plane and the official welcoming committee.
A study of two large housing cooperatives has shown that the residents were willing and able to spend more on housing to be able to live in the co-ops.
MOSCOW, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A Soviet scientific expedition that had drifted for three-and-one-half years on an ice floe near the North Pole was abandoned today, Tass reported.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The United States Government is again trying to sell to private enterprise a big, though profitable business headache.

The Chase Manhattan Bank completed yesterday its purchase of the West Indies Bank and Trust Company, which operates four offices in the Virgin Islands. The acquisition of the $12,304,000 institution attracted attention because of the unusual arrangement that made it possible for Chase Manhattan to make the purchase without issuing additional shares of stock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -The heads of the Soviet and United States atomic energy programs discussed today closer cooperation in the peaceful development of nuclear energy and the sharing of their research with the rest of the world.
May I clarify my position regarding your recent editorial which commented on the United Housing Foundation proposal and my own in connection with the $70,000,000 Warbasse Housing Project.

Columbia Artists Management, Inc., announced yesterday that it was preparing a nationwide tour of Jules Verne's operetta-fantasy, "Voyage to the Moon," with music by Offenbach. The attraction will open in Boston in November and start on Broadway sometime in April.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -The capital gave the nation a carefully planned demonstration today of how the Administration thinks Premier Khrushchev should be treated in this country. Everything was muted but the military bands and the twenty-one-gun salute.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -The United States rejected today a Soviet proposal for an international conference to deal with the crisis in Laos.
City Council President Abe Stark came out strongly yesterday in favor of fluoridating the city's water supply.
Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's speech of welcome yesterday to Premier Khrushchev and of the translation of the Soviet leader's reply in Russian, as recorded by The New York Times:

As reported on Aug. 29 by your Hong Kong correspondent, Tillman Durdin, Peiping now blandly acknowledges the falsity of its previous claim to have doubled production of food grains, steel and other essentials in 1958.

Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens appeared to have won a three-way fight in yesterday's Democratic primary vote for Borough President. He was backed by a majority of President. He was backed by a majority of the district leaders.
Robert Moses made public yesterday his "final" reply in a heated dispute with General Outdoor Advertising Company about highway billboards.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- "These are nice-looking boys," Premier Khrushchev observed today as he inspected the combat-ready troops of the Third Infantry who served as a guard of honor at Andrews Air Force Base.
White children returned to classes yesterday at five Queens public schools, ending a one-day boycott protesting the transfer of Negro and Puerto Rican pupils from Brooklyn.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 10 -- Business is booming these days in the United States Army and Air Force finance officers in charge of exchanging Turkish lire for dollars at the legal rate.
The two Brooklyn shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company will be consolidated by the end of this month, the company announced yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Arson was blamed for an early-morning fire that badly damaged the twenty-room suburban home of Gene San Soucie, a Midwestern teamsters leader.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The First Session of the Eighty-sixth Congress died with a yawn this morning just before breakfast.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Premier Khrushchev arrived today and received a big but undemonstrative welcome. He was greeted on landing by President Eisenhower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- The drawing of Ghana's name first in the annual lottery for seats gave the Ghanaian delegation front-row places today at the opening of the General Assembly's fourteenth session.
The Transit Authority is having trouble setting post times for its non-stop special trains to Aqueduct race track, but expects to operate on a firm schedule within a week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Following is the list of guests at President and Mrs. Eisenhower's dinner tonight for Premier and Mme. Khrushchev and other Soviet visitors, as made public by the White House:

The enormous increase in the number of women who work for a living and the greater number of children women in general are bearing have posed a growing problem: what should be done about leave of absence from the job for women to have children and return to their jobs afterward? The National Industrial Conference Board has been taking a measure of this situation and how leading companies are dealing with it.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Sept. 15 (UPI) -- Dr. Wernher von Braun, the space scientist, said today that the Soviet Union was far ahead of the United States in space projects "and there is no amount of money which can buy back lost time."
" A KNIT dress assumes the time of day," says Pat Lavery, Altman's sportswear buyer, pointing out just one more reason why knitted clothes have become indispensable to so many women's wardrobes.
THE Paris import collection at Lord Taylor bears the signature of a daring spirit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- a vote on a resolution allegedly aimed at thwarting New York's plans for a World's Fair in 1964 was blocked last night.

Stocks plunged in early trading yesterday, then paused about midway in the session and wiped out a little more than half of what they had lost. Market values on the New York Stock Exchange fell about $1,600,000,000.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Sept. 15 (UPI) -- The General Electric Company presented a sixty-acre island and camp site on Lake Ontario today to the New York State Young Men's Christian Association. The tract originally cost more than $1,000,000.
Nine persons were injured yesterday when a driverless trailer truck rolled down a grade at Broadway and West 233d Street in the Bronx and collided with a bus and a tank truck.

FLORENCE, Italy, Sept. 15 -- The world's first International Antiques Show, which opened here last week, is attracting large crowds of both Florentines and tourists. The exhibition, which will continue through Oct. 11, has been underwritten by the Italian Government. By way of an inducement, foreign exhibitors received free exhibition space and a 45 per cent discount on the transportation of their antiques.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A skywriter drew a cross today as Premier Khrushchev started his drive into Washington, but the wind soon dispelled it.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- The Liberal party opened its general election campaign tonight with a fierce attack on Britain's two major parties.
THE television version of "Fibber McGee and Molly" one of the more durable institutions of radio, made its debut at 8:30 last night on Channel 4. The premiere was not too encouraging.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 -- Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, declared here tonight that "significant action" in the promotion of America's educational system must not be predicated upon a "fear of Soviet Russia."
Mayor Wagner's Committee on Harlem Affairs went to work yesterday on the problem of reducing racial tensions.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 15 -- Anthony B. Gioffre of Port Chester today won the Republican nomination for Assemblyman in the Fourth District of Westchester County.

planned by George Izenour. Jose Quintero, the director, also helped to plan the O'Neill exhibition. Alvin Eisenman, associate professor of graphic arts at Yale and another planner of the exhibition, is in Sao Paulo to supervise the project.

AN ideal accompaniment to a toast to Princess Beatrix, now touring in this country, would be a cocktail biscuit produced in her native land. Called Cheese Caps, these baby rounds from the Netherlands taste like a soft shortbread highly flavored with cheese.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 15 -- The defending champion, Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood, and the medalist, Mrs. Philip Cudone of Forest Hill, scored first-round victories today in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's match-play championship at the Essex County Country Club.

CENTRE ISLAND, L. I., Sept. 15 -- The United States took the lead in the five-race series for the North American 6-meter sailing championships as the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club conducted the first race in a fifteen-to-eighteenknot southwesterly wind in mid-Sound today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Two unions representing packinghouse workers reached formal agreement today with Cudahy Packing Company, covering 4,500 union members in plants in six cities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -The first full month of the steel strike dropped industrial production only 4 per cent from its record peak of June, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Bronx Zoo has come up with a duck that thinks it's a chicken, a hippopotamus that has learned to balance on its back legs and beg, and a teenaged keeper who is perhaps the world's only llama exerciser.
Section 130 of the Labor Laws of the State of New York prohibits the employment of children under 16 years.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 15 -- President Adolfo Lopez Mateos proclaimed the renewal of diplomatic relations with Guatemala in a nation-wide radio address today.
Investment returns on United States Government notes and bonds rose to beyond 5 per cent yesterday for the first time since the 1921 money stringency that followed World War I.
HATTIESBURG, Miss., Sept. 15 (AP) -- A 30-year-old Mississippi Negro was jailed today after trying to enroll in all-white Mississippi Southern College.

The High School Teachers Association here charged yesterday that juvenile delinquency stems partly from books, magazines, motion pictures and television programs that undermine the morals of teen-agers.

Puerto Rican and city labor union officials announced plans yesterday to work more closely together to strengthen the labor movement in Puerto Rico and to improve working conditions for Puerto Ricans here.

On July 16, 1945, the first atomic bomb exploded in the desert of New Mexico and the atomic age began. A few miles away, William L. Laurence watched that birth. In his forthcoming book, "Men and Atoms," he gives a behind-the-scene account of the wartime development of the nuclear weapon and the scientists involved with it.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 3 to 11 points yesterday, with the far months showing new strength. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.)
HARTFORD, Sept. 15 (UPI) -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff said today that a decline in the size of the expected state-deficit showed that his policy of no new taxes had been justified.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 15 -The United Nations fact-finding body arrived today and found the capital a city of broken sidewalks, rutted roads and stray dogs.
BOSTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) -- The Boston Red Sox tallied in the ninth inning tonight to beat the Cleveland Indians, 1 -- 0.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 15 -- Queen Juliana opened Parliament today with an address that mirrored the thrifty, industrious, freedom-loving Dutch character.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 15-- The General Assembly opened its 1959 session today in a tranquil atmosphere. Dr. Victor A. Belaunde of Peru, who was elected president, told the Assembly that he wanted to express again "my unshakable faith in our organization."

Hooker Chemical Corporation priced its subscription offering of $24,444,900 of 25-year convertible subordinated debentures at 100 yesterday and the offering went on the market. By the close, the debentures were trading at 105 bid in the over-the-counter market.

Paperboard production dropped sharply to a fourteen-month low of 250,491 tons last week from 335,940 tons the week before the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.

Raymond Burns, who had to sell his Bronx candy store and give up his taxi-driving job after having been shot by a policeman six years ago, was awarded $60,000 disability compensation yesterday.

A series of twenty-five Wednesday evenings of chamber music, beginning Oct. 21, will mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the educational program of the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

Australia has an adequate supply of foreign capital for the development of her private industry but requires more funds for Government development projects, Harold Holt, Treasurer of Australia, said yesterday.
HARRISON, N. J., Sept. 15 -- Employes of seven of the nine plants of the Worthington Corporation, manufacturer of industrial equipment, went on strike today.

Two highly touted rookies -Bob Riefsnyder, a tackle, and Bobby Newman, a quarterback -- were released yesterday as National Football League teams trimmed their rosters to the thirty-eight-man limit. Three well-known players also were dropped.

THE Whitney Museum of American Art opens its season today with an exhibition of prints, sixty-two examples in assorted techniques including experimental ones. It is a good show, and a representative one of "American Prints Today," its title, ranging from conventional avantgarde examples to conventional old-guard ones, in so far as these are still around.

Hare Koninklijke Hoogheid Prinses Beatrix became an honorary citizen of Brooklyn yesterday. She assumed her duties immediately by stooping to pick up the scroll of citizenship when Borough President John Cashmore dropped it during the presentation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) -- Wilfred J. McNeil resigned as Assistant Secretary of Defense today to become president of the Grace Line Steamship Company.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 15 -The cells that make up beans, yams, potatoes and several other plants can now be grown in large volume as free floating cells, an American Chemical Society symposium was told today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 -- A new union program to combat inflation and ward off economic slumps was unveiled here tonight. It called for the establishment by major industries of an insurance system intended to guarantee that companies would be able to cover their basic overhead costs in bad years as well as good.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15 -- Alvaro Alsogaray, Economy Minister, defied the threat of a general strike by the Peronist-Communist labor front today. He rejected an ultimatum for a change in the Government's economic policies.

With the exception of New Year's Eve, vacation time generally is regarded as the best one - for inaugurating good resolutions. This is not hard to understand, for the new year and the days of vacation have much in common.
A new approach to school financing, with the state giving $115,000,000 more immediately, was recommended yesterday by the New York State Educational Conference Board.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 15 -- Charley Coe and Dee Replogle, two Oklahomans wearing red baseball caps with big "O" insignias, captured much of the attention today in the second round of the United States Amateur golf championship.

Reports attributing John Houseman's recent resignation as artistic director of the American Shakespeare Festival at Stratford, Conn., to personal differences between him and Lawrence Langner, chairman of the festival's executive committee, were vigorously denied yesterday by the latter.

Sales of the nation's major retail chains and mail order companies surged ahead of the comparable 1958 levels in August and in the first eight months of this year. A survey yesterday by The New York Times indicated that volume rose 7.1 per cent last month and 9.5 per cent in the year to date.

LONG association with Casey Stengel is starting to have its effect on Alfonso Ramon Lopez, somewhat in the fashion of a delayed-action bomb. Or maybe it's the proximity of a pennant for his White Sox that has the Happy Hidalgo reacting like his old manager. At any rate the senior now demonstrates his words with gestures.
The Go-Go White Sox went another step toward Chicago's first American League pennant in forty years yesterday by winning a 4-3 thriller from the Yankees.

A collection of antiques culled from all corners of the world is now on view at Hofstatter's, 227 East Fifty-sixth Street. Reproductions manufactured by the concern also are included in the exhibition, which is open only to decorators and their clients.

The patents of the late Maj. Edwin Howard Armstrong, who spent many years fighting for legal recognition as the inventor of frequency modulation, were declared valid yesterday by Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri.

The Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company of Bethlehem, Pa., may soon be free of its seventy-year association of railroad interests with the Central Railroad of New Jersey. This would be accomplished through the sale of the railroad interests of Lehigh Coal-and Navigation to Jersey Central.
TORONTO, Sept. 15 -- The Toronto Art Gallery was looted of $600,000 worth of paintings last night.

LONG BEACH, L. I., -- Sept. 15 -- Charges of "brazen violations" of the Election Law and sharp denials tonight enlivened a Democratic primary here in which an insurgent fought the organization slate for the City Council.

MONDAY night a new bridge club opened in Great Neck, L. I., which is recognized as a bridge center even though its women have spent most of the last twenty years playing various games of the rummy family, such as canasta (the present favorite), Oklahoma, gin rummy and continental rummy.

AMERICAN designers have "be-furred" their fall creations with a lavish hand. Most of the coats, suits and ensembles in Bloomingdale's Green Room, the salon section of the store that offers the designs of the leading Seventh Avenue houses, are liberally adorned with fur.

The top trophy for the first annual East Coast interclub sports car championship at Bridgehampton, L. I., on Saturday and Sunday will be presented in honor of George C. Rand of Oyster Bay, L. I. A racing driver since 1928, Rand organized the Automobile Racing Club of America in 1932.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 15 -- A Monmouth County plan to create a 440-acre public recreation park on the Government-owned Sandy Hook Peninsula is expected to be presented tomorrow or Thursday to Secretary of the Army Wilber M. Brucker.

Carmine G. De Sapio retained his Greenwich Village Tammany district leadership by a razor-thin margin last night but found his leadership of the New York County Democratic organization materially weakened.

HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 15 -A man tossed a suitcase of explosives on a school playground today and killed three children, himself and two other adults. The police identified one of the dead as the bomber's son.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 -- The Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 8 -- 7, in a wild ten-inning game today and tied them for second place in the National League pennant race.

Phoenix, Ariz., borrowed $5,500,000 in the bond market yesterday on obligations secured by the city's taxing power. The city also posted for sale $2,000,000 of street and highway improvement revenue bonds on Sept. 29.

FRASER, Mich., Sept. 15 (UPI) -- In a mass picket assault on the plant of the Cross Manufacturing Company here today one man was injured when his car was turned over. Several cars were stoned or smeared with dye and a strike sympathizer was arrested.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Overshadowed by a fresh increase in the United States Treasury bill rate and Monday's setback on Wall Street, share prices here today moved narrowly and irregularly.

The general feeling among the directors of the new Aqueduct race track yesterday was one of optimism -- particularly after the attendance of 24,567 was made known. Bobby Fischer, the United States champion, suffered his second defeat in the world championship challenger's chess tournament in Bled yesterday, according to a report reaching here last night through Yugoslav news sources.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -The Soviet Union stopped Jamming Voice of America broadcasts today for the first time in ten years. The jamming transmitters went off the air just about the time Premier Khrushchev left Moscow for Washington.

WARSAW, Sept. 3 -- For a year and a half a Polish-born architect from New Jersey has been lobbying in Washington and buttonholing in Warsaw. It seems that he will get what he has been after -- the construction of the first American-built hospital in a Communist country.

Commercial and finance paper and bankers acceptance rates were advanced yesterday in the wake of Monday's rise in the Treasury bill rate to 4.166 per cent, its highest level since the banking holiday of 1933. It was the first time since then that it had exceeded 4 per cent.

ONE way of writing history that has become increasingly popular in recent years is to take the microscopic view. Instead of chronicling an important epoch, a major war, or the slow development of political and social change, the microscopic historians concentrate their attention on a small incident sufficiently crucial or dramatic ...

Edwin J. Graf has been elected a vice president of Smith-Corona Marchant. He will be general manager of the company's new Smith-Corona division.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- President Eisenhower told 500 exchange teachers from sixty countries today that it was more important to put new ideas into orbit than to orbit satellites.

The National Stock Exchange, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the New York Mercantile Exchange, became a legal entity yesterday with the filing of its charter with the Secretary of State at Albany.

Production of electric power dipped to a fourteen-week low of 13,109,000,000 kilowatt-hours last week from 13,759,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange declined sharply yesterday in a session that left prices virtually unchanged.
Middle Brother convinced a crowd of 25,673 at Aqueduct yesterday that he is a formidable distance runner.
There was a touch of autumn in the air yesterday. Yet only a week ago the thermometer registered a high of 91.9 degrees.
The St. Louis-San Francisco ('Frisco) Railway has surrendered in its battle with the Interstate Commerce Commission over control of the Central of Georgia Railway.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 -- Representatives of twenty maritime unions affiliated with the merged labor federation called today for abolition of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.

Tape recordings of a conversation involving a $10,000 personal loan played a dramatic part yesterday in the State Athletic Commission's investigation of the Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson world title fight of June 26.

The functions of the cotton futures exchanges have been eliminated by the present cotton-marketing system, the New York and New Orleans Cotton Exchanges and the American Farm Bureau Federations said yesterday in a joint statement. They called it a "complete and utter failure."
IN the last act of "Song for a Certain Midnight," acted at the Jan Hus Auditorium last evening, it is possible that the characters pull themselves together and face a cheerful morn.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- A new bookkeeping account opened cheerfully on the stock market here today. Although business remained small, a little extra demand sufficed to raise prices in British Government bonds and in most other issues.
HAVANA, Sept. 16 -- Heavy taxes were imposed on alcoholic beverages by the Cuban Revolutionary Cabinet early this morning. The taxes become effective Oct. 1.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 17 -- Wines, movie stars and dancers were organized here today for the luncheon on Saturday in honor of Premier Khrushchev.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Eisenhower's news conference, which centered largely on United States-Soviet relations, was broadcast to the Soviet Union today by the Voice of America.
NEWARK, Sept. 17 -- Three officials of the defunct Manufacturers Bank of Edgewater and four other persons have been indicted on charges stemming from allegedly fraudulent loans totaling $150,000.

Dennis Craig, columnist for The Rand Daily Mail in Johannesburg and co-author of a forthcoming book, has signed with Harper for the publication of another book. As yet untitled, it will give an account of Operation Noah's Ark, the rescuing of African animals trapped on islands by man-made floods.
ISLAND BEACH, N. J., Sept. 17-- A "plantation" has been established by the Federal Government, in the arid - looking sand dunes of the state park here.
PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Hadj Messali, leader of the Algerian National Movement, survived an assassination attempt this morning near his home near Chantilly, north of Paris.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) off to 2 points (10 cents a bale) up yesterday, after fluctuating narrowly all day.
American steamship companies traded in three vessels last month. The number of such ships involved in the current multi-billion-dollar program for fleet replacement is thirty-six.
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 17 -- Senator John F. Kennedy urged the legal profession today to cleanse its ranks of unscrupulous and unethical lawyers who have preyed upon the labor movement.
MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 18 -- The Soviet people are demonstrating uncommon interest in reading about Premier Khrushchev's travels in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Eisenhower said today that Congressional refusal to permit higher interest rates on long-term Government bonds was "one of the most serious things that has happened to the United States in my time."

The reliance on police powers to solve the social problem of juvenile violence is more an admission that insufficient resources have been applied in solving the problem and preventing it than that restrictive measures may be more successful in coping with it.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Eisenhower was urged by Senator Albert Gore today to prevent "deliberate defaulting" of Federal obligations to the states in the interstate highway program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Paul M. Butler said today that the Democratic party would claim a "substantial" share of the credit in 1960 for the passage of this year's labor-reform bill.

AS a participant in the first wave of defiant avant-gardism in this country before World War I, Oscar F. Bluemner stands permanently along with Stieglitz, Marin, Dove, Hartley and a dozen others -- in modern American art history.
Art and alcohol will be mixed by Schenley Industries, Inc., in a Yule holiday gift-wrap promotion.

The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation announced yesterday that "substantial progress" had been made toward the organization of a proposed jointly owned subsidiary, Dynamics Reading Chemicals, Inc.

Premier Khrushchev goes before the United Nations General Assembly today to submit a new proposal on what he rightly terms the most burning problem of our day -- the problem of disarmament. The world must hope that it will be a really new proposal and that it will change the previous Soviet attitude sufficiently to break the twelve-year-old deadlock.

The enlargement of the managing committee of the Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, San Francisco, by the appointment of four additional executive vice presidents was announced yesterday by S. Clark Beise, president.
The Wagner Administration's plan to ban the occupancy of single rooms by families with children was warmly praised and sharply attacked at a public hearing yesterday.

Mme. Nina Petrovna Khrushchev launched out on her own yesterday, and went home last night with the enthusiastic applause of Broadway ringing in her ears.

New Yorkers who lined the sidewalks yesterday hoping for a glimpse of Premier Khrushchev got only that -- a quick glimpse of his profile flashing by, his right hand waving from an automobile, his face smiling behind glass.
Mayor Wagner's administration was the target of Queens Republicans last night as they opened their campaign to elect Robert E. Barnes as Borough President.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- United Nations officials are girding themselves for a long speech and a brief tour by Premier Khrushchev tomorrow.
Premier Khrushchev traveled from Washington to Manhattan yesterday morning in an observation car named for George Washington that was guarded by an extraordinary security detail.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 -- About 5,000 fans broke dirt with the Dodgers today in hallowed Chavez Ravine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- A Special Senate Committee on unemployment announced plans today for a nation-wide survey to measure the impact of a possible thaw in the "cold war" and other factors on United States employment and economic activity.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 -- The merged labor federation was told today that a scramble for special treatment among the federation's own units had been partly responsible for the passage in Congress of a tough union control bill.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Leo Durocher quit his $65,000-a-year television job with the National Broadcasting Company today to return to baseball as a manager, possibly with the Cleveland Indians.
WASHINGTON, Sept 17 -- Premier Khrushchev's itinerary for the last four days of his United States tour was announced today by the White House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The son of the Secretary of Agriculture and the son-in-law of Premier Khrushchev had a pleasant chat on their way back from Beltsville, Md. The subject: The Mormon Church.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 17 (AP) -- A settlement of a minority stockholders' suit over incentive pay for executives of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation was approved today. The suit protested the size of bonuses paid to high officials of the company.

A new issue of $18,000,000 of mortgage bonds of the Georgia Power Company is being offered for public subscription today by investment bankers on terms representing a yield of 5.65 per cent to maturity.

Sergei N. Khrushchev, 24-year-old son of the Soviet Premier, examined New York from the window of an Army helicopter yesterday afternoon. He decided that the skyscrapers were impressive, but that he would not "like to live up so high."
The directors of Litton Industries, Inc., voted a two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday.

The proposed merger of the Tidewater Oil Company and the Skelly Oil Company has been abandoned, according to an announcement made here late yesterday by Tidewater. A controlling stock interest in both companies is held by the Getty Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Senator J. W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that better schools were a "national necessity" -- because of the "superior educational system in the hands of Russia -- "a menacing totalitarian power."
Carmine G. De Sapio was reported yesterday to be planning to relinquish his office as New York County Democratic chairman but retain the more powerful position of county leader, or head of Tammany.

Commercial and industrial borrowings at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City rose $135,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Borrowings by finance companies, factors and other business credit companies rose $163,000,000.

More than 2,500 anti-Communists rallied at Carnegie Hall last night to hear bitter denunciations of the Khrushchev visit.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands followed the trail of the old Dutch settlers up the Hudson River yesterday, carrying out a rigorous schedule that even they would have approved.

Jose Rivera, one of four youths charged with unlawful assembly in the West Side playground killings last month, was charged with homicide yesterday. He was the seventh so charged in the case.
Montreal made what Branch Rickey called an "impressive" formal application yesterday for a franchise in the new third major league.

At long last the Board of Monitors, appointed by Federal Judge Letts to purge the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has taken definite steps to have Mr. Hoffa removed as the union's president. This move comes after more than a year of obstruction and delay by the Teamsters in obeying the monitors' recommendations, held by the Federal Court of Appeals last July to be legally enforceable if approved by Judge Letts.
Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools, warned Harlem parents yesterday that he would take "appropriate legal steps" if they kept their children out of school.

The high praise that President Eisenhower gave to President de Gaulle's Algerian offer in his press conference yesterday was merited. President Eisenhower disclaimed any intention yesterday of taking any part "on one side or the other" in the national steel strike.

Sidney J. Ungar, the originator of the Riverside-Amsterdam housing plan, said yesterday that he would fight in court and at City Hall to prevent the Committee on Slum Clearance from dropping him as sponsor of part of the nine-block redevelopment.

Lumber production fell sharply to 225,790,000 board feet from 242,640,000 in the preceding week, according to reports from regional associations to The New York Times. The latest level, affected by the Labor Day holiday, compared with the output in the non-holiday 1958 week of 251,169,000 board feet.

MADRID, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- Two girl students from the New York area were killed and another seriously injured today when their car collided with a truck near Fraga in northern Spain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week, in which the Labor Day holiday fell, totaled 480,647 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

THOSE passing the Thirty-second Street windows of Gimbels in the next two weeks will be in for a surprise. Here, amid much bouncing, hammering, boiling and freezing, this store will demonstrate the sturdiness of a virtually unbreakable new glassware called Duralex.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- The controversial film "Les Liaisons Dangereuses" ("Dangerous Relations") was seized today as the result of civil action taken against it by the Society of Men of Letters. Projection was halted for several hours, then allowed to resume.

As the new academic year gets under way throughout the country many colleges face a difficult financial future. Hence tuition fees have spiraled in recent years. Fortunately, this is also true of the number and value of scholarships and loans.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- A victorious Labor party would seek early negotiations with the Soviet Union on a zone of controlled disarmament in Central Europe as a first step toward a general European settlement.

HOUSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Harry C. Melges Jr. skippered Wisconsin's Inland Lakes Yachting Association to the Mallory Cup national small-boat sailing championship today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17 -- The discovery of a large-quantity source of a substance that may help to control hardening of the arteries has been reported to the American Chemical Society.

Average member bank borrowings rose $2,000,000 to $1,059,000,000 in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Excess reserves declined $78,000,000 to $496,000,000. This produced average net borrowed reserves (excess reserves less borrowings) of $563,000,000, or $80,000,000 more than a week earlier.

For one happy moment yesterday. Premier Khrushchev chose freedom from the hordes of officials pressing about him.

The October position in world sugar was traded actively yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. It was first notice day for the contract and a total of 709 notices of intentions to deliver were issued, the highest number in several years.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 17 -- Two battalions of Communist-led Pathet Lao troops were reported today to be operating near Thakhek, near the Thai border about 135 miles southeast of this Laotian capital.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The request of the public's monitors of the international teamsters' union to Chief Judge Letts of the Federal District Court here for a hearing which could at last lead to the ousting of James R. Hoffa as head of this most powerful of labor organizations is the direct consequence of a contribution to orderly society in this country by a man only 33 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Central-American countries have advanced the date for realization of a common market from ten years to five.

C. Mahlon Kline's competent jumper, Gridiron, won the Harbor Hill Handicap, the steeplechase that topped the program at Aqueduct yesterday. With Ed Deveau guiding him, Gridiron succeeded in beating the favored Narcissus II by a length and a half in the race of about two miles.
A private report issued here yesterday said that the Government of Hungary was ruling with increasing terror.

LAWRENCE PETER BERRA, a shy man, is wandering about in a daze right now, muttering constantly to himself. He keeps repeating the same three sentences over and over and over. Those three sentences represent the speech he will recite -- if he doesn't forget them -- in the ceremonies at home plate on Yogi Berra Day at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow afternoon.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 17 -- The medical profession was scolded today by a Ford Foundation executive at the dedication of Stanford University's new medical center.

TRENTON, Sept. 17 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner warned today that the Federal Government would have to give financial assistance to the distressed commuter railroads if all of their problems were to be solved.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 -- United Air Lines' huge new jet aircraft maintenance base here was ready today for the inauguration tomorrow of the company's transcontinental jet liner service.

Companies affiliated with Sam Minskoff Sons, Inc., investment builders, announced plans yesterday for a twenty-fivestory office building at the northeast corner of Third Avenue and Forty-third Street. It will be occupied by the American Home Products Corporation, manufacturer of pharmaceuticals, food and household products.
The Scott Paper Company will have a 20 per cent interest in a pulp mill being built in Nova Scotia by Swedish interests. The mill is believed to require an investment of about $40,000,000.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 17 -- Barbara Hepworth, a British sculptor whose modernistic work draws inspiration from Greek classicism, won the grand international prize for plastic arts at the fifth Biennial of Modern Art in Sao Paulo.

Net assets of the nation's mutual funds slipped in August from the July level, the National Association of Investment Companies reported time since February, 1958, yesterday. This was the first that any month's figures were lower than those of a month before. George A. Mooney, executive director, said the decline reflected in part the drop in the general level of security prices.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17-- The United States appealed to the Soviet Union today to join in a new attempt to control the armaments race and "prevent it from exploding into nuclear conflict."

Municipal housing authorities, subsidized by the Public Housing Administration, are planning the sale of bond issues amounting to about $100,000,000 in a month or so. The last sale of such obligations was on May 26, when $104,750,000 of the housing obligations were sold at an average interest cost of 3.776 per cent.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 17 (AP) -- E. A. Lauderdale, one of five men charged in Little Rock's Labor Day bombings, filed a $50,000 damage suit against Police Chief Eugene Smith today. He alleged that his civil rights had been violated.

Three corporations---one national and the other international--have leased all the space up to the ninth floor of the new twenty-one-story office building at 410 Park Avenue, southwest corner of Fifty-fifth Street.
BRILLAT-SAVARIN, the French gastronome, once said that the invention of a new dish was more important than the discovery of a new star. Although he spoke of food, he might have had cookware in mind.
TUNIS, Sept. 17 -- A North African conference has been called to consider President Charles de Gaulle's new plan for self-determination for Algeria.

THE handsome fabrics of eighteenth-century England are traced in an exhibition that opens today at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 57 East Fifty-seventh Street. The museum is open from 9 A. M. to 5 P. M. Mondays through Fridays. Admission is free.
The May Department Stores Company, which operates forty-five downtown and suburban stores, increased its sales and earnings in the three, six and nine months ended on July 31.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Two Federal narcotics agents and a Narcotics Bureau employe were sentenced to six months apiece in jail today for mistakenly identifying a suspected narcotics seller.
Omer Simeon, the New Orleans jazz clarinetist, died of cancer yesterday in Harlem Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 181 West 135th Street.
FALL is inappropriately named as far as the cost of food is concerned. Rising prices already are noted among meats, fruits and vegetables.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Eisenhower suggested today that the metal pennants that the Soviet Union says it has placed on the moon might have been vaporized by the impact with the lunar surface.

United States Government securities stiffened their resistance yesterday to further price declines. The technical rally staged on Wednesday widened to include most of the actively traded issues of interest-bearing securities and discount bills.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A moderate demand strengthened soybean and rye futures today but other grains on the Board of Trade showed little change.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Manufacturing profits rose to a record dollar figure in the second quarter of this year, the Federal Trade Commission and Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
WOODMERE, L. I., N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Shelley Mayfield took a lead of one stroke after thirty-six holes in the Metropolitan open golf championship at the Woodmere Club course today.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 17 -- Miss E. R. Sears' bay gelding Diamant, from Pride's Crossing, Mass., took the Professional Horsemen's Association Challenge Trophy as the fifth-fourth annual piping rock horse show opened today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- The chairman of the Senate Constitutional Rights subcommittee asked the State Department today to establish a consistent policy on visas for foreign newsmen. He said it would help United States news correspondents abroad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Eisenhower and the State Department emphatically denied today charges by Premier Khrushchev that the United States wanted to cut back the cultural exchange program while the Soviet Union sought to expand it.

CAPE MAY, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Bird watchers and photographers have been making expeditions here for close-up views of a seldom-seen migrant, the cattle egret of North Africa.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A Department of Agriculture survey indicated today that this year's fall pig crop might be only about 5 per cent greater than that of 1958 instead of the 7 per cent officially forecast last June.

Like a rich uncle surrounded by some ungrateful relatives, the United States has often smarted recently under abuse and critical statements from recipients of its help -- money or commodity.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 17 -- The revolt of a 38-year-old mother against housework and over-the-fence chatter about children began this morning on the tree-shaded campus of Douglass College. After six years of study she hopes to obtain a law degree.

CENTER ISLAND, L. I., Sept. 17 -- James C. Crang scored his second straight victory today to maintain Canada's lead in the North American six-meter sailing championships at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 -- George Meany asserted today that Premier Khrushchev's sole aim was to enslave the world through a policy of "deceit: treachery and inhuman ruthlessness."

The United States chess champion, Bobby Fischer, played Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union yesterday in the seventh round of the challengers' tournament at Bled and gave a good account of himself before the five-hour time limit brought an adjournment.

One hundred and seventy-six parcels of city-owned real estate were sold at auction yesterday for a total of $1,521,400, or more than double the total upset price of $750,100. The upset is the minimum figure at which a bid is acceptable.

The election of Paul E. Prosswimmer as president of the Franklin National Bank of Long Island, Franklin Square, L. I., was announced yesterday. Mr. Prosswimmer succeeds Arthur T. Roth, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Burma, as the world's largest exporter of rice for the last three years, has been improving her marketing and cultivation of that product. The development is appraised by the United Na tions Food and Agriculture Organization as likely to have important long-term influences on global trade in rice.

THE American Contract Bridge League, through its directors or committees, will select two teams of six players each to represent the United States in the next world championship matches to be played in Europe -- probably in Rome -- next April.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The nation's civilian space agency disclosed plans today to establish a satellite-tracking station in Minnesota -- the first of its kind in the Middle West.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 17 (AP) -- More than 1,000 Unitarians and Universalists will meet here from Oct. 27 to Nov. 1 to discuss detailed plans for merger of the two religious groups.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration sought widespread publicity today for a warning that use of a permanent-wave product made by Richard Hudnut Company might irritate the eyes.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 17 -- The nation's first plane for carrying man into space made its initial powered test flight successfully today.
MONTIVEDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 17 -- Delegates of seven South American countries met today to consider steps toward economic integration.

Bank clearings in the twenty-six major cities of the nation totaled $26,208,624,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. This represented a rise of 43.1 per cent above the $18,313,767,000 volume of the previous week, which included the Labor Day holiday.

With Charley Black, a former fight manager, as the sole witness, the State Athletic Commission tried yesterday to tie the missing Cus D'Amato directly into the promotion of last June's heavyweight title fight between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood and Mrs. Philip Cudone of Forest Hill today gained the final of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association match play championship at the Essex County Country Club.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Prices continued to improve in the stock market here today. The exceptions were real estate shares, which were unsettled by the heavy fall in the issues of companies comprising the H. Jasper group, and rubber shares.

DUXBURY, Mass., Sept. 17 (UPI) -- The body of a Naval Air Reserve officer who had been doing classified work for the Navy was found on a beach here last night. Death was attributed to a bullet wound in the head.

Franchot Tone has dropped out of the Theatre Guild's impending production of "Jolly's Progress," co-starring Eartha Kitt. There is a good chance he will be replaced by Wendell Corey, last seen here in "Night of the Auk" (1956).
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A fraternity pledge being hazed during an initiation choked to death today while trying to swallow a large piece of oil-soaked raw liver.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Msgr. William J. McDonald, rector of the Catholic University of America, announced today a project to bring out a new Roman Catholic encyclopedia.

OTTAWA, Sept. 17 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government's 1959 series of savings bonds will go on sale on Oct. 13, bearing a record average interest yield of 4.98 per cent a year for the nine-year maturities.

No squirrel, no chipmunk and no woodchuck can tell you the hour, or even the day, when the autumnal equinox comes. Nor can any flicker or robin tell you. The precise hour and minute is something important, in its way, to man; but bird and beast do very well without such data. At 2:09 next Wednesday afternoon the sun crosses the celestial equator, and thereafter summer will be past, autumn here.
