The new president of the Municipal Bond Women's Club of New York is a witty auburn-haired cashier of a revenue bond house who endorses Wall Street careers for women.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, said today that vetoes of four money bills and other threatened vetoes by President Eisenhower had helped bring a cut in appropriations by the 1959 Congress.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -- Labor in New York has set up formal machinery to consider building its own hospital chain and operating its own medical insurance system in competition with Blue Cross and Blue Shield.
AN exhibition of porcelain birds will go on view at Tiffany's today.
In an unusual game in which the winning pitcher, Duke Maas, faced one batter, the Yankees defeated the Red Sox, 7-4, before 17,199 persons at the Stadium yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20 -- A steel shortage existed in the country last week. No matter when the steelworkers go back to the mills, all steel users are expected to be in trouble until the mills get back to full shipping capacity.

President Eisenhower was urged last night to raise with Premier Khrushchev the problem of Soviet-dominated peoples "in the spirit of the Captive Nations Week" that the President himself had proclaimed.

President Eisenhower could hardly have been expected to do anything else than he has done in saying he would appoint a board of inquiry in the steel dispute only if both parties should ask for it. However desirable -- at least from the public point of view -- it might be for such a board to be set up, it was formally requested by only one party to the dispute, the union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Disarmament Subcommittee warned today that a reduction in United States defense spending might bring economic dislocations. He also accused the Administration of showing a lack of interest in the problem.
A study of personal products advertising on television has resulted in the conclusion that, while the majority of commercials are in "excellent taste," there is room for improvement.
Three tankers in the California Texas Oil Company's Panamanian fleet are being transferred to British registry, it was reported yesterday.

It will be a loss to the country if President Eisenhower's somewhat critical review of some acts of the past session of Congress is dismissed as a mere partisan gesture. Actually, what the President is obviously trying to do is to lay some groundwork for the next session and to establish a line of policy that he believes to be fundamentally sound.
The Rev. John Sutherland Bonnell yesterday began his twenty-fifth year in the pulpit of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.
LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP) -The Soviet Union's moon rocket was guided only in the first few minutes of its space flight, Moscow radio reported tonight.
Angry magistrates in the Bronx and Queens set unusually high bail yesterday for two pairs of youths accused of kidnapping and sex offenses against two teen-aged girls.
HONG KONG, Sept. 20 -- A new attempt in Peiping to mend relations between Japan and Communist China appeared today to have made little headway.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -Mira Slovak, a 29-year-old refugee from behind the Iron Curtain, today won the President's Cup, one of speed boating's toplofty trophies.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Sept. 20 -- Robert Smart and James Candelet, representing the Eastern Division, captured the second annual United States lawn bowling championship today at the Buck Hill Falls Lawn Bowling Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -- It must be something in the California air. Every where you turn they manufacture cliff hangers. On the baseball diamond the Giants and the Dodgers, once New York's own, are battling on the edge of a precipice. In the opera house a new production becomes a breathless encounter with danger.

THE practice of literary criticism is not without its occupational hazards. One of them is the considerable portion of the critic's life spent in peculiar company. In the ordinary line of duty I have lived (vicariously) among alcoholics, narcotics addicts, gangsters and the sexually depraved. And while I have seemed to be sitting in an easy chair I have passed many a grueling day in hospitals, old people's homes, mental hospitals, prisons and concentration camps.
The head of a giant Italian Government holding company, who turns portions of its vast assets over to private industry whenever possible, is touring this country.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -The extended price declines on the Board of Trade carried all corn futures contracts to a succession of new low prices for the season again last week.

The Democratic reform group in Greenwich Village began a legal challenge yesterday to the election of Carmine G. De Sapio as a member of the New York County Democratic Committee in last Tuesday's primary.

Wentworth D. Fling's 35-foot ketch, Highland, out of Port Washington, L. I., yesterday was confirmed as the over-all winner of the Stuyvesant Yacht Club's twelfth annual day race and the Heifetz Trophy.
An American film company announced yesterday that it has reached preliminary agreement with a Soviet agency for the exchange of filmed television programs and motion pictures.

The Kohon String Quartet made an appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon, playing a program that featured the first New York performance of the Mixolydian Quartet by Yizchak Edel, Israeli composer.
TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Invitations have been sent out to the seventy-first annual Tuexdo Autumn Ball to be held Oct. 24 in the Tuxedo Club.

COLOGNE, Germany, Sept. 20 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer participated in the opening of a new synagogue her today. He asked the Jews who would worship there to pray not only for their co-religionists murdered by the Nazis but also for the Christians who were killed by the same thugs.

The International Finance Corporation has committed itself to invest up to $1,250,000 in a new Venezuelan corporation to make refractory bricks and materials. The concern, Refractarios General-Vikora de Venezuela, C.A., (Grefkora) will be owned by the General Refractories Company of Philadelphia and the Corao family and associates in Venezuela.

In September, before the trees have fully changed color and long before harvesting is done, the newly retired executive feels an urge to revisit the scene of his former triumphs. He must go back and say hello to the gang, he rationalizes.
FOIE GRAS, the name for genuine goose liver, is frequently called the most sublime of foods.
LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP) -Premier Khrushchev has shown remarkable restraint, on the whole, in the face of "American heckling," The Times of London said tonight.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 20 -- Amid the displays of temperament during Premier Khrushchev's visit here yesterday, the man who had the most reason to let off steam remained his usual urbane self.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- American corporations increased their working capital by three billion dollars to a record of $125,400,000,000 in the April-June quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The city's program to replace 64,000 cast-iron lamp-posts with multi-purpose posts of aluminum or steel got a token start yesterday. Two aluminum poles -- to be used now for street lighting only -- were installed at the intersection of Murray Street and Broadway, across from City Hall.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Four years of consistent effort by West Pakistan has begun to yield dividends through the reclamation of formerly productive land that has been submerged by mobile sand dunes.

The National Association of Supervisors of State Banks has announced its support of a bill before Congress to take from the Federal Reserve Board its power to rule on the continuation of branches acquired by state-chartered banks in mergers.
The Tidewater Oil Company announced plans over the weekend for a multimillion-dollar petroleum refinery and storage terminal in Denmark. It will be Denmark's first crude oil refinery.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 -Premier Khrushchev headed for San Francisco today after a stormy twenty hours in Los Angeles.
LINCOLN, Neb. (UPI) -- Food scientists have come up with new ways to cook broccoli to retain flavor, color, texture and a high percentage of Vitamin C.

A WINTER coat is the biggest investment a woman makes in her wardrobe all year. Considering the money involved and the amount of wear it will get during the season, it is a purchase that cannot be treated lightly.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- The perennial question of the admission of Communist China to the United Nations is scheduled to come before the General Assembly tomorrow. For the ninth straight year, the door is expected to be kept shut to the Peiping regime.
Nation-wide hearings on "teen-age terrorists" will be started here Wednesday and Thursday by the Senate subcommittee on juvenile delinquency.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 20 -- The open jumper championship at the fifty-fourth annual Piping Rock Horse Show finished in a three-way tie at 13 points as the four-day show closed today.

Three floors and a major portion of a fourth floor in the new office building at 110 William Street, corner of John Street, have been leased by the 195 Broadway Corporation, real estate subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The longest test by the Project Mercury astronauts before one tries to go into orbit will apparently be an 1,800-mile flight.
SARANAC INN, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- The creation of a permanent Presidential advisory council on education was urged today by Dr. James E. Allen, State Commissioner of Education.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A speaker at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Park Executives, opening in Philadelphia tomorrow, will be Sgt. 1/c Marvin Jones.

THE champions of television theatre were caught in a familiar dilemma last night. There could only be cheers for the National Broadcasting Company in starting a new series of hour-long dramas: "Sunday Showcase" at 8 o'clock over Channel 4.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- With more faith in the public opinion polls that indicate a Conservative party victory next month than in Labor's chances of imposing its threatened capital gains tax, the stock market closed last week full of confidence and on firm ground.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -- The State Department has asked Henry Cabot Lodge to do what he can to avoid unnecessary and useless public arguments with Premier Khrushchev.

Mass media -- radio, television, newspapers and magazines -were described yesterday by Msgr. Thomas A. Donnellan, Chancellor of the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese, as instruments of profound potential good.

An enthusiastic audience crammed Carnegie Hall and flowed over onto the stage Saturday night at the first indoor Hootenanny of the season. This was the beginning of the eighteenth year of Hootenannies in New York, according to Pete Seeger, one of the performers on Saturday's program. They were originated by the Almanac Singers as Sunday afternoon rent parties.
Printers love the mutual fund.

ATHENS, Sept. 20 -- The intellectual fascination of paradox was first cultivated in this ancient city some two and a half millennia ago. Therefore it is not wholly astonishing that Greece today should be enjoying an extremely paradoxical political situation.
MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 21 -- The appearance of hecklers during Premier Khrushchev's speeches in the United States and his annoyance with them were reported here for the first time this morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -- Following, in unofficial translation, is a statement entitled "Against the Limitation of Soviet-American Cultural Relations," issued here tonight by the Committee for Cultural Relations with Foreign Countries of the Council of Ministers of the U. S. S. R. with the authorization of Premier Khrushchev:

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 20 -- In hungry India the Food Minister's office is known as "the graveyard of political hopes." Many able men have tackled the problem of keeping the nation's multiplying millions fed, but the sheer magnitude of the task has forced out minister after minister with less luster than he brought to it.

We read of over 1,200 acres of vacant land in Flushing Meadow Park being selected as a site for the 1964 world's fair, with an adjoining parcel chosen for a new ball park. As great a project as the fair undoubtedly is, and with the big demand for a new baseball team in New York, one must seriously question why all this land has remained unused for so many years.

ABOARD KHRUSHCHEV'S TRAIN, En Route to San Francisco, Sept. 20 -- Premier Khrushchev met his first ordinary Americans today. He also ruled out the idea that he might return to the Soviet Union before his tour was over next Sunday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman said today that too many Americans "have gazed on the face of the enemy until they see there not the countless crushed bodies of freedom fighters of the world but only the seductive smile of the sinister master of Moscow."
VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 20 -- Reports from the northern provinces last week indicated that the new Laotian military tactics of "hitting below the belt" had rebel leaders confused and indignant.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20 -- Thirteen Iraqi Army officers and four civilians were executed today as enemies of the regime of Premier Abdul Karim Kassim, the Baghdad radio announced.
Channel 13 presented last night the first of a filmed series of British Broadcasting Corporation interviews entitled "Face to Face."

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 20 -- The Dutch budget, submitted to parliament last week, makes a good impression. It shows a total deficit for 1960 of 951,000,000 guilders against 1,850,000,000 for 1959. The Finance Minister intends to cover the resulting treasury deficit of some 625,000,000 in the long-term capital market a step that is expected to be fairly easy.
MACY'S Little Shop is growing bigger again.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) -- The Government plans to increase soon the maximum interest rate on Federal Housing Administration insured home loans from 5 1/4 per cent to 5 3/4 per cent, informed sources said today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -The Milwaukee Braves stayed in the thick of the National League pennant struggle today, but it wasn't easy.

Few Jews will draw satisfaction from the defense of Soviet Jewry by William Buckley Jr., as reported in The New York Times of Sept. 18. His remarks contribute nothing to a dispassionate consideration of Soviet Jewry's difficult plight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 20 -- Indian Harbor Luders-16 Class helmsmen defeated the Western Long Island Sound fleet 145 -- 92, today in their annual match for the Firefly Trophy at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.
Dale D. McConkey writes in your issue of Sept. 17 that the payment of unemployment benefits to striking steelworkers in New York State has prostituted a basically sound law.

IF the Yankees of 1927 are not considered the greatest of all baseball teams, the distinction is generally accorded to the White Sox of forty years ago. They were first assembled in 1917 under the not-too-expert direction of Clarence (Pants) Rowland, whose main qualification for the managerial job was that he was a pal of the original Charles Comiskey, the owner of the club.

Earnings of the Monroe Auto Equipment Company in the fiscal year ended June 30 more than doubled those of the preceding year, while sales climbed almost $6,000,000, according to the report of B.D. McIntyre, president.

The St. Brendan Cup in hurling will return to Ireland. That was determined yesterday when the clever Tipperary fifteen ran the New York All-Stars ragged in the second half and won by 23 to 8 at Gaelic Park.
Twenty-three families in the New York area are fighting the high cost of education with a private college bus that takes off today on its first trip to Knox College in Galesburg, Ill.

ONCE there was a bridge club in New York called the Ferguson Club. One week, many years ago, it sent out a notice that said, "Beginning October 3, our regular Wednesday-night duplicate games will be held on Tuesday nights instead of on Monday nights."
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 20 -- The Senate voted President Francois Duvalier full powers last night to rule by decree for a month.
TAHAWUS, N.Y., Sept. 20 (UPI) -- A State Conservation Department plane crashed and burned today on the side of a rugged Adirondack mountain. One man was killed and at least one was injured.
An investigation into United States overseas oil transportation policies by the Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization appeared in the making yesterday.

The motorist in Chicago stopped for a red light. The car behind him, however, was slower with the brakes. But the bumpers absorbed most of the shock and all of the damage of the collision. The driver of the first car complained of a headache when he got home. Twelve hours later he was dead because, as was later discovered, he was a hemophiliac.
Internal radiation from potassium 40 can be used as a lifetime clock to study aspects of human growth and aging, scientists have reported.
SMOKING not only is unhealthy for teen-agers; it also is illegal.
The president of the Economic Club of New York has apologized in a letter to Premier Khrushchev for the "manners" of those who heckled the Soviet leader at the club's dinner for him Thursday night.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Sept. 20 -- The divided Colorado party met today at a special convention attended by President Alfredo Stroessner in an effort to re-establish harmony in the Government party.
The Kerr Stable's Round Table, the leading money-winning horse in the world, arrived at Aqueduct yesterday from Atlantic City to start in the $100,000-added Woodward Stakes Saturday.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The Liberal party asserted tonight that, since it was tied to neither big business nor big labor, it was the only political body in Britain still in a position to ventilate the dark corners of power politics.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -- The two top officials of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations are scheduled to get pay increases of $10,000 a year each this week.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he planned an early start on his efforts to close the Democratic party rift pointed up by the primary election here.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -- A New York woman and a Briton on an evening stroll were injured last night when they jumped a fence into a minefield.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 -- Premier Khrushchev and seven American labor leaders concluded tonight that their positions were "irreconcilable" after they had debated philo sophical questions for three hours and twenty minutes.

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 20 -- A tiring young Dutch princess smiled her way today through the final lap of her ten-day barnstorming tour of the Hudson Valley and took leave of the caravan in the late afternoon to rest before returning to the Netherlands tomorrow.

DAVID SMITH, 53-year-old dean of American metal sculptors, has returned to painting after a very long pause. In his exhibition at French Co., Madison Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, Mr. Smith exhibits twenty-two paintings and thirty-four large drawings, most of them executed during the last year.

Melbourne Reid, tenor from Jamaica, B.W.I., who made his debut here in 1957, presented a Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon, the feature of which was Schumann's "Diehterliebe" cycle. Also heard were Beethoven's "Adelaide." "O Paradiso," from "L'Africana" and other works by Dupare, Faure, Price, Dvorak, Blumenthal, Quilter and Mana-Zucca.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 20 -- President Tito took the offensive today aginst Soviet-bloc critics of his policies, challenging them to come and see how well Yugoslavia is doing and then copy her.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Br. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, opened its 213th year this morning with an admonition to students not to take appearances for reality.

GOSHEN, Conn., Sept. 20 -- A Norwegian elkhound, Ch. Tortasen's Bjonn II, was selected as best in show by Mrs. Edward P. Renner of Lakeville, Conn., at the Northwestern Connecticut Dog Club's event today.

Howard Barnaby and S. G. Schimenti have announced plans for a twenty-four-story office building on a plot they have purchased at 66 Beaver Street, a block from Wall Street. The sponsors of the project, who are building contractors, bought the site recently and have demolished the buildings there.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -The Air Force has ordered the development of a nuclear Ramjet engine that could propel a missile around the world at supersonic speeds, Pentagon officials disclosed today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of the speech by Premier Khrushchev at a Los Angeles dinner in his honor tonight (unofficial translation):
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -Military security has reached a peak. It seems safe to predict it will never be surpassed.

ALBANY, Sept. 20 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller announced the appointment of a council on rehabilitation today. It will advise him and the interdepartmental Health Resources Board on strengthening and expanding the state's rehabilitation program.

The Chinese Bandits of Louisiana State, defensive specialists, tasted the heady rice wine of scoring a touchdown Saturday as the Bengal Tigers opened their football season with a 26-3 victory over the Rice Owls.
The city's Commission on Intergroup Relations is setting up a city-wide alarm system to warn of any racial tensions that might threaten to erupt in neighborhood strife.

MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 21 -- Soviet scientists reported today that data from their successful moon rocket had turned up no evidence that there was a magnetic field around the moon or that it was surrounded by belts of radiation.
NEWARK, Sept. 20 -- Plans for Newark's first concentrated industrial development were announced today.

CARACAS, Sept. 20 -- A twelve-man commission from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) arrived here today to begin a detailed study of the Venezuelan economy. The commission has been invited by the Venezuelan Government.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Chicago's pennant-hungry White Sox were obliged to conclude their regular 1959 operations at Comiskey Park with unsated appetites today.
In your issue of Sept. 6 John F. Borre emphasized the need for student visits to Washington.
Truckers are doubly unhappy about the decision last week of the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve a reduction of volume rates for freight forwarders between here and Chicago.
EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Marty Furgol of Coghill, Ill., posted a 7-under-par 65 in the final round of the $20,000 El Paso open today to win by 4 strokes. He finished with 273.

Former President Harry S. Truman appealed last night for strong public support for the United Nations as a "continuation really" of the League of Nations, for which Woodrow Wilson campaigned until his health broke down forty years ago.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 20 -- More than 600 persons attended the opening today of a benefit show and sale of paintings by well-known amateur and professional artists.

The Margo Jones Theatre in Dallas, Tex., is again taking credit for having discovered a play that will become a Broadway entry. Since its founding twelve years ago, the theatre has served as a try-out arena for a number of productions that later emerged as Broadway hits, including "Inherit the Wind."
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 -Mayor Norris Poulson, in greeting Premier Khrushchev at the airport yesterday, said simply: "I welcome you to the City of Angels, where the impossible always happens."
The Southern Baptist Convention, representing 9,000,000 churchgoers, will spend at least $3,000,000 on a nation-wide television campaign to curb juvenile delinquency. It will begin in January.

ARLES, France, Sept. 21 -- For another month costumed young men will crowd the arenas of Spain and southern France slaying bulls according to ritual -- sometimes with eclat, sometimes without. Then the cold weather will move in and end the season that most aficionados are saying is ended already.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The White House asked Americans today to be courteous to Premier Khrushchev. At the same time, the State Department again vigorously denied the charge twice made by Mr. Khrushchev, and detailed by his aides in San Francisco last night, that the department was obstructing exchanges between the Soviet Union and the United States.
MENLO PARK, Calif., Sept 21 -- The foreign-trade official in Premier Khrushchev's party said today that there were some signs of improved prospects for an increase in Soviet-American trade.
HONG KONG, Sept. 21 -- Chinese Communist newspapers gave extensive and approving publicity today to Premier Khrushchev's proposal for disarmament.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Unopened champagne bottles and an undelivered telegram symbolize the drama of tomorrow night's game here between the Chicago White Sox and the Cleveland Indians.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -- Following is the text of a summary of the dinner meeting of American labor leaders with Premier Khrushchev last night in the Mark Hopkins Hotel, as made public by the labor leaders present.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The space agency has decided against firing an astronaut 1,800 miles out across the Atlantic in an Atlas ballistic missile.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 -- The United States Court of Appeals upheld the validity of Arkansas' pupil placement laws today. The decision was hailed by state officials as a step toward orderly transition to public school integration.
NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Nassau County Executive A. Holly Patterson was unanimously elected county Republican leader here tonight to succeed J. Russel Sprague.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 (AP) -- George Altman hit two homers and Ernie Banks one -- his forty-third -- for the Chicago Cubs tonight, making it easy for Glenn Hobbie to gain his sixteenth victory, a 12-3 romp over the St. Louis Cardinals.
CLOSE at the elbow of Premier Khrushchev on his trip through the United States in the last week has been the editor of one of Moscow's two leading daily newspapers.

ALGIERS, Sept. 21 -- Gen. Maurice Challe, French Commander in Chief in Algeria, told his troops tonight that "the struggle against the rebellion will be intensified" until "total pacification" is reached.
VIENTIANE, Sept. 21 -- A spokesman for a United Nations fact-finding committee said the twenty-page presentation delivered by the Laotian Government two days ago contained basic charges and evidence.
DETROIT, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers rehired Jimmie Dykes today as their manager.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen, State Department specialist on Soviet affairs, has been recalled from Manila to become adviser to Secretary of State Christian A. Herter.
A teen-aged gang ambushed a 16-year-old boy yesterday and shot him fatally as he ran up the front steps of his Bronx high school seeking haven.

Directors of Puget Sound Power and Light Company announced yesterday election of a new chairman and president. Frank McLaughlin, who had been president and chief executive officer, was elevated to the post of chairman and top managing officer in charge of policies, business and affairs of the Pacific Northwest utility.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -- The temptation to stage Carl Orff's fundamentally choral piece, "Carmina Burana," is hard to resist. In Brussels last year it was presented outdoors in the medieval Grande Palace.

Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools, opened a series of radio reports to the public last night, with an appeal to parents to join educators in helping to provide the best possible school programs to children.

Would not public interest be better served if, along with a stronger Police Department and more correctional institutions to deal with juvenile offenders in the present crisis, emphasis were also given by city and state leaders to the work of preventive agencies which cope with the causes of juvenile delinquency?

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 21 (UPI) -- A Negro group here called today on the Federal Communications Commission to investigate the "widespread use of the air waves by those who preach racial or religious intolerance."
The chief of the Boston Homicide Squad said here yesterday that the divorcee whose body was found Saturday in Boston Harbor might have committed suicide.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The delay in integration of the Dollarway School District, which will evidently result from today's decision by the Court of Appeals, has the private approval of Justice Department officials.
DES MOINES, Sept. 21 -- Solid, stolid Iowa made final plans today for a "calm and dignified" reception for Premier Khrushchev and begged him to mingle freely with Iowans of all classes.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 21 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has been advised to watch Kashmir as the next potential trouble spot for India in relation to the Communist problem here. The situation in Kashmir is given particular point by the state's proximity to Red China.
The voice of the piano was heard in the land as sixty-three talented young musicians started competing yesterday for the twentieth annual Edgar M. Leventritt Award.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Harry S. Ashmore, executive editor of The Arkansas Gazette, has resigned to work with a study foundation in California.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed into law today a bill honoring Dr. Samuel Alexander Mudd, the physician once imprisoned for giving medical aid to Lincoln's assassin.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- American officials traveling with Premier Khrushchev think they finally have his complicated family relationships figured out.

VIENNA, Sept. 21 -- The international "atoms for peace" organization will meet in Austria's old Imperial Palace tomorrow. Scientists, diplomats and politicians from seventy countries will participate in the two-week meeting.
ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N. J., Sept. 21 -- Bowling and bowling establishments took a verbal pounding during a five-hour Town Council meeting last week in this town of 3,000 persons on the Palisades.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- Nicholas Petrulli, who nearly became a man without a country when he sought Soviet citizenship, flew out of Moscow today clutching a passport marked for return to the United States only.
Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands left New York yesterday after pronouncing her hosts "a great people and a wonderful state."
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Viscount Hailsham declared tonight that Labor party rule would mean "public disagreements" with the United States over policy in Europe, the Middle East and Far East.
The city's Salute to Seasons will get a bright addition tonight, on the eve of Autumn.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The steep upward march of the Treasury bill rate was reversed this week, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Following are the text of a statement made today before the General Assembly by Walter S. Robertson, United States delegate, on the question of admission of Communist China to the United Nations, and excerpts from a speech by Vasily V. Kuznetsov of the Soviet Union on this issue:
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -- American labor gave Premier Khrushchev new proof today that its differences with him were "irreconcilable."
FOUR years ago Chekhov's "The Three Sisters" seemed beautiful at the Fourth Street Theatre under David Ross' direction.
The Johns-Manville Corporation has acquired F. E. Schundler Co., Inc. of Joliet, Ill. for about $7,000,000.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 21 -- Harvard University announced today an experiment in freshman seminar work of the kind usually taken by advanced students.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- The United States is drifting toward fascism "under the leadership of President Eisenhower," a union president charged today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text, in unofficial translation, of Premier Khrushchev's remarks tonight before a joint dinner of the San Francisco Commonwealth Club and the World Affairs Council:

GENEVA, Sept. 21 -- George F. Kennan, former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, said today that Premier Khrushchev "occupied a prominent place" among Soviet leaders who felt shamed and humiliated by the brutalities of Stalin.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -- Premier Khrushchev is not achieving the stated objectives of his visit to the United States. He is not "deucing tensions." If anything, he is increasing them among a substantial number of precisely those influential Americans he presumably wanted to impress.
The sleek British liner Arcadia, new to the Port of New York, received a traditional harbor welcome here yesterday.

The nation's steel strike is blamed by the Norfolk and Western Railway for a 20 per cent drop in the carrier's operating revenues last month. Gross fell to $15,292,741 from $19,118,185 in August of 1958.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -- In high good humor. Premier Khrushchev took an early morning walk along San Francisco's streets today, then went on a boat tour of the Bay.

Plans for a project to convert waste copper slag into steel were announced yesterday by William Zeckendorf, president of Webb Knapp, Inc., real estate development concern. The project would involve the construction and operation of the first integrated steel mill in Arizona.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy was ordered yesterday to establish a system of deducting dues from the pay of 22,000 members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Pote Sarasin, Secretary General of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization, said today it might send troops to Laos if that country asked for aid.
DETROIT, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The auto industry has markedly increased the production pace of 1960 models as the time approaches for their public introduction.

Air Products, Inc., of Allentown, Pa., announced plans yesterday to build and operate four major oxygen producing plants for various steel companies at a total investment of more than $33,000,000. The oxygen production from these new plants would be equal to about half of all the oxygen consumed by the steel industry last year, the announcement said.
HAVANA, Sept. 21 -- Maj. William A. Morgan, who fought with Fidel Castro's rebels in Las Villas Province during the revolution, will renounce his United States citizenship and become a Cuban.
Eight award-winning playwrights will have their scripts tested through grants from the Ford Foundation.

Governor Rockefeller declared yesterday that the state's success in luring private capital into middle-income housing during the last six months would lead to a major expansion of the program next year.

A SOPHISTICATED and self-contained people, the Japanese no longer are startled or impressed by the sight of an American. Here, they have seen both soldiers -- and now tourists -- in large numbers. But they are surprised by American inquisitiveness and enthusiasm over their houses, gardens, art, culture and behavior.

The outflow of gold from the United States to foreign countries through the first week in September this year (exclusive of $343.8 million representing our additional subscription to the International Monetary Fund) was $650 million.
